January 1, 153 BC: For the first time, Roman consuls begin their year in office on January 1.[2]
January 1, 45 BC: The Julian calendar takes effect as the civil calendar of the Roman Empire, establishing January 1 as the new date of the new year.[3]
January 1, 42 BC: The Roman Senate posthumously deifies Julius Caesar.[4]
January 1, 193: The Senate chooses Pertinax against his will to succeed Commodus as Roman emperor.[5]
January 1, 404: Saint Telemachus tries to stop a gladiatorial fight in a Roman amphitheatre, and is stoned to death by the crowd. This act impresses the Christian Emperor Honorius, who issues a historic ban on gladiatorial fights.[6]
January 1, 417: Emperor Honorius forces Galla Placidia into marriage to Constantius, his famous general (magister militum) (probable).[7]
January 1, 1001: Grand Prince Stephen I of Hungary is named the first King of Hungary by Pope Sylvester II (probable).[8]
January 1, 1068: Romanos IV Diogenes marries Eudokia Makrembolitissa and is crowned Byzantine Emperor.[9]
January 1, 1259: Michael VIII Palaiologos is proclaimed co-emperor of the Empire of Nicaea with his ward John IV Laskaris.[10]
January 1, 1438: Albert II of Habsburg is crowned King of Hungary.
January 1, 1502: The present-day location of Rio de Janeiro, Brazil is first explored by the Portuguese.[11]
January 1, 1515: Twenty-year-old Francis, Duke of Brittany, succeeds to the French throne following the death of his father-in-law, Louis XII.[12]
January 1, 1527: Croatian nobles elect Ferdinand I of Austria as King of Croatia in the Parliament on Cetin.[13]
January 1, 1600: Scotland recognises January 1 as the start of the year, instead of March 25.[14]
January 1, 1651: Charles II is crowned King of Scotland.[15]
January 1, 1700: Russia begins using the Anno Domini era instead of the Anno Mundi era of the Byzantine Empire.
January 1, 1707: John V is proclaimed King of Portugal and the Algarves in Lisbon.[16]
January 1, 1739: Bouvet Island, the world's remotest island is discovered by French explorer Jean-Baptiste Charles Bouvet de Lozier.[17]
January 1, 1772: The first traveler's cheques, which could be used in 90 European cities, were issued by the London Credit Exchange Company.[18]
January 1, 1788: First edition of The Times of London, previously The Daily Universal Register, is published.[22]
January 1, 1801: Ceres, the largest and first known object in the Asteroid belt, is discovered by Giuseppe Piazzi.[24]
January 1, 1803: Emperor Gia Long orders all bronze wares of the Tây Sơn dynasty to be collected and melted into nine cannons for the Royal Citadel in Huế, Vietnam.
January 1, 1804: French rule ends in Haiti. Haiti becomes the first black republic and second independent country in North America after the United States.[25]
January 1, 1806: The French Republican Calendar is abolished.[26]
January 1, 1808: The United States bans the importation of slaves.[27]
January 1, 1810: Major-General Lachlan Macquarie officially becomes Governor of New South Wales.[28]
January 1, 1822: The Greek Constitution of 1822 is adopted by the First National Assembly at Epidaurus.[29]
January 1, 1847: The world's first "Mercy" Hospital is founded in Pittsburgh, United States, by a group of Sisters of Mercy from Ireland;[30] the name will go on to grace over 30 major hospitals throughout the world.
January 1, 1860: The first Polish stamp is issued, replacing the Russian stamps previously in use.[31]
January 1, 1861: Liberal forces supporting Benito Juárez enter Mexico City.[32]
January 1, 1877: Queen Victoria of the United Kingdom is proclaimed Empress of India.[34]
January 1, 1885: Twenty-five nations adopt Sandford Fleming's proposal for standard time (and also, time zones)
January 1, 1890: Eritrea is consolidated into a colony by the Italian government.[35]
January 1, 1892: Ellis Island begins processing immigrants into the United States.[36]
January 1, 1898: New York, New York annexes land from surrounding counties, creating the City of Greater New York. The four initial boroughs, Manhattan, Brooklyn, Queens, and The Bronx, are joined on January 25 by Staten Island to create the modern city of five boroughs.
January 1, 1901: The British colonies of New South Wales, Queensland, Victoria, South Australia, Tasmania, and Western Australia federate as the Commonwealth of Australia; Edmund Barton is appointed the first Prime Minister.[39]
January 1, 1902: The first American college football bowl game, the Rose Bowl between Michigan and Stanford, is held in Pasadena, California.[40]
January 1, 1910: Captain David Beatty is promoted to Rear admiral, and becomes the youngest admiral in the Royal Navy (except for Royal family members) since Horatio Nelson.[41]
January 1, 1912: The Republic of China is established.[42]
January 1, 1914: The SPT Airboat Line becomes the world's first scheduled airline to use a winged aircraft.[43]
January 1, 1927: New Mexican oil legislation goes into effect, leading to the formal outbreak of the Cristero War.[44]
January 1, 1928: Boris Bazhanov defects through Iran. He is the only assistant of Joseph Stalin's secretariat to have defected from the Eastern Bloc.[45]
January 1, 1929: The former municipalities of Point Grey, British Columbia and South Vancouver, British Columbia are amalgamated into Vancouver.[46]
January 1, 1932: The United States Post Office Department issues a set of 12 stamps commemorating the 200th anniversary of George Washington's birth.[47]
January 1, 1934: A "Law for the Prevention of Genetically Diseased Offspring" comes into effect in Nazi Germany.[49]
January 1, 1942: The Declaration by United Nations is signed by twenty-six nations.
January 1, 1947: The Canadian Citizenship Act 1946 comes into effect, converting British subjects into Canadian citizens.[52] Prime Minister William Lyon Mackenzie King becomes the first Canadian citizen.
January 1, 1948: The British railway network is nationalized to form British Railways.[53]
January 1, 1949: United Nations cease-fire takes effect in Kashmir from one minute before midnight. War between India and Pakistan stops accordingly.[54]
January 1, 1956: Sudan achieves independence from Egypt and the United Kingdom.[55]
January 1, 1957: George Town, Penang, is made a city by a royal charter of Queen Elizabeth II of the United Kingdom.[56]
January 1, 1960: Cameroon achieves independence from France and the United Kingdom.[59]
January 1, 1962: Western Samoa achieves independence from New Zealand; its name is changed to the Independent State of Western Samoa.[60]
January 1, 1964: The Federation of Rhodesia and Nyasaland is divided into the independent republics of Zambia and Malawi, and the British-controlled Rhodesia.[61]
January 1, 1965: The People's Democratic Party of Afghanistan is founded in Kabul, Afghanistan.
January 1, 1971: Cigarette advertisements are banned on American television.
January 1, 1973: Denmark, Ireland and the United Kingdom are admitted into the European Economic Community.
January 1, 1978: Air India Flight 855, a Boeing 747, crashes into the sea, due to instrument failure, spatial disorientation, and pilot error, off the coast of Bombay, India, killing all 213 people on board.[63]
January 1, 1979: Formal diplomatic relations are established between the People's Republic of China and the United States.[citation needed]
January 1, 1981: Greece is admitted into the European Community.[64]
January 1, 1982: Peruvian Javier Pérez de Cuéllar becomes the first Latin American to hold the title of Secretary-General of the United Nations.[65]
January 1, 1983: The ARPANET officially changes to using the Internet Protocol, creating the Internet.
January 1, 1984: Brunei becomes independent of the United Kingdom.[67]
January 1, 1985: The first British mobile phone call is made by Michael Harrison to his father Sir Ernest Harrison, chairman of Vodafone.
January 1, 1987: The Isleta Pueblo tribe elect Verna Williamson to be their first female governor.[68]
January 1, 1988: The Evangelical Lutheran Church in America comes into existence, creating the largest Lutheran denomination in the United States.[69]
January 1, 1989: The Montreal Protocol comes into force, stopping the use of chemicals contributing to ozone depletion.[70]
January 1, 1990: David Dinkins is sworn in as New York City's first black mayor.[71]
January 1, 1994: The North American Free Trade Agreement (NAFTA) comes into effect.[74]
January 1, 1995: Austria, Finland and Sweden join the EU.[77]
January 1, 1998: Following a currency reform, Russia begins to circulate new rubles to stem inflation and promote confidence.[78]
January 1, 1999: Euro currency is introduced in 11 member nations of the European Union (with the exception of the United Kingdom, Denmark, Greece and Sweden; Greece later adopts the euro).
January 1, 2004: In a vote of confidence, General Pervez Musharraf wins 658 out of 1,170 votes in the Electoral College of Pakistan, and according to Article 41(8) of the Constitution of Pakistan, is "deemed to be elected" to the office of President until October 2007.[79]
January 1, 2007: Adam Air Flight 574 breaks apart in mid-air and crashes near the Makassar Strait, Indonesia killing all 102 people on board.[80]
January 1, 2009: Sixty-six people die in a nightclub fire in Bangkok, Thailand.[81]
January 1, 2010: A suicide car bomber detonates at a volleyball tournament in Lakki Marwat, Pakistan, killing 105 and injuring 100 more.[82]
January 1, 2011: Estonia officially adopts the Euro currency and becomes the 17th Eurozone country.[84]
January 1, 2013: At least 60 people are killed and 200 injured in a stampede after celebrations at Félix Houphouët-Boigny Stadium in Abidjan, Ivory Coast.
January 1, 2015: The Eurasian Economic Union comes into effect, creating a political and economic union between Russia, Belarus, Armenia, Kazakhstan and Kyrgyzstan.[85]
January 1, 2017: An attack on a nightclub in Istanbul, Turkey, during New Year's celebrations, kills at least 39 people and injures more than 60 others.[86]
January 2, AD 69: The Roman legions in Germania Superior refuse to swear loyalty to Galba. They rebel and proclaim Vitellius as emperor.[1]
January 2, 366: The Alemanni cross the frozen Rhine in large numbers, invading the Roman Empire.[2]
January 2, 533: Mercurius becomes Pope John II, the first pope to adopt a new name upon elevation to the papacy.[3]
January 2, 1788: Georgia becomes the fourth state to ratify the United States Constitution.[7]
January 2, 1791: Big Bottom massacre in the Ohio Country, North America, marking the beginning of the Northwest Indian War.[8]
January 2, 1818: The British Institution of Civil Engineers is founded by a group of six engineers; Thomas Telford would later become its first president.[9]
January 2, 1833: Captain James Onslow, in the Clio, arrives at Port Egmont to reassert British sovereignty over the Falkland Islands.[10]
January 2, 1900: American statesman and diplomat John Hay announces the Open Door Policy to promote trade with China.[12]
January 2, 1920: The second Palmer Raid, ordered by the US Department of Justice, results in 6,000 suspected communists and anarchists being arrested and held without trial.[13]
January 2, 1942: The Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI) obtains the conviction of 33 members of a German spy ring headed by Fritz Joubert Duquesne in the largest espionage case in United States history—the Duquesne Spy Ring.[15]
January 2, 1949: Luis Muñoz Marín is inaugurated as the first democratically elected Governor of Puerto Rico.[17]
January 2, 1954: India establishes its highest civilian awards, the Bharat Ratna and the Padma Vibhushan.[18]
January 2, 1955: Following the assassination of the Panamanian president José Antonio Remón Cantera, his deputy, José Ramón Guizado, takes power, but is quickly deposed after his involvement in Cantera's death is discovered.[19]
January 2, 1959: Luna 1, the first spacecraft to reach the vicinity of the Moon and to orbit the Sun, is launched by the Soviet Union.[20]
January 2, 1967: Ronald Reagan, past movie actor and future President of the United States, is sworn in as Governor of California.[22]
January 2, 1971: The second Ibrox disaster kills 66 fans at a Rangers-Celtic association football (soccer) match.[23]
January 2, 1974: United States President Richard Nixon signs a bill lowering the maximum U.S. speed limit to 55 MPH in order to conserve gasoline during an OPEC embargo.[24]
January 2, 1975: The Federal Rules of Evidence are approved by the United States Congress.[26]
January 2, 1976: The Gale of January 1976 begins, resulting in coastal flooding around the southern North Sea coasts, affecting countries from Ireland to Yugoslavia and causing at least 82 deaths and US$1.3 billion in damage.[27]
January 2, 1978: On the orders of Pakistan's president, Muhammad Zia-ul-Haq, paramilitary forces opened fire on peaceful protesting workers in Multan, Pakistan, its known as 1978 massacre at Multan Colony Textile Mills.[28]
January 2, 1981: One of the largest investigations by a British police force ends when serial killer Peter Sutcliffe, the "Yorkshire Ripper", is arrested in Sheffield, South Yorkshire.[29]
January 2, 1991: Sharon Pratt Kelly becomes the first African American woman mayor of a major city and first woman Mayor of the District of Columbia.[30]
January 2, 2004: Stardust successfully flies past Comet Wild 2, collecting samples that are returned to Earth.[32]
January 3, 250: Emperor Decius orders everyone in the Roman Empire (except Jews) to make sacrifices to the Roman gods.[1]
January 3, 1521: Pope Leo X excommunicates Martin Luther in the papal bull Decet Romanum Pontificem.[2]
January 3, 1653: By the Coonan Cross Oath, the Eastern Church in India cuts itself off from colonial Portuguese tutelage.[3]
January 3, 1749: The first issue of Berlingske, Denmark's oldest continually operating newspaper, is published.[5]
January 3, 1777: American General George Washington defeats British General Lord Cornwallis at the Battle of Princeton.[6]
January 3, 1815: Austria, the United Kingdom, and France form a secret defensive alliance against Prussia and Russia.[7]
January 3, 1823: Stephen F. Austin receives a grant of land in Texas from the government of Mexico.
January 3, 1833: The United Kingdom claims sovereignty over the Falkland Islands.[8]
January 3, 1848: Joseph Jenkins Roberts is sworn in as the first president of Liberia.[9]
January 3, 1870: Construction work begins on the Brooklyn Bridge in New York, United States.[12]
January 3, 1871: In the Battle of Bapaume, an engagement in the Franco-Prussian War, General Louis Faidherbe's forces bring about a Prussian retreat.[13]
January 3, 1911: A gun battle in the East End of London left two dead and sparked a political row over the involvement of then-Home Secretary Winston Churchill.[16]
January 3, 1913: An Atlantic coast storm sets the lowest confirmed barometric pressure reading for a non-tropical system in the continental United States.[17]
January 3, 1919: At the Paris Peace Conference, Emir Faisal I of Iraq signs an agreement with Zionist leader Chaim Weizmann on the development of a Jewish homeland in Palestine.
January 3, 1925: Benito Mussolini announces he is taking dictatorial powers over Italy.[18]
January 3, 1932: Martial law is declared in Honduras to stop a revolt by banana workers fired by the United Fruit Company.
January 3, 1933: Minnie D. Craig becomes the first woman elected as Speaker of the North Dakota House of Representatives, the first woman to hold a Speaker position anywhere in the United States.
January 3, 1938: The March of Dimes is established as a foundation to combat infant polio by President Franklin D. Roosevelt.
January 3, 1946: Popular Canadian American jockey George Woolf dies in a freak accident during a race; the annual George Woolf Memorial Jockey Award is created to honor him.[21]
January 3, 1947: Proceedings of the U.S. Congress are televised for the first time.[22]
January 3, 1949: The Bangko Sentral ng Pilipinas, the central bank of the Philippines, is established.[23]
January 3, 1953: Frances P. Bolton and her son, Oliver from Ohio, become the first mother and son to serve simultaneously in the U.S. Congress.
January 3, 1956: A fire damages the top part of the Eiffel Tower.
January 3, 1957: The Hamilton Watch Company introduces the first electric watch.
January 3, 1958: The West Indies Federation is formed.
January 3, 1959: Alaska is admitted as the 49th U.S. state.
January 3, 1961: A protest by agricultural workers in Baixa de Cassanje, Portuguese Angola, turns into a revolt, opening the Angolan War of Independence, the first of the Portuguese Colonial Wars.
January 3, 1962: Pope John XXIII excommunicates Fidel Castro.[24]
January 3, 1976: The International Covenant on Economic, Social and Cultural Rights, adopted by the United Nations General Assembly, comes into force.[25]
January 3, 1993: In Moscow, Russia, George H. W. Bush and Boris Yeltsin sign the second Strategic Arms Reduction Treaty (START).[28]
January 3, 1994: More than seven million people from the former apartheid Homelands receive South African citizenship.
January 3, 1999: The Mars Polar Lander is launched by NASA.
January 3, 2000: Final daily edition of the Peanuts comic strip.
January 3, 2004: Flash Airlines Flight 604 crashes into the Red Sea, resulting in 148 deaths, making it one of the deadliest aviation accidents in Egyptian history.
January 3, 2009: The first block of the blockchain of the decentralized payment system Bitcoin, called the Genesis block, was established by the creator of the system, Satoshi Nakamoto.
January 3, 2015: Boko Haram militants raze the entire town of Baga in north-east Nigeria, starting the Baga massacre and killing as many as 2,000 people.
January 3, 2016: Following the fallout caused by the execution of Nimr al-Nimr, Iran ends its diplomatic relations with Saudi Arabia.
January 3, 2018: Computer analysts report two major security vulnerabilities, named "Meltdown" and "Spectre," affecting the microprocessors of almost all computers in the world.
January 3, 2019: Chang'e 4 makes the first soft landing on the far side of the Moon, deploying the Yutu-2 lunar rover.[30]
January 4, 46 BC: Julius Caesar fights Titus Labienus in the Battle of Ruspina.[1]
January 4, 1717: The Netherlands, Great Britain, and France sign the Triple Alliance[4] in an attempt to maintain the Treaty of Utrecht; Britain having signed a preliminary alliance with France on November 28 (November 17, 1716).
January 4, 1762: Great Britain declares war on Spain, thus entering the Seven Years' War.[5]
January 4, 1798: Constantine Hangerli arrives in Bucharest, Wallachia, as its new Prince, invested by the Ottoman Empire.[6]
January 4, 1853: After having been kidnapped and sold into slavery in the American South, Solomon Northup regains his freedom; his memoir Twelve Years a Slave later becomes a national bestseller.[7]
January 4, 1854: The McDonald Islands are discovered by Captain William McDonald aboard the Samarang.[8]
January 4, 1863: The New Apostolic Church, a Christian and chiliastic church, is established in Hamburg, Germany.[9]
January 4, 1884: The Fabian Society is founded in London, United Kingdom.[11]
January 4, 1896: Utah is admitted as the 45th U.S. state.[12]
January 4, 1903: Topsy, an elephant, is electrocuted by the owners of Luna Park, Coney Island. The Edison film company records the film Electrocuting an Elephant of Topsy's death.[13]
January 4, 1912: The Scout Association is incorporated throughout the British Empire by royal charter.[14]
January 4, 1918: The Finnish Declaration of Independence is recognized by Russia, Sweden, Germany and France.[15]
January 4, 1948: Burma gains its independence from the United Kingdom becoming an independent republic,[17] named the Union of Burma, with Sao Shwe Thaik as its first President and U Nu its first Prime Minister.
January 4, 1956: The Greek National Radical Union is formed by Konstantinos Karamanlis.[19]
January 4, 1958: Sputnik 1, the first artificial Earth satellite, launched by the Soviet Union in 1957, falls to Earth from orbit.[20]
January 4, 1959: Luna 1 becomes the first spacecraft to reach the vicinity of the Moon.[21]
January 4, 1972: Rose Heilbron becomes the first female judge to sit at the Old Bailey in London, UK.[22]
January 4, 1990: In Pakistan's deadliest train accident an overloaded passenger train collides with an empty freight train, resulting in 307 deaths and 700 injuries.[26]
January 4, 1998: A massive ice storm hits eastern Canada and the northeastern United States, continuing through January 10 and causing widespread destruction.[27]
January 4, 1999: Former professional wrestler Jesse Ventura is sworn in as governor of Minnesota, United States.[28]
January 4, 2004: Mikheil Saakashvili is elected President of Georgia following the November 2003 Rose Revolution.[30]
January 4, 2006: Ehud Olmert becomes acting Prime Minister of Israel after the incumbent, Ariel Sharon, suffers a second, apparently more serious stroke.[31]
January 4, 2007: The 110th United States Congress convenes, electing Nancy Pelosi as the first female Speaker of the House in U.S. history.[32]
January 4, 2010: The Burj Khalifa, the current tallest building in the world, officially opens in Dubai.[33]
January 4, 2013: A gunman kills eight people in a house-to-house rampage in Kawit, Cavite, Philippines.[34]
January 5, 1664: Maratha forces under Chhatrapati Shivaji defeat the Mughals in the Battle of Surat.
January 5, 1757: Louis XV of France survives an assassination attempt by Robert-François Damiens, the last person to be executed in France by drawing and quartering, the traditional and gruesome form of capital punishment used for regicides.
January 5, 1846: The United States House of Representatives votes to stop sharing the Oregon Territory with the United Kingdom.
January 5, 1875: The Palais Garnier, one of the most famous opera houses in the world, is inaugurated in Paris.
January 5, 1882: Charles J. Guiteau is found guilty of assassinating US President James A. Garfield, and is sentenced to death by hanging.
January 5, 1911: Kappa Alpha Psi, the world's third oldest and largest black fraternity, is founded at Indiana University.
January 5, 1912: The Prague Party Conference takes place.
January 5, 1914: The Ford Motor Company announces an eight-hour workday and minimum daily wage of $5 in salary plus bonuses[2] subject to restrictions and imposed "character standards."[3]
January 5, 1919: The German Workers' Party, which would become the Nazi Party, is founded.
January 5, 1925: Nellie Tayloe Ross of Wyoming becomes the first female governor in the United States.
January 5, 1933: Construction of the Golden Gate Bridge begins in San Francisco Bay.
January 5, 1944: The Daily Mail becomes the first transoceanic newspaper.
January 5, 1945: The Soviet Union recognizes the new pro-Soviet government of Poland.
January 5, 1949: United States President Harry S. Truman unveils his Fair Deal program.
January 5, 1950: In the Sverdlovsk air disaster, all 19 of those on board were killed, including almost the entire national ice hockey team (VVS Moscow) of the Soviet Air Force – 11 players, as well as a team doctor and a masseur.
January 5, 1953: The play Waiting for Godot by Samuel Beckett is first performed.
January 5, 1957: In a speech given to the United States Congress, United States President Dwight D. Eisenhower announces the establishment of what will later be called the Eisenhower Doctrine.
January 5, 1968: Alexander Dubček comes to power; "Prague Spring" begins in Czechoslovakia.
January 5, 1970: The 7.1 Mw  Tonghai earthquake shakes Tonghai County, Yunnan province, China, with a maximum Mercalli intensity of X (Extreme). Between 10,000–15,621 were killed and 26,783 were injured.
January 5, 1972: United States President Richard Nixon orders the development of a Space Shuttle program.
January 5, 1974: The warmest reliably measured temperature below the Antarctic Circle of +59 °F (+15 °C) is recorded at Vanda Station.
January 5, 1975: The Tasman Bridge in Tasmania, Australia, is struck by the bulk ore carrier Lake Illawarra, killing twelve people.
January 5, 1976: The Khmer Rouge proclaim the Constitution of Democratic Kampuchea.
January 5, 1991: The United States Embassy to Somalia in Mogadishu is evacuated by helicopter airlift days after violence enveloped Mogadishu during the Somali Civil War
January 5, 1993: The oil tanker MV Braer runs aground on the coast of the Shetland Islands, spilling 84,700 tons of crude oil.
January 5, 2005: Eris, the most massive and second-largest known dwarf planet in the Solar System, is discovered by the team of Michael E. Brown, Chad Trujillo, and David L. Rabinowitz using images originally taken on October 21, 2003, at the Palomar Observatory.
January 5, 2014: A launch of the communication satellite GSAT-14 aboard the GSLV MK.II D5 marks the first successful flight of an Indian cryogenic engine.
January 6, 1066: Following the death of Edward the Confessor on the previous day, the Witan meets to confirm Harold Godwinson as the new King of England; Harold is crowned the same day, sparking a succession crisis that will eventually lead to the Norman conquest of England.[1]
January 6, 1205: Philip of Swabia undergoes a second coronation as King of the Romans.[2]
January 6, 1322: Stephen Uroš III is crowned King of Serbia, having defeated his half-brother Stefan Konstantin in battle. His son is crowned "young king" in the same ceremony.[3]
January 6, 1355: Charles I of Bohemia is crowned with the Iron Crown of Lombardy as King of Italy in Milan.
January 6, 1449: Constantine XI is crowned Byzantine Emperor at Mystras.
January 6, 1492: The Catholic Monarchs Ferdinand and Isabella enter Granada, completing the Reconquista.
January 6, 1536: The first European school of higher learning in the Americas, Colegio de Santa Cruz de Tlatelolco, is founded by Viceroy Antonio de Mendoza and Bishop Juan de Zumárraga in Mexico City.[4]
January 6, 1540: King Henry VIII of England marries Anne of Cleves.
January 6, 1579: The Union of Arras unites the southern Netherlands under the Duke of Parma (Ottavio Farnese), governor in the name of King Philip II of Spain.
January 6, 1690: Joseph, son of Emperor Leopold I, becomes King of the Romans.
January 6, 1721: The Committee of Inquiry on the South Sea Bubble publishes its findings.
January 6, 1781: In the Battle of Jersey, the British defeat the last attempt by France to invade Jersey in the Channel Islands.
January 6, 1809: Combined British, Portuguese and colonial Brazilian forces begin the Invasion of Cayenne during the Napoleonic Wars.
January 6, 1838: Alfred Vail demonstrates a telegraph system using dots and dashes (this is the forerunner of Morse code).
January 6, 1839: The Night of the Big Wind, the most damaging storm in 300 years, sweeps across Ireland, damaging or destroying more than 20% of the houses in Dublin.
January 6, 1847: Samuel Colt obtains his first contract for the sale of revolver pistols to the United States government.[5]
January 6, 1870: The inauguration of the Musikverein in Vienna, Austria.
January 6, 1893: The Washington National Cathedral is chartered by Congress. The charter is signed by President Benjamin Harrison.
January 6, 1907: Maria Montessori opens her first school and daycare center for working class children in Rome, Italy.
January 6, 1912: German geophysicist Alfred Wegener first presents his theory of continental drift.
January 6, 1929: Mother Teresa arrives in Calcutta, India, to begin her work among India's poorest and sick people.
January 6, 1930: The first diesel-powered automobile trip is completed, from Indianapolis, Indiana, to New York, New York.
January 6, 1931: Thomas Edison signs his last patent application.
January 6, 1941: United States President Franklin D. Roosevelt delivers his Four Freedoms speech in the State of the Union address.
January 6, 1946: The first general election ever in Vietnam is held.
January 6, 1947: Pan American Airlines becomes the first commercial airline to offer a round-the-world ticket.
January 6, 1950: The United Kingdom recognizes the People's Republic of China. The Republic of China severs diplomatic relations with the UK in response.
January 6, 1960: The Associations Law comes into force in Iraq, allowing registration of political parties.
January 6, 1974: In response to the 1973 oil crisis, daylight saving time commences nearly four months early in the United States.
January 6, 1978: The Crown of St. Stephen (also known as the Holy Crown of Hungary) is returned to Hungary from the United States, where it was held after World War II.
January 6, 1989: Satwant Singh and Kehar Singh are sentenced to death for conspiracy in the assassination of Prime Minister Indira Gandhi; the two men are executed the same day.
January 6, 1992: President of Georgia Zviad Gamsakhurdia flees the country as a result of the military coup.
January 6, 1993: Indian Border Security Force units kill 55 Kashmiri civilians in Sopore, Jammu and Kashmir, in revenge after militants ambushed a BSF patrol.
January 6, 1995: A chemical fire in an apartment complex in Manila, Philippines, leads to the discovery of plans for Project Bojinka, a mass-terrorist attack.
January 6, 2001: The US Congress certifies George W. Bush winner of 2000 presidential election.
January 6, 2005: A train collision in Graniteville, South Carolina, United States, releases about 60 tons of chlorine gas.
January 6, 2012: Twenty-six people are killed and 63 wounded when a suicide bomber blows himself up at a police station in Damascus.
January 6, 2017: The US Congress certifies Donald Trump winner of 2016 presidential election.
January 6, 2019: 40 people were killed in a gold mine collapse in northern Afghanistan.[6]
January 7, 1131: Canute Lavard was murdered at Haraldsted, Denmark by his cousin, Magnus I of Sweden.
January 7, 1325: Alfonso IV becomes King of Portugal.
January 7, 1558: French troops, led by Francis, Duke of Guise, take Calais, the last continental possession of England.
January 7, 1738: A peace treaty is signed between Peshwa Bajirao and Jai Singh II following Maratha victory in the Battle of Bhopal.
January 7, 1782: The first American commercial bank, the Bank of North America, opens.
January 7, 1785: Frenchman Jean-Pierre Blanchard and American John Jeffries travel from Dover, England, to Calais, France, in a gas balloon.
January 7, 1835: HMS Beagle drops anchor off the Chonos Archipelago.
January 7, 1894: William Kennedy Dickson receives a patent for motion picture film.
January 7, 1904: The distress signal "CQD" is established only to be replaced two years later by "SOS".
January 7, 1919: Montenegrin guerrilla fighters rebel against the planned annexation of Montenegro by Serbia, but fail.
January 7, 1920: The New York State Assembly refuses to seat five duly elected Socialist assemblymen.
January 7, 1922: Dáil Éireann ratifies the Anglo-Irish Treaty by a 64–57 vote.
January 7, 1927: The first transatlantic telephone service is established from New York City to London.
January 7, 1928: A disastrous flood of the River Thames kills 14 people and causes extensive damage to much of riverside London.
January 7, 1931: Guy Menzies flies the first solo non-stop trans-Tasman flight (from Australia to New Zealand) in 11 hours and 45 minutes, crash-landing on New Zealand's west coast.
January 7, 1935: Benito Mussolini and French Foreign minister Pierre Laval sign the Franco-Italian Agreement.
January 7, 1948: Kentucky Air National Guard pilot Thomas Mantell crashes while in pursuit of a supposed UFO.
January 7, 1955: Contralto Marian Anderson becomes the first person of color to perform at the Metropolitan Opera in Giuseppe Verdi's Un ballo in maschera.
January 7, 1959: The United States recognizes the new Cuban government of Fidel Castro.
January 7, 1973: Mark Essex fatally shoots ten people and wounds 13 others at Howard Johnson's Hotel in New Orleans, Louisiana, before being shot to death by police officers.
January 7, 1980: U.S. President Jimmy Carter authorizes legislation giving $1.5 billion in loans to bail out the Chrysler Corporation.
January 7, 1984: Brunei becomes the sixth member of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN).
January 7, 1985: Japan Aerospace Exploration Agency launches Sakigake, Japan's first interplanetary spacecraft and the first deep space probe to be launched by any country other than the United States or the Soviet Union.
January 7, 1991: Roger Lafontant, former leader of the Tonton Macoute in Haiti under François Duvalier, attempts a coup d'état, which ends in his arrest.
January 7, 1993: The Fourth Republic of Ghana is inaugurated with Jerry Rawlings as President.
January 7, 1999: The Senate trial in the impeachment of U.S. President Bill Clinton begins.
January 7, 2012: A hot air balloon crashes near Carterton, New Zealand, killing all 11 people on board.
January 7, 2015: A car bomb explodes outside a police college in the Yemeni capital Sana'a with at least 38 people reported dead and more than 63 injured.
January 8, 307: Jin Huaidi becomes emperor of China in succession to his father, Jin Huidi, despite a challenge from his uncle, Sima Ying.[1]
January 8, 871: Alfred the Great leads a West Saxon army to repel an invasion by Danelaw Vikings.[2]
January 8, 1297: François Grimaldi, disguised as a monk, leads his men to capture the fortress protecting the Rock of Monaco, establishing his family as the rulers of Monaco.
January 8, 1454: The papal bull Romanus Pontifex awards the Kingdom of Portugal exclusive trade and colonization rights to all of Africa south of Cape Bojador.[3]
January 8, 1499: Louis XII of France marries Anne of Brittany in accordance with a law set by his predecessor, Charles VIII.
January 8, 1547: The first Lithuanian-language book, Simple Words of Catechism, is published in Königsberg.
January 8, 1735: The premiere of George Frideric Handel's Ariodante takes place at the Royal Opera House, Covent Garden.
January 8, 1790: George Washington delivers the first State of the Union address in New York City.
January 8, 1806: Cape Colony becomes a British colony.
January 8, 1811: An unsuccessful slave revolt is led by Charles Deslondes in St. Charles and St. James, Louisiana.
January 8, 1828: The Democratic Party of the United States is organized.
January 8, 1835: The United States national debt is zero for the only time.
January 8, 1867: African American men are granted the right to vote in Washington, D.C.
January 8, 1877: Crazy Horse and his warriors fight their last battle against the United States Cavalry at Wolf Mountain, Montana Territory.
January 8, 1889: Herman Hollerith is issued US patent #395,791 for the 'Art of Applying Statistics' — his punched card calculator.
January 8, 1904: The Blackstone Library is dedicated, marking the beginning of the Chicago Public Library system.
January 8, 1912: The African National Congress is founded, under the name South African Native National Congress (SANNC).[4]
January 8, 1918: U.S. President Woodrow Wilson announces his "Fourteen Points" for the aftermath of World War I.
January 8, 1920: The steel strike of 1919 ends in a complete failure for the Amalgamated Association of Iron, Steel and Tin Workers labor union.
January 8, 1926: Abdul-Aziz ibn Saud is crowned King of Hejaz.[5]
January 8, 1936: Kashf-e hijab decree is enforced by Reza Shah ordering the police to physically remove the Hijab from any woman in public.
January 8, 1961: In France a referendum supports Charles de Gaulle's policies in Algeria.
January 8, 1963: Leonardo da Vinci's Mona Lisa is exhibited in the United States for the first time, at the National Gallery of Art in Washington, D.C.
January 8, 1964: President Lyndon B. Johnson declares a "War on Poverty" in the United States.
January 8, 1972: Bowing to international pressure, President of Pakistan Zulfikar Ali Bhutto releases Bengali leader Sheikh Mujibur Rahman from prison, who had been arrested after declaring the independence of Bangladesh.
January 8, 1973: Soviet space mission Luna 21 is launched.
January 8, 1975: Ella T. Grasso becomes Governor of Connecticut, the first woman to serve as a Governor in the United States other than by succeeding her husband.
January 8, 1977: Three bombs explode in Moscow, Russia, Soviet Union, within 37 minutes, killing seven. The bombings are attributed to an Armenian separatist group.
January 8, 1981: A local farmer reports a UFO sighting in Trans-en-Provence, France, claimed to be "perhaps the most completely and carefully documented sighting of all time".
January 8, 1994: Russian cosmonaut Valeri Polyakov on Soyuz TM-18 leaves for Mir. He would stay on the space station until March 22, 1995, for a record 437 days in space.
January 8, 1996: An Antonov An-32 cargo aircraft crashes into a crowded market in Kinshasa, Zaire, killing up to 223 on the ground; two of six crew members are also killed.
January 8, 2002: President George W. Bush signs into law the No Child Left Behind Act.
January 8, 2003: Air Midwest Flight 5481 crashes at Charlotte-Douglas Airport, Charlotte, North Carolina, killing all 21 people on board.
January 8, 2004: The RMS Queen Mary 2, then the largest ocean liner ever built, is christened by her namesake's granddaughter, Queen Elizabeth II.
January 8, 2005: The nuclear sub USS San Francisco collides at full speed with an undersea mountain south of Guam. One man is killed, but the sub surfaces and is repaired.
January 8, 2009: A 6.1-magnitude earthquake in northern Costa Rica kills 15 people and injures 32.
January 8, 2010: Gunmen from an offshoot the Front for the Liberation of the Enclave of Cabinda attack a bus carrying the Togo national football team on its way to the 2010 Africa Cup of Nations, killing three.
January 8, 2011: The attempted assassination of Arizona Representative Gabrielle Giffords and subsequent shooting in Casas Adobes, Arizona, in which five people were shot dead.
January 8, 2016: Joaquín Guzmán, widely regarded as the world's most powerful drug trafficker, is recaptured following his escape from a maximum security prison in Mexico.
January 9, 475: Byzantine Emperor Zeno is forced to flee his capital at Constantinople, and his general, Basiliscus gains control of the empire.
January 9, 1150: Wanyan Liang and other court officials murder Emperor Xizong of Jin. Wanyan Liang succeeds him as emperor.
January 9, 1349: The Jewish population of Basel, believed by the residents to be the cause of the ongoing Black Death, is rounded up and incinerated.
January 9, 1431: Judges' investigations for the trial of Joan of Arc begin in Rouen.
January 9, 1760: Ahmad Shah Durrani defeats the Marathas in the Battle of Barari Ghat.
January 9, 1788: Connecticut becomes the fifth state to ratify the Constitution.
January 9, 1792: Treaty of Jassy between Russian and Ottoman Empire is signed.
January 9, 1793: Jean-Pierre Blanchard becomes the first person to fly in a balloon in the United States.
January 9, 1799: British Prime Minister William Pitt the Younger introduces an income tax of two shillings to the pound to raise funds for Great Britain's war effort in the Napoleonic Wars.
January 9, 1806: Admiral Horatio Lord Nelson receives a state funeral and is interred in St Paul's Cathedral.
January 9, 1816: Sir Humphry Davy tests his safety lamp for miners at Hebburn Colliery.
January 9, 1822: The Portuguese prince Pedro I of Brazil decides to stay in Brazil against the orders of the Portuguese King João VI, beginning the Brazilian independence process.
January 9, 1839: The French Academy of Sciences announces the Daguerreotype photography process.
January 9, 1857: The 7.9 Mw  Fort Tejon earthquake shakes Central and Southern California with a maximum Mercalli intensity of IX (Violent).
January 9, 1858: Anson Jones, the last President of the Republic of Texas, commits suicide.
January 9, 1861: Mississippi becomes the second state to secede from the Union before the outbreak of the American Civil War.
January 9, 1878: Umberto I becomes King of Italy.
January 9, 1894: New England Telephone and Telegraph installs the first battery-operated telephone switchboard in Lexington, Massachusetts.
January 9, 1903: Hallam Tennyson, 2nd Baron Tennyson, son of the poet Alfred Tennyson, becomes the second Governor-General of Australia.
January 9, 1909: Ernest Shackleton, leading the Nimrod Expedition to the South Pole, plants the British flag 97 nautical miles (180 km; 112 mi) from the South Pole, the farthest anyone had ever reached at that time.
January 9, 1914: Phi Beta Sigma Fraternity Inc., the first historically black intercollegiate Greek-letter fraternity to be officially recognized at Howard University, is founded.
January 9, 1923: Lithuanian residents of the Memel Territory rebel against the League of Nations' decision to leave the area as a mandated region under French control.
January 9, 1927: A fire at the Laurier Palace movie theatre in Montreal, Quebec, Canada, kills 78 children.
January 9, 1957: British Prime Minister Sir Anthony Eden resigns from office following his failure to retake the Suez Canal from Egyptian sovereignty.
January 9, 1960: President of Egypt Gamal Abdel Nasser opens construction on the Aswan Dam by detonating ten tons of dynamite to demolish twenty tons of granite on the east bank of the Nile.
January 9, 1961: British authorities announce they have uncovered the Soviet Portland Spy Ring in London.
January 9, 1965: The Mirzapur Cadet College formally opens for academic activities in East Pakistan (now Bangladesh).
January 9, 1991: Representatives from the United States and Iraq meet at the Geneva Peace Conference to try to find a peaceful resolution to the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait.
January 9, 1992: The first discoveries of extrasolar planets are announced by astronomers Aleksander Wolszczan and Dale Frail. They discovered two planets orbiting the pulsar PSR 1257+12.[1]
January 9, 2004: An inflatable boat carrying illegal Albanian emigrants stalls near the Karaburun Peninsula en route to Brindisi, Italy; exposure to the elements kills 28. This is the second deadliest marine disaster in Albanian history.
January 9, 2005: The Sudan People's Liberation Movement and the Government of Sudan sign the Comprehensive Peace Agreement to end the Second Sudanese Civil War.
January 9, 2007: Apple CEO Steve Jobs introduces the original iPhone at a Macworld keynote in San Francisco.
January 9, 2011: Iran Air Flight 277 crashes near Orumiyeh in the northwest of the country, killing 77 people.
January 9, 2014: An explosion at a Mitsubishi Materials chemical plant in Yokkaichi, Japan, kills at least five people and injures 17 others.
January 9, 2015: A mass poisoning at a funeral in Mozambique involving beer that was contaminated with Burkholderia gladioli leaves 75 dead and over 230 people ill.[2]
January 10, 49 BC: Julius Caesar crosses the Rubicon, signalling the start of civil war.
January 10, AD 9: The Western Han dynasty ends when Wang Mang claims that the divine Mandate of Heaven called for the end of the dynasty and the beginning of his own, the Xin dynasty.
January 10, AD 69: Lucius Calpurnius Piso Licinianus is appointed by Galba as deputy Roman Emperor.
January 10, 236: Pope Fabian succeeds Anterus to become the twentieth pope of Rome.
January 10, 1072: Robert Guiscard conquers Palermo in Sicily.
January 10, 1430: Philip the Good, the Duke of Burgundy, establishes the Order of the Golden Fleece, the most prestigious, exclusive, and expensive order of chivalry in the world.[1]
January 10, 1475: Stephen III of Moldavia defeats the Ottoman Empire at the Battle of Vaslui.
January 10, 1645: Archbishop William Laud is beheaded for treason at the Tower of London.
January 10, 1791: The Siege of Dunlap's Station begins near Cincinnati during the Northwest Indian War.
January 10, 1806: Two British brigades occupy Cape Town after the Battle of Blaauwberg.
January 10, 1812: The first steamboat on the Ohio River or the Mississippi River arrives in New Orleans, 82 days after departing from Pittsburgh.
January 10, 1863: The Metropolitan Railway, the world's oldest underground railway, opens between Paddington and Farringdon, marking the beginning of the London Underground.
January 10, 1870: John D. Rockefeller incorporates Standard Oil.
January 10, 1901: The first great Texas oil gusher is discovered at Spindletop in Beaumont, Texas.
January 10, 1920: League of Nations Covenant enters into force. On January 16 the organization holds its first council meeting, in Paris.
January 10, 1927: Fritz Lang's futuristic film Metropolis is released in Germany.
January 10, 1946: The United States Army Signal Corps successfully conducts Project Diana, bouncing radio waves off the Moon and receiving the reflected signals.
January 10, 1954: BOAC Flight 781, a de Havilland DH.106 Comet 1, explodes and falls into the Tyrrhenian Sea killing 35 people.
January 10, 1966: Tashkent Declaration, a peace agreement between India and Pakistan signed that resolved the Indo-Pakistani War of 1965.
January 10, 1972: Sheikh Mujibur Rahman returns to the newly independent Bangladesh as president after spending over nine months in prison in Pakistan.
January 10, 1985: Sandinista Daniel Ortega becomes president of Nicaragua and vows to continue the transformation to socialism and alliance with the Soviet Union and Cuba; American policy continues to support the Contras in their revolt against the Nicaraguan government.
January 10, 1990: Time Warner is formed by the merger of Time Inc. and Warner Communications.
January 10, 2007: A general strike begins in Guinea in an attempt to get President Lansana Conté to resign.
January 10, 2012: A bombing in Khyber Agency, Pakistan, kills at least 30 people and 78 others injured.
January 10, 2013: More than 100 people are killed and 270 injured in several bomb blasts in Pakistan.
January 10, 2015: A traffic accident between an oil tanker truck and passenger coach en route to Shikarpur from Karachi on the Pakistan National Highway Link Road near Gulshan-e-Hadeed, Karachi, killing at least 62 people.
January 11, 947: Emperor Tai Zong of the Khitan-led Liao Dynasty invades the Later Jin, resulting in the destruction of the Later Jin.
January 11, 1055: Theodora is crowned empress of the Byzantine Empire.
January 11, 1158: Vladislaus II, Duke of Bohemia becomes King of Bohemia.
January 11, 1571: Austrian nobility is granted freedom of religion.
January 11, 1693: A powerful earthquake destroys parts of Sicily and Malta.
January 11, 1759: In Philadelphia, Pennsylvania, the first American life insurance company is incorporated.
January 11, 1779: Ching-Thang Khomba is crowned King of Manipur.
January 11, 1787: William Herschel discovers Titania and Oberon, two moons of Uranus.
January 11, 1908: Grand Canyon National Monument is created.
January 11, 1912: Immigrant textile workers in Lawrence, Massachusetts, go on strike when wages are reduced in response to a mandated shortening of the work week.
January 11, 1917: The Kingsland munitions factory explosion occurs as a result of sabotage.
January 11, 1922: First use of insulin to treat diabetes in a human patient.
January 11, 1927: Louis B. Mayer, head of film studio Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer (MGM), announces the creation of the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences, at a banquet in Los Angeles, California.
January 11, 1935: Amelia Earhart becomes the first person to fly solo from Hawaii to California.
January 11, 1943: Italian-American anarchist Carlo Tresca is assassinated in New York City.
January 11, 1946: Enver Hoxha, Secretary General of the Communist Party of Albania, declares the People's Republic of Albania with himself as head of state.
January 11, 1949: The first "networked" television broadcasts took place as KDKA-TV in Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania goes on the air connecting the east coast and mid-west programming.
January 11, 1957: The African Convention is founded in Dakar, Senegal.
January 11, 1961: Throgs Neck Bridge over the East River, linking New York City's boroughs of The Bronx and Queens, opens to road traffic.
January 11, 1962: An avalanche on Huascarán in Peru causes around 4,000 deaths.
January 11, 1973: Major League Baseball owners vote in approval of the American League adopting the designated hitter position.
January 11, 1986: The Gateway Bridge, Brisbane, Queensland, Australia is officially opened.
January 11, 1994: The Irish Government announces the end of a 15-year broadcasting ban on the IRA and its political arm Sinn Féin.
January 11, 1998: Over 100 people are killed in the Sidi-Hamed massacre in Algeria.
January 11, 2003: Illinois Governor George Ryan commutes the death sentences of 167 prisoners on Illinois's death row based on the Jon Burge scandal.
January 11, 2013: One French soldier and 17 militants are killed in a failed attempt to free a French hostage in Bulo Marer, Somalia.
January 12, 1528: Gustav I of Sweden is crowned King of Sweden, having already reigned since his election in June 1523.
January 12, 1554: Bayinnaung, who would go on to assemble the largest empire in the history of Southeast Asia, is crowned King of Burma.
January 12, 1616: The city of Belém, Brazil is founded on the Amazon River delta, by Portuguese captain Francisco Caldeira Castelo Branco.
January 12, 1808: The organizational meeting leading to the creation of the Wernerian Natural History Society, a former Scottish learned society, is held in Edinburgh.
January 12, 1848: The Palermo rising takes place in Sicily against the Bourbon Kingdom of the Two Sicilies.
January 12, 1866: The Royal Aeronautical Society is formed in London.
January 12, 1872: Yohannes IV is crowned Emperor of Ethiopia in Axum, the first imperial coronation in that city in over 200 years.
January 12, 1895: The National Trust is founded in the United Kingdom.
January 12, 1908: A long-distance radio message is sent from the Eiffel Tower for the first time.
January 12, 1911: The University of the Philippines College of Law is formally established; three future Philippine presidents are among the first enrollees.
January 12, 1915: The United States House of Representatives rejects a proposal to require states to give women the right to vote.
January 12, 1916: Both Oswald Boelcke and Max Immelmann, for achieving eight aerial victories each over Allied aircraft, receive the German Empire's highest military award, the Pour le Mérite as the first German aviators to earn it.
January 12, 1918: The Minnie Pit Disaster coal mining accident occurs in Halmer End, Staffordshire, in which 155 men and boys die.
January 12, 1921: Acting to restore confidence in baseball after the Black Sox Scandal, Judge Kenesaw Mountain Landis is elected as Major League Baseball's first commissioner.
January 12, 1932: Hattie Caraway becomes the first woman elected to the United States Senate.
January 12, 1964: Rebels in Zanzibar begin a revolt known as the Zanzibar Revolution and proclaim a republic.
January 12, 1966: Lyndon B. Johnson states that the United States should stay in South Vietnam until Communist aggression there is ended.
January 12, 1967: Dr. James Bedford becomes the first person to be cryonically preserved with intent of future resuscitation.
January 12, 1969: The New York Jets of the American Football League defeat the Baltimore Colts of the National Football League to win Super Bowl III in what is considered to be one of the greatest upsets in sports history.
January 12, 1970: Biafra capitulates, ending the Nigerian Civil War.
January 12, 1976: The United Nations Security Council votes 11–1 to allow the Palestine Liberation Organization to participate in a Security Council debate (without voting rights).
January 12, 1990: A seven-day pogrom breaks out against the Armenian civilian population of Baku, Azerbaijan, during which Armenians were beaten, tortured, murdered, and expelled from the city.
January 12, 1998: Nineteen European nations agree to forbid human cloning.
January 12, 2001: Downtown Disney opens to the public as part of the Disneyland Resort in Anaheim, California.
January 12, 2004: The world's largest ocean liner, RMS Queen Mary 2, makes its maiden voyage.
January 12, 2005: Deep Impact launches from Cape Canaveral on a Delta II rocket.
January 12, 2006: A stampede during the Stoning of the Devil ritual on the last day at the Hajj in Mina, Saudi Arabia, kills at least 362 Muslim pilgrims.
January 12, 2010: An earthquake in Haiti occurs, killing over 100,000 people and destroying much of the capital Port-au-Prince.
January 12, 2012: Violent protests occur in Bucharest, Romania, as two-day-old demonstrations continue against President Traian Băsescu's economic austerity measures. Clashes are reported in numerous Romanian cities between protesters and law enforcement officers.
January 12, 2015: Government raids kill 143 Boko Haram fighters in Kolofata, Cameroon.
January 12, 2016: Ten people are killed and 15 wounded in a bombing near the Blue Mosque in Istanbul.
January 13, 532: The Nika riots break out, during the racing season at the Hippodrome in Constantinople, as a result of discontent with the rule of the Emperor Justinian I.[1][2]
January 13, 1435: Sicut Dudum, forbidding the enslavement of the Guanche natives in Canary Islands by the Spanish, is promulgated by Pope Eugene IV.
January 13, 1547: Henry Howard, Earl of Surrey, is sentenced to death for treason, on the grounds of having quartered his arms to make them similar to those of the King, Henry VIII of England.[3]
January 13, 1607: The Bank of Genoa fails after announcement of national bankruptcy in Spain.
January 13, 1793: Nicolas Jean Hugon de Bassville, representative of Revolutionary France, lynched by a mob in Rome
January 13, 1822: The design of the Greek flag is adopted by the First National Assembly at Epidaurus.
January 13, 1830: The Great Fire of New Orleans begins.
January 13, 1833: United States President Andrew Jackson writes to Vice President Martin Van Buren expressing his opposition to South Carolina's defiance of federal authority in the Nullification Crisis.
January 13, 1840: The steamship Lexington burns and sinks four miles off the coast of Long Island with the loss of 139 lives.
January 13, 1842: Dr. William Brydon, an assistant surgeon in the British East India Company Army during the First Anglo-Afghan War, becomes famous for being the sole survivor of an army of 4,500 men and 12,000 camp followers when he reaches the safety of a garrison in Jalalabad, Afghanistan.
January 13, 1847: The Treaty of Cahuenga ends the Mexican–American War in California.
January 13, 1849: Establishment of the Colony of Vancouver Island.
January 13, 1879: In Mozart Gardens Brooklyn Ada Anderson completed a great feat of pedestrianism - 2700 quarter miles in 2700 quarter hours, earning her $8000.
January 13, 1888: The National Geographic Society is founded in Washington, D.C.
January 13, 1893: U.S. Marines land in Honolulu, Hawaii from the USS Boston to prevent the queen from abrogating the Bayonet Constitution.
January 13, 1898: Émile Zola's J'accuse…! exposes the Dreyfus affair.
January 13, 1908: The Rhoads Opera House fire in Boyertown, Pennsylvania kills 171 people.
January 13, 1910: The first public radio broadcast takes place; a live performance of the operas Cavalleria rusticana and Pagliacci are sent out over the airwaves from the Metropolitan Opera House in New York.
January 13, 1915: The 6.7 Mw  Avezzano earthquake shakes the Province of L'Aquila in Italy with a maximum Mercalli intensity of XI (Extreme), killing between 29,978–32,610.
January 13, 1935: A plebiscite in Saarland shows that 90.3% of those voting wish to join Nazi Germany.
January 13, 1939: The Black Friday bushfires burn 20,000 square kilometers of land in Australia, claiming the lives of 71 people.
January 13, 1942: Henry Ford patents a plastic automobile, which is 30% lighter than a regular car.
January 13, 1950: Finland forms diplomatic relations with the People's Republic of China.
January 13, 1953: An article appears in Pravda accusing some of the most prestigious and prominent doctors, mostly Jews, in the Soviet Union of taking part in a vast plot to poison members of the top Soviet political and military leadership.
January 13, 1958: The Moroccan Army of Liberation ambushes a Spanish patrol in the Battle of Edchera.
January 13, 1963: Coup d'état in Togo results in the assassination of president Sylvanus Olympio.
January 13, 1964: In Manchester, New Hampshire, fourteen-year-old Pamela Mason is murdered. Edward Coolidge is tried and convicted of the crime, but the conviction is set aside by the landmark Fourth Amendment case Coolidge v. New Hampshire (1971).
January 13, 1966: Robert C. Weaver becomes the first African American Cabinet member when he is appointed United States Secretary of Housing and Urban Development.
January 13, 1968: Johnny Cash performs live at Folsom State Prison.
January 13, 1972: Prime Minister Kofi Abrefa Busia and President Edward Akufo-Addo of Ghana are ousted in a bloodless military coup by Colonel Ignatius Kutu Acheampong.
January 13, 1974: Seraphim is elected Archbishop of Athens and All Greece.
January 13, 1978: United States Food and Drug Administration requires all blood donations to be labeled "paid" or "volunteer" donors.
January 13, 1982: Shortly after takeoff, Air Florida Flight 90, a Boeing 737 jet, crashes into Washington, D.C.'s 14th Street Bridge and falls into the Potomac River, killing 78 including four motorists.
January 13, 1985: A passenger train plunges into a ravine in Ethiopia, killing 428 in the worst railroad disaster in Africa.
January 13, 1986: A month-long violent struggle begins in Aden, South Yemen between supporters of Ali Nasir Muhammad and Abdul Fattah Ismail, resulting in thousands of casualties.
January 13, 1988: Lee Teng-hui becomes the first native Taiwanese President of the Republic of China.
January 13, 1990: Douglas Wilder becomes the first elected African American governor as he takes office as Governor of Virginia in Richmond, Virginia.
January 13, 1991: Soviet Union troops attack Lithuanian independence supporters in Vilnius, killing 14 people and wounding around 1000 others.
January 13, 1993: The Chemical Weapons Convention (CWC) is signed.[4]
January 13, 1998: Alfredo Ormando sets himself on fire in St. Peter's Square, protesting against homophobia.
January 13, 2001: An earthquake hits El Salvador, killing more than 800.
January 13, 2012: The passenger cruise ship Costa Concordia sinks off the coast of Italy due to the captain Francesco Schettino's negligence and irresponsibility. There are 32 confirmed deaths.
January 13, 2018: A false emergency alert warning of an impending missile strike in Hawaii caused widespread panic in the state.
January 14, 1236: King Henry III of England marries Eleanor of Provence.[1]
January 14, 1301: Andrew III of Hungary dies, ending the Árpád dynasty in Hungary.
January 14, 1343: Arnošt of Pardubice becomes the last bishop of Prague and, subsequently, the first Archbishop of Prague.
January 14, 1639: The "Fundamental Orders", the first written constitution that created a government, is adopted in Connecticut.
January 14, 1761: The Third Battle of Panipat is fought in India between the Afghans under Ahmad Shah Durrani and the Marathas.
January 14, 1858: Napoleon III of France escapes an assassination attempt made by Felice Orsini and his accomplices in Paris.
January 14, 1907: An earthquake in Kingston, Jamaica kills more than 1,000 people.
January 14, 1911: Roald Amundsen's South Pole expedition makes landfall on the eastern edge of the Ross Ice Shelf.
January 14, 1939: Norway claims Queen Maud Land in Antarctica.
January 14, 1950: The first prototype of the MiG-17 makes its maiden flight.
January 14, 1952: NBC's long-running morning news program Today debuts, with host Dave Garroway.
January 14, 1953: Josip Broz Tito is inaugurated as the first President of Yugoslavia.
January 14, 1954: The Hudson Motor Car Company merges with Nash-Kelvinator Corporation forming the American Motors Corporation.
January 14, 1957: Kripalu Maharaj was named fifth Jagadguru (world teacher) after giving seven days of speeches before 500 Hindu scholars.
January 14, 1960: The Reserve Bank of Australia, the country's central bank and banknote issuing authority, is established.
January 14, 1972: Queen Margrethe II of Denmark ascends the throne, the first Queen of Denmark since 1412 and the first Danish monarch not named Frederick or Christian since 1513.
January 14, 1973: Elvis Presley's concert Aloha from Hawaii is broadcast live via satellite, and sets the record as the most watched broadcast by an individual entertainer in television history.
January 14, 1993: In Poland's worst peacetime maritime disaster, ferry MS Jan Heweliusz sinks off the coast of Rügen, drowning 55 passengers and crew; nine crew-members are saved.
January 14, 2000: A United Nations tribunal sentences five Roman Catholic Bosnian Croats to up to 25 years in prison for the 1993 killing of more than 100 Bosnian Muslims.
January 14, 2004: The national flag of the Republic of Georgia, the so-called "five cross flag", is restored to official use after a hiatus of some 500 years.
January 14, 2010: Yemen declares an open war against the terrorist group al-Qaeda.
January 14, 2011: Former president of Tunisia, Zine El Abidine Ben Ali flees his country to Saudi Arabia after a series of street demonstrations against his regime and corrupt policies, asking for freedom, rights and democracy, considered as the anniversary of the Tunisian Revolution and the birth of the Arab Spring.
January 15, 69: Otho seizes power in Rome, proclaiming himself Emperor of Rome,[1] beginning a reign of only three months.
January 15, 1541: King Francis I of France gives Jean-François Roberval a commission to settle the province of New France (Canada) and provide for the spread of the "Holy Catholic faith".[2]
January 15, 1559: Elizabeth I is crowned Queen of England in Westminster Abbey, London.[3]
January 15, 1759: The British Museum opens to the public.[5]
January 15, 1782: Superintendent of Finance Robert Morris goes before the U.S. Congress to recommend establishment of a national mint and decimal coinage.
January 15, 1818: A paper by David Brewster is read to the Royal Society, belatedly announcing his discovery of what we now call the biaxial class of doubly-refracting crystals. On the same day, Augustin-Jean Fresnel signs a "supplement" (submitted four days later) on reflection of polarized light.
January 15, 1844: University of Notre Dame receives its charter from the state of Indiana.
January 15, 1867: Forty people died when ice covering the boating lake at Regents Park, London, collapsed.
January 15, 1870: A political cartoon for the first time symbolizes the Democratic Party with a donkey ("A Live Jackass Kicking a Dead Lion" by Thomas Nast for Harper's Weekly).
January 15, 1876: The first newspaper in Afrikaans, Die Afrikaanse Patriot, is published in Paarl.
January 15, 1889: The Coca-Cola Company, then known as the Pemberton Medicine Company, is incorporated in Atlanta.
January 15, 1892: James Naismith publishes the rules of basketball.
January 15, 1908: The Alpha Kappa Alpha sorority becomes the first Greek-letter organization founded and established by African American college women.
January 15, 1910: Construction ends on the Buffalo Bill Dam in Wyoming, United States, which was the highest dam in the world at the time, at 325 ft (99 m).
January 15, 1919: Rosa Luxemburg and Karl Liebknecht, two of the most prominent socialists in Germany, are tortured and murdered by the Freikorps at the end of the Spartacist uprising.
January 15, 1934: The 8.0 Mw  Nepal–Bihar earthquake strikes Nepal and Bihar with a maximum Mercalli intensity of XI (Extreme), killing an estimated 6,000–10,700 people.
January 15, 1936: The first building to be completely covered in glass, built for the Owens-Illinois Glass Company, is completed in Toledo, Ohio.
January 15, 1943: The Pentagon is dedicated in Arlington, Virginia.
January 15, 1962: The Derveni papyrus, Europe's oldest surviving manuscript dating to 340 BC, is found in northern Greece.
January 15, 1966: The First Nigerian Republic, led by Abubakar Tafawa Balewa is overthrown in a military coup d'état.
January 15, 1967: The first Super Bowl is played in Los Angeles. The Green Bay Packers defeat the Kansas City Chiefs 35–10.
January 15, 1970: Muammar Gaddafi is proclaimed premier of Libya.
January 15, 1975: The Alvor Agreement is signed, ending the Angolan War of Independence and giving Angola independence from Portugal.
January 15, 1976: Gerald Ford's would-be assassin, Sara Jane Moore, is sentenced to life in prison.
January 15, 1981: Pope John Paul II receives a delegation from Solidarity (Polish trade union) at the Vatican led by Lech Wałęsa.
January 15, 1991: Elizabeth II, in her capacity as Queen of Australia, signs letters patent allowing Australia to become the first Commonwealth realm to institute its own Victoria Cross in its honours system.
January 15, 2001: Wikipedia, a free wiki content encyclopedia, goes online.
January 15, 2005: ESA's SMART-1 lunar orbiter discovers elements such as calcium, aluminum, silicon, iron, and other surface elements on the Moon.
January 15, 2007: Barzan Ibrahim al-Tikriti, former Iraqi intelligence chief and half-brother of Saddam Hussein, and Awad Hamed al-Bandar, former chief judge of the Revolutionary Court, are executed by hanging in Iraq.
January 15, 2009: US Airways Flight 1549 ditches safely in the Hudson River after the plane collides with birds less than two minutes after take-off.
January 15, 2013: A train carrying Egyptian Army recruits derails near Giza, Greater Cairo, killing 19 and injuring 120 others.
January 15, 2015: The Swiss National Bank abandons the cap on the franc's value relative to the euro, causing turmoil in international financial markets
January 15, 2016: The Kenyan Army suffers it worst defeat ever in a battle with Al-Shabaab Islamic insurgents in El-Adde, Somalia. An estimated 150 soldiers die.
January 15, 2019: Theresa May's UK government suffers the biggest government defeat in modern times, when 432 MPs voting against the proposed European Union withdrawal agreement, giving her opponents a majority of 230.[8]
January 16, 27 BCE: Gaius Julius Caesar Octavianus is granted the title Augustus by the Roman Senate, marking the beginning of the Roman Empire.
January 16, 378: General Siyaj K'ak' conquers Tikal, enlarging the domain of King Spearthrower Owl of Teotihuacán.
January 16, 929: Emir Abd-ar-Rahman III established the Caliphate of Córdoba.
January 16, 1120: The Council of Nablus is held, establishing the earliest surviving written laws of the Crusader Kingdom of Jerusalem.
January 16, 1362: A storm tide in the North Sea ravages the East coast of England and destroys the German city of Rungholt on the island of Strand.
January 16, 1412: The Medici family is appointed official banker of the Papacy.
January 16, 1492: The first grammar of the Spanish language (Gramática de la lengua castellana) is presented to Queen Isabella I.
January 16, 1547: Grand Duke Ivan IV of Muscovy becomes the first Tsar of Russia, replacing the 264-year-old Grand Duchy of Moscow with the Tsardom of Russia.
January 16, 1556: Philip II becomes King of Spain.
January 16, 1572: Thomas Howard, 4th Duke of Norfolk is tried for treason for his part in the Ridolfi plot to restore Catholicism in England.
January 16, 1605: The first edition of El ingenioso hidalgo Don Quijote de la Mancha (Book One of Don Quixote) by Miguel de Cervantes is published in Madrid, Spain.
January 16, 1707: The Scottish Parliament ratifies the Act of Union, paving the way for the creation of Great Britain.
January 16, 1757: Forces of the Maratha Empire defeat a 5,000-strong army of the Durrani Empire in the Battle of Narela.[1]
January 16, 1786: Virginia enacts the Statute for Religious Freedom authored by Thomas Jefferson.
January 16, 1847: John C. Frémont is appointed Governor of the new California Territory.
January 16, 1883: The Pendleton Civil Service Reform Act, establishing the United States Civil Service, is passed.
January 16, 1900: The United States Senate accepts the Anglo-German treaty of 1899 in which the United Kingdom renounces its claims to the Samoan islands.
January 16, 1909: Ernest Shackleton's expedition finds the magnetic South Pole.
January 16, 1919: The United States ratifies the Eighteenth Amendment to the United States Constitution, requiring Prohibition in the United States one year after ratification.
January 16, 1920: The League of Nations holds its first council meeting in Paris, France.
January 16, 1921: The Marxist Left in Slovakia and the Transcarpathian Ukraine holds its founding congress in Ľubochňa.
January 16, 1942: Crash of TWA Flight 3, killing all 22 aboard, including film star Carole Lombard.
January 16, 1945: Adolf Hitler moves into his underground bunker, the so-called Führerbunker.
January 16, 1964: Hello, Dolly! opened on Broadway, beginning a run of 2,844 performances.
January 16, 1969: Soviet spacecraft Soyuz 4 and Soyuz 5 perform the first-ever docking of manned spacecraft in orbit, the first-ever transfer of crew from one space vehicle to another, and the only time such a transfer was accomplished with a space walk.
January 16, 1979: The last Iranian Shah flees Iran with his family for good and relocates to Egypt.
January 16, 1991: Coalition Forces go to war with Iraq, beginning the Gulf War.
January 16, 1992: El Salvador officials and rebel leaders sign the Chapultepec Peace Accords in Mexico City, Mexico ending the 12-year Salvadoran Civil War that claimed at least 75,000 lives.
January 16, 2001: US President Bill Clinton awards former President Theodore Roosevelt a posthumous Medal of Honor for his service in the Spanish–American War.
January 16, 2002: The UN Security Council unanimously establishes an arms embargo and the freezing of assets of Osama bin Laden, al-Qaeda, and the remaining members of the Taliban.
January 16, 2003: The Space Shuttle Columbia takes off for mission STS-107 which would be its final one. Columbia disintegrated 16 days later on re-entry.
January 16, 2006: Ellen Johnson Sirleaf is sworn in as Liberia's new president. She becomes Africa's first female elected head of state.
January 16, 2016: Thirty-three out of 126 freed hostages are injured and 23 killed in terrorist attacks in Ouagadougou, Burkina Faso on a hotel and a nearby restaurant.
January 17, 38 BC: Octavian divorces his wife Scribonia and marries Livia Drusilla, ending the fragile peace between the Second Triumvirate and Sextus Pompey.[1]
January 17, 1287: The Treaty of San Agayz is signed. King Alfonso III of Aragon conquers the island of Menorca from the Moors.
January 17, 1377: Pope Gregory XI reaches Rome, after deciding to move the Papacy back to Rome from Avignon.[2]
January 17, 1524: Giovanni da Verrazzano sets sail westward from Madeira to find a sea route to the Pacific Ocean.
January 17, 1562: France recognizes the Huguenots by the Edict of Saint-Germain.
January 17, 1595: During the French Wars of Religion, Henry IV of France declares war on Spain.
January 17, 1608: Emperor Susenyos I of Ethiopia surprises an Oromo army at Ebenat; his army reportedly kills 12,000 Oromo at the cost of 400 of his men.
January 17, 1648: England's Long Parliament passes the "Vote of No Addresses", breaking off negotiations with King Charles I and thereby setting the scene for the second phase of the English Civil War.
January 17, 1773: Captain James Cook commands the first expedition to sail south of the Antarctic Circle.
January 17, 1799: Maltese patriot Dun Mikiel Xerri, along with a number of other patriots, is executed.
January 17, 1852: The United Kingdom signs the Sand River Convention with the South African Republic.
January 17, 1873: A group of Modoc warriors defeats the United States Army in the First Battle of the Stronghold, part of the Modoc War.
January 17, 1885: A British force defeats a large Dervish army at the Battle of Abu Klea in the Sudan.
January 17, 1893: Lorrin A. Thurston, along with the Citizens' Committee of Public Safety, led the Overthrow of the Kingdom of Hawaii and the government of Queen Liliʻuokalani.
January 17, 1899: The United States takes possession of Wake Island in the Pacific Ocean.
January 17, 1903: El Yunque National Forest in Puerto Rico becomes part of the United States National Forest System as the Luquillo Forest Reserve.
January 17, 1904: Anton Chekhov's The Cherry Orchard receives its premiere performance at the Moscow Art Theatre.
January 17, 1912: British polar explorer Captain Robert Falcon Scott reaches the South Pole, one month after Roald Amundsen.
January 17, 1915: Russia defeats Ottoman Turkey in the Battle of Sarikamish during the Caucasus Campaign of World War I.
January 17, 1917: The United States pays Denmark $25 million for the Virgin Islands.
January 17, 1929: Popeye the Sailor Man, a cartoon character created by E. C. Segar, first appears in the Thimble Theatre comic strip.
January 17, 1945: Swedish diplomat Raoul Wallenberg is taken into Soviet custody while in Hungary; he is never publicly seen again.
January 17, 1946: The UN Security Council holds its first session.
January 17, 1948: The Renville Agreement between the Netherlands and Indonesia is ratified.
January 17, 1950: United Nations Security Council Resolution 79 relating to arms control is adopted.
January 17, 1961: Former Congolese Prime Minister Patrice Lumumba is murdered in circumstances suggesting the support and complicity of the governments of Belgium and the United States.
January 17, 1969: Black Panther Party members Bunchy Carter and John Huggins are killed during a meeting in Campbell Hall on the campus of UCLA.
January 17, 1977: Capital punishment in the United States resumes after a ten-year hiatus, as convicted murderer Gary Gilmore is executed by firing squad in Utah.
January 17, 1981: President of the Philippines Ferdinand Marcos lifts martial law eight years and five months after declaring it.
January 17, 1991: Crown prince Harald V of Norway becomes King Harald V, following the death of his father, King Olav V.
January 17, 1992: During a visit to South Korea, Japanese Prime Minister Kiichi Miyazawa apologizes for forcing Korean women into sexual slavery during World War II.
January 17, 1994: The 6.7 Mw  Northridge earthquake shakes the Greater Los Angeles Area with a maximum Mercalli intensity of IX (Violent), leaving 57 people dead and more than 8,700 injured.
January 17, 1995: The 6.9 Mw  Great Hanshin earthquake shakes the southern Hyōgo Prefecture with a maximum Shindo of VII, leaving 5,502–6,434 people dead, and 251,301–310,000 displaced.
January 17, 1996: The Czech Republic applies for membership of the European Union.
January 17, 2002: Mount Nyiragongo erupts in the Democratic Republic of the Congo, displacing an estimated 400,000 people.
January 17, 2007: The Doomsday Clock is set to five minutes to midnight in response to North Korea's nuclear testing.
January 17, 2010: Rioting begins between Muslim and Christian groups in Jos, Nigeria, results in at least 200 deaths.
January 18, 474: Seven-year-old Leo II succeeds his maternal grandfather Leo I as Byzantine emperor.[1] He dies ten months later.
January 18, 1126: Emperor Huizong abdicates the Chinese throne in favour of his son Emperor Qinzong.[2]
January 18, 1486: King Henry VII of England marries Elizabeth of York, daughter of Edward IV uniting the House of Lancaster and the House of York.[3]
January 18, 1562: Pope Pius IV reopens the Council of Trent for its third and final session.
January 18, 1591: King Naresuan of Siam kills Crown Prince Mingyi Swa of Burma in single combat, for which this date is now observed as Royal Thai Armed Forces day.
January 18, 1701: Frederick I crowns himself King of Prussia in Königsberg.
January 18, 1778: James Cook is the first known European to discover the Hawaiian Islands, which he names the "Sandwich Islands".
January 18, 1788: The first elements of the First Fleet carrying 736 convicts from Great Britain to Australia arrive at Botany Bay.
January 18, 1806: Jan Willem Janssens surrenders the Dutch Cape Colony to the British.
January 18, 1866: Wesley College is established in Melbourne, Australia.[4]
January 18, 1871: Wilhelm I of Germany is proclaimed Kaiser Wilhelm in the Hall of Mirrors of the Palace of Versailles (France) towards the end of the Franco-Prussian War. Wilhelm already had the title of German Emperor since the constitution of 1 January 1871, but he had hesitated to accept the title.
January 18, 1886: Modern field hockey is born with the formation of The Hockey Association in England.
January 18, 1896: An X-ray generating machine is exhibited for the first time by H. L. Smith.
January 18, 1911: Eugene B. Ely lands on the deck of the USS Pennsylvania anchored in San Francisco Bay, the first time an aircraft landed on a ship.
January 18, 1915: Japan issues the "Twenty-One Demands" to the Republic of China in a bid to increase its power in East Asia.
January 18, 1919: Ignacy Jan Paderewski becomes Prime Minister of the newly independent Poland.
January 18, 1958: Willie O'Ree, the first Black Canadian National Hockey League player, makes his NHL debut with the Boston Bruins.
January 18, 1960: Capital Airlines Flight 20 crashes into a farm in Charles City County, Virginia, killing all 50 aboard, the third fatal Capital Airlines crash in as many years.
January 18, 1967: Albert DeSalvo, the "Boston Strangler", is convicted of numerous crimes and is sentenced to life imprisonment.
January 18, 1969: United Airlines Flight 266 crashes into Santa Monica Bay killing all 32 passengers and six crew members.
January 18, 1974: A Disengagement of Forces agreement is signed between the Israeli and Egyptian governments, ending conflict on the Egyptian front of the Yom Kippur War.
January 18, 1976: Lebanese Christian militias kill at least 1,000 in Karantina, Beirut.
January 18, 1977: SFR Yugoslavia's Prime minister, Džemal Bijedić, his wife and six others are killed in a plane crash in Bosnia and Herzegovina.
January 18, 1978: The European Court of Human Rights finds the United Kingdom's government guilty of mistreating prisoners in Northern Ireland, but not guilty of torture.
January 18, 1983: The International Olympic Committee restores Jim Thorpe's Olympic medals to his family.
January 18, 1990: Washington, D.C. Mayor Marion Barry is arrested for drug possession in an FBI sting.
January 18, 1993: Martin Luther King, Jr. Day is officially observed for the first time in all 50 states.
January 18, 2002: Sierra Leone Civil War is declared over.
January 18, 2003: A bushfire kills four people and destroys more than 500 homes in Canberra, Australia.
January 18, 2005: The Airbus A380, the world's largest commercial jet, is unveiled at a ceremony in Toulouse, France
January 18, 2007: The strongest storm in the United Kingdom in 17 years kills 14 people and Germany sees the worst storm since 1999 with 13 deaths. Cyclone Kyrill causes at least 44 deaths across 20 countries in Western Europe.
January 18, 2008: The Euphronios Krater is unveiled in Rome after being returned to Italy by the Metropolitan Museum of Art.
January 18, 2018: A bus catches fire on the Samara–Shymkent road in Yrgyz District, Aktobe, Kazakhstan.[5] The fire kills 52 passengers, with three passengers and two drivers escaping.[6][7][8]
