February 5, 1975: Riots break in Lima, Peru after the police forces go on strike the day before. The uprising (locally known as the Limazo) is bloodily suppressed by the military dictatorship.
February 5, 1985: Ugo Vetere, then the mayor of Rome, and Chedli Klibi, then the mayor of Carthage meet in Tunis to sign a treaty of friendship officially ending the Third Punic War which lasted 2,131 years.
February 5, 1988: Manuel Noriega is indicted on drug smuggling and money laundering charges.
February 5, 1994: Markale massacres, more than 60 people are killed and some 200 wounded as a mortar shell explodes in a downtown marketplace in Sarajevo.
February 5, 1997: The so-called Big Three banks in Switzerland announce the creation of a $71 million fund to aid Holocaust survivors and their families.
February 5, 2000: Russian forces massacre at least 60 civilians in the Novye Aldi suburb of Grozny, Chechnya.
February 5, 2004: Rebels from the Revolutionary Artibonite Resistance Front capture the city of Gonaïves, starting the 2004 Haiti rebellion.
February 5, 2008: A major tornado outbreak across the Southern United States kills 57.
February 6, AD 60: The earliest date for which the day of the week is known. A graffito in Pompeii identifies this day as a dies Solis (Sunday). In modern reckoning, this date would have been a Wednesday.
February 6, 1579: The Archdiocese of Manila was made a diocese by a papal bull with Domingo de Salazar being its first bishop.
February 6, 1685: James II of England and VII of Scotland becomes King upon the death of his brother Charles II.
February 6, 1788: Massachusetts becomes the sixth state to ratify the United States Constitution.
February 6, 1815: New Jersey grants the first American railroad charter to John Stevens.
February 6, 1819: Sir Thomas Stamford Raffles founds Singapore.
February 6, 1820: The first 86 African American immigrants sponsored by the American Colonization Society depart New York to start a settlement in present-day Liberia.
February 6, 1833: Otto becomes the first modern King of Greece.
February 6, 1840: Signing of the Treaty of Waitangi, establishing New Zealand as a British colony.
February 6, 1843: The first minstrel show in the United States, The Virginia Minstrels, opens (Bowery Amphitheatre in New York City).
February 6, 1851: The largest Australian bushfires in a populous region in recorded history take place in the state of Victoria.
February 6, 1900: The Permanent Court of Arbitration, an international arbitration court at The Hague, is created when the Senate of the Netherlands ratifies an 1899 peace conference decree.
February 6, 1918: British women over the age of 30 who meet minimum property qualifications, get the right to vote when  Representation of the People Act 1918 is passed by Parliament.
February 6, 1922: The Washington Naval Treaty is signed in Washington, D.C., limiting the naval armaments of United States, Britain, Japan, France, and Italy.
February 6, 1934: Far-right leagues rally in front of the Palais Bourbon in an attempted coup against the French Third Republic, creating a political crisis in France.
February 6, 1951: The Broker, a Pennsylvania Railroad passenger train derails near Woodbridge Township, New Jersey. The accident kills 85 people and injures over 500 more. The wreck is one of the worst rail disasters in American history.
February 6, 1952: Elizabeth II becomes Queen of the United Kingdom and her other Realms and Territories and Head of the Commonwealth upon the death of her father, George VI. At the exact moment of succession, she was in a tree house at the Treetops Hotel in Kenya.
February 6, 1958: Eight Manchester United F.C. players and 15 other passengers are killed in the Munich air disaster.
February 6, 1959: At Cape Canaveral, Florida, the first successful test firing of a Titan intercontinental ballistic missile is accomplished.
February 6, 1976: In testimony before a United States Senate subcommittee, Lockheed Corporation president Carl Kotchian admits that the company had paid out approximately $3 million in bribes to the office of Japanese Prime Minister Kakuei Tanaka.
February 6, 1978: The Blizzard of 1978, one of the worst Nor'easters in New England history, hit the region, with sustained winds of 65 mph and snowfall of four inches an hour.
February 6, 1981: The National Resistance Army of Uganda launches an attack on a Ugandan Army installation in the central Mubende District to begin the Ugandan Bush War.
February 6, 1987: Justice Mary Gaudron becomes the first woman to be appointed to the High Court of Australia.
February 6, 1988: Michael Jordan makes his signature slam dunk from the free throw line inspiring Air Jordan and the Jumpman logo.
February 6, 1989: The Round Table Talks start in Poland, thus marking the beginning of the overthrow of communism in Eastern Europe.
February 6, 1996: Birgenair Flight 301 crashed off the coast of the Dominican Republic, killing all 189 people on board. This is the deadliest aviation accident involving a Boeing 757.
February 6, 1998: Washington National Airport is renamed Ronald Reagan National Airport.
February 6, 2016: An earthquake of magnitude 6.6 strikes southern Taiwan, killing 117 people.
February 6, 2018: SpaceX's Falcon Heavy, a super heavy launch vehicle, makes its maiden flight.
February 7, 457: Leo I the Thracian becomes emperor of the Byzantine Empire.[1]
February 7, 987: Bardas Phokas the Younger and Bardas Skleros, Byzantine generals of the military elite, begin a wide-scale rebellion against Emperor Basil II.
February 7, 1301: Edward of Caernarvon (later king Edward II of England) becomes the first English Prince of Wales.[2]
February 7, 1497: In Florence, Italy, supporters of Girolamo Savonarola burn cosmetics, art, and books, in a "Bonfire of the vanities".[3]
February 7, 1795: The 11th Amendment to the United States Constitution is ratified.
February 7, 1812: The strongest in a series of earthquakes strikes New Madrid, Missouri.
February 7, 1813: In the action of 7 February 1813 near the Îles de Los, the frigates Aréthuse and Amelia batter each other, but neither can gain the upper hand.
February 7, 1819: Sir Thomas Stamford Raffles leaves Singapore after just taking it over, leaving it in the hands of William Farquhar.
February 7, 1854: A law is approved to found the Swiss Federal Institute of Technology. Lectures started October 16, 1855.
February 7, 1863: HMS Orpheus sinks off the coast of Auckland, New Zealand, killing 189.
February 7, 1894: The Cripple Creek miner's strike, led by the Western Federation of Miners, begins in Cripple Creek, Colorado.
February 7, 1900: A Chinese immigrant in San Francisco falls ill to bubonic plague in the first plague epidemic in the continental United States.[5]
February 7, 1904: A fire begins in Baltimore, Maryland;[6] it destroys over 1,500 buildings in 30 hours.
February 7, 1940: The second full-length animated Walt Disney film, Pinocchio, premieres.
February 7, 1962: The United States bans all Cuban imports and exports.
February 7, 1974: Grenada gains independence from the United Kingdom.
February 7, 1979: Pluto moves inside Neptune's orbit for the first time since either was discovered.
February 7, 1986: Twenty-eight years of one-family rule end in Haiti, when President Jean-Claude Duvalier flees the Caribbean nation.
February 7, 1991: Haiti's first democratically elected president, Jean-Bertrand Aristide, is sworn in.
February 7, 1992: The Maastricht Treaty is signed, leading to the creation of the European Union.
February 7, 1995: Ramzi Yousef, the mastermind of the 1993 World Trade Center bombing, is arrested in Islamabad, Pakistan.
February 7, 1997: NeXT merges with Apple Computer, starting the path to Mac OS X.
February 7, 1999: Crown Prince Abdullah becomes the King of Jordan on the death of his father, King Hussein.
February 7, 2009: Bushfires in Victoria leave 173 dead in the worst natural disaster in Australia's history.
February 7, 2012: President Mohamed Nasheed of the Republic of Maldives resigns, after 23 days of anti-governmental protests calling for the release of Chief Judge unlawfully arrested by the military.
February 7, 2013: The U.S. state of Mississippi officially certifies the Thirteenth Amendment, becoming the last state to approve the abolition of slavery. The Thirteenth Amendment was formally ratified by Mississippi in 1995.
February 7, 2014: Scientists announce that the Happisburgh footprints in Norfolk, England, date back to more than 800,000 years ago, making them the oldest known hominid footprints outside Africa.[7]
February 7, 2016: North Korea launches Kwangmyŏngsŏng-4 into outer space violating multiple UN treaties and prompting condemnation from around the world.
February 8, 421: Constantius III becomes co-Emperor of the Western Roman Empire.[1]
February 8, 1238: The Mongols burn the Russian city of Vladimir.
February 8, 1347: The Byzantine civil war of 1341–47 ends with a power-sharing agreement between John VI Kantakouzenos and John V Palaiologos.
February 8, 1575: Leiden University is founded,[3] and given the motto Praesidium Libertatis.
February 8, 1587: Mary, Queen of Scots, is executed on suspicion of having been involved in the Babington Plot to murder her cousin, Queen Elizabeth I.
February 8, 1590: Luis de Carabajal the younger is tortured by the Inquisition in Mexico City.
February 8, 1601: Robert Devereux, 2nd Earl of Essex, rebels against Queen Elizabeth I and the revolt is quickly crushed.
February 8, 1693: The College of William & Mary in Williamsburg, Virginia, is granted a charter by King William III and Queen Mary II.
February 8, 1807: After two days of bitter fighting, the Russians under Bennigsen and the Prussians under L'Estocq concede the Battle of Eylau to Napoleon.
February 8, 1817: Las Heras crosses the Andes with an army to join San Martín and liberate Chile from Spain.
February 8, 1837: Richard Johnson becomes the first Vice President of the United States chosen by the United States Senate.
February 8, 1865: Delaware refuses to ratify the Thirteenth Amendment to the U.S. Constitution. Slavery was outlawed in the United States, including Delaware, when the Amendment was ratified by the requisite number of states on December 6, 1865. Delaware ratified the Thirteenth Amendment on February 12, 1901, which was the ninety-second anniversary of the birth of Abraham Lincoln.
February 8, 1879: The England cricket team led by Lord Harris is attacked in a riot during a match in Sydney.
February 8, 1885: The first government-approved Japanese immigrants arrived in Hawaii.
February 8, 1887: The Dawes Act authorizes the President of the United States to survey Native American tribal land and divide it into individual allotments.
February 8, 1910: The Boy Scouts of America is incorporated by William D. Boyce.
February 8, 1915: D. W. Griffith's controversial film The Birth of a Nation premieres in Los Angeles.
February 8, 1922: United States President Warren G. Harding introduces the first radio set in the White House.
February 8, 1946: The first portion of the Revised Standard Version of the Bible, the first serious challenge to the popularity of the Authorized King James Version, is published.
February 8, 1955: The Government of Sindh, Pakistan, abolishes the Jagirdari system in the province. One million acres (4000 km2) of land thus acquired is to be distributed among the landless peasants.
February 8, 1960: Queen Elizabeth II of the United Kingdom issues an Order-in-Council, stating that she and her family would be known as the House of Windsor, and that her descendants will take the name Mountbatten-Windsor.
February 8, 1962: Charonne massacre. Nine trade unionists are killed by French police at the instigation of Nazi collaborator Maurice Papon, then chief of the Paris Prefecture of Police.
February 8, 1963: The regime of Prime Minister of Iraq, Brigadier General Abd al-Karim Qasim is overthrown by the Ba'ath Party.
February 8, 1965: Eastern Air Lines Flight 663 crashes into the Atlantic Ocean and explodes, killing everyone aboard.
February 8, 1971: South Vietnamese ground troops launch an incursion into Laos to try to cut off the Ho Chi Minh trail and stop communist infiltration.
February 8, 1974: After 84 days in space, the crew of Skylab 4, the last crew to visit American space station Skylab, returns to Earth.
February 8, 1978: Proceedings of the United States Senate are broadcast on radio for the first time.
February 8, 1981: Twenty-one association football spectators are trampled to death at Karaiskakis Stadium in Neo Faliro, Greece, after a football match between Olympiacos F.C. and AEK Athens F.C.
February 8, 1983: The Melbourne dust storm hits Australia's second largest city. The result of the worst drought on record and a day of severe weather conditions, a 320 metres (1,050 ft) deep dust cloud envelops the city, turning day to night.
February 8, 1989: Independent Air Flight 1851 strikes Pico Alto mountain while on approach to Santa Maria Airport (Azores) killing all 144 passengers on board.
February 8, 1993: General Motors sues NBC after Dateline NBC allegedly rigs two crashes intended to demonstrate that some GM pickups can easily catch fire if hit in certain places. NBC settles the lawsuit the next day.
February 8, 1996: The U.S. Congress passes the Communications Decency Act.
February 8, 2010: A freak storm in the Hindu Kush mountains of Afghanistan triggers a series of at least 36 avalanches, burying over two miles of road, killing at least 172 people and trapping over 2,000 travelers.
February 8, 2013: A blizzard disrupts transportation and leaves hundreds of thousands of people without electricity in the Northeastern United States and parts of Canada.
February 8, 2014: A hotel fire in Medina, Saudi Arabia kills 15 Egyptian pilgrims with 130 others injured.
February 9, 474: Zeno is crowned as co-emperor of the Byzantine Empire.[1]
February 9, 1003: Boleslaus III is restored to authority with armed support from Bolesław I the Brave of Poland.
February 9, 1555: Bishop of Gloucester John Hooper is burned at the stake.[2]
February 9, 1621: Gregory XV becomes Pope, the last Pope elected by acclamation.[3]
February 9, 1654: The Capture of Fort Rocher takes place during the Anglo-Spanish War.[4]
February 9, 1788: The Habsburg Empire joins the Russo-Turkish War in the Russian camp.
February 9, 1825: After no candidate receives a majority of electoral votes in the US presidential election of 1824, the United States House of Representatives elects John Quincy Adams as President of the United States.
February 9, 1849: The new Roman Republic is declared.
February 9, 1870: US president Ulysses S. Grant signs a joint resolution of Congress establishing the U.S. Weather Bureau.
February 9, 1889: US president Grover Cleveland signs a bill elevating the United States Department of Agriculture to a Cabinet-level agency.
February 9, 1895: William G. Morgan creates a game called Mintonette, which soon comes to be referred to as volleyball.
February 9, 1900: The Davis Cup competition is established.
February 9, 1907: The Mud March is the first large procession organised by the National Union of Women's Suffrage Societies (NUWSS).
February 9, 1913: A group of meteors is visible across much of the eastern seaboard of North and South America, leading astronomers to conclude the source had been a small, short-lived natural satellite of the Earth.
February 9, 1920: Under the terms of the Svalbard Treaty, international diplomacy recognizes Norwegian sovereignty over Arctic archipelago Svalbard, and designates it as demilitarized.
February 9, 1922: Brazil becomes a member of the Berne Convention copyright treaty.
February 9, 1942: Year-round Daylight saving time aka War Time is re-instated in the United States as a wartime measure to help conserve energy resources.[6]
February 9, 1959: The R-7 Semyorka, the first intercontinental ballistic missile, becomes operational at Plesetsk, USSR.
February 9, 1964: The Beatles make their first appearance on The Ed Sullivan Show, performing before a "record-busting" audience of 73 million viewers across the USA.
February 9, 1965: The United States Marine Corps sends a MIM-23 Hawk missile battalion to South Vietnam, the first American troops in-country without an official advisory or training mission.
February 9, 1971: Satchel Paige becomes the first Negro League player to be voted into the USA's Baseball Hall of Fame.
February 9, 1975: The Soyuz 17 Soviet spacecraft returns to Earth.
February 9, 1978: The Budd Company unveils its first SPV-2000 self-propelled railcar in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania.
February 9, 1986: Halley's Comet last appeared in the inner Solar System.
February 9, 1991: Voters in Lithuania vote for independence.
February 9, 1996: Copernicium is discovered, by Sigurd Hofmann, Victor Ninov et al.[7]
February 9, 2016: Two passenger trains collided in the German town of Bad Aibling in the state of Bavaria. Twelve people died, and 85 others were injured.
February 10, 1306: In front of the high altar of Greyfriars Church in Dumfries, Robert the Bruce murders John Comyn sparking the revolution in the Wars of Scottish Independence.
February 10, 1355: The St Scholastica Day riot breaks out in Oxford, England, leaving 63 scholars and perhaps 30 locals dead in two days.[1]
February 10, 1502: Vasco da Gama sets sail from Lisbon, Portugal, on his second voyage to India.[2]
February 10, 1567: Lord Darnley, second husband of Mary, Queen of Scots, is found strangled following an explosion at the Kirk o' Field house in Edinburgh, Scotland, a suspected assassination.
February 10, 1712: Huilliches in Chiloé rebel against Spanish encomenderos.
February 10, 1840: Queen Victoria of the United Kingdom marries Prince Albert of Saxe-Coburg-Gotha.
February 10, 1861: Jefferson Davis is notified by telegraph that he has been chosen as provisional President of the Confederate States of America.
February 10, 1870: The YWCA is founded in New York City.
February 10, 1906: HMS Dreadnought, the first of a revolutionary new breed of battleships is christened and launched by King Edward VII.
February 10, 1920: Józef Haller de Hallenburg performs symbolic wedding of Poland to the sea, celebrating restitution of Polish access to open sea.
February 10, 1923: Texas Tech University is founded as Texas Technological College in Lubbock, Texas
February 10, 1930: The Việt Nam Quốc Dân Đảng launches the failed Yên Bái mutiny in hope to overthrow French protectorate over Vietnam.
February 10, 1933: In round 13 of a boxing match at New York City's Madison Square Garden, Primo Carnera knocks out Ernie Schaaf. Schaaf dies four days later.
February 10, 1940: Tom and Jerry make their debut with Puss Gets the Boot.
February 10, 1947: Crowds gathered at shop windows in Paris to see Christian Dior's New Look fashion—longer skirts, nipped-in waists and padded shoulders.
February 10, 1954: U.S. President Dwight D. Eisenhower warns against United States intervention in Vietnam.
February 10, 1962: Roy Lichtenstein's first solo exhibition opened, and it included Look Mickey, which featured his first employment of Ben-Day dots, speech balloons and comic imagery sourcing, all of which he is now known for.
February 10, 1967: The 25th Amendment to the United States Constitution is ratified.
February 10, 1972: Ras Al Khaimah joins the United Arab Emirates, now making up seven emirates.
February 10, 1984: Kenyan soldiers commit the worst ever human rights violation in the country by slaughtering an estimated 5000 ethnic Somali Kenyans in Wagalla in N.E.-Kenya.
February 10, 1989: Ron Brown is elected chairman of the Democratic National Committee becoming the first African American to lead a major American political party.
February 10, 1996: IBM supercomputer Deep Blue defeats Garry Kasparov in chess for the first time.
February 10, 2003: France and Belgium break the NATO procedure of silent approval concerning the timing of protective measures for Turkey in case of a possible war with Iraq.
February 10, 2007: Then Illinois senator Barack Obama announces his candidacy for president in the 2008 elections, which he later goes on to win.
February 10, 2009: The communications satellites Iridium 33 and Kosmos 2251 collide in orbit, destroying both.
February 10, 2013: Thirty-six people are killed and 39 others are injured in a stampede in Allahabad, India, during the Kumbh Mela festival.
February 10, 2016: South Korea decides to stop the operation of the Kaesong joint industrial complex with North Korea in response to the launch of Kwangmyŏngsŏng-4.
February 10, 2018: 19 people are killed and 66 injured when a Kowloon Motor Bus double decker on route 872 in Hong Kong overturns.
February 11, 660 BC: Traditional date for the foundation of Japan by Emperor Jimmu.
February 11, AD 55: Tiberius Claudius Caesar Britannicus, heir to the Roman emperorship, dies under mysterious circumstances in Rome. This clears the way for Nero to become Emperor.
February 11, 244: Emperor Gordian III is murdered by mutinous soldiers in Zaitha (Mesopotamia). A mound is raised at Carchemish in his memory.
February 11, 1177: John de Courcy's army defeats the native Dunleavey Clan in Ulster. The English establish themselves in Ulster.
February 11, 1534: Henry VIII of England is recognized as supreme head of the Church of England.
February 11, 1626: Emperor Susenyos I of Ethiopia and Patriarch Afonso Mendes declare the primacy of the Roman See over the Ethiopian Church, and Catholicism to be the state religion of Ethiopia.
February 11, 1659: The assault on Copenhagen by Swedish forces is beaten back with heavy losses.
February 11, 1790: The Religious Society of Friends, also known as Quakers, petitions U.S. Congress for the abolition of slavery.
February 11, 1794: First session of United States Senate opens to the public.
February 11, 1808: Jesse Fell burns anthracite on an open grate as an experiment in heating homes with coal.
February 11, 1812: Massachusetts governor Elbridge Gerry is accused of "gerrymandering" for the first time.
February 11, 1826: University College London is founded as University of London.
February 11, 1840: Gaetano Donizetti's opera La fille du régiment receives its first performance in Paris, France.
February 11, 1843: Giuseppe Verdi's opera I Lombardi alla prima crociata receives its first performance in Milan, Italy.
February 11, 1855: Kassa Hailu is crowned Tewodros II, Emperor of Ethiopia, by Abuna Salama III in a ceremony at the church of Derasge Maryam.
February 11, 1856: The Kingdom of Awadh is annexed by the British East India Company and Wajid Ali Shah, the king of Awadh, is imprisoned and later exiled to Calcutta.
February 11, 1858: Bernadette Soubirous's first vision of the Blessed Virgin Mary in Lourdes, France.
February 11, 1873: King Amadeo I of Spain abdicates.
February 11, 1889: Meiji Constitution of Japan is adopted; the first National Diet convenes in 1890.
February 11, 1903: Anton Bruckner's 9th Symphony receives its first performance in Vienna, Austria.
February 11, 1906: Pope Pius X publishes the encyclical Vehementer Nos.
February 11, 1919: Friedrich Ebert (SPD), is elected President of Germany.
February 11, 1929: Kingdom of Italy and the Vatican sign the Lateran Treaty.
February 11, 1937: The Flint sit-down strike ends when General Motors recognizes the United Auto Workers trade union.
February 11, 1938: BBC Television produces the world's first ever science fiction television program, an adaptation of a section of the Karel Čapek play R.U.R., that coined the term "robot".
February 11, 1939: A Lockheed P-38 Lightning flies from California to New York in seven hours two minutes.
February 11, 1953: The Soviet Union breaks off diplomatic relations with Israel.
February 11, 1959: The Federation of Arab Emirates of the South, which will later become South Yemen, is created as a protectorate of the United Kingdom.
February 11, 1964: Greeks and Turks begin fighting in Limassol, Cyprus.
February 11, 1979: The Iranian Revolution establishes an Islamic theocracy under the leadership of Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini.
February 11, 1981: Around 100,000 US gallons (380 m3) of radioactive coolant leak into the containment building of TVA Sequoyah 1 nuclear plant in Tennessee, contaminating eight workers.
February 11, 1990: Nelson Mandela is released from Victor Verster Prison outside Cape Town, South Africa after 27 years as a political prisoner.
February 11, 1997: Space Shuttle Discovery is launched on a mission to service the Hubble Space Telescope.
February 11, 1999: Pluto crosses Neptune's orbit, ending a nearly 20-year period (since 1979) when it was closer to the Sun than the gas giant; Pluto is not expected to interact with Neptune's orbit for another 228 years.
February 11, 2001: A Dutch programmer launched the Anna Kournikova virus infecting millions of emails via a trick photo of the tennis star.
February 11, 2006: U.S. Vice President Dick Cheney shot Harry Whittington, a 78-year-old Texas attorney, while participating in a quail hunt on a ranch in Riviera, Texas.
February 11, 2008: Rebel East Timorese soldiers seriously wound President José Ramos-Horta. Rebel leader Alfredo Reinado is killed in the attack.
February 11, 2013: The Vatican confirmed that Pope Benedict XVI would resign the papacy on 28 February 2013, as a result of his advanced age.
February 11, 2014: A military transport plane crashes in a mountainous area of Oum El Bouaghi Province in eastern Algeria, killing 77 people.
February 11, 2015: A university student was murdered as she resisted an attempted rape in Turkey, sparking nationwide protests and public outcry against harassment and violence against women.
February 11, 2016: A man shoots six people dead at an education center in Jizan Province, Saudi Arabia.
February 11, 2017: North Korea test fires a ballistic missile across the Sea of Japan.
February 11, 2018: Saratov Airlines Flight 703 crashes near Moscow, Russia. All 71 people on board die.
February 12, 1429: English forces under Sir John Fastolf defend a supply convoy carrying rations to the army besieging Orléans in the Battle of the Herrings.[1]
February 12, 1502: Isabella I issues an edict outlawing Islam in the Crown of Castile, forcing virtually all her Muslim subjects to convert to Christianity.[2]
February 12, 1541: Santiago, Chile is founded by Pedro de Valdivia.[3]
February 12, 1689: The Convention Parliament declares that the flight to France in 1688 by James II, the last Roman Catholic British monarch, constitutes an abdication.
February 12, 1771: Gustav III becomes the King of Sweden.[5]
February 12, 1817: An Argentine/Chilean patriotic army, after crossing the Andes, defeats Spanish troops at the Battle of Chacabuco.[6]
February 12, 1818: Bernardo O'Higgins formally approves the Chilean Declaration of Independence near Concepción, Chile.[7]
February 12, 1825: The Creek cede the last of their lands in Georgia to the United States government by the Treaty of Indian Springs, and migrate west.
February 12, 1894: Anarchist Émile Henry hurls a bomb into the Cafe Terminus in Paris, killing one person and wounding 20.
February 12, 1909: New Zealand's worst maritime disaster of the 20th century happens when the SS Penguin, an inter-island ferry, sinks and explodes at the entrance to Wellington Harbour.
February 12, 1912: The Xuantong Emperor, the last Emperor of China, abdicates.
February 12, 1915: In Washington, D.C., the first stone of the Lincoln Memorial is put into place.
February 12, 1921: Bolsheviks launch a revolt in Georgia as a preliminary to the Red Army invasion of Georgia.
February 12, 1924: George Gershwin's Rhapsody in Blue received its premiere in a concert titled "An Experiment in Modern Music", in Aeolian Hall, New York, by Paul Whiteman and his band, with Gershwin playing the piano.
February 12, 1935: USS Macon, one of the two largest helium-filled airships ever created, crashes into the Pacific Ocean off the coast of California and sinks.
February 12, 1946: African American United States Army veteran Isaac Woodard is severely beaten by a South Carolina police officer to the point where he loses his vision in both eyes. The incident later galvanizes the civil rights movement and partially inspires Orson Welles' film Touch of Evil.
February 12, 1947: Christian Dior unveils a "New Look", helping Paris regain its position as the capital of the fashion world.
February 12, 1961: The Soviet Union launches Venera 1 towards Venus.
February 12, 1963: Construction begins on the Gateway Arch in St. Louis, Missouri.
February 12, 1965: Malcolm X visits Smethwick following the racial charged 1964 general election.[8]
February 12, 1968: Phong Nhị and Phong Nhất massacre.
February 12, 1974: Aleksandr Solzhenitsyn, winner of the Nobel Prize in Literature in 1970, is exiled from the Soviet Union.
February 12, 1983: One hundred women protest in Lahore, Pakistan against military dictator Zia-ul-Haq's proposed Law of Evidence. The women were tear-gassed, baton-charged and thrown into lock-up. The women were successful in repealing the law.
February 12, 1990: Carmen Lawrence becomes the first female Premier in Australian history when she becomes Premier of Western Australia.
February 12, 1992: The current Constitution of Mongolia comes into effect.
February 12, 1993: Two-year-old James Bulger is abducted from New Strand Shopping Centre by two ten-year-old boys, who later torture and murder him.
February 12, 1994: Four thieves break into the National Gallery of Norway and steal Edvard Munch's iconic painting The Scream.
February 12, 1999: United States President Bill Clinton is acquitted by the United States Senate in his impeachment trial.
February 12, 2001: NEAR Shoemaker spacecraft touches down in the "saddle" region of 433 Eros, becoming the first spacecraft to land on an asteroid.
February 12, 2002: An Iran Airtour Tupolev Tu-154 crashes in the mountains outside Khorramabad, Iran while descending for a landing at Khorramabad Airport, killing 119.
February 12, 2004: The city of San Francisco begins issuing marriage licenses to same-sex couples in response to a directive from Mayor Gavin Newsom.
February 12, 2009: Colgan Air Flight 3407 crashes into a house in Clarence Center, New York while on approach to Buffalo Niagara International Airport, killing all on board and one on the ground.
February 12, 2016: Pope Francis and Patriarch Kirill sign an Ecumenical Declaration in the first such meeting between leaders of the Catholic and Russian Orthodox Churches since their split in 1054.
February 13, 951: Guo Wei, a court official, leads a military coup and declares himself emperor of the new Later Zhou.
February 13, 962: Emperor Otto I and Pope John XII co-sign the Diploma Ottonianum, recognizing John as ruler of Rome.
February 13, 1322: The central tower of Ely Cathedral falls on the night of 12th–13th.
February 13, 1462: The Treaty of Westminster is finalised between Edward IV of England and the Scottish Lord of the Isles.
February 13, 1542: Catherine Howard, the fifth wife of Henry VIII of England, is executed for adultery.
February 13, 1633: Galileo Galilei arrives in Rome for his trial before the Inquisition.
February 13, 1660: With the accession of young Charles XI of Sweden, his regents begin negotiations to end the Second Northern War.
February 13, 1689: William and Mary are proclaimed co-rulers of England.
February 13, 1849: The delegation headed by Metropolitan bishop Andrei Șaguna hands out to the Emperor Franz Joseph I of Austria the General Petition of Romanian leaders in Transylvania, Banat and Bukovina, which demands that the Romanian nation be recognized.
February 13, 1867: Work begins on the covering of the Senne, burying Brussels's primary river and creating the modern central boulevards.
February 13, 1913: The 13th Dalai Lama proclaims Tibetan independence following a period of domination by Manchu Qing dynasty and initiated a period of almost four decades of independence.
February 13, 1920: The Negro National League is formed.
February 13, 1931: The British Raj completes its transfer from Calcutta to New Delhi.
February 13, 1935: A jury in Flemington, New Jersey finds Bruno Hauptmann guilty of the 1932 kidnapping and murder of the Lindbergh baby, the son of Charles Lindbergh.
February 13, 1954: Frank Selvy becomes the only NCAA Division I basketball player ever to score 100 points in a single game.
February 13, 1955: Israel obtains four of the seven Dead Sea Scrolls.
February 13, 1960: Black college students stage the first of the Nashville sit-ins at three lunch counters in Nashville, Tennessee.
February 13, 1961: An allegedly 500,000-year-old rock is discovered near Olancha, California, US, that appears to anachronistically encase a spark plug.
February 13, 1967: American researchers discover the Madrid Codices by Leonardo da Vinci in the National Library of Spain.
February 13, 1975: Fire at the World Trade Center in New York.
February 13, 1979: An intense windstorm strikes western Washington and sinks a 1/2-mile-long section of the Hood Canal Bridge.
February 13, 1981: A series of sewer explosions destroys more than two miles of streets in Louisville, Kentucky.
February 13, 1983: A cinema fire in Turin, Italy, kills 64 people.
February 13, 1984: Konstantin Chernenko succeeds the late Yuri Andropov as general secretary of the Communist Party of the Soviet Union.
February 13, 1996: The Nepalese Civil War is initiated in the Kingdom of Nepal by the Communist Party of Nepal (Maoist-Centre).
February 13, 2001: An earthquake measuring 7.6 on the Richter magnitude scale hits El Salvador, killing at least 944.
February 13, 2004: The Harvard–Smithsonian Center for Astrophysics announces the discovery of the universe's largest known diamond, white dwarf star BPM 37093. Astronomers named this star "Lucy" after The Beatles' song "Lucy in the Sky with Diamonds".
February 13, 2007: Taiwan opposition leader Ma Ying-jeou resigns as the chairman of the Kuomintang party after being indicted on charges of embezzlement during his tenure as the mayor of Taipei; Ma also announces his candidacy for the 2008 presidential election.
February 13, 2008: Australian Prime Minister Kevin Rudd makes a historic apology to the Indigenous Australians and the Stolen Generations.
February 13, 2010: A bomb explodes in the city of Pune, Maharashtra, India, killing 17 and injuring 60 more.
February 13, 2011: For the first time in more than 100 years the Umatilla, an American Indian tribe, are able to hunt and harvest a bison just outside Yellowstone National Park, restoring a centuries-old tradition guaranteed by a treaty signed in 1855.
February 13, 2012: The European Space Agency (ESA) conducted the first launch of the European Vega rocket from Europe's spaceport in Kourou, French Guiana.
February 13, 2017: Kim Jong-nam, brother of North Korean dictator Kim Jong-Un, is assassinated at Kuala Lumpur International Airport.
February 14, 842: Charles the Bald and Louis the German swear the Oaths of Strasbourg in the French and German languages.
February 14, 1014: Pope Benedict VIII crowns Henry of Bavaria, King of Germany and of Italy, as Holy Roman Emperor.
February 14, 1076: Pope Gregory VII excommunicates Henry IV, Holy Roman Emperor.
February 14, 1349: Several hundred Jews are burned to death by mobs while the remaining Jews are forcibly removed from Strasbourg.
February 14, 1400: Richard II of England dies, most probably from starvation, in Pontefract Castle, on the orders of Henry Bolingbroke.
February 14, 1530: Spanish conquistadores, led by Nuño de Guzmán, overthrow and execute Tangaxuan II, the last independent monarch of the Tarascan state in present-day central Mexico.
February 14, 1778: The United States flag is formally recognized by a foreign naval vessel for the first time, when French Admiral Toussaint-Guillaume Picquet de la Motte renders a nine gun salute to USS Ranger, commanded by John Paul Jones.
February 14, 1779: James Cook is killed by Native Hawaiians near Kealakekua on the Island of Hawaii.
February 14, 1804: Karađorđe leads the First Serbian Uprising against the Ottoman Empire.
February 14, 1831: Ras Marye of Yejju marches into Tigray and defeats and kills Dejazmach Sabagadis in the Battle of Debre Abbay.
February 14, 1835: The original Quorum of the Twelve Apostles, in the Latter Day Saint movement, is formed in Kirtland, Ohio.
February 14, 1849: In New York City, James Knox Polk becomes the first serving President of the United States to have his photograph taken.
February 14, 1852: Great Ormond St Hospital for Sick Children, the first hospital in England to provide in-patient beds specifically for children, is founded in London.
February 14, 1855: Texas is linked by telegraph to the rest of the United States, with the completion of a connection between New Orleans and Marshall, Texas.
February 14, 1859: Oregon is admitted as the 33rd U.S. state.
February 14, 1876: Alexander Graham Bell applies for a patent for the telephone, as does Elisha Gray.
February 14, 1879: The War of the Pacific breaks out when Chilean armed forces occupy the Bolivian port city of Antofagasta.
February 14, 1899: Voting machines are approved by the U.S. Congress for use in federal elections.
February 14, 1900: British forces begin the Battle of the Tugela Heights in an effort to lift the Siege of Ladysmith.
February 14, 1903: The United States Department of Commerce and Labor is established (later split into the Department of Commerce and the Department of Labor).
February 14, 1912: The U.S. Navy commissions its first class of diesel-powered submarines.
February 14, 1920: The League of Women Voters is founded in Chicago.
February 14, 1924: The Computing-Tabulating-Recording Company changes its name to International Business Machines Corporation (IBM).
February 14, 1942: Battle of Pasir Panjang contributes to the fall of Singapore.
February 14, 1945: President Franklin D. Roosevelt meets King Ibn Saud of Saudi Arabia aboard the USS Quincy, officially beginning U.S.-Saudi diplomatic relations.
February 14, 1946: The Bank of England is nationalized.
February 14, 1949: The Asbestos Strike begins in Canada. The strike marks the beginning of the Quiet Revolution in Quebec.
February 14, 1979: In Kabul, Setami Milli militants kidnap the American ambassador to Afghanistan, Adolph Dubs who is later killed during a gunfight between his kidnappers and police.
February 14, 1983: United American Bank of Knoxville, Tennessee collapses. Its president, Jake Butcher, is later convicted of fraud.
February 14, 1989: Iranian leader Ruhollah Khomeini issues a fatwa encouraging Muslims to kill Salman Rushdie, author of The Satanic Verses.
February 14, 1990: The Voyager 1 spacecraft takes the photograph of planet Earth that later become famous as Pale Blue Dot.
February 14, 1998: An oil tanker train collides with a freight train in Yaoundé, Cameroon, spilling fuel oil. One person scavenging the oil created a massive explosion which kills 120.
February 14, 2000: The spacecraft NEAR Shoemaker enters orbit around asteroid 433 Eros, the first spacecraft to orbit an asteroid.
February 14, 2004: In a suburb of Moscow, Russia, the roof of the Transvaal water park collapses, killing more than 25 people, and wounding more than 100 others.
February 14, 2005: YouTube is launched by a group of college students, eventually becoming the largest video sharing website in the world and a main source for viral videos.
February 14, 2011: As a part of Arab Spring, the Bahraini uprising begins with a 'Day of Rage'.
February 14, 2018: Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School shooting in the Miami metropolitan area is one of the deadliest school massacres with 17 fatalities and 15 injuries.
February 15, 590: Khosrau II is crowned king of Persia.[1]
February 15, 706: Byzantine emperor Justinian II has his predecessors Leontios and Tiberios III publicly executed in the Hippodrome of Constantinople.
February 15, 1002: At an assembly at Pavia of Lombard nobles, Arduin of Ivrea is restored to his domains and crowned King of Italy.[2]
February 15, 1113: Pope Paschal II issues Pie Postulatio Voluntatis, recognizing the Order of Hospitallers.[3]
February 15, 1214: During the Anglo-French War (1213–1214), an English invasion force led by John, King of England, lands at La Rochelle in France.[4]
February 15, 1493: While on board the Niña, Christopher Columbus writes an open letter (widely distributed upon his return to Portugal) describing his discoveries and the unexpected items he came across in the New World.[5]
February 15, 1637: Ferdinand III becomes Holy Roman Emperor.
February 15, 1690: Constantin Cantemir, Prince of Moldavia, and the Holy Roman Empire sign a secret treaty in Sibiu, stipulating that Moldavia would support the actions led by the House of Habsburg against the Ottoman Empire.
February 15, 1764: The city of St. Louis is established in Spanish Louisiana (now in Missouri, USA).
February 15, 1798: The Roman Republic is proclaimed after Louis-Alexandre Berthier, a general of Napoleon, had invaded the city of Rome five days earlier.
February 15, 1835: The first constitutional law in modern Serbia is adopted.
February 15, 1870: Stevens Institute of Technology is founded in New Jersey, USA and offers the first Bachelor of Engineering degree in Mechanical Engineering.
February 15, 1891: Allmänna Idrottsklubben (AIK) (Swedish Sports Club) is founded.
February 15, 1898: The battleship USS Maine explodes and sinks in Havana harbor in Cuba, killing 274. This event leads the United States to declare war on Spain.
February 15, 1901: The association football club Alianza Lima is founded in Lima, Peru, under the name Sport Alianza.
February 15, 1909: The Flores Theater fire in Acapulco, Mexico kills 250.
February 15, 1921: Kingdom of Romania establishes its legation in Helsinki.
February 15, 1923: Greece becomes the last European country to adopt the Gregorian calendar.
February 15, 1933: In Miami, Giuseppe Zangara attempts to assassinate US President-elect Franklin D. Roosevelt, but instead shoots Chicago mayor Anton J. Cermak, who dies of his wounds on March 6, 1933.
February 15, 1946: ENIAC, the first electronic general-purpose computer, is formally dedicated at the University of Pennsylvania in Philadelphia.
February 15, 1949: Gerald Lankester Harding and Roland de Vaux begin excavations at Cave 1 of the Qumran Caves, where they will eventually discover the first seven Dead Sea Scrolls.
February 15, 1952: King George VI of the United Kingdom is buried in St George's Chapel, Windsor Castle.
February 15, 1954: Canada and the United States agree to construct the Distant Early Warning Line, a system of radar stations in the far northern Arctic regions of Canada and Alaska.
February 15, 1961: Sabena Flight 548 crashes in Belgium, killing 73, including the entire United States figure skating team along with several of their coaches and family members.
February 15, 1965: A new red-and-white maple leaf design is adopted as the flag of Canada, replacing the old Canadian Red Ensign banner.
February 15, 1971: The decimalisation of British coinage is completed on Decimal Day.
February 15, 1972: José María Velasco Ibarra, serving as President of Ecuador for the fifth time, is overthrown by the military for the fourth time.
February 15, 1982: The drilling rig Ocean Ranger sinks during a storm off the coast of Newfoundland, killing 84 workers.
February 15, 1991: The Visegrád Agreement, establishing cooperation to move toward free-market systems, is signed by the leaders of Czechoslovakia, Hungary and Poland.
February 15, 1992: Air Transport International Flight 805 crashes near Toledo Express Airport in Ohio, killing all four people on board.[7]
February 15, 1996: At the Xichang Satellite Launch Center in China, a Long March 3 rocket, carrying an Intelsat 708, crashes into a rural village after liftoff, killing many people.
February 15, 2001: The first draft of the complete human genome is published in Nature.
February 15, 2003: Protests against the Iraq war take place in over 600 cities worldwide. It is estimated that between eight million to 30 million people participate, making this the largest peace demonstration in history.
February 15, 2010: Two trains collide in the Halle train collision in Halle, Belgium, killing 19 and injuring 171 people.
February 15, 2012: Three hundred sixty people die in a fire at a Honduran prison in the city of Comayagua.
February 15, 2013: A meteor explodes over Russia, injuring 1,500 people as a shock wave blows out windows and rocks buildings. This happens unexpectedly only hours before the expected closest ever approach of the larger and unrelated asteroid 2012 DA14.
February 16, 116: Emperor Trajan sends laureatae to the Roman Senate at Rome on account of his victories and conquest of Parthia.
February 16, 1249: Andrew of Longjumeau is dispatched by Louis IX of France as his ambassador to meet with the Khagan of the Mongol Empire.
February 16, 1270: Grand Duchy of Lithuania defeats the Livonian Order in the Battle of Karuse.
February 16, 1630: Dutch forces led by Hendrick Lonck capture Olinda in what was to become part of Dutch Brazil.
February 16, 1699: First Leopoldine Diploma is issued by the Holy Roman Emperor, recognizing the Greek Catholic clergy enjoyed the same privileges as Roman Catholic priests in the Principality of Transylvania.
February 16, 1742: Spencer Compton, Earl of Wilmington, becomes British Prime Minister.
February 16, 1796: Colombo in Ceylon (now Sri Lanka) falls to the British, completing their invasion of Ceylon.[1]
February 16, 1866: Spencer Compton Cavendish, Marquess of Hartington becomes British Secretary of State for War.
February 16, 1881: The Canadian Pacific Railway is incorporated by Act of Parliament at Ottawa (44th Vic., c.1).
February 16, 1899: Iceland's first football club, Knattspyrnufélag Reykjavíkur, is founded.
February 16, 1918: The Council of Lithuania unanimously adopts the Act of Independence, declaring Lithuania an independent state.
February 16, 1923: Howard Carter unseals the burial chamber of Pharaoh Tutankhamun.
February 16, 1930: The Romanian Football Federation joins FIFA.
February 16, 1934: The Austrian Civil War ends with the defeat of the Social Democrats and the Republikanischer Schutzbund.
February 16, 1936: Elections bring the Popular Front to power in Spain.
February 16, 1937: Wallace H. Carothers receives a United States patent for nylon.
February 16, 1959: Fidel Castro becomes Premier of Cuba after dictator Fulgencio Batista was overthrown on January 1.
February 16, 1960: The U.S. Navy submarine USS Triton begins Operation Sandblast, setting sail from New London, Connecticut, to begin the first submerged circumnavigation of the globe.
February 16, 1962: Flooding in the coastal areas of West Germany kills 315 and destroys the homes of about 60,000 people.
February 16, 1968: In Haleyville, Alabama, the first 9-1-1 emergency telephone system goes into service.
February 16, 1978: The first computer bulletin board system is created (CBBS in Chicago).
February 16, 1983: The Ash Wednesday bushfires in Victoria and South Australia kill 75.
February 16, 1986: The Soviet liner MS Mikhail Lermontov runs aground in the Marlborough Sounds, New Zealand.
February 16, 1991: Nicaraguan Contras leader Enrique Bermúdez is assassinated in Managua.
February 16, 1996: A Chicago-bound Amtrak train, the Capitol Limited, collides with a MARC commuter train bound for Washington, D.C., killing 11 people.
February 16, 1998: China Airlines Flight 676 crashes into a road and residential area near Chiang Kai-shek International Airport in Taiwan, killing all 196 aboard and seven more on the ground.
February 16, 2005: The National Hockey League cancels the entire 2004–05 regular season and playoffs.
February 16, 2006: The last Mobile army surgical hospital (MASH) is decommissioned by the United States Army.
February 16, 2013: A bomb blast at a market in Hazara Town, Quetta, Pakistan kills more than 80 people and injures 190 others.
February 17, 364: Roman Emperor Jovian dies after a reign of eight months. He is found dead in his tent at Tyana (Asia Minor) en route back to Constantinople in suspicious circumstances.
February 17, 1411: Following the successful campaigns during the Ottoman Interregnum, Musa Çelebi, one of the sons of Bayezid I, becomes Sultan with the support of Mircea I of Wallachia.
February 17, 1500: Duke Friedrich and Duke Johann attempt to subdue the peasantry of Dithmarschen, Denmark, in the Battle of Hemmingstedt.
February 17, 1600: The philosopher Giordano Bruno is burned alive, for heresy, at Campo de' Fiori in Rome.
February 17, 1621: Myles Standish is appointed as first military commander of the English Plymouth Colony in North America.
February 17, 1739: The Battle of Vasai commences as the Marathas move to invade Portuguese-occupied territory.
February 17, 1753: In Sweden February 17 is followed by March 1 as the country moves from the Julian calendar to the Gregorian calendar.
February 17, 1801: An electoral tie between Thomas Jefferson and Aaron Burr is resolved when Jefferson is elected President of the United States and Burr, Vice President by the United States House of Representatives.
February 17, 1819: The United States House of Representatives passes the Missouri Compromise for the first time.
February 17, 1854: The United Kingdom recognizes the independence of the Orange Free State.
February 17, 1863: A group of citizens of Geneva founded an International Committee for Relief to the Wounded, which later became known as the International Committee of the Red Cross.
February 17, 1867: The first ship passes through the Suez Canal.
February 17, 1871: The victorious Prussian Army parades through Paris, France, after the end of the Siege of Paris during the Franco-Prussian War.
February 17, 1904: Madama Butterfly receives its première at La Scala in Milan.
February 17, 1913: The Armory Show opens in New York City, displaying works of artists who are to become some of the most influential painters of the early 20th century.
February 17, 1919: The Ukrainian People's Republic asks Entente and the US for help fighting the Bolsheviks.
February 17, 1949: Chaim Weizmann begins his term as the first President of Israel.
February 17, 1964: Gabonese president Léon M'ba is toppled by a coup and his rival, Jean-Hilaire Aubame, is installed in his place.
February 17, 1968: In Springfield, Massachusetts, the Naismith Memorial Basketball Hall of Fame opens.
February 17, 1972: Cumulative sales of the Volkswagen Beetle exceed those of the Ford Model T.
February 17, 1974: Robert K. Preston, a disgruntled U.S. Army private, buzzes the White House in a stolen helicopter.
February 17, 1980: First winter ascent of Mount Everest by Krzysztof Wielicki and Leszek Cichy.
February 17, 1995: The Cenepa War between Peru and Ecuador ends on a ceasefire brokered by the UN.
February 17, 1996: The 8.2 Mw  Biak earthquake shakes the Papua province of eastern Indonesia with a maximum Mercalli intensity of VIII (Severe). A large tsunami followed, leaving one-hundred sixty-six people dead or missing and 423 injured.
February 17, 2006: A massive mudslide occurs in Southern Leyte, Philippines; the official death toll is set at 1,126.
February 17, 2015: Eighteen people are killed and 78 injured in a stampede at a Mardi Gras parade in Haiti.
February 17, 2016: Military vehicles explode outside a Turkish Armed Forces barracks in Ankara, Turkey, killing at least 29 people and injuring 61 others.
February 18, 1268: Battle of Wesenberg between the Livonian Order and Dovmont of Pskov.
February 18, 1332: Amda Seyon I, Emperor of Ethiopia begins his campaigns in the southern Muslim provinces.
February 18, 1478: George, Duke of Clarence, convicted of treason against his older brother Edward IV of England, is executed in private at the Tower of London.
February 18, 1791: Congress passes a law admitting the state of Vermont to the Union, effective 4 March, after that state had existed for 14 years as a de facto independent largely unrecognized state.
February 18, 1861: With Italian unification almost complete, Victor Emmanuel II of Piedmont, Savoy and Sardinia assumes the title of King of Italy.
February 18, 1873: Bulgarian revolutionary leader Vasil Levski is executed by hanging in Sofia by the Ottoman authorities.
February 18, 1878: John Tunstall is murdered by outlaw Jesse Evans, sparking the Lincoln County War in Lincoln County, New Mexico.
February 18, 1885: Adventures of Huckleberry Finn by Mark Twain is published in the United States.
February 18, 1906: Édouard de Laveleye forms the Belgian Olympic Committee in Brussels.
February 18, 1911: The first official flight with airmail takes place from Allahabad, United Provinces, British India (now India), when Henri Pequet, a 23-year-old pilot, delivers 6,500 letters to Naini, about 10 kilometres (6.2 mi) away.
February 18, 1930: Elm Farm Ollie becomes the first cow to fly in a fixed-wing aircraft and also the first cow to be milked in an aircraft.
February 18, 1932: The Empire of Japan declares a puppet state of Manzhouguo (the obsolete Chinese name for Manchuria) independent from the Republic of China and installed former Chinese Emperor Aisin Gioro Puyi as Chief Executive of the State.
February 18, 1946: Sailors of the Royal Indian Navy mutiny in Bombay harbour, from where the action spreads throughout the Provinces of British India, involving 78 ships, twenty shore establishments and 20,000 sailors
February 18, 1954: The first Church of Scientology is established in Los Angeles.
February 18, 1957: Walter James Bolton becomes the last person legally executed in New Zealand.
February 18, 1965: The Gambia becomes independent from the United Kingdom.
February 18, 1970: The Chicago Seven are found not guilty of conspiring to incite riots at the 1968 Democratic National Convention.
February 18, 1972: The California Supreme Court in the case of People v. Anderson, (6 Cal.3d 628) invalidates the state's death penalty and commutes the sentences of all death row inmates to life imprisonment.
February 18, 1977: The Space Shuttle Enterprise test vehicle is carried on its maiden "flight" on top of a Boeing 747.
February 18, 1979: Richard Petty wins a then-record sixth Daytona 500 after leaders Donnie Allison and Cale Yarborough crash on the final lap of the first NASCAR race televised live flag-to-flag.
February 18, 1983: Thirteen people die and one is seriously injured in the Wah Mee massacre in Seattle. It is said to be the largest robbery-motivated mass-murder in U.S. history.
February 18, 1991: The IRA explodes bombs in the early morning at Paddington station and Victoria station in London.
February 18, 2001: FBI agent Robert Hanssen is arrested for spying for the Soviet Union. He is ultimately convicted and sentenced to life imprisonment.
February 18, 2003: Nearly 200 people die in the Daegu subway fire in South Korea.
February 18, 2004: Up to 295 people, including nearly 200 rescue workers, die near Nishapur, Iran when a runaway freight train carrying sulfur, petrol and fertilizer catches fire and explodes.
February 18, 2007: Samjhauta Express bombings occurred around midnight in Diwana near the Indian city of Panipat, 80 kilometres (50 mi) north of New Delhi, India.
February 18, 2010: WikiLeaks publishes the first of hundreds of thousands of classified documents disclosed by the soldier now known as Chelsea Manning.
February 18, 2013: Armed robbers steal a haul of diamonds worth $50 million during a raid at Brussels Airport in Belgium.
February 18, 2014: At least 76 people are killed and hundreds are injured in clashes between riot police and demonstrators in Kiev, Ukraine.
February 19, 197: Emperor Septimius Severus defeats usurper Clodius Albinus in the Battle of Lugdunum, the bloodiest battle between Roman armies.
February 19, 356: Emperor Constantius II issues a decree closing all pagan temples in the Roman Empire.
February 19, 1594: Having already been elected to the throne of the Polish–Lithuanian Commonwealth  in 1587, Sigismund III of the House of Vasa is crowned King of Sweden, having succeeded his father John III of Sweden in 1592.
February 19, 1600: The Peruvian stratovolcano Huaynaputina explodes in the most violent eruption in the recorded history of South America.
February 19, 1649: The Second Battle of Guararapes takes place, effectively ending Dutch colonization efforts in Brazil.
February 19, 1674: England and the Netherlands sign the Treaty of Westminster, ending the Third Anglo-Dutch War. A provision of the agreement transfers the Dutch colony of New Amsterdam to England, and it is renamed New York.
February 19, 1726: The Supreme Privy Council is established in Russia.
February 19, 1807: Former Vice President of the United States Aaron Burr is arrested for treason in Wakefield, Alabama and confined to Fort Stoddert.
February 19, 1819: British explorer William Smith discovers the South Shetland Islands and claims them in the name of King George III.
February 19, 1846: In Austin, Texas the newly formed Texas state government is officially installed. The Republic of Texas government officially transfers power to the State of Texas government following the annexation of Texas by the United States.
February 19, 1847: The first group of rescuers reaches the Donner Party.
February 19, 1859: Daniel E. Sickles, a New York Congressman, is acquitted of murder on grounds of temporary insanity.
February 19, 1884: More than sixty tornadoes strike the Southern United States, one of the largest tornado outbreaks in U.S. history.
February 19, 1913: Pedro Lascuráin becomes President of Mexico for 45 minutes; this is the shortest term to date of any person as president of any country.
February 19, 1948: The Conference of Youth and Students of Southeast Asia Fighting for Freedom and Independence convenes in Calcutta.
February 19, 1949: Ezra Pound is awarded the first Bollingen Prize in poetry by the Bollingen Foundation and Yale University.
February 19, 1959: The United Kingdom grants Cyprus independence, which is formally proclaimed on August 16, 1960.
February 19, 1960: China successfully launches the T-7, its first sounding rocket.
February 19, 1963: The publication of Betty Friedan's The Feminine Mystique reawakens the feminist movement in the United States as women's organizations and consciousness raising groups spread.
February 19, 1965: Colonel Phạm Ngọc Thảo of the Army of the Republic of Vietnam, and a communist spy of the North Vietnamese Viet Minh, along with Generals Lâm Văn Phát and Trần Thiện Khiêm, all Catholics, attempt a coup against the military junta of the Buddhist Nguyễn Khánh.
February 19, 1976: Executive Order 9066, which led to the relocation of Japanese Americans to internment camps, is rescinded by President Gerald Ford's Proclamation 4417.
February 19, 1978: Egyptian forces raid Larnaca International Airport in an attempt to intervene in a hijacking, without authorisation from the Republic of Cyprus authorities. The Cypriot National Guard and Police forces kill 15 Egyptian commandos and destroy the Egyptian C-130 transport plane in open combat.
February 19, 1985: Iberia Airlines Boeing 727 crashes into Mount Oiz in Spain, killing 148.
February 19, 2002: NASA's Mars Odyssey space probe begins to map the surface of Mars using its thermal emission imaging system.
February 19, 2003: An Ilyushin Il-76 military aircraft crashes near Kerman, Iran, killing 275.
February 19, 2006: A methane explosion in a coal mine near Nueva Rosita, Mexico, kills 65 miners.
February 19, 2011: The debut exhibition of the Belitung shipwreck, containing the largest collection of Tang dynasty artifacts found in one location, begins in Singapore.
February 19, 2012: Forty-four people are killed in a prison brawl in Apodaca, Nuevo León, Mexico.
February 20, 1339: The Milanese army and the St. George's (San Giorgio) Mercenaries of Lodrisio Visconti clash in the Battle of Parabiago; Visconti is defeated.[1]
February 20, 1472: Orkney and Shetland are pawned by Norway to Scotland in lieu of a dowry for Margaret of Denmark.[2]
February 20, 1547: Edward VI of England is crowned King of England at Westminster Abbey.[3]
February 20, 1685: René-Robert Cavelier establishes Fort St. Louis at Matagorda Bay thus forming the basis for France's claim to Texas.
February 20, 1792: The Postal Service Act, establishing the United States Post Office Department, is signed by United States President George Washington.
February 20, 1798: Louis-Alexandre Berthier removes Pope Pius VI from power.
February 20, 1813: Manuel Belgrano defeats the royalist army of Pío de Tristán during the Battle of Salta.
February 20, 1816: Rossini's opera The Barber of Seville premieres at the Teatro Argentina in Rome.
February 20, 1835: The 1835 Concepción earthquake destroys Concepción, Chile.
February 20, 1846: Polish insurgents lead an uprising in Kraków to incite a fight for national independence.
February 20, 1865: End of the Uruguayan War, with a peace agreement between President Tomás Villalba and rebel leader Venancio Flores, setting the scene for the destructive War of the Triple Alliance.
February 20, 1872: The Metropolitan Museum of Art opens in New York City.
February 20, 1877: Tchaikovsky's ballet Swan Lake receives its premiere at the Bolshoi Theatre in Moscow.
February 20, 1901: The legislature of Hawaii Territory convenes for the first time.
February 20, 1909: Publication of the Futurist Manifesto in the French journal Le Figaro.
February 20, 1913: King O'Malley drives in the first survey peg to mark commencement of work on the construction of Canberra.
February 20, 1920: An earthquake kills between 114 and 130 in Georgia and heavily damages the town of Gori.
February 20, 1931: The U.S. Congress approves the construction of the San Francisco–Oakland Bay Bridge by the state of California.
February 20, 1933: Adolf Hitler secretly meets with German industrialists to arrange for financing of the Nazi Party's upcoming election campaign.
February 20, 1935: Caroline Mikkelsen becomes the first woman to set foot in Antarctica.
February 20, 1942: Lieutenant Edward O'Hare becomes America's first World War II flying ace.
February 20, 1943: The Saturday Evening Post publishes the first of Norman Rockwell's Four Freedoms in support of United States President Franklin Roosevelt's 1941 State of the Union address theme of Four Freedoms.
February 20, 1952: Emmett Ashford becomes the first African-American umpire in organized baseball by being authorized to be a substitute umpire in the Southwestern International League.
February 20, 1956: The United States Merchant Marine Academy becomes a permanent Service Academy.
February 20, 1959: The Avro Arrow program to design and manufacture supersonic jet fighters in Canada is cancelled by the Diefenbaker government amid much political debate.
February 20, 1965: Ranger 8 crashes into the Moon after a successful mission of photographing possible landing sites for  the Apollo program astronauts.
February 20, 1971: The United States Emergency Broadcast System is accidentally activated in an erroneous national alert.
February 20, 1979: An earthquake cracks open the Sinila volcanic crater on the Dieng Plateau, releasing poisonous H2S gas and killing 149 villagers in the Indonesian province of Central Java.
February 20, 1986: The Soviet Union launches its Mir spacecraft. Remaining in orbit for 15 years, it is occupied for ten of those years.
February 20, 1988: The Nagorno-Karabakh Autonomous Oblast votes to secede from Azerbaijan and join Armenia, triggering the Nagorno-Karabakh War.
February 20, 1991: In the Albanian capital Tirana, a gigantic statue of Albania's long-time leader, Enver Hoxha, is brought down by mobs of angry protesters.
February 20, 1998: American figure skater Tara Lipinski becomes the youngest gold-medalist at the 1998 Winter Olympics in Nagano, Japan.
February 20, 2003: During a Great White concert in West Warwick, Rhode Island, a pyrotechnics display sets the Station nightclub ablaze, killing 100 and injuring over 200 others.
February 20, 2005: Spain becomes the first country to vote in a referendum on ratification of the proposed Constitution of the European Union, passing it by a substantial margin, but on a low turnout.
February 20, 2009: Two Tamil Tigers aircraft packed with C4 explosives en route to the national airforce headquarters are shot down by the Sri Lankan military before reaching their target, in a kamikaze style attack.
February 20, 2010: In Madeira Island, Portugal, heavy rain causes floods and mudslides, resulting in at least 43 deaths, in the worst disaster in the history of the archipelago.
February 20, 2014: Dozens of Euromaidan anti-government protesters died in Ukraine's capital Kiev, many reportedly killed by snipers.
February 20, 2015: Two trains collide in the Swiss town of Rafz resulting in as many as 49 people injured and Swiss Federal Railways cancelling some services.
February 20, 2016: Six people are killed and two injured in multiple shooting incidents in Kalamazoo County, Michigan.
February 21, 1245: Thomas, the first known Bishop of Finland, is granted resignation after confessing to torture and forgery.
February 21, 1613: Mikhail I is unanimously elected Tsar by a national assembly, beginning the Romanov dynasty of Imperial Russia.
February 21, 1797: A force of 1,400 French soldiers invaded Britain at Fishguard in support of the Society of United Irishmen. They were defeated by 500 British reservists.
February 21, 1804: The first self-propelling steam locomotive makes its outing at the Pen-y-Darren Ironworks in Wales.
February 21, 1808: Without a previous declaration of war, Russian troops cross the border to Sweden at Abborfors in eastern Finland, thus beginning the Finnish War, in which Sweden will lose the eastern half of the country (i.e. Finland) to Russia.
February 21, 1828: Initial issue of the Cherokee Phoenix is the first periodical to use the Cherokee syllabary invented by Sequoyah.
February 21, 1842: John Greenough is granted the first U.S. patent for the sewing machine.
February 21, 1848: Karl Marx and Friedrich Engels publish The Communist Manifesto.
February 21, 1866: Lucy Hobbs Taylor becomes the first American woman to graduate from dental school.
February 21, 1874: The Oakland Daily Tribune publishes its first edition.
February 21, 1878: The first telephone directory is issued in New Haven, Connecticut.
February 21, 1885: The newly completed Washington Monument is dedicated.
February 21, 1896: An Englishman raised in Australia, Bob Fitzsimmons, fought an Irishman, Peter Maher, in an American promoted event which technically took place in Mexico, winning the 1896 World Heavyweight Championship in boxing.
February 21, 1913: Ioannina is incorporated into the Greek state after the Balkan Wars.
February 21, 1918: The last Carolina parakeet dies in captivity at the Cincinnati Zoo.
February 21, 1919: German socialist Kurt Eisner is assassinated. His death results in the establishment of the Bavarian Soviet Republic and parliament and government fleeing Munich, Germany.
February 21, 1921: Rezā Shāh takes control of Tehran during a successful coup.
February 21, 1925: The New Yorker publishes its first issue.
February 21, 1929: In the first battle of the Warlord Rebellion in northeastern Shandong against the Nationalist government of China, a 24,000-strong rebel force led by Zhang Zongchang was defeated at Zhifu by 7,000 NRA troops.[1]
February 21, 1937: The League of Nations bans foreign national "volunteers" in the Spanish Civil War.
February 21, 1947: In New York City, Edwin Land demonstrates the first "instant camera", the Polaroid Land Camera, to a meeting of the Optical Society of America.
February 21, 1952: The Bengali Language Movement protests occur at the University of Dhaka in East Pakistan (now Bangladesh).
February 21, 1958: The CND symbol, aka peace symbol, commissioned by the Direct Action Committee in protest against the Atomic Weapons Research Establishment, is designed and completed by Gerald Holtom.
February 21, 1971: The Convention on Psychotropic Substances is signed at Vienna.
February 21, 1972: The Soviet unmanned spaceship Luna 20 lands on the Moon.
February 21, 1973: Over the Sinai Desert, Israeli fighter aircraft shoot down Libyan Arab Airlines Flight 114 jet killing 108 people.
February 21, 1974: The last Israeli soldiers leave the west bank of the Suez Canal pursuant to a truce with Egypt.
February 21, 1995: Steve Fossett lands in Leader, Saskatchewan, Canada becoming the first person to make a solo flight across the Pacific Ocean in a balloon.
February 21, 2013: At least 17 people are killed and 119 injured following several bombings in the Indian city of Hyderabad.
February 22, 705: Empress Wu Zetian abdicates the throne, restoring the Tang dynasty.
February 22, 1316: Battle of Picotin between Ferdinand of Majorca and the forces of Matilda of Hainaut.
February 22, 1371: Robert II becomes King of Scotland, beginning the Stuart dynasty.
February 22, 1495: King Charles VIII of France enters Naples to claim the city's throne.
February 22, 1632: Galileo's Dialogue Concerning the Two Chief World Systems is published.
February 22, 1797: The last Invasion of Britain begins near Fishguard, Wales.
February 22, 1819: By the Adams–Onís Treaty, Spain sells Florida to the United States for five million U.S. dollars.
February 22, 1848: The French Revolution of 1848, which would lead to the establishment of the French Second Republic, begins.
February 22, 1853: Washington University in St. Louis is founded as Eliot Seminary in St. Louis, Missouri.
February 22, 1855: The Pennsylvania State University is founded in State College, Pennsylvania (as the Farmers' High School of Pennsylvania).
February 22, 1856: The United States Republican Party opens its first national convention in Pittsburgh.
February 22, 1862: Jefferson Davis is officially inaugurated for a six-year term as the President of the Confederate States of America in Richmond, Virginia. He was previously inaugurated as a provisional president on February 18, 1861.
February 22, 1872: The Prohibition Party holds its first national convention in Columbus, Ohio, nominating James Black as its presidential nominee.
February 22, 1878: In Utica, New York, Frank Woolworth opens the first of many of five-and-dime Woolworth stores.
February 22, 1889: President Grover Cleveland signs a bill admitting North Dakota, South Dakota, Montana and Washington as U.S. states.
February 22, 1899: Filipino forces led by General Antonio Luna launch counterattacks for the first time against the American forces during the Philippine–American War. The Filipinos fail to regain Manila from the Americans.
February 22, 1904: The United Kingdom sells a meteorological station on the South Orkney Islands to Argentina; the islands are subsequently claimed by the United Kingdom in 1908.
February 22, 1909: The sixteen battleships of the Great White Fleet, led by USS Connecticut, return to the United States after a voyage around the world.
February 22, 1921: After Russian forces under Baron Roman von Ungern-Sternberg drive the Chinese out, the Bogd Khan is reinstalled as the emperor of Mongolia.
February 22, 1924: U.S. President Calvin Coolidge becomes the first President to deliver a radio address from the White House.
February 22, 1946: The "Long Telegram", proposing how the United States should deal with the Soviet Union, arrives from the US embassy in Moscow.[1]
February 22, 1957: Ngô Đình Diệm of South Vietnam survives a communist shooting assassination attempt in Buôn Ma Thuột.
February 22, 1958: Egypt and Syria join to form the United Arab Republic.
February 22, 1959: Lee Petty wins the first Daytona 500.
February 22, 1972: The Official Irish Republican Army detonates a car bomb at Aldershot barracks, killing seven and injuring nineteen others.
February 22, 1974: Samuel Byck attempts to hijack an aircraft at Baltimore/Washington International Airport with the intention of crashing it into the White House to assassinate Richard Nixon, but is killed by police.[2]
February 22, 1983: The notorious Broadway flop Moose Murders opens and closes on the same night at the Eugene O'Neill Theatre.
February 22, 1984: President of Bangladesh, H M Ershad upgraded South Sylhet's sub-division status to a district and renamed it back to Moulvibazar.[3]
February 22, 1986: Start of the People Power Revolution in the Philippines.
February 22, 1994: Aldrich Ames and his wife are charged by the United States Department of Justice with spying for the Soviet Union.
February 22, 1995: The Corona reconnaissance satellite program, in existence from 1959 to 1972, is declassified.
February 22, 1997: In Roslin, Midlothian, British scientists announce that an adult sheep named Dolly has been successfully cloned.
February 22, 2002: Angolan political and rebel leader Jonas Savimbi is killed in a military ambush.
February 22, 2005: The 6.4 Mw  Zarand earthquake shakes the Kerman Province of Iran with a maximum Mercalli intensity of VIII (Severe), leaving 612 people dead and 1,411 injured.
February 22, 2006: At least six men stage Britain's biggest robbery, stealing £53m (about $92.5 million or €78 million) from a Securitas depot in Tonbridge, Kent.
February 22, 2011: New Zealand's second deadliest earthquake strikes Christchurch, killing 185 people.
February 22, 2012: A train crash in Buenos Aires, Argentina, kills 51 people and injures 700 others.
February 22, 2014: President Viktor Yanukovych of Ukraine is impeached by the Verkhovna Rada of Ukraine by a vote of 328–0, fulfilling a major goal of the Euromaidan rebellion.
February 22, 2015: A ferry carrying 100 passengers capsizes in the Padma River, killing 70 people.
February 22, 2018: A man throws a grenade at the U.S embassy in Podgorica, Montenegro. He dies at the scene from a second explosion, with no one else hurt.
February 23, 303: Roman emperor Diocletian orders the destruction of the Christian church in Nicomedia, beginning eight years of Diocletianic Persecution.[1]
February 23, 532: Byzantine emperor Justinian I orders the building of a new Orthodox Christian basilica in Constantinople – the Hagia Sophia.
February 23, 1455: Traditional date for the publication of the Gutenberg Bible, the first Western book printed with movable type.
February 23, 1554: Mapuche forces, under the leadership of Lautaro, score a victory over the Spanish at the Battle of Marihueñu in Chile.
February 23, 1739: At York Castle, the outlaw Dick Turpin is identified by his former schoolteacher. Turpin had been using the name Richard Palmer.
February 23, 1854: The official independence of the Orange Free State is declared.
February 23, 1861: President-elect Abraham Lincoln arrives secretly in Washington, D.C., after the thwarting of an alleged assassination plot in Baltimore, Maryland.
February 23, 1883: Alabama becomes the first U.S. state to enact an anti-trust law.
February 23, 1886: Charles Martin Hall produced the first samples of aluminium from the electrolysis of aluminium oxide, after several years of intensive work. He was assisted in this project by his older sister, Julia Brainerd Hall.[2]
February 23, 1887: The French Riviera is hit by a large earthquake, killing around 2,000.
February 23, 1898: Émile Zola is imprisoned in France after writing J'Accuse…!, a letter accusing the French government of antisemitism and wrongfully imprisoning Captain Alfred Dreyfus.
February 23, 1903: Cuba leases Guantánamo Bay to the United States "in perpetuity".
February 23, 1905: Chicago attorney Paul Harris and three other businessmen meet for lunch to form the Rotary Club, the world's first service club.
February 23, 1909: The AEA Silver Dart makes the first powered flight in Canada and the British Empire.
February 23, 1917: First demonstrations in Saint Petersburg, Russia. The beginning of the February Revolution (March 8 in the Gregorian calendar).
February 23, 1927: German theoretical physicist Werner Heisenberg writes a letter to fellow physicist Wolfgang Pauli, in which he describes his uncertainty principle for the first time.
February 23, 1934: Leopold III becomes King of Belgium.
February 23, 1941: Plutonium is first produced and isolated by Dr. Glenn T. Seaborg.
February 23, 1943: A fire breaks out at Saint Joseph's Orphanage, County Cavan, Ireland, killing 35 children and one adult.
February 23, 1944: The Soviet Union begins the forced deportation of the Chechen and Ingush people from the North Caucasus to Central Asia.
February 23, 1947: International Organization for Standardization is founded.
February 23, 1954: The first mass inoculation of children against polio with the Salk vaccine begins in Pittsburgh.
February 23, 1966: In Syria, Ba'ath Party member Salah Jadid leads an intra-party military coup that replaces the previous government of General Amin al-Hafiz, also a Baathist.
February 23, 1974: The Symbionese Liberation Army demands $4 million more to release kidnap victim Patty Hearst.
February 23, 1981: In Spain, Antonio Tejero attempts a coup d'état by capturing the Spanish Congress of Deputies.
February 23, 1983: The United States Environmental Protection Agency announces its intent to buy out and evacuate the dioxin-contaminated community of Times Beach, Missouri.
February 23, 1987: Supernova 1987a is seen in the Large Magellanic Cloud.
February 23, 1991: In Thailand, General Sunthorn Kongsompong leads a bloodless coup d'état, deposing Prime Minister Chatichai Choonhavan.
February 23, 1998: In the United States, tornadoes in central Florida destroy or damage 2,600 structures and kill 42 people.
February 23, 1999: Kurdish rebel leader Abdullah Öcalan is charged with treason in Ankara, Turkey.
February 23, 2007: A train derails on an evening express service near Grayrigg, Cumbria, England, killing one person and injuring 88. This results in hundreds of points being checked over the UK after a few similar accidents.
February 23, 2008: A United States Air Force B-2 Spirit bomber crashes on Guam, marking  the first operational loss of a B-2.
February 23, 2010: Unknown criminals pour more than 2​1⁄2 million liters of diesel oil and other hydrocarbons into the river Lambro, in northern Italy, sparking an environmental disaster.
February 23, 2012: A series of attacks across Iraq leave at least 83 killed and more than 250 injured.
February 23, 2017: The Turkish-backed Free Syrian Army captures Al-Bab from ISIL.
February 23, 2019: Atlas Air Flight 3591 crashes into Trinity Bay near Anahuac, Texas, killing all three people on board.[3]
February 24, 484: King Huneric removes the Christian bishops from their offices and banished some to Corsica. A few are martyred, including former proconsul Victorian along with Frumentius and other merchants. They are killed at Hadrumetum after refusing to become Arians.
February 24, 1209: Foundation of the Order of Friars Minor by St. Francis of Assisi.
February 24, 1303: Battle of Roslin, of the First War of Scottish Independence.
February 24, 1386: King Charles III of Naples and Hungary is assassinated at Buda.
February 24, 1525: A Spanish-Austrian army defeats a French army at the Battle of Pavia.
February 24, 1538: Treaty of Nagyvárad between Ferdinand I and John Zápolya.
February 24, 1582: With the papal bull Inter gravissimas, Pope Gregory XIII announces the Gregorian calendar.
February 24, 1607: L'Orfeo by Claudio Monteverdi, one of the first works recognized as an opera, receives its première performance.
