February 24, 1711: The London première of Rinaldo by George Frideric Handel, the first Italian opera written for the London stage.
February 24, 1803: In Marbury v. Madison, the Supreme Court of the United States establishes the principle of judicial review.
February 24, 1809: London's Drury Lane Theatre burns to the ground, leaving owner Richard Brinsley Sheridan destitute.
February 24, 1821: Final stage of the Mexican War of Independence from Spain with Plan of Iguala.
February 24, 1822: The first Swaminarayan temple in the world, Shri Swaminarayan Mandir, Ahmedabad, is inaugurated.
February 24, 1826: The signing of the Treaty of Yandabo marks the end of the First Anglo-Burmese War.
February 24, 1831: The Treaty of Dancing Rabbit Creek, the first removal treaty in accordance with the Indian Removal Act, is proclaimed. The Choctaws in Mississippi cede land east of the river in exchange for payment and land in the West.
February 24, 1848: King Louis-Philippe of France abdicates the throne.
February 24, 1854: A Penny Red with perforations was the first perforated postage stamp to be officially issued for distribution.
February 24, 1863: Arizona is organized as a United States territory.
February 24, 1868: Andrew Johnson becomes the first President of the United States to be impeached by the United States House of Representatives. He is later acquitted in the Senate.
February 24, 1875: The SS Gothenburg hits the Great Barrier Reef and sinks off the Australian east coast, killing approximately 100, including a number of high-profile civil servants and dignitaries.
February 24, 1881: China and Russia sign the Sino-Russian Ili Treaty.
February 24, 1895: Revolution breaks out in Baire, a town near Santiago de Cuba, beginning the Cuban War of Independence, that ends with the Spanish–American War in 1898.
February 24, 1916: The Governor-General of Korea establishes a clinic called Jahyewon in Sorokdo to segregate Hansen's disease patients.
February 24, 1920: Nancy Astor became the first woman to speak in the House of Commons of the United Kingdom following her election as a Member of Parliament (MP) three months earlier.
February 24, 1942: An order-in-council passed under the Defence of Canada Regulations of the War Measures Act gives the Canadian federal government the power to intern all "persons of Japanese racial origin".
February 24, 1945: Egyptian Premier Ahmad Mahir Pasha is killed in Parliament after reading a decree.
February 24, 1946: Colonel Juan Perón, founder of the political movement that became known as Peronism, is elected to his first term as President of Argentina.
February 24, 1949: The Armistice Agreements are signed, to formally end the hostilities of the 1948 Arab-Israeli War.[3]
February 24, 1971: The All India Forward Bloc holds an emergency central committee meeting after its chairman, Hemantha Kumar Bose, is killed three days earlier. P.K. Mookiah Thevar is appointed as the new chairman.
February 24, 1976: The current constitution of Cuba is formally proclaimed.
February 24, 1980: The United States Olympic hockey team completes its Miracle on Ice by defeating Finland 4–2 to win the gold medal.
February 24, 1981: The 6.7 Ms Gulf of Corinth earthquake affected Central Greece with a maximum Mercalli intensity of VIII (Severe). Twenty-two people were killed, 400 were injured, and damage totaled $812 million.
February 24, 1983: A special commission of the United States Congress condemns the Japanese American internment during World War II.
February 24, 1984: Tyrone Mitchell perpetrates the 49th Street Elementary School shooting in Los Angeles, killing two children and injuring 12 more.
February 24, 1989: United Airlines Flight 811, bound for New Zealand from Honolulu, rips open during flight, blowing nine passengers out of the business-class section.
February 24, 1996: Two civilian airplanes operated by the Miami-based group Brothers to the Rescue are shot down in international waters by the Cuban Air Force.
February 24, 2004: The 6.3 Mw Al Hoceima earthquake strikes northern Morocco with a maximum Mercalli intensity of IX (Violent). At least 628 people are killed, 926 are injured, and up to 15,000 are displaced.
February 24, 2006: Philippine President Gloria Macapagal Arroyo declares Proclamation 1017 placing the country in a state of emergency in attempt to subdue a possible military coup.
February 24, 2007: Japan launches its fourth spy satellite, stepping up its ability to monitor potential threats such as North Korea.
February 24, 2008: Fidel Castro retires as the President of Cuba and the Council of Ministers after 32 years. He remains as head of the Communist Party for another three years.
February 24, 2015: A Metrolink train derails in Oxnard, California following a collision with a truck, leaving more than 30 injured.
February 24, 2016: Tara Air Flight 193, a de Havilland Canada DHC-6 Twin Otter aircraft, crashed, with 23 fatalities, in Solighopte, Myagdi District, Dhaulagiri Zone, while en route from Pokhara Airport to Jomsom Airport.
February 25, 138: The Roman emperor Hadrian adopts Antoninus Pius, effectively making him his successor.[1]
February 25, 628: Khosrow II, the last great king of the Sasanian Empire, is overthrown by his son Kavadh II.
February 25, 1336: Four thousand defenders of Pilėnai commit mass suicide rather than be taken captive by the Teutonic Knights.
February 25, 1797: Colonel William Tate and his force of 1000–1500 soldiers surrender after the Last invasion of Britain.
February 25, 1831: Battle of Olszynka Grochowska, part of Polish November Uprising against Russian Empire.
February 25, 1836: Samuel Colt is granted a United States patent for the Colt revolver.
February 25, 1843: Lord George Paulet occupies the Kingdom of Hawaii in the name of Great Britain in the Paulet Affair (1843).
February 25, 1848: Provisional government in revolutionary France, by Louis Blanc's motion, guarantees workers' rights.
February 25, 1856: A Peace conference opens in Paris after the Crimean War.
February 25, 1866: Miners in Calaveras County, California, discover what is now called the Calaveras Skull – human remains that supposedly indicated that man, mastodons, and elephants had co-existed.
February 25, 1870: Hiram Rhodes Revels, a Republican from Mississippi, is sworn into the United States Senate, becoming the first African American ever to sit in the U.S. Congress.
February 25, 1875: Guangxu Emperor of Qing dynasty China begins his reign, under Empress Dowager Cixi's regency.
February 25, 1901: J. P. Morgan incorporates the United States Steel Corporation.
February 25, 1912: Marie-Adélaïde, the eldest of six daughters of Guillaume IV, becomes the first reigning Grand Duchess of Luxembourg.
February 25, 1919: Oregon places a one cent per U.S. gallon tax on gasoline, becoming the first U.S. state to levy a gasoline tax.
February 25, 1921: Tbilisi, capital of the Democratic Republic of Georgia, is occupied by Bolshevist Russia.
February 25, 1928: Charles Jenkins Laboratories of Washington, D.C. becomes the first holder of a broadcast license for television from the Federal Radio Commission.
February 25, 1932: Adolf Hitler obtains German citizenship by naturalization, which allows him to run in the 1932 election for Reichspräsident.
February 25, 1933: The USS Ranger is launched. It is the first US Navy ship to be designed from the start of construction as an aircraft carrier.
February 25, 1939: The first of 2​1⁄2  million Anderson air raid shelters appeared in North London.
February 25, 1947: The formal abolition of Prussia is proclaimed by the Allied Control Council. The Prussian government had already been abolished by the Preußenschlag of 1932.
February 25, 1951: The first Pan American Games were officially opened in Buenos Aires, Argentina by President Juan Perón.
February 25, 1954: Gamal Abdel Nasser is made premier of Egypt.
February 25, 1964: North Korean Prime Minister Kim Il-sung calls for the removal of feudalistic land ownership aimed at turning all cooperative farms into state-run ones.
February 25, 1980: The government of Suriname is overthrown by a military coup led by Dési Bouterse.
February 25, 1987: Southern Methodist University's football program is the first college football program to be banned from competition by the NCAA's Committee on Infractions.
February 25, 1997: Yi Han-yong, a North Korean defector, was murdered by unidentified assailants in Bundang, South Korea.
February 25, 2009: Turkish Airlines Flight 1951 crashed during landing at the Amsterdam Schiphol Airport, Netherlands, primarily due to a faulty radio altimeter, resulting in the death of nine passengers and crew including all three pilots.
February 25, 2015: At least 310 people are killed in avalanches in northeastern Afghanistan.
February 25, 2016: Three people are killed and fourteen others injured in a series of shootings in the small Kansas cities of Newton and Hesston.
February 26, 364: Valentinian I is proclaimed Roman emperor.
February 26, 1606: The Janszoon voyage of 1605–06 becomes the first European expedition to sight Australia, although it is mistaken as a part of New Guinea.
February 26, 1616: Galileo Galilei is formally banned by the Roman Catholic Church from teaching or defending the view that the earth orbits the sun.
February 26, 1794: The first Christiansborg Palace in Copenhagen burns down.
February 26, 1876: Japan and Korea sign a treaty granting Japanese citizens extraterritoriality rights, opening three ports to Japanese trade, and ending Korea's status as a tributary state of Qing dynasty China.
February 26, 1909: Kinemacolor, the first successful color motion picture process, is first shown to the general public at the Palace Theatre in London.
February 26, 1914: HMHS Britannic, sister to the RMS Titanic, is launched at Harland and Wolff shipyard in Belfast.
February 26, 1919: President Woodrow Wilson signs an act of Congress establishing the Grand Canyon National Park.
February 26, 1929: President Calvin Coolidge signs an executive order establishing the 96,000 acre Grand Teton National Park in Wyoming.
February 26, 1935: Robert Watson-Watt carries out a demonstration near Daventry which leads directly to the development of radar in the United Kingdom.
February 26, 1936: In the February 26 Incident, young Japanese military officers attempt to stage a coup against the government.
February 26, 1952: Vincent Massey is sworn in as the first Canadian-born Governor General of Canada.
February 26, 1960: A New York-bound Alitalia airliner crashes into a cemetery in Shannon, Ireland, shortly after takeoff, killing 34 of the 52 persons on board.
February 26, 1971: U.N. Secretary-General U Thant signs United Nations proclamation of the vernal equinox as Earth Day.
February 26, 1979: The Superliner railcar enters revenue service with Amtrak.
February 26, 1980: Egypt and Israel establish full diplomatic relations.
February 26, 1995: The UK's oldest investment banking institute, Barings Bank, collapses after a rogue securities broker Nick Leeson loses $1.4 billion by speculating on the Singapore International Monetary Exchange using futures contracts.
February 26, 2008: The New York Philharmonic performs in Pyongyang, North Korea; this is the first event of its kind to take place in North Korea.
February 26, 2012: A train derails in Burlington, Ontario, Canada killing at least three people and injuring 45.
February 26, 2013: A hot air balloon crashes near Luxor, Egypt, killing 19 people.
February 27, 425: The University of Constantinople is founded by Emperor Theodosius II at the urging of his wife Aelia Eudocia.
February 27, 907: Abaoji, a Khitan chieftain, is enthroned as Emperor Taizu, establishing the Liao dynasty in northern China.
February 27, 1560: The Treaty of Berwick, which would expel the French from Scotland, is signed by England and the Lords of the Congregation of Scotland.
February 27, 1594: Henry IV is crowned King of France.
February 27, 1617: Sweden and Russia sign the Treaty of Stolbovo, ending the Ingrian War and shutting Russia out of the Baltic Sea.
February 27, 1626: Yuan Chonghuan is appointed Governor of Liaodong, after he led the Chinese into a great victory against the Manchurians under Nurhaci.
February 27, 1700: The island of New Britain is discovered.
February 27, 1801: Pursuant to the District of Columbia Organic Act of 1801, Washington, D.C. is placed under the jurisdiction of the U.S. Congress.
February 27, 1812: Poet Lord Byron gives his first address as a member of the House of Lords, in defense of Luddite violence against Industrialism in his home county of Nottinghamshire.
February 27, 1844: The Dominican Republic gains independence from Haiti.
February 27, 1860: Abraham Lincoln makes a speech at Cooper Union in the city of New York that is largely responsible for his election to the Presidency.
February 27, 1861: Russian troops fire on a crowd in Warsaw protesting against Russian rule over Poland, killing five protesters.
February 27, 1870: The current flag of Japan is first adopted as the national flag for Japanese merchant ships.
February 27, 1898: King George I of Greece survives an assassination attempt.
February 27, 1921: The International Working Union of Socialist Parties is founded in Vienna.
February 27, 1922: A challenge to the Nineteenth Amendment to the United States Constitution, allowing women the right to vote, is rebuffed by the Supreme Court of the United States in Leser v. Garnett.
February 27, 1940: Martin Kamen and Sam Ruben discover carbon-14.
February 27, 1943: In Berlin, the Gestapo arrest 1,800 Jewish men with German wives, leading to the Rosenstrasse protest.
February 27, 1951: The Twenty-second Amendment to the United States Constitution, limiting Presidents to two terms, is ratified.
February 27, 1961: The first congress of the Spanish Trade Union Organisation is inaugurated.
February 27, 1962: Two dissident Republic of Vietnam Air Force pilots bomb the Independence Palace in Saigon in a failed attempt to assassinate South Vietnam President Ngô Đình Diệm.
February 27, 1963: The Dominican Republic receives its first democratically elected president, Juan Bosch, since the end of the dictatorship led by Rafael Trujillo.
February 27, 1964: The Government of Italy asks for help to keep the Leaning Tower of Pisa from toppling over.
February 27, 1971: Doctors in the first Dutch abortion clinic (the Mildredhuis in Arnhem) start performing artificially-induced abortions.
February 27, 1973: The American Indian Movement occupies Wounded Knee in protest of the federal government.[1]
February 27, 1976: The formerly Spanish territory of Western Sahara, under the auspices of the Polisario Front declares independence as the Sahrawi Arab Democratic Republic.
February 27, 2002: Ryanair Flight 296 catches fire at London Stansted Airport. Subsequent investigations criticize Ryanair's handling of the evacuation.
February 27, 2004: Shoko Asahara, the leader of the Japanese doomsday cult Aum Shinrikyo, is sentenced to death for masterminding the 1995 Tokyo subway sarin attack
February 27, 2010: An earthquake measuring 8.8 on the moment magnitude scale strikes central parts of Chile leaving over 500 victims, and thousands injured. The quake triggered a tsunami which struck Hawaii shortly after.
February 27, 2013: Five people (including the perpetrator) are killed and five others injured in a shooting at a factory in Menznau, Switzerland.
February 28, 202 BC: Liu Bang is enthroned as the Emperor of China, beginning four centuries of rule by the Han dynasty.
February 28, 870: The Fourth Council of Constantinople closes.
February 28, 1246: The siege of Jaén ends in the context of the Spanish Reconquista resulting in the Castilian takeover of the city from the Taifa of Jaen.
February 28, 1525: Aztec king Cuauhtémoc is executed on the order of conquistador Hernán Cortés.
February 28, 1638: The Scottish National Covenant is signed in Edinburgh.
February 28, 1700: Today is followed by March 1 in Sweden, thus creating the Swedish calendar.
February 28, 1728: Peshwa Bajirao I of the Maratha Empire defeats Asaf Jah I in the Battle of Palkhed.
February 28, 1784: John Wesley charters the Methodist Church.
February 28, 1827: The Baltimore and Ohio Railroad is incorporated, becoming the first railroad in America offering commercial transportation of both people and freight.
February 28, 1838: Robert Nelson, leader of the Patriotes, proclaims the independence of Lower Canada (today Quebec).
February 28, 1844: A gun on USS Princeton explodes while the boat is on a Potomac River cruise, killing six people, including two United States Cabinet members.
February 28, 1847: The Battle of the Sacramento River during the Mexican–American War is a decisive victory for the United States leading to the capture of Chihuahua.
February 28, 1849: Regular steamship service from the east to the west coast of the United States begins with the arrival of the SS California in San Francisco Bay, four months 22 days after leaving New York Harbor.
February 28, 1867: Seventy years of Holy See–United States relations are ended by a Congressional ban on federal funding of diplomatic envoys to the Vatican and are not restored until January 10, 1984.
February 28, 1870: The Bulgarian Exarchate is established by decree of Sultan Abdülaziz of the Ottoman Empire.
February 28, 1874: One of the longest cases ever heard in an English court ends when the defendant is convicted of perjury for attempting to assume the identity of the heir to the Tichborne baronetcy.
February 28, 1893: The USS Indiana, the lead ship of her class and the first battleship in the United States Navy comparable to foreign battleships of the time, is launched.
February 28, 1897: Queen Ranavalona III, the last monarch of Madagascar, is deposed by a French military force.
February 28, 1904: S.L. Benfica is founded in Portugal.
February 28, 1922: The United Kingdom ends its protectorate over Egypt through a Unilateral Declaration of Independence.
February 28, 1925: The Charlevoix-Kamouraska earthquake strikes northeastern North America.
February 28, 1935: DuPont scientist Wallace Carothers invents nylon.
February 28, 1939: The erroneous word "dord" is discovered in the Webster's New International Dictionary, Second Edition, prompting an investigation.
February 28, 1940: Basketball is televised for the first time (Fordham University vs. the University of Pittsburgh in Madison Square Garden).
February 28, 1942: The heavy cruiser USS Houston is sunk in the Battle of Sunda Strait with 693 crew members killed, along with HMAS Perth which lost 375 men.
February 28, 1948: Christiansborg Cross-Roads shooting in the Gold Coast, when a British police officer opens fire on a march of ex-servicemen, killing three of them and sparking major riots and looting in Accra.
February 28, 1953: James Watson and Francis Crick announce to friends that they have determined the chemical structure of DNA; the formal announcement takes place on April 25 following publication in April's Nature (pub. April 2).
February 28, 1954: The first color television sets using the NTSC standard are offered for sale to the general public.
February 28, 1958: A school bus in Floyd County, Kentucky hits a wrecker truck and plunges down an embankment into the rain-swollen Levisa Fork river. The driver and 26 children die in what remains one of the worst school bus accidents in U.S. history.
February 28, 1959: Discoverer 1, an American spy satellite that is the first object intended to achieve a polar orbit, is launched but fails to achieve orbit.
February 28, 1975: In London, an underground train fails to stop at Moorgate terminus station and crashes into the end of the tunnel, killing 43 people.
February 28, 1980: Andalusia approves its statute of autonomy through a referendum.
February 28, 1983: The final episode of M*A*S*H airs, with almost 106 million viewers. It still holds the record for the highest viewership of a season finale.
February 28, 1985: The Provisional Irish Republican Army carries out a mortar attack on the Royal Ulster Constabulary police station at Newry, killing nine officers in the highest loss of life for the RUC on a single day.
February 28, 1986: Olof Palme, 26th Prime Minister of Sweden, is assassinated in Stockholm.
February 28, 1993: The Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms agents raid the Branch Davidian church in Waco, Texas with a warrant to arrest the group's leader David Koresh. Four ATF agents and six Davidians die in the initial raid, starting a 51-day standoff.
February 28, 1995: Former Australian Liberal party leader John Hewson resigns from the Australian parliament almost two years after losing the 1993 Australian federal election.
February 28, 1997: GRB 970228, a highly luminous flash of gamma rays, strikes the Earth for 80 seconds, providing early evidence that gamma-ray bursts occur well beyond the Milky Way.
February 28, 1998: First flight of RQ-4 Global Hawk, the first unmanned aerial vehicle certified to file its own flight plans and fly regularly in U.S. civilian airspace.
February 28, 2002: During the religious violence in Gujarat, the 97 people killed in the Naroda Patiya massacre and 69 in Gulbarg Society massacre.
February 28, 2004: Over one million Taiwanese participate in the 228 Hand-in-Hand rally form a 500-kilometre (310 mi) long human chain to commemorate the February 28 Incident in 1947.
February 28, 2005: A suicide bombing at a police recruiting centre in Al Hillah, Iraq kills 127.
February 28, 2013: Pope Benedict XVI resigns as the pope of the Catholic Church, becoming the first pope to do so since Pope Gregory XII, in 1415.
February 29, 1504: Christopher Columbus uses his knowledge of a lunar eclipse that night to convince Native Americans to provide him with supplies.
February 29, 1644: Abel Tasman's second Pacific voyage began.
February 29, 1712: February 29 is followed by February 30 in Sweden, in a move to abolish the Swedish calendar for a return to the Julian calendar.
February 29, 1720: Ulrika Eleonora, Queen of Sweden abdicates in favour of her husband, who becomes King Frederick I on 24 March.
February 29, 1752: King Alaungpaya founds Konbaung Dynasty, the last dynasty of Burmese monarchy.
February 29, 1796: The Jay Treaty between the United States and Great Britain comes into force, facilitating ten years of peaceful trade between the two nations.
February 29, 1912: The Piedra Movediza (Moving Stone) of Tandil falls and breaks.
February 29, 1920: Czechoslovak National assembly adopted the Constitution.
February 29, 1960: The 5.7 Mw  Agadir earthquake shakes coastal Morocco with a maximum perceived intensity of X (Extreme), destroying Agadir, and leaving 12,000 dead and another 12,000 injured.
February 29, 1964: In Sydney, Australian swimmer Dawn Fraser sets a new world record in the 100-meter freestyle swimming competition (58.9 seconds).
February 29, 1980: Gordie Howe of the then Hartford Whalers makes NHL history as he scores his 800th goal.
February 29, 1992: First day of Bosnia and Herzegovina independence referendum.
February 29, 2004: Jean-Bertrand Aristide is removed as President of Haiti following a coup.
February 29, 2012: Tokyo Skytree construction completed. It is, as of 2017[update], the tallest tower in the world, 634 meters high, and second tallest artificial structure on Earth, next to Burj Khalifa.
March 1, 509 BC: Publius Valerius Publicola celebrates the first triumph of the Roman Republic after his victory over the deposed king Lucius Tarquinius Superbus at the Battle of Silva Arsia.
March 1, 86 BC: Lucius Cornelius Sulla, at the head of a Roman Republic army, enters Athens, removing the tyrant Aristion who was supported by troops of Mithridates VI of Pontus ending the Siege of Athens and Piraeus.
March 1, 293: Emperor Diocletian and Maximian appoint Constantius Chlorus and Galerius as Caesars. This is considered the beginning of the Tetrarchy, known as the Quattuor Principes Mundi ("Four Rulers of the World").
March 1, 317: Crispus and Constantine II, sons of Roman Emperor Constantine I, and Licinius Iunior, son of Emperor Licinius, are made Caesares.
March 1, 350: Vetranio is asked by Constantina, sister of Constantius II, to proclaim himself Caesar.
March 1, 834: Emperor Louis the Pious is restored as sole ruler of the Frankish Empire. After his re-accession to the throne, his eldest son Lothair I flees to Burgundy.
March 1, 1457: The Unitas Fratrum is established in the village of Kunvald, on the Bohemian-Moravian borderland. It is to date the second oldest Protestant denomination.
March 1, 1476: Forces of the Catholic Monarchs engage the combined Portuguese-Castilian armies of Afonso V and Prince John at the Battle of Toro.
March 1, 1562: Sixty-three Huguenots are massacred in Wassy, France, marking the start of the French Wars of Religion.
March 1, 1565: The city of Rio de Janeiro is founded.
March 1, 1628: Writs issued in February by Charles I of England mandate that every county in England (not just seaport towns) pay ship tax by this date.
March 1, 1633: Samuel de Champlain reclaims his role as commander of New France on behalf of Cardinal Richelieu.
March 1, 1642: Georgeana, Massachusetts (now known as York, Maine), becomes the first incorporated city in the United States.
March 1, 1692: Sarah Good, Sarah Osborne and Tituba are brought before local magistrates in Salem Village, Massachusetts, beginning what would become known as the Salem witch trials.
March 1, 1700: Sweden introduces its own Swedish calendar, in an attempt to gradually merge into the Gregorian calendar, reverts to the Julian calendar on this date in 1712, and introduces the Gregorian calendar on this date in 1753.
March 1, 1713: The siege and destruction of Fort Neoheroka begins during the Tuscarora War in North Carolina, effectively opening up the colony's interior to European colonization.
March 1, 1781: The Continental Congress adopts the Articles of Confederation.
March 1, 1790: The first United States census is authorized.
March 1, 1796: The Dutch East India Company is nationalized by the Batavian Republic.
March 1, 1805: Justice Samuel Chase is acquitted at the end of his impeachment trial by the U.S. Senate.
March 1, 1811: Leaders of the Mamluk dynasty are killed by Egyptian ruler Muhammad Ali.
March 1, 1815: Georgetown University's congressional charter is signed into law by President James Madison.
March 1, 1836: A convention of delegates from 57 Texas communities convenes in Washington-on-the-Brazos, Texas, to deliberate independence from Mexico.
March 1, 1845: United States President John Tyler signs a bill authorizing the United States to annex the Republic of Texas.
March 1, 1852: Archibald Montgomerie, 13th Earl of Eglinton, is appointed Lord Lieutenant of Ireland.
March 1, 1854: German psychologist Friedrich Eduard Beneke disappears; two years later his remains are found in a canal near Charlottenburg.
March 1, 1867: Nebraska becomes the 37th U.S. state; Lancaster, Nebraska is renamed Lincoln and becomes the state capital.
March 1, 1868: The Pi Kappa Alpha Fraternity is founded at the University of Virginia.
March 1, 1870: Marshal F. S. López dies during the Battle of Cerro Corá thus marking the end of the Paraguayan War.
March 1, 1872: Yellowstone National Park is established as the world's first national park.
March 1, 1873: E. Remington and Sons in Ilion, New York begins production of the first practical typewriter.
March 1, 1881: The first Minnesota State Capitol burns down due to a fire.
March 1, 1886: The Anglo-Chinese School, Singapore is founded by Bishop William Oldham.
March 1, 1893: Electrical engineer Nikola Tesla gives the first public demonstration of radio in St. Louis, Missouri.
March 1, 1910: The worst avalanche in United States history buries a Great Northern Railway train in northeastern King County, Washington, killing 96 people.
March 1, 1914: The Republic of China joins the Universal Postal Union.
March 1, 1917: The Zimmermann Telegram is reprinted in newspapers across the United States after the U.S. government releases its unencrypted text.
March 1, 1919: March 1st Movement begins in Korea under Japanese rule.
March 1, 1921: The Australian cricket team captained by Warwick Armstrong becomes the first team to complete a whitewash of The Ashes, something that would not be repeated for 86 years.
March 1, 1932: Charles Lindbergh's son is reportedly kidnapped.
March 1, 1939: An Imperial Japanese Army ammunition dump explodes at Hirakata, Osaka, Japan, killing 94.
March 1, 1946: The Bank of England is nationalised.
March 1, 1947: The International Monetary Fund begins financial operations.
March 1, 1949: Indonesian Army recaptures and occupies for six hours its capital city Yogyakarta from the Dutch.
March 1, 1953: Soviet Premier Joseph Stalin suffers a stroke and collapses; he dies four days later.
March 1, 1954: Armed Puerto Rican nationalists attack the United States Capitol building, injuring five Representatives.
March 1, 1956: Formation of the East German Nationale Volksarmee.
March 1, 1958: Samuel Alphonsus Stritch is appointed Pro-Prefect of the Propagation of Faith and thus becomes the first U.S. member of the Roman Curia.
March 1, 1961: Uganda becomes self-governing and holds its first elections.
March 1, 1964: Villarrica Volcano begins a strombolian eruption causing lahars that destroy half of the town of Coñaripe.
March 1, 1966: The Ba'ath Party takes power in Syria.
March 1, 1971: President of Pakistan Yahya Khan indefinitely postpones the pending national assembly session, precipitating massive civil disobedience in East Pakistan.
March 1, 1972: The Thai province of Yasothon is created after being split off from the Ubon Ratchathani Province.
March 1, 1973: Black September storms the Saudi embassy in Khartoum, Sudan, resulting in the assassination of three Western hostages.
March 1, 1981: Provisional Irish Republican Army member Bobby Sands begins his hunger strike in HM Prison Maze.
March 1, 1983: First collection of twelve Swatch models was introduced in Zürich, Switzerland.
March 1, 1990: Steve Jackson Games is raided by the United States Secret Service, prompting the later formation of the Electronic Frontier Foundation.
March 1, 1991: Uprisings against Saddam Hussein begin in Iraq, leading to the death of more than 25,000 people mostly civilian.
March 1, 1992: Bosnia and Herzegovina declares its independence from Socialist Federal Republic of Yugoslavia.
March 1, 1998: Titanic became the first film to gross over $1 billion worldwide.
March 1, 2002: The Envisat environmental satellite successfully reaches an orbit 800 kilometers (500 mi) above the Earth on its 11th launch, carrying the heaviest payload to date at 8500 kilograms (8.5 tons).
March 1, 2003: The International Criminal Court holds its inaugural session in The Hague.
March 1, 2005: In Roper v. Simmons, the U.S. Supreme Court rules that the execution of juveniles found guilty of murder is unconstitutional.
March 1, 2006: English-language Wikipedia reaches its one millionth article, Jordanhill railway station.
March 1, 2007: Tornadoes break out across the southern United States, killing at least 20 people, including eight at Enterprise High School.
March 1, 2008: The Armenian police clash with peaceful opposition rally protesting against allegedly fraudulent presidential elections, as a result ten people are killed.
March 1, 2014: 35 people are killed and 143 injured in a mass stabbing at Kunming Railway Station in China.
March 2, 986: Louis V becomes King of the Franks.
March 2, 1127: Assassination of Charles the Good, Count of Flanders.
March 2, 1444: Skanderbeg organizes a group of Albanian nobles to form the League of Lezhë.
March 2, 1458: George of Poděbrady is chosen as the king of Bohemia.
March 2, 1484: The College of Arms is formally incorporated by Royal Charter signed by King Richard III of England.
March 2, 1498: Vasco da Gama's fleet visits the Island of Mozambique.
March 2, 1561: Mendoza, Argentina is founded by Spanish conquistador Pedro del Castillo.
March 2, 1717: The Loves of Mars and Venus is the first ballet performed in England.
March 2, 1791: Long-distance communication speeds up with the unveiling of a semaphore machine in Paris.
March 2, 1797: The Bank of England issues the first one-pound and two-pound banknotes.
March 2, 1807: The U.S. Congress passes the Act Prohibiting Importation of Slaves, disallowing the importation of new slaves into the country.
March 2, 1808: The inaugural meeting of the Wernerian Natural History Society, a former Scottish learned society, is held in Edinburgh.
March 2, 1815: Signing of the Kandyan Convention treaty by British invaders and the leaders of the Kingdom of Kandy.
March 2, 1825: Roberto Cofresí, one of the last successful Caribbean pirates, is defeated in combat and captured by authorities.
March 2, 1855: Alexander II becomes Tsar of Russia.
March 2, 1859: The two-day Great Slave Auction, the largest such auction in United States history, begins.
March 2, 1867: The U.S. Congress passes the first Reconstruction Act.
March 2, 1882: Queen Victoria narrowly escapes an assassination attempt by Roderick McLean in Windsor.
March 2, 1896: The Battle of Adwa - The Italian Army defeated by the Ethiopian Army in Adwa, Tigray, Ethiopia.
March 2, 1901: The U.S. Congress passes the Platt Amendment limiting the autonomy of Cuba, as a condition of the withdrawal of American troops.
March 2, 1903: In New York City the Martha Washington Hotel opens, becoming the first hotel exclusively for women.
March 2, 1917: The enactment of the Jones–Shafroth Act grants Puerto Ricans United States citizenship.
March 2, 1919: The first Communist International meets in Moscow.
March 2, 1933: The film King Kong opens at New York's Radio City Music Hall.
March 2, 1937: The Steel Workers Organizing Committee signs a collective bargaining agreement with U.S. Steel, leading to unionization of the United States steel industry.
March 2, 1939: Cardinal Eugenio Pacelli is elected Pope and takes the name Pius XII.
March 2, 1946: Ho Chi Minh is elected the President of North Vietnam.
March 2, 1949: Captain James Gallagher lands his B-50 Superfortress Lucky Lady II in Fort Worth, Texas after completing the first non-stop around-the-world airplane flight in 94 hours and one minute.
March 2, 1955: Norodom Sihanouk, king of Cambodia, abdicates the throne in favor of his father, Norodom Suramarit.
March 2, 1961: John F. Kennedy announces the creation of the Peace Corps in a nationally televised broadcast.
March 2, 1962: Wilt Chamberlain sets the single-game scoring record in the National Basketball Association by scoring 100 points.
March 2, 1965: The US and Republic of Vietnam Air Force begin Operation Rolling Thunder, a sustained bombing campaign against North Vietnam.
March 2, 1968: Baggeridge Colliery closes marking the end of over 300 years of coal mining in the Black Country.[1]
March 2, 1969: In Toulouse, France, the first test flight of the Anglo-French Concorde is conducted.
March 2, 1970: Rhodesia declares itself a republic, breaking its last links with the British crown.
March 2, 1972: The Pioneer 10 space probe is launched from Cape Canaveral, Florida with a mission to explore the outer planets.
March 2, 1977: Libya becomes the Socialist People's Libyan Arab Jamahiriya as the General People's Congress adopted the "Declaration on the Establishment of the Authority of the People".
March 2, 1978: Czech Vladimír Remek becomes the first non-Russian or non-American to go into space, when he is launched aboard Soyuz 28.
March 2, 1983: Compact discs and players are released for the first time in the United States and other markets. They had previously been available only in Japan.
March 2, 1989: Twelve European Community nations agree to ban the production of all chlorofluorocarbons (CFCs) by the end of the century.
March 2, 1990: Nelson Mandela is elected deputy President of the African National Congress.
March 2, 1991: Battle at Rumaila oil field brings an end to the 1991 Gulf War.
March 2, 1992: Armenia, Azerbaijan, Kazakhstan, Kyrgyzstan, Moldova, San Marino, Tajikistan, Turkmenistan and Uzbekistan join the United Nations.
March 2, 1998: Data sent from the Galileo spacecraft indicates that Jupiter's moon Europa has a liquid ocean under a thick crust of ice.
March 2, 2012: A tornado outbreak occurred over a large section of the Southern United States and into the Ohio Valley region, resulting in 40 tornado-related fatalities.
March 2, 2017: The elements Moscovium, Tennessine, and Oganesson were officially added to the periodic table at a conference in Moscow, Russia.
March 3, 473: Gundobad (nephew of Ricimer) nominates Glycerius as emperor of the Western Roman Empire.
March 3, 724: Empress Genshō abdicates the throne in favor of her nephew Shōmu who becomes emperor of Japan.
March 3, 1575: Mughal Emperor Akbar defeats Sultan of Bengal Daud Khan Karrani's army at the Battle of Tukaroi.
March 3, 1585: The Olympic Theatre, designed by Andrea Palladio, is inaugurated in Vicenza.
March 3, 1799: The Russo-Ottoman siege of Corfu ends with the surrender of the French garrison.
March 3, 1820: The U.S. Congress passes the Missouri Compromise.
March 3, 1845: Florida is admitted as the 27th U.S. state.
March 3, 1849: The Territory of Minnesota was created.
March 3, 1859: The two-day Great Slave Auction, the largest such auction in United States history, concludes.
March 3, 1861: Alexander II of Russia signs the Emancipation Manifesto, freeing serfs.
March 3, 1865: Opening of The Hongkong and Shanghai Banking Corporation, the founding member of the HSBC Group.
March 3, 1875: The first ever organized indoor game of ice hockey is played in Montreal, Quebec, Canada as recorded in the Montreal Gazette.
March 3, 1878: The Russo-Turkish War ends with Bulgaria regaining its independence from the Ottoman Empire according to the Treaty of San Stefano; a few months afterwards the Congress of Berlin stripped its status to a vassal principality of the Ottoman Empire.
March 3, 1885: The American Telephone & Telegraph Company is incorporated in New York.
March 3, 1891: Shoshone National Forest is established as the first national forest in the US and world.
March 3, 1904: Kaiser Wilhelm II of Germany becomes the first person to make a sound recording of a political document, using Thomas Edison's phonograph cylinder.
March 3, 1913: Thousands of women march in a suffrage parade in Washington, D.C.
March 3, 1918: Russia signs the Treaty of Brest-Litovsk, agreeing to withdraw from World War I, and conceding German control of the Baltic States, Belarus and Ukraine. It also conceded Turkish control of Ardahan, Kars and Batumi.
March 3, 1923: TIME magazine is published for the first time.
March 3, 1924: The Free State of Fiume is annexed by the Kingdom of Italy.
March 3, 1931: The United States adopts The Star-Spangled Banner as its national anthem.
March 3, 1938: Oil is discovered in Saudi Arabia.
March 3, 1939: In Bombay, Mohandas Gandhi begins a hunger strike in protest at the autocratic rule in British India.
March 3, 1940: Five people are killed in an arson attack on the offices of the communist newspaper Flamman in Luleå, Sweden.
March 3, 1944: The Order of Nakhimov and Order of Ushakov are instituted in USSR as the highest naval awards.
March 3, 1951: Jackie Brenston, with Ike Turner and his band, records "Rocket 88", often cited as "the first rock and roll record", at Sam Phillips's recording studios in Memphis, Tennessee.
March 3, 1953: A De Havilland Comet (Canadian Pacific Air Lines) crashes in Karachi, Pakistan, killing 11.
March 3, 1958: Nuri al-Said becomes Prime Minister of Iraq for the eighth time.
March 3, 1972: Mohawk Airlines Flight 405 crashes as a result of a control malfunction and insufficient training in emergency procedures.
March 3, 1974: Turkish Airlines Flight 981 crashes at Ermenonville near Paris, France killing all 346 aboard.
March 3, 1980: The USS Nautilus is decommissioned and stricken from the Naval Vessel Register.
March 3, 1985: A magnitude 8.3 earthquake strikes the Valparaíso Region of Chile, killing 177 and leaving nearly a million people homeless.
March 3, 1986: The Australia Act 1986 commences, causing Australia to become fully independent from the United Kingdom.
March 3, 1991: An amateur video captures the beating of Rodney King by Los Angeles police officers.
March 3, 2005: Margaret Wilson is elected as Speaker of the New Zealand House of Representatives, beginning a period lasting until August 23, 2006 where all the highest political offices (including Elizabeth II as Head of State), were occupied by women, making New Zealand the first country for this to occur.
March 3, 2013: A bomb blast in Karachi, Pakistan, kills at least 45 people and injured 180 others in a predominately Shia Muslim area.
March 4, AD 51: Nero, later to become Roman emperor, is given the title princeps iuventutis (head of the youth).
March 4, 306: Martyrdom of Saint Adrian of Nicomedia.
March 4, 852: Croatian Knez Trpimir I issues a statute, a document with the first known written mention of the Croats name in Croatian sources.
March 4, 938: Translation of the relics of martyr Wenceslaus I, Duke of Bohemia, Prince of the Czechs.
March 4, 1152: Frederick I Barbarossa is elected King of Germany.
March 4, 1238: The Battle of the Sit River is fought in the northern part of the present-day Yaroslavl Oblast of Russia between the Mongol hordes of Batu Khan and the Russians under Yuri II of Vladimir-Suzdal during the Mongol invasion of Rus'.
March 4, 1386: Władysław II Jagiełło (Jogaila) is crowned King of Poland.
March 4, 1493: Explorer Christopher Columbus arrives back in Lisbon, Portugal, aboard his ship Niña from his voyage to what are now The Bahamas and other islands in the Caribbean.
March 4, 1519: Hernán Cortés arrives in Mexico in search of the Aztec civilization and its wealth.
March 4, 1628: The Massachusetts Bay Colony is granted a Royal charter.
March 4, 1665: English King Charles II declares war on the Netherlands marking the start of the Second Anglo-Dutch War.
March 4, 1675: John Flamsteed is appointed the first Astronomer Royal of England.
March 4, 1681: Charles II grants a land charter to William Penn for the area that will later become Pennsylvania.
March 4, 1789: In New York City, the first Congress of the United States meets, putting the United States Constitution into effect. The United States Bill of Rights is written and proposed to Congress.
March 4, 1790: France is divided into 83 départements, cutting across the former provinces in an attempt to dislodge regional loyalties based on ownership of land by the nobility.
March 4, 1791: Vermont is admitted to the United States as the fourteenth state.
March 4, 1794: The 11th Amendment to the U.S. Constitution is passed by the U.S. Congress.
March 4, 1797: John Adams is inaugurated as the 2nd President of the United States of America, becoming the first President to begin his presidency on March 4.
March 4, 1813: Cyril VI of Constantinople is elected Ecumenical Patriarch of Constantinople.
March 4, 1814: Americans defeat British forces at the Battle of Longwoods between London, Ontario and Thamesville, near present-day Wardsville, Ontario.
March 4, 1837: The city of Chicago is incorporated.
March 4, 1848: Carlo Alberto di Savoia signs the Statuto Albertino that will later represent the first constitution of the Regno d'Italia.
March 4, 1849: President-Elect Zachary Taylor and Vice President-Elect Millard Fillmore did not take their respective Oath's of office, leading to the  theory that outgoing President Pro Tempore of the United States Senate David Rice Atchison assumed the role of Acting President of the United States for one day.
March 4, 1861: The first national flag of the Confederate States of America (the "Stars and Bars") is adopted.
March 4, 1865: The third and final national flag of the Confederate States of America is adopted by the Confederate Congress.
March 4, 1882: Britain's first electric trams run in east London.
March 4, 1890: The longest bridge in Great Britain, the Forth Bridge in Scotland, measuring 1,710 feet (520 m) long, is opened by the Prince of Wales, later King Edward VII.
March 4, 1899: Cyclone Mahina sweeps in north of Cooktown, Queensland, with a 12 metres (39 ft) wave that reaches up to 5 kilometres (3.1 mi) inland, killing over 300.
March 4, 1908: The Collinwood school fire, Collinwood near Cleveland, Ohio, kills 174 people.
March 4, 1909: U.S. President William Taft used what became known as a Saxbe fix, a mechanism to avoid the restriction of the U.S. Constitution's Ineligibility Clause, to appoint Philander C. Knox as U.S. Secretary of State.
March 4, 1913: The United States Department of Labor is formed.
March 4, 1917: Jeannette Rankin of Montana becomes the first female member of the United States House of Representatives.
March 4, 1933: The Parliament of Austria is suspended because of a quibble over procedure – Chancellor Engelbert Dollfuss initiates an authoritarian rule by decree.
March 4, 1957: The S&P 500 stock market index is introduced, replacing the S&P 90.
March 4, 1960: The French freighter La Coubre explodes in Havana, Cuba, killing 100.
March 4, 1962: A Caledonian Airways Douglas DC-7 crashes shortly after takeoff from Cameroon, killing 111 – the worst crash of a DC-7.
March 4, 1966: In an interview in the London Evening Standard, The Beatles' John Lennon declares that the band is "more popular than Jesus now".
March 4, 1970: French submarine Eurydice explodes underwater, resulting in the loss of the entire 57-man crew.
March 4, 1974: People magazine is published for the first time in the United States as People Weekly.
March 4, 1976: The Northern Ireland Constitutional Convention is formally dissolved in Northern Ireland resulting in direct rule of Northern Ireland from London by the British parliament.
March 4, 1977: The 1977 Vrancea earthquake in eastern and southern Europe kills more than 1,500, mostly in Bucharest, Romania.
March 4, 1980: Nationalist leader Robert Mugabe wins a sweeping election victory to become Zimbabwe's first black prime minister.
March 4, 1985: The Food and Drug Administration approves a blood test for AIDS infection, used since then for screening all blood donations in the United States.
March 4, 1986: The Soviet Vega 1 begins returning images of Halley's Comet and the first images of its nucleus.
March 4, 1996: A derailed train in Weyauwega, Wisconsin (USA) causes the emergency evacuation of 2,300 people for 16 days.
March 4, 2009: The International Criminal Court (ICC) issues an arrest warrant for Sudanese President Omar Hassan al-Bashir for war crimes and crimes against humanity in Darfur. Al-Bashir is the first sitting head of state to be indicted by the ICC since its establishment in 2002.
March 4, 2012: A series of explosions is reported at a munitions dump in Brazzaville, the capital of the Republic of the Congo, killing at least 250 people.
March 4, 2015: At least 34 miners die in a suspected gas explosion at the Zasyadko coal mine in the rebel-held Donetsk region of Ukraine.
March 4, 2018: Former MI6 spy Sergei Skripal and his daughter are poisoned with a Novichok nerve agent in Salisbury, England, causing a diplomatic uproar that results in mass-expulsions of diplomats from all countries involved.
March 5, 363: Roman Emperor Julian moves from Antioch with an army of 90,000 to attack the Sasanian Empire, in a campaign which would bring about his own death.
March 5, 1046: Nasir Khusraw begins the seven-year Middle Eastern journey which he will later describe in his book Safarnama.
March 5, 1279: The Livonian Order is defeated in the Battle of Aizkraukle by the Grand Duchy of Lithuania.
March 5, 1496: King Henry VII of England issues letters patent to John Cabot and his sons, authorising them to explore unknown lands.
March 5, 1616: Nicolaus Copernicus's book On the Revolutions of the Heavenly Spheres is added to the Index of Forbidden Books 73 years after it was first published.
March 5, 1766: Antonio de Ulloa, the first Spanish governor of Louisiana, arrives in New Orleans.
March 5, 1836: Samuel Colt patents the first production-model revolver, the .34-caliber.
March 5, 1850: The Britannia Bridge across the Menai Strait between the island of Anglesey and the mainland of Wales is opened.
March 5, 1860: Parma, Tuscany, Modena and Romagna vote in referendums to join the Kingdom of Sardinia.
March 5, 1868: Mefistofele, an opera by Arrigo Boito, receives its premiere performance at La Scala.
March 5, 1872: George Westinghouse patents the air brake.
March 5, 1933: Adolf Hitler's Nazi Party receives 43.9% at the Reichstag elections, which allows the Nazis to later pass the Enabling Act and establish a dictatorship.
March 5, 1936: First flight of K5054, the first prototype Supermarine Spitfire advanced monoplane fighter aircraft in the United Kingdom.
March 5, 1940: Six high-ranking members of Soviet politburo, including Joseph Stalin, sign an order for the execution of 25,700 Polish intelligentsia, including 14,700 Polish POWs, in what will become known as the Katyn massacre.
March 5, 1943: First Flight of the Gloster Meteor, Britain's first combat jet aircraft.
March 5, 1953: Joseph Stalin, the longest serving leader of the Soviet Union, dies at his Volynskoe dacha in Moscow after suffering a cerebral hemorrhage 4 days earlier.
March 5, 1960: Indonesian President Sukarno dismissed the Dewan Perwakilan Rakyat (DPR), 1955 democratically elected parliament, and replaced with DPR-GR, the parliament of his own selected members.
March 5, 1963: American country music stars Patsy Cline, Hawkshaw Hawkins, Cowboy Copas and their pilot Randy Hughes are killed in a plane crash in Camden, Tennessee.
March 5, 1970: The Treaty on the Non-Proliferation of Nuclear Weapons goes into effect after ratification by 43 nations.
March 5, 1978: The Landsat 3 is launched from Vandenberg Air Force Base in California.
March 5, 1979: Soviet probes Venera 11, Venera 12 and the German-American solar satellite Helios II all are hit by "off the scale" gamma rays leading to the discovery of soft gamma repeaters.
March 5, 1981: The ZX81, a pioneering British home computer, is launched by Sinclair Research and would go on to sell over 1.5 million units around the world.
March 5, 1982: Soviet probe Venera 14 lands on Venus.
March 5, 2003: In Haifa, 17 Israeli civilians are killed in the Haifa bus 37 suicide bombing.
March 5, 2012: Tropical Storm Irina kills over 75 as it passes through Madagascar.
March 6, 12 BC: The Roman Emperor Augustus is named Pontifex Maximus, incorporating the position into that of the emperor.
March 6, 632: The Farewell Sermon (Khutbah, Khutbatul Wada') of the Islamic prophet Muhammad.
March 6, 845: Execution of the 42 Martyrs of Amorium at Samarra.
March 6, 961: Byzantine conquest of Chandax by Nikephoros Phokas, end of the Emirate of Crete.
March 6, 1204: The Siege of Château Gaillard ends in a French victory over King John of England, who loses control of Normandy to King Philip II Augustus.
March 6, 1323: Treaty of Paris of 1323 is signed.
March 6, 1665: The first joint Secretary of the Royal Society, Henry Oldenburg, publishes the first issue of Philosophical Transactions of the Royal Society, the world's longest-running scientific journal.
March 6, 1788: The First Fleet arrives at Norfolk Island in order to found a convict settlement.
March 6, 1820: The Missouri Compromise is signed into law by President James Monroe. The compromise allows Missouri to enter the Union as a slave state, brings Maine into the Union as a free state, and makes the rest of the northern part of the Louisiana Purchase territory slavery-free.
March 6, 1834: York, Upper Canada, is incorporated as Toronto.
March 6, 1857: The Supreme Court of the United States rules in the Dred Scott v. Sandford case.
March 6, 1869: Dmitri Mendeleev presents the first periodic table to the Russian Chemical Society.
March 6, 1921: Portuguese Communist Party is founded as the Portuguese Section of the Communist International.
March 6, 1930: International Unemployment Day demonstrations globally initiated by the Comintern.
March 6, 1943: Norman Rockwell published Freedom from Want in The Saturday Evening Post with a matching essay by Carlos Bulosan as part of the Four Freedoms series.
March 6, 1946: Ho Chi Minh signs an agreement with France which recognizes Vietnam as an autonomous state in the Indochinese Federation and the French Union.
March 6, 1953: Georgy Malenkov succeeds Joseph Stalin as Premier of the Soviet Union and First Secretary of the Communist Party of the Soviet Union.
March 6, 1957: Ghana becomes the first Sub-Saharan country to gain independence from the British.
March 6, 1964: Constantine II becomes King of Greece.
March 6, 1965: Premier Tom Playford of South Australia loses power after 27 years in office.
March 6, 1968: Three rebels are executed by Rhodesia, the first executions since UDI, prompting international condemnation.
March 6, 1970: An explosion at the Weather Underground safe house in Greenwich Village kills three.
March 6, 1975: For the first time the Zapruder film of the assassination of John F. Kennedy is shown in motion to a national TV audience by Robert J. Groden and Dick Gregory.
March 6, 1983: The first United States Football League games are played.
March 6, 1984: In the United Kingdom, a walkout at Cortonwood Colliery in Brampton Bierlow signals the start of a strike that lasted almost a year and involved the majority of the country's miners.
March 6, 1987: The British ferry MS Herald of Free Enterprise capsizes in about 90 seconds, killing 193.
March 6, 1988: Three Provisional Irish Republican Army volunteers are shot dead by the SAS in Gibraltar in Operation Flavius.
March 6, 1992: The Michelangelo computer virus begins to affect computers.
March 6, 2003: Air Algérie Flight 6289 crashes at the Aguenar – Hadj Bey Akhamok Airport in Tamanrasset, Algeria, killing 102 out of the 103 people on board.[1]
March 6, 2008: A suicide bomber kills 68 people (including first responders) in Baghdad on the same day that a gunman kills eight students in Jerusalem.
March 7, 161: Marcus Aurelius and L. Commodus (who changes his name to Lucius Verus) become joint emperors of Rome on the death of Antoninus Pius.[1]
March 7, 1277: Stephen Tempier, bishop of Paris, condemns 219 philosophical and theological theses.
March 7, 1573: A peace treaty is signed between the Ottoman Empire and the Republic of Venice, ending the Ottoman–Venetian War and leaving Cyprus in Ottoman hands.
March 7, 1799: Napoleon Bonaparte captures Jaffa in Palestine and his troops proceed to kill more than 2,000 Albanian captives.
March 7, 1814: Emperor Napoleon I of France wins the Battle of Craonne.
March 7, 1827: Brazilian marines unsuccessfully attack the temporary naval base of Carmen de Patagones, Argentina.
March 7, 1850: Senator Daniel Webster gives his "Seventh of March" speech endorsing the Compromise of 1850 in order to prevent a possible civil war.
March 7, 1876: Alexander Graham Bell is granted a patent for an invention he calls the "telephone".
March 7, 1900: The German liner SS Kaiser Wilhelm der Grosse becomes the first ship to send wireless signals to shore.
March 7, 1914: Prince William of Wied arrives in Albania to begin his reign as King.
March 7, 1941: Günther Prien and the crew of German submarine U-47, one of the most successful U-boats of World War II, disappear without a trace.[2]
March 7, 1951: In a mosque in Tehran president Ali Razmara was shot by and Islamic fundamentalists of  Fedayan I-Islam.
March 7, 1967: The Majelis Permusyawaratan Rakyat Sementara (MPRS), Indonesia's provisional parliament, revoked Sukarno's mandate as President of Indonesia.
March 7, 1971: Sheikh Mujibur Rahman, political leader of then East Pakistan (present day-Bangladesh), delivers his historic 7th March speech in the Racecourse Field (Now Suhrawardy Udyan) in Dhaka.
March 7, 1989: Iran and the United Kingdom break diplomatic relations after a fight over Salman Rushdie and his controversial novel, The Satanic Verses.
March 7, 1993: The tugboat Thomas Hebert sank off the coast of New Jersey, USA.
March 7, 2006: The terrorist organisation Lashkar-e-Taiba coordinates a series of bombings in Varanasi, India.
March 7, 2007: The British House of Commons votes to make the upper chamber, the House of Lords, 100% elected.
March 7, 2009: The Real Irish Republican Army kills two British soldiers and injures two other soldiers and two civilians at Massereene Barracks, the first British military deaths in Northern Ireland since the end of The Troubles.
March 8, 1010: Ferdowsi completes his epic poem Shahnameh.
March 8, 1126: Following the death of his mother Urraca, Alfonso VII is proclaimed king of Castile and León.
March 8, 1262: Battle of Hausbergen between bourgeois militias and the army of the bishop of Strasbourg.
March 8, 1576: Spanish explorer Diego García de Palacio first sights the ruins of the ancient Mayan city of Copán.
March 8, 1618: Johannes Kepler discovers the third law of planetary motion.
March 8, 1655: John Casor becomes the first legally-recognized slave in England's North American colonies where a crime was not committed.
March 8, 1702: Queen Anne, the younger sister of Mary II, becomes Queen regnant of England, Scotland, and Ireland.
March 8, 1722: The Safavid Empire of Iran is defeated by an army from Afghanistan at the Battle of Gulnabad, pushing Iran into anarchy.
March 8, 1736: Nader Shah, founder of the Afsharid dynasty, is crowned Shah of Iran.
March 8, 1775: An anonymous writer, thought by some to be Thomas Paine, publishes "African Slavery in America", the first article in the American colonies calling for the emancipation of slaves and the abolition of slavery.
March 8, 1777: Regiments from Ansbach and Bayreuth, sent to support Great Britain in the American Revolutionary War, mutiny in the town of Ochsenfurt.
March 8, 1817: The New York Stock Exchange is founded.
March 8, 1844: King Oscar I ascends to the thrones of Sweden and Norway.
March 8, 1910: French aviator Raymonde de Laroche becomes the first woman to receive a pilot's license.
March 8, 1914: First flights (for the Royal Thai Air Force) at Don Mueang International Airport in Bangkok.
March 8, 1917: The United States Senate votes to limit filibusters by adopting the cloture rule.
March 8, 1920: The Arab Kingdom of Syria, the first modern Arab state to come into existence, is established.
March 8, 1921: Spanish Prime Minister Eduardo Dato Iradier is assassinated while exiting the parliament building in Madrid.
March 8, 1924: A mine disaster kills 172 coal miners near Castle Gate, Utah.
March 8, 1936: Daytona Beach and Road Course holds its first oval stock car race.
March 8, 1947: Thirteen thousand troops of the Republic of China Army arrive in Taiwan after the February 28 Incident and launch crackdowns which kill thousands of people, including many elites. This turns into a major root of the Taiwan independence movement.
March 8, 1949: President of France Vincent Auriol and ex-emperor of Annam Bảo Đại sign the Élysée Accords, giving Vietnam greater independence from France and creating the State of Vietnam to oppose Viet Minh-led Democratic Republic of Vietnam.
March 8, 1957: The 1957 Georgia Memorial to Congress, which petitions the U.S. Congress to declare the ratification of the 14th and 15th Amendments to the U.S. Constitution null and void, is adopted by the U.S. state of Georgia.
March 8, 1963: The Ba'ath Party comes to power in Syria in a coup d'état by a clique of quasi-leftist Syrian Army officers calling themselves the National Council of the Revolutionary Command.
March 8, 1965: Thirty-five hundred United States Marines are the first American land combat forces committed during the Vietnam War.
March 8, 1966: Nelson's Pillar in Dublin, Ireland, destroyed by a bomb.
March 8, 1971: The Fight of the Century between Joe Frazier and Muhammad Ali commences. Frazier wins in 15 rounds via unanimous decision.
March 8, 1974: Charles de Gaulle Airport opens in Paris, France.
March 8, 1979: Philips demonstrates the compact disc publicly for the first time.
March 8, 1985: A supposed failed assassination attempt on Islamic cleric Sayyed Mohammad Hussein Fadlallah in Beirut, Lebanon kills at least 45 and injures 175 others.
March 8, 2004: A new constitution is signed by Iraq's Governing Council.
March 8, 2014: Malaysia Airlines Flight 370, carrying a total of 239 people, disappears en route from Kuala Lumpur to Beijing.
March 8, 2017: The Azure Window, a natural arch on the Maltese island of Gozo, collapsed in stormy weather.
March 9, 141 BC: Liu Che, posthumously known as Emperor Wu of Han, assumes the throne over the Han dynasty of China.
March 9, 1009: First known mention of Lithuania, in the annals of the monastery of Quedlinburg.
March 9, 1226: Khwarazmian sultan Jalal ad-Din conquers the Georgian capital of Tbilisi.[1]
March 9, 1230: Bulgarian Tsar Ivan Asen II defeats Theodore of Epirus in the Battle of Klokotnitsa.
March 9, 1276: Augsburg becomes a Free imperial city.
March 9, 1500: The fleet of Pedro Álvares Cabral leaves Lisbon for the Indies. The fleet will discover Brazil which lies within boundaries granted to Portugal in the Treaty of Tordesillas.
March 9, 1566: David Rizzio, private secretary to Mary, Queen of Scots, is murdered in the Palace of Holyroodhouse, Edinburgh, Scotland.
March 9, 1765: After a campaign by the writer Voltaire, judges in Paris posthumously exonerate Jean Calas of murdering his son. Calas had been tortured and executed in 1762 on the charge, though his son may have actually committed suicide.
March 9, 1776: The Wealth of Nations by Scottish economist and philosopher Adam Smith is published.
March 9, 1796: Napoléon Bonaparte marries his first wife, Joséphine de Beauharnais.
March 9, 1811: Paraguayan forces defeat Manuel Belgrano at the Battle of Tacuarí.
March 9, 1815: Francis Ronalds describes the first battery-operated clock in the Philosophical Magazine.
March 9, 1841: The U.S. Supreme Court rules in the United States v. The Amistad case that captive Africans who had seized control of the ship carrying them had been taken into slavery illegally.
March 9, 1842: The first documented discovery of gold in California occurs at Rancho San Francisco, six years before the California Gold Rush.
March 9, 1896: Prime Minister Francesco Crispi resigns following the Italian defeat at the Battle of Adwa.
March 9, 1908: Inter Milan was founded on Football Club Internazionale, following a schism from the Milan Cricket and Football Club.
March 9, 1910: The Westmoreland County coal strike, involving 15,000 coal miners represented by the United Mine Workers, begins.
March 9, 1946: Bolton Wanderers stadium disaster at Burnden Park, Bolton, England, kills 33 and injures hundreds more.
March 9, 1956: Soviet forces suppress mass demonstrations in the Georgian SSR, reacting to Nikita Khrushchev's de-Stalinization policy.
March 9, 1957: The 8.6 Mw  Andreanof Islands earthquake shakes the Aleutian Islands with a maximum Mercalli intensity of VIII (Severe), causing $5 million in damage from ground movement and a destructive tsunami that affected Hawaii, where two people were killed in a plane crash while documenting its arrival.
March 9, 1959: The Barbie doll makes its debut at the American International Toy Fair in New York.
March 9, 1960: Dr. Belding Hibbard Scribner implants for the first time a shunt he invented into a patient, which allows the patient to receive hemodialysis on a regular basis.
March 9, 1961: Sputnik 9 successfully launches, carrying a human dummy nicknamed Ivan Ivanovich, and demonstrating that the Soviet Union was ready to begin human spaceflight.
March 9, 1967: Trans World Airlines Flight 553, a Douglas DC-9-15, crashes in a field in Concord Township, Ohio following a mid-air collision with a Beechcraft Baron, killing 26.
March 9, 1974: The Mars 7 Flyby bus releases the descent module too early, missing Mars.
March 9, 1976: Forty-two people die in the Cavalese cable car disaster, the worst cable-car accident to date.
March 9, 1978: President Soeharto inaugurated Jagorawi Toll Road, the first toll highway in Indonesia, connecting Jakarta, Bogor and Ciawi, West Java.
March 9, 2011: Space Shuttle Discovery makes its final landing after 39 flights.
March 9, 2012: At least 130 rockets are fired into Israel from Gaza.  Twelve Palestinians militants are killed as part of the latest escalation in violence in the region.
March 10, 298: Roman Emperor Maximian concludes his campaign in North Africa against the Berbers, and makes a triumphal entry into Carthage.
March 10, 947: The Later Han is founded by Liu Zhiyuan. He declares himself emperor and establishes the capital in Bian, present-day Kaifeng.
March 10, 1607: Susenyos I defeats the combined armies of Yaqob and Abuna Petros II at the Battle of Gol in Gojjam, making him Emperor of Ethiopia.
March 10, 1629: Charles I dissolves the Parliament of England, beginning the eleven-year period known as the Personal Rule.
March 10, 1735: An agreement between Nader Shah and Russia is signed near Ganja, Azerbaijan and Russian troops are withdrawn from Baku.
March 10, 1762: French Huguenot Jean Calas, who had been wrongly convicted of killing his son, dies after being tortured by authorities; the event inspired Voltaire to begin a campaign for religious tolerance and legal reform.
March 10, 1814: Emperor Napoleon I is defeated at the Battle of Laon in France.
March 10, 1830: The Royal Netherlands East Indies Army is created.
March 10, 1848: The Treaty of Guadalupe Hidalgo is ratified by the United States Senate, ending the Mexican–American War.
March 10, 1861: El Hadj Umar Tall seizes the city of Ségou, destroying the Bamana Empire of Mali.
March 10, 1865: Amy Spain, American slave, is executed for stealing from her owner; believed to have been the last legal execution of a female slave in America.
March 10, 1873: The first Azerbaijani play "The Adventures of the Vizier of the Khan of Lenkaran" prepared by Akhundov was performed by Hassan-bey Zardabi and dramatist and Najaf-bey Vezirov. [1][2]
March 10, 1876: The first successful test of a telephone is made by Alexander Graham Bell.
March 10, 1891: Almon Strowger, an undertaker in Topeka, Kansas, patents the Strowger switch, a device which led to the automation of telephone circuit switching.
March 10, 1906: The Courrières mine disaster, Europe's worst ever, kills 1099 miners in northern France.
March 10, 1909: By signing the Anglo-Siamese Treaty of 1909, Thailand relinquishes its sovereignty over the Malay states of Kedah, Kelantan, Perlis and Terengganu, which become British protectorates.
March 10, 1916: The McMahon–Hussein Correspondence between Hussein bin Ali, Sharif of Mecca and the British official Henry McMahon concerning the Arab revolt against the Ottoman Empire ends.
March 10, 1917: Some provinces and cities in the Philippines are incorporated due to the ratification of Act No. 2711 or the Administrative Code of the Philippines.
March 10, 1922: Mahatma Gandhi is arrested in India, tried for sedition, and sentenced to six years in prison, only to be released after nearly two years for an appendicitis operation.
March 10, 1933: The 6.4 Mw  Long Beach earthquake affects the Greater Los Angeles Area with a maximum Mercalli intensity of VIII (Severe), leaving 115–120 people dead, and causing an estimated $40 million in damage.
March 10, 1949: Mildred Gillars ("Axis Sally") is convicted of treason.[3]
March 10, 1952: Fulgencio Batista leads a successful coup in Cuba and appoints himself as the "provisional president".
March 10, 1966: Military Prime Minister of South Vietnam Nguyễn Cao Kỳ sacked rival General Nguyễn Chánh Thi, precipitating large-scale civil and military dissension in parts of the nation.
March 10, 1969: In Memphis, Tennessee, James Earl Ray pleads guilty to assassinating Martin Luther King, Jr. He later unsuccessfully attempts to recant.
March 10, 1977: Astronomers discover the rings of Uranus.
March 10, 1990: In Haiti, Prosper Avril is ousted 18 months after seizing power in a coup.
March 10, 2000: The Nasdaq Composite stock market index peaks at 5132.52, signaling the beginning of the end of the dot-com boom.
March 10, 2006: The Mars Reconnaissance Orbiter arrives at Mars.
March 10, 2017: The impeachment of President Park Geun-hye of South Korea in response to a major political scandal is unanimously upheld by the country's Constitutional Court, ending her presidency.
March 11, 222: Emperor Elagabalus is assassinated, along with his mother, Julia Soaemias, by the Praetorian Guard during a revolt. Their mutilated bodies are dragged through the streets of Rome before being thrown into the Tiber.
March 11, 1641: Guaraní forces living in the Jesuit reductions defeat bandeirantes loyal to the Portuguese Empire at the Battle of Mbororé in present-day Panambí, Argentina.
March 11, 1649: The Frondeurs and the French sign the Peace of Rueil.
March 11, 1702: The Daily Courant, England's first national daily newspaper is published for the first time.
March 11, 1708: Queen Anne withholds Royal Assent from the Scottish Militia Bill, the last time a British monarch vetoes legislation.
March 11, 1784: The signing of the Treaty of Mangalore brings the Second Anglo-Mysore War to an end.
March 11, 1811: During André Masséna's retreat from the Lines of Torres Vedras, a division led by French Marshal Michel Ney fights off a combined Anglo-Portuguese force to give Masséna time to escape.
March 11, 1824: The United States Department of War creates the Bureau of Indian Affairs.
March 11, 1848: Louis-Hippolyte Lafontaine and Robert Baldwin become the first Prime Ministers of the Province of Canada to be democratically elected under a system of responsible government.
March 11, 1851: The first performance of Rigoletto by Giuseppe Verdi takes place in Venice.
March 11, 1864: The Great Sheffield Flood kills 238 people in Sheffield, England.
March 11, 1872: Construction of the Seven Sisters Colliery, South Wales, begins; located on one of the richest coal sources in Britain.
March 11, 1879: Shō Tai formally abdicated his position of King of Ryūkyū, under orders from Tokyo, ending the Ryukyu Kingdom.
March 11, 1888: The Great Blizzard of 1888 begins along the eastern seaboard of the United States, shutting down commerce and killing more than 400.
March 11, 1927: In New York City, Samuel Roxy Rothafel opens the Roxy Theatre.
March 11, 1931: Ready for Labour and Defence of the USSR, abbreviated as GTO, is introduced in the Soviet Union.
March 11, 1946: Rudolf Höss, the first commandant of Auschwitz concentration camp, is captured by British troops.
March 11, 1981: Hundreds of students protest in the University of Pristina in Kosovo, then part of Yugoslavia, to give their republic more political rights. The protests then became a nationwide movement.
March 11, 1983: Bob Hawke is appointed Prime Minister of Australia.
March 11, 1985: Mikhail Gorbachev is elected to the position of General Secretary of the Communist Party of the Soviet Union making Gorbachev the USSR's de facto, and last, head of state.
March 11, 1989: Sir Tim Berners-Lee submitted his proposal to CERN for an information management system which would be developed into the world wide web.
March 11, 1990: Patricio Aylwin is sworn in as the first democratically elected President of Chile since 1970.
March 11, 1993: Janet Reno is confirmed by the United States Senate and sworn in the next day, becoming the first female Attorney General of the United States.
March 11, 1999: Infosys becomes the first Indian company listed on the NASDAQ stock exchange.
March 11, 2006: Michelle Bachelet is inaugurated as first female president of Chile.
March 11, 2007: Georgia claims Russian helicopters attacked the Kodori Valley in Abkhazia, an accusation that Russia categorically denies later.
March 11, 2010: Economist and businessman Sebastián Piñera is sworn in as President of Chile, while three earthquakes, the strongest measuring magnitude 6.9 and all centered next to Pichilemu, capital of Cardenal Caro province, hit central Chile during the ceremony.
March 11, 2011: An earthquake measuring 9.0 in magnitude strikes 130 km (81 mi) east of Sendai, Japan, triggering a tsunami killing thousands of people. This event also triggered the second largest nuclear accident in history, and one of only two events to be classified as a Level 7 on the International Nuclear Event Scale.
March 11, 2012: A U.S. soldier kills 16 civilians in the Panjwayi District of Afghanistan near Kandahar.
March 11, 2016: At least 21 people are killed by flooding and mudslides in and around São Paulo, Brazil, following heavy rain.
March 12, 538: Vitiges, king of the Ostrogoths ends his siege of Rome and retreats to Ravenna, leaving the city in the hands of the victorious Byzantine general, Belisarius
March 12, 1550: Several hundred Spanish and indigenous troops under the command of Pedro de Valdivia defeat an army of 60,000 Mapuche at the Battle of Penco during the Arauco War in present-day Chile.
March 12, 1622: Ignatius of Loyola and Francis Xavier, founders of the Society of Jesus, are canonized by the Roman Catholic Church.
March 12, 1672: Robert Holmes attacks a Dutch trade convoy, the Smyrna fleet, beginning the Rampjaar.
March 12, 1689: The Williamite War in Ireland begins.
March 12, 1881: Andrew Watson makes his Scotland debut as the world's first black international football player and captain.
March 12, 1894: Coca-Cola is bottled and sold for the first time in Vicksburg, Mississippi, by local soda fountain operator Joseph A. Biedenharn.
March 12, 1912: The Girl Guides (later renamed the Girl Scouts of the USA) are founded in the United States.
March 12, 1918: Moscow becomes the capital of Russia again after Saint Petersburg held this status for 215 years.
March 12, 1920: The Kapp Putsch begins when the Marinebrigade Ehrhardt is ordered to march on Berlin.
March 12, 1921: İstiklâl Marşı is adopted in the Grand National Assembly of Turkey.
March 12, 1922: Armenia, Georgia, and Azerbaijan form the Transcaucasian Socialist Federative Soviet Republic.
March 12, 1928: In California, the St. Francis Dam fails; the resulting floods kill 431 people.
March 12, 1930: Mahatma Gandhi begins the Salt March, a 200-mile march to the sea to protest the British monopoly on salt in India.
March 12, 1934: Konstantin Päts and General Johan Laidoner stage a coup in Estonia, and ban all political parties.
March 12, 1950: The Llandow air disaster occurs near Sigingstone, Wales, in which 80 people die when their aircraft crashed, making it the world's deadliest air disaster at the time.
March 12, 1961: First winter ascent of the North Face of the Eiger.
March 12, 1967: Suharto takes power from Sukarno when the MPRS inaugurate him as Acting President of Indonesia.
March 12, 1968: Mauritius achieves independence from the United Kingdom.
March 12, 1971: The March 12 Memorandum is sent to the Suleyman Demirel government of Turkey and the government resigns.
March 12, 1992: Mauritius becomes a republic while remaining a member of the Commonwealth of Nations.
March 12, 1993: Several bombs explode in Mumbai, India, killing about 300 and injuring hundreds more.
March 12, 1994: The Church of England ordains its first female priests.
March 12, 1999: Former Warsaw Pact members the Czech Republic, Hungary and Poland join NATO.
March 12, 2003: WHO officially release global warning on pandemic SARS disease.
March 12, 2009: Financier Bernard Madoff pleads guilty in New York to scamming $18 billion, the largest in Wall Street's history.
March 12, 2011: A reactor at the Fukushima Daiichi Nuclear Power Plant melts and explodes and releases radioactivity into the atmosphere a day after Japan's earthquake.
March 12, 2014: A gas explosion in the New York City neighborhood of East Harlem kills eight and injures 70 others.
March 12, 2019: In the House of Commons, the revised EU Withdrawal Bill was rejected by a margin of 149 votes.[1]
March 13, 874: The bones of Saint Nicephorus are interred in the Church of the Holy Apostles, Constantinople.
March 13, 1138: Cardinal Gregorio Conti is elected Antipope as Victor IV, succeeding Anacletus II.
March 13, 1567: The Battle of Oosterweel, traditionally regarded as the start of the Eighty Years' War, commences.
March 13, 1639: Harvard College is named after clergyman John Harvard.
March 13, 1697: Nojpetén, capital of the last independent Maya kingdom, fell to Spanish conquistadors, the final step in the Spanish conquest of Guatemala.
March 13, 1809: Gustav IV Adolf of Sweden is deposed in a coup d'état.
March 13, 1845: Felix Mendelssohn's Violin Concerto receives its première performance in Leipzig with Ferdinand David as soloist.
March 13, 1848: The German revolutions of 1848–49 begin in Vienna.
March 13, 1881: Alexander II of Russia is killed near his palace when a bomb is thrown at him (this is the Gregorian date; it was March 1 in the Julian calendar then in use in Russia).
March 13, 1884: The Siege of Khartoum begins. It lasts until January 26, 1885.
March 13, 1920: The Kapp Putsch briefly ousts the Weimar Republic government from Berlin.
March 13, 1921: Mongolia is proclaimed an independent monarchy, ruled by Russian military officer Roman von Ungern-Sternberg as a dictator.
March 13, 1930: The news of the discovery of Pluto is telegraphed to the Harvard College Observatory.
March 13, 1957: Cuban student revolutionaries storm the presidential palace in Havana in a failed attempt on the life of President Fulgencio Batista.
March 13, 1962: Lyman Lemnitzer, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, delivers a proposal, called Operation Northwoods, regarding performing terrorist attacks upon Guantanamo Bay Naval Base, to Secretary of Defense Robert McNamara. The proposal is scrapped and President John F. Kennedy removes Lemnitzer from his position.
March 13, 1979: The New Jewel Movement, headed by Maurice Bishop, ousts Prime Minister Eric Gairy in a nearly bloodless coup d'état in Grenada.
March 13, 1985: The Kenilworth Road riot takes place at an association football match at Kenilworth Road in Luton, England with disturbances before, during and after an FA Cup 6th Round tie between Luton Town F.C. and Millwall F.C..
March 13, 1988: The Seikan Tunnel, the longest undersea tunnel in the world, opens between Aomori and Hakodate, Japan.
March 13, 1991: The United States Department of Justice announces that Exxon has agreed to pay $1 billion for the clean-up of the Exxon Valdez oil spill in Alaska.
March 13, 1992: The Mw  6.7 Erzincan earthquake strikes eastern Turkey with a maximum Mercalli intensity of VIII (Severe). At least 498 were killed in this strike-slip event on the North Anatolian Fault.
March 13, 1997: The Phoenix Lights are seen over Phoenix, Arizona by hundreds of people, and by millions on television.
March 13, 2003: The journal Nature reports that 350,000-year-old footprints have been found in Italy.
March 13, 2008: Gold prices on the New York Mercantile Exchange hit $1,000 per ounce for the first time.
March 13, 2012: At least 28 people are killed in a bus crash in a motorway tunnel near the town of Sierre in the Swiss canton of Valais.
March 13, 2013: Pope Francis is elected, in the papal conclave, as the 266th Pope of the Catholic Church.
March 13, 2016: Three gunmen attack two hotels in the Ivory Coast town of Grand-Bassam, killing at least 18 people and injuring 33 others.
