March 14, 44 BC: Casca and Cassius decide, on the night before the Assassination of Julius Caesar, that Mark Antony should live.
March 14, 313: Emperor Jin Huaidi is executed by Liu Cong, ruler of the Xiongnu state (Han Zhao).
March 14, 1381: Chioggia concludes an alliance with Zadar and Trogir against Venice, which becomes changed in 1412 in Šibenik.
March 14, 1489: The Queen of Cyprus, Catherine Cornaro, sells her kingdom to Venice.
March 14, 1663: Otto von Guericke completes his book on Vacuum.
March 14, 1757: Admiral Sir John Byng is executed by firing squad aboard HMS Monarch for breach of the Articles of War.
March 14, 1794: Eli Whitney is granted a patent for the cotton gin.
March 14, 1885: The Mikado, a light opera by W. S. Gilbert and Arthur Sullivan, receives its first public performance in London.
March 14, 1900: The Gold Standard Act is ratified, placing United States currency on the gold standard.
March 14, 1903: Pelican Island National Wildlife Refuge is established by US President Theodore Roosevelt.
March 14, 1910: Lakeview Gusher, the largest U.S. oil well gusher near Bakersfield, California, vents to atmosphere.
March 14, 1931: Alam Ara, India's first talking film, is released.
March 14, 1936: The first all-sound film version of Show Boat opens at Radio City Music Hall.
March 14, 1939: Slovakia declares independence under German pressure.
March 14, 1942: Orvan Hess and John Bumstead became the first in the United States successfully to treat a patient, Anne Miller, using penicillin.
March 14, 1961: USAF Broken Arrow nuclear weapon mishap in B-52 crash near Yuba City, Ca.
March 14, 1964: A jury in Dallas finds Jack Ruby guilty of killing Lee Harvey Oswald, the assumed assassin of John F. Kennedy.
March 14, 1967: The body of U.S. President John F. Kennedy is moved to a permanent burial place at Arlington National Cemetery.[1]
March 14, 1978: The Israel Defense Forces invade and occupies southern Lebanon in Operation Litani.
March 14, 1979: In China, a Hawker Siddeley Trident crashes into a factory near Beijing, killing 44 and injuring at least 200.
March 14, 1980: In Poland, LOT Flight 7 crashes during final approach near Warsaw, killing 87 people, including a 14-man American boxing team.
March 14, 1982: The South African government bombs the headquarters of the African National Congress in London.[2]
March 14, 2006: Members of the Chadian military fail in an attempted coup d'état.
March 14, 2007: The Left Front government of West Bengal sends at least 3,000 police to Nandigram in an attempt to break Bhumi Uchhed Pratirodh Committee resistance there; the resulting clash leaves 14 dead.
March 14, 2008: A series of riots, protests, and demonstrations erupt in Lhasa and elsewhere in Tibet.
March 14, 2019: Cyclone Idai has swept through Mozambique, Malawi and Zimbabwe over the past few days, destroying almost everything in its path, causing devastating floods, killing and injuring thousands of people and ruining crops. More than 2.6 million people could be affected across the three countries, and the port city of Beira, which was hit on March 8 and is home to 500,000 people, is now an “island in the ocean”, almost completely cut off.[3]
March 15, 474 BC: Roman consul Gnaeus Manlius Vulso celebrates an ovation for concluding the war against Veii and securing a forty years' truce.[1]
March 15, 44 BC: Marcus Junius Brutus the Younger and his fellow conspirators, Gaius Cassius Longinus, Decimus Junius Brutus, and several other Roman senators, march to the Capitol following the assassination of Julius Caesar, but there is no response to their appeals to the population, who have left the streets in fear. Caesar's body remains in its place
March 15, 351: Constantius II elevates his cousin Gallus to Caesar, and puts him in charge of the Eastern part of the Roman Empire.
March 15, 493: Odoacer, the first barbarian King of Italy after the fall of the Western Roman Empire, is slain by Theoderic the Great, king of the Ostrogoths, while the two kings were feasting together.
March 15, 856: Michael III, emperor of the Byzantine Empire, overthrows the regency of his mother, empress Theodora (wife of Theophilos) with support of the Byzantine nobility.
March 15, 933: After a ten-year truce, German King Henry the Fowler defeats a Hungarian army at the Battle of Riade near the Unstrut river.
March 15, 1493: Christopher Columbus returns to Spain after his first trip to the Americas.
March 15, 1564: Mughal Emperor Akbar abolishes "jizya" (per capita tax).
March 15, 1672: Charles II of England issues the Royal Declaration of Indulgence.
March 15, 1783: In an emotional speech in Newburgh, New York, George Washington asks his officers not to support the Newburgh Conspiracy. The plea is successful and the threatened coup d'état never takes place.
March 15, 1819: French physicist Augustin Fresnel is adjudged the winner of the Grand Prix of the Académie des Sciences for his "Memoir on the Diffraction of Light", which verifies the Fresnel integrals, accounts for the limited extent to which light spreads into shadows, and thereby demolishes Newton's initial objection to the wave theory of light.
March 15, 1848: A revolution breaks out in Hungary. The Habsburg rulers are compelled to meet the demands of the Reform party.
March 15, 1874: France and Vietnam sign the Second Treaty of Saigon, further recognizing the full sovereignty of France over Cochinchina.
March 15, 1875: Archbishop of New York John McCloskey is named the first cardinal in the United States.
March 15, 1878: Restoration of the Scottish Catholic hierarchy, broken off back in 1603.
March 15, 1888: Start of the Anglo-Tibetan War of 1888.
March 15, 1916: United States President Woodrow Wilson sends 4,800 United States troops over the U.S.–Mexico border to pursue Pancho Villa.
March 15, 1917: Tsar Nicholas II of Russia abdicates the Russian throne ending the 304-year Romanov dynasty.
March 15, 1921: Talaat Pasha, former Grand Vizir of the Ottoman Empire and chief architect of the Armenian Genocide is assassinated in Berlin by a 23-year-old Armenian, Soghomon Tehlirian.
March 15, 1922: After Egypt gains nominal independence from the United Kingdom, Fuad I becomes King of Egypt.
March 15, 1926: The dictator Theodoros Pangalos is elected President of Greece without opposition.
March 15, 1927: The first Women's Boat Race between the University of Oxford and the University of Cambridge takes place on The Isis in Oxford.
March 15, 1931: SS Viking explodes off Newfoundland, killing 27 of the 147 on board.
March 15, 1933: Austrian Chancellor Engelbert Dollfuss keeps members of the National Council from convening, starting the Austrofascist dictatorship.
March 15, 1939: Carpatho-Ukraine declares itself an independent republic, but is annexed by Hungary the next day.
March 15, 1941: Philippine Airlines, the flag carrier of the Philippines takes its first flight between Manila (from Nielson Field) to Baguio City with a Beechcraft Model 18 making the airline the first and oldest commercial airline in Asia operating under its original name.
March 15, 1952: In Cilaos, Réunion, 1870 mm (73 inches) of rain falls in a 24-hour period, setting a new world record (March 15 through March 16).
March 15, 1961: At the 1961 Commonwealth Prime Ministers' Conference, South Africa announces that it will withdraw from the Commonwealth when the South African Constitution of 1961 comes into effect.
March 15, 1965: President Lyndon B. Johnson, responding to the Selma crisis, tells U.S. Congress "We shall overcome" while advocating the Voting Rights Act.
March 15, 1978: Somalia and Ethiopia signed a truce to end the Ethio-Somali War.
March 15, 1990: Mikhail Gorbachev is elected as the first President of the Soviet Union.
March 15, 2008: Stockpiles of obsolete ammunition explode at an ex-military ammunition depot in the village of Gërdec, Albania, killing 26 people. To date, no other tragedy has caused more deaths in post-World War II Albania.
March 15, 2011: Beginning of the Syrian Civil War.
March 15, 2019: 1.4 million young people in 123 countries go on strike to protest climate change.[2]
March 16, 934: Meng Zhixiang declares himself emperor and establishes Later Shu as a new state independent of Later Tang.
March 16, 1190: Massacre of Jews at Clifford's Tower, York.
March 16, 1244: Over 200 Cathars who refuse to recant are burned to death after the Fall of Montségur.[1]
March 16, 1322: The Battle of Boroughbridge takes place in the Despenser Wars.
March 16, 1521: Ferdinand Magellan reaches the island of Homonhon in the Philippines.
March 16, 1621: Samoset, a Mohegan, visited the settlers of Plymouth Colony and greets them, "Welcome, Englishmen! My name is Samoset."
March 16, 1660: The Long Parliament of England is dissolved so as to prepare for the new Convention Parliament.
March 16, 1689: The 23rd Regiment of Foot, or Royal Welch Fusiliers, is founded.
March 16, 1792: King Gustav III of Sweden is shot; he dies on March 29.
March 16, 1802: The Army Corps of Engineers is established to found and operate the United States Military Academy at West Point.
March 16, 1815: Prince Willem proclaims himself King of the United Kingdom of the Netherlands, the first constitutional monarch in the Netherlands.
March 16, 1818: In the Second Battle of Cancha Rayada, Spanish forces defeated Chileans under José de San Martín.
March 16, 1870: The first version of the overture fantasy Romeo and Juliet by Tchaikovsky receives its première performance.
March 16, 1872: The Wanderers F.C. won the first FA Cup, the oldest football competition in the world, beating Royal Engineers A.F.C. 1–0 at The Oval in Kennington, London.
March 16, 1894: Jules Massenet's opera Thaïs is first performed.
March 16, 1898: In Melbourne the representatives of five colonies adopted a constitution, which would become the basis of the Commonwealth of Australia.[2]
March 16, 1900: Sir Arthur Evans purchased the land around the ruins of Knossos, the largest Bronze Age archaeological site on Crete.
March 16, 1916: The 7th and 10th US cavalry regiments under John J. Pershing cross the US–Mexico border to join the hunt for Pancho Villa.
March 16, 1924: In accordance with the Treaty of Rome, Fiume becomes annexed as part of Italy.
March 16, 1925: An earthquake occurs in Yunnan, China.
March 16, 1935: Adolf Hitler orders Germany to rearm herself in violation of the Treaty of Versailles. Conscription is reintroduced to form the Wehrmacht.
March 16, 1936: Warmer-than-normal temperatures rapidly melt snow and ice on the upper Allegheny and Monongahela rivers, leading to a major flood in Pittsburgh.
March 16, 1939: From Prague Castle, Hitler proclaims Bohemia and Moravia a German protectorate.
March 16, 1940: First person killed (James Isbister) in a German bombing raid on the UK in World War II during a raid on Scapa Flow in the Orkney Islands.
March 16, 1945: Ninety percent of Würzburg, Germany is destroyed in only 20 minutes by British bombers, resulting in around 5,000 deaths.
March 16, 1958: The Ford Motor Company produces its 50 millionth automobile, the Thunderbird, averaging almost a million cars a year since the company's founding.
March 16, 1962: A Flying Tiger Line Super Constellation disappears in the western Pacific Ocean, with all 107 aboard missing and presumed dead.
March 16, 1966: Launch of Gemini 8, the 12th manned American space flight and first space docking with an Agena Target Vehicle.
March 16, 1968: General Motors produces its 100 millionth automobile, the Oldsmobile Toronado.
March 16, 1969: A Viasa McDonnell Douglas DC-9 crashes in Maracaibo, Venezuela, killing 155.
March 16, 1976: British Prime Minister Harold Wilson resigns, citing personal reasons.
March 16, 1977: Assassination of Kamal Jumblatt, the main leader of the anti-government forces in the Lebanese Civil War.
March 16, 1978: Supertanker Amoco Cadiz splits in two after running aground on the Portsall Rocks, three miles off the coast of Brittany, resulting in the largest oil spill in history at that time.
March 16, 1983: Demolition of the Ismaning radio transmitter, the last wooden radio tower in Germany.
March 16, 1984: William Buckley, the CIA station chief in Beirut, Lebanon, is kidnapped by Islamic fundamentalists. (He later dies in captivity.)
March 16, 1985: Associated Press newsman Terry Anderson is taken hostage in Beirut. He is released on December 4, 1991.
March 16, 1989: In Egypt, a 4400-year-old mummy is found near the Pyramid of Cheops.
March 16, 1991: The airplane carrying eight members of Reba McEntire's touring band crashed on the side of Otay Mountain.
March 16, 1995: Mississippi formally ratifies the Thirteenth Amendment, becoming the last state to approve the abolition of slavery. The Thirteenth Amendment was officially ratified in 1865.
March 16, 2001: A series of bomb blasts that took place in the city of Shijiazhuang, China killed 108 people and injured 38 others, was the biggest mass murder in China in decades.
March 16, 2003: American activist Rachel Corrie is killed in Rafah trying to obstruct the demolition of a home by being run over by a bulldozer.
March 16, 2005: Israel officially hands over Jericho to Palestinian control.
March 16, 2014: Crimea votes in a controversial referendum to secede from Ukraine to join Russia.
March 16, 2016: Two suicide bombers detonate their explosives at a mosque during morning prayer on the outskirts of Maiduguri, Nigeria, killing 22 and injuring 18.
March 17, 45 BC: In his last victory, Julius Caesar defeats the Pompeian forces of Titus Labienus and Pompey the Younger in the Battle of Munda.
March 17, 180: Commodus becomes sole emperor of the Roman Empire at the age of eighteen, following the death of his father, Marcus Aurelius.[1]
March 17, 455: Petronius Maximus becomes, with support of the Roman Senate, emperor of the Western Roman Empire; he forces Licinia Eudoxia, the widow of his predecessor, Valentinian III, to marry him.[2]
March 17, 1001: The Raja of Butuan in what is now the Philippines sends a tributary mission to the Song dynasty.
March 17, 1337: Edward, the Black Prince is made Duke of Cornwall, the first Duchy in England.
March 17, 1452: The Battle of Los Alporchones is fought in the context of the Spanish Reconquista between the Emirate of Granada and the combined forces of the Kingdom of Castile and Murcia resulting in a Christian victory.
March 17, 1560: Fort Coligny on Villegagnon Island in Rio de Janeiro is attacked and destroyed during the Portuguese campaign against France Antarctique.
March 17, 1677: The Siege of Valenciennes, during the Franco-Dutch War, ends with France's taking of the city.
March 17, 1805: The Italian Republic, with Napoleon as president, becomes the Kingdom of Italy, with Napoleon as King.
March 17, 1824: The Anglo-Dutch Treaty is signed in London, dividing the Malay archipelago. As a result, the Malay Peninsula is dominated by the British, while Sumatra and Java and surrounding areas are dominated by the Dutch.
March 17, 1842: The Relief Society of The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints is formed.
March 17, 1852: Annibale De Gasparis discovers in Naples the asteroid Psyche from the north dome of the Astronomical Observatory of Capodimonte
March 17, 1860: The First Taranaki War begins in Taranaki, New Zealand, a major phase of the New Zealand Wars.
March 17, 1861: The Kingdom of Italy is proclaimed.
March 17, 1891: SS Utopia collides with HMS Anson in the Bay of Gibraltar and sinks, killing 562 of the 880 passengers on board.
March 17, 1921: The Second Polish Republic adopts the March Constitution.
March 17, 1941: In Washington, D.C., the National Gallery of Art is officially opened by President Franklin D. Roosevelt.
March 17, 1945: The Ludendorff Bridge in Remagen, Germany, collapses, ten days after its capture.
March 17, 1947: First flight of the B-45 Tornado strategic bomber.
March 17, 1948: Belgium, France, Luxembourg, the Netherlands and the United Kingdom sign the Treaty of Brussels, a precursor to the North Atlantic Treaty establishing NATO.
March 17, 1950: Researchers at the University of California, Berkeley announce the creation of element 98, which they name "californium".
March 17, 1957: A plane crash in Cebu, Philippines kills Philippine President Ramon Magsaysay and 24 others.
March 17, 1958: The United States launches the Vanguard 1 satellite.
March 17, 1959: Tenzin Gyatso, the 14th Dalai Lama, flees Tibet for India.
March 17, 1960: U.S. President Dwight D. Eisenhower signs the National Security Council directive on the anti-Cuban covert action program that will ultimately lead to the Bay of Pigs Invasion.
March 17, 1963: Mount Agung erupted on Bali killing more than 1,100 people.
March 17, 1966: Off the coast of Spain in the Mediterranean, the DSV Alvin submarine finds a missing American hydrogen bomb.
March 17, 1968: As a result of nerve gas testing in Skull Valley, Utah, over 6,000 sheep are found dead.
March 17, 1969: Golda Meir becomes the first female Prime Minister of Israel.
March 17, 1973: The Pulitzer Prize-winning photograph Burst of Joy is taken, depicting a former prisoner of war being reunited with his family, which came to symbolize the end of United States involvement in the Vietnam War.
March 17, 1979: The Penmanshiel Tunnel collapses during engineering works, killing two workers.
March 17, 1985: Serial killer Richard Ramirez, aka the "Night Stalker", commits the first two murders in his Los Angeles murder spree.
March 17, 1988: A Colombian Boeing 727 jetliner, Avianca Flight 410, crashes into a mountainside near the Venezuelan border killing 143.
March 17, 1992: A referendum to end apartheid in South Africa is passed 68.7% to 31.2%.
March 17, 2000: Five hundred thirty members of the Ugandan cult Movement for the Restoration of the Ten Commandments of God die in a fire, considered to be a mass murder or suicide orchestrated by leaders of the cult. Elsewhere another 248 members are later found dead.
March 17, 2003: Secretary of State for Foreign and Commonwealth Affairs Robin Cook, resigns from the British Cabinet in disagreement with government plans for the 2003 invasion of Iraq.
March 18, 1068: An earthquake in the Levant and the Arabian Peninsula, leaves up to 20,000 dead.
March 18, 1229: Frederick II, Holy Roman Emperor, declares himself King of Jerusalem in the Sixth Crusade.
March 18, 1314: Jacques de Molay, the 23rd and final Grand Master of the Knights Templar, is burned at the stake.
March 18, 1438: Albert II of Habsburg becomes Holy Roman Emperor.
March 18, 1608: Susenyos is formally crowned Emperor of Ethiopia.
March 18, 1644: The Third Anglo-Powhatan War begins in the Colony of Virginia.
March 18, 1741: New York governor George Clarke's complex at Fort George is burned in an arson attack, starting the New York Conspiracy of 1741.
March 18, 1793: Flanders Campaign of the French Revolution, Battle of Neerwinden.
March 18, 1834: Six farm labourers from Tolpuddle, Dorset, England are sentenced to be transported to Australia for forming a trade union.
March 18, 1850: American Express is founded by Henry Wells and William Fargo.
March 18, 1871: Declaration of the Paris Commune; President of the French Republic, Adolphe Thiers, orders the evacuation of Paris.
March 18, 1874: Hawaii signs a treaty with the United States granting exclusive trade rights.
March 18, 1892: Former Governor General Lord Stanley pledges to donate a silver challenge cup as an award for the best hockey team in Canada; it was later named after him as the Stanley Cup.
March 18, 1902: Macario Sakay issues Presidential Order No. 1 of his Tagalog Republic.[1]
March 18, 1913: King George I of Greece is assassinated in the recently liberated city of Thessaloniki.
March 18, 1921: The second Peace of Riga is signed between Poland and the Soviet Union.
March 18, 1922: In India, Mohandas Gandhi is sentenced to six years in prison for civil disobedience, of which he serves only two.
March 18, 1925: The Tri-State Tornado hits the Midwestern states of Missouri, Illinois, and Indiana, killing 695 people.
March 18, 1937: The New London School explosion in New London, Texas, kills 300 people, mostly children.
March 18, 1938: Mexico creates Pemex by expropriating all foreign-owned oil reserves and facilities.
March 18, 1942: The War Relocation Authority is established in the United States to take Japanese Americans into custody.
March 18, 1944: Mount Vesuvius in Naples, Italy erupts killing 26 people and causing thousands to flee their homes.
March 18, 1948: Soviet consultants leave Yugoslavia in the first sign of the Tito–Stalin Split.
March 18, 1953: An earthquake hits western Turkey, killing 265 people.
March 18, 1959: The Hawaii Admission Act is signed into law.
March 18, 1962: The Évian Accords end the Algerian War of Independence, which had begun in 1954.
March 18, 1965: Cosmonaut Alexei Leonov, leaving his spacecraft Voskhod 2 for 12 minutes, becomes the first person to walk in space.
March 18, 1967: The supertanker Torrey Canyon runs aground off the Cornish coast.
March 18, 1969: The United States begins secretly bombing the Sihanouk Trail in Cambodia, used by communist forces to infiltrate South Vietnam.
March 18, 1970: Lon Nol ousts Prince Norodom Sihanouk of Cambodia.
March 18, 1980: A Vostok-2M rocket at Plesetsk Cosmodrome Site 43 explodes during a fueling operation, killing 48 people.
March 18, 1990: In the largest art theft in US history, 12 paintings, collectively worth around $500 million, are stolen from the Isabella Stewart Gardner Museum in Boston.[2]
March 18, 1994: Bosnia's Bosniaks and Croats sign the Washington Agreement, ending war between the Croatian Republic of Herzeg-Bosnia and the Republic of Bosnia and Herzegovina, and establishing the Federation of Bosnia and Herzegovina.
March 18, 1996: A nightclub fire in Quezon City, Philippines kills 162 people.
March 18, 1997: The tail of a Russian Antonov An-24 charter plane breaks off while en route to Turkey causing the plane to crash and killing all 50 people on board.
March 18, 2014: The parliaments of Russia and Crimea sign an accession treaty.
March 18, 2015: The Bardo National Museum in Tunisia is attacked by gunmen. 23 people, almost all tourists, are killed, and at least 50 other people are wounded.
March 19, 1279: A Mongol victory at the Battle of Yamen ends the Song dynasty in China.
March 19, 1284: The Statute of Rhuddlan incorporates the Principality of Wales into England.[1]
March 19, 1563: The Edict of Amboise is signed, ending the first phase of the French Wars of Religion and granting certain freedoms to the Huguenots.
March 19, 1649: The House of Commons of England passes an act abolishing the House of Lords, declaring it "useless and dangerous to the people of England".
March 19, 1687: Explorer Robert Cavelier de La Salle, searching for the mouth of the Mississippi River, is murdered by his own men.
March 19, 1812: The Cádiz Cortes promulgates the Spanish Constitution of 1812.
March 19, 1853: The Taiping reform movement occupies and makes Nanjing its capital until 1864.
March 19, 1861: The First Taranaki War ends in New Zealand.
March 19, 1863: The SS Georgiana, said to have been the most powerful Confederate cruiser, is destroyed on her maiden voyage with a cargo of munitions, medicines and merchandise then valued at over $1,000,000.
March 19, 1885: Louis Riel declares a provisional government in Saskatchewan, beginning the North-West Rebellion.
March 19, 1895: Auguste and Louis Lumière record their first footage using their newly patented cinematograph.
March 19, 1918: The U.S. Congress establishes time zones and approves daylight saving time.
March 19, 1920: The United States Senate rejects the Treaty of Versailles for the second time (the first time was on November 19, 1919).
March 19, 1932: The Sydney Harbour Bridge is opened.
March 19, 1943: Frank Nitti, the Chicago Outfit Boss after Al Capone, commits suicide at the Chicago Central Railyard.
March 19, 1946: French Guiana, Guadeloupe, Martinique and Réunion become overseas départements of France.
March 19, 1954: Willie Mosconi sets a world record by running 526 consecutive balls without a miss during a straight pool exhibition at East High Billiard Club in Springfield, Ohio, setting a record which remains unbroken.
March 19, 1958: The Monarch Underwear Company fire leaves 24 dead and 15 injured.
March 19, 1964: Over 500,000 Brazilians attend the March of the Family with God for Liberty, in protest against the government of João Goulart and against Communism.
March 19, 1965: The wreck of the SS Georgiana, valued at over $50,000,000 and said to have been the most powerful Confederate cruiser, is discovered by teenage diver and pioneer underwater archaeologist E. Lee Spence, exactly 102 years after its destruction.
March 19, 1966: Texas Western becomes the first college basketball team to win the Final four with an all-black starting lineup.
March 19, 1969: The 385 metres (1,263 ft) tall TV-mast at Emley Moor transmitting station, United Kingdom, collapses due to ice build-up.
March 19, 1979: The United States House of Representatives begins broadcasting its day-to-day business via the cable television network C-SPAN.
March 19, 1987: Televangelist Jim Bakker resigns as head of the PTL Club due to a brewing sex scandal; he hands over control to Jerry Falwell.
March 19, 1989: The Egyptian flag is raised at Taba marking the end of Israeli occupation since the Six Days War in 1967 and the Egypt–Israel Peace Treaty in 1979.
March 19, 1990: The ethnic clashes of Târgu Mureș begin four days after the anniversary of the Revolutions of 1848 in the Austrian Empire.
March 19, 2002: Zimbabwe is suspended from the Commonwealth on charges of human rights abuses and of electoral fraud, following a turbulent presidential election.
March 19, 2013: A series of bombings and shootings kills at least 98 people and injures 240 others across Iraq.
March 19, 2016: An explosion occurs in Taksim Square in Istanbul, Turkey, killing five people and injuring 36.
March 19, 2018: The last male northern white rhinoceros, Sudan, dies, ensuring a chance of extinction for the species.
March 20, 673: Emperor Tenmu of Japan assumes the Chrysanthemum Throne at the Palace of Kiyomihara in Asuka.
March 20, 1206: Michael IV Autoreianos is appointed Ecumenical Patriarch of Constantinople.
March 20, 1602: The Dutch East India Company is established.
March 20, 1616: Sir Walter Raleigh is freed from the Tower of London after 13 years of imprisonment.
March 20, 1760: The Great Boston Fire of 1760 destroys 349 buildings.
March 20, 1815: After escaping from Elba, Napoleon enters Paris with a regular army of 140,000 and a volunteer force of around 200,000, beginning his "Hundred Days" rule.
March 20, 1852: Harriet Beecher Stowe's Uncle Tom's Cabin is published.
March 20, 1854: The Republican Party of the United States is organized in Ripon, Wisconsin.
March 20, 1883: The Paris Convention for the Protection of Industrial Property is signed.
March 20, 1888: The premiere of the very first Romani language operetta is staged in Moscow, Russia.
March 20, 1890: Prime minister of the German Empire Otto von Bismarck is dismissed by Emperor Wilhelm II.
March 20, 1896: With the approval of Emperor Guangxu, the Qing dynasty post office is opened, marking the beginning of a postal service in China.
March 20, 1913: Sung Chiao-jen, a founder of the Chinese Nationalist Party, is wounded in an assassination attempt and dies 2 days later.
March 20, 1915: Albert Einstein publishes his general theory of relativity.
March 20, 1921: The Upper Silesia plebiscite was a plebiscite mandated by the Versailles Treaty to determine a section of the border between Weimar Germany and Poland.
March 20, 1922: The USS Langley is commissioned as the first United States Navy aircraft carrier.
March 20, 1923: The Arts Club of Chicago hosts the opening of Pablo Picasso's first United States showing, entitled Original Drawings by Pablo Picasso, becoming an early proponent of modern art in the United States.
March 20, 1933: Reichsführer-SS Heinrich Himmler ordered the creation of Dachau concentration camp as Chief of Police of Munich and appointed Theodor Eicke as the camp commandant.
March 20, 1948: With a Musicians Union ban lifted, the first telecasts of classical music in the United States, under Eugene Ormandy and Arturo Toscanini, are given on CBS and NBC.
March 20, 1951: Fujiyoshida, a city located in Yamanashi Prefecture, Japan, in the center of the Japanese main island of Honshū is founded.
March 20, 1952: The US Senate ratifies the Security Treaty Between the United States and Japan.
March 20, 1964: The precursor of the European Space Agency, ESRO (European Space Research Organisation) is established per an agreement signed on June 14, 1962.
March 20, 1985: Canadian paraplegic athlete and humanitarian Rick Hansen begins his circumnavigation of the globe in a wheelchair in the name of spinal cord injury medical research.
March 20, 1987: The Food and Drug Administration approves the anti-AIDS drug, AZT.
March 20, 1990: Ferdinand Marcos's widow, Imelda Marcos, goes on trial for bribery, embezzlement, and racketeering.
March 20, 1995: The Japanese cult Aum Shinrikyo carries out a sarin gas attack on the Tokyo subway, killing 13 and wounding over 6,200 people.
March 20, 1999: Legoland California, the first Legoland outside of Europe, opens in Carlsbad, California.
March 20, 2000: Jamil Abdullah Al-Amin, a former Black Panther once known as H. Rap Brown, is captured after murdering Georgia sheriff's deputy Ricky Kinchen and critically wounding Deputy Aldranon English.
March 20, 2006: Over 150 Chadian soldiers are killed in eastern Chad by members of the rebel UFDC. The rebel movement sought to overthrow Chadian president Idriss Déby.
March 20, 2012: At least 52 people are killed and more than 250 injured in a wave of terror attacks across ten cities in Iraq.
March 20, 2014: Four suspected Taliban members attack the luxurious Kabul Serena Hotel, killing at least nine people.
March 20, 2015: A Solar eclipse, equinox, and a Supermoon all occur on the same day.
March 21, 630: Emperor Heraclius returns the True Cross, one of the holiest Christian relics, to Jerusalem.
March 21, 717: Battle of Vincy between Charles Martel and Ragenfrid.
March 21, 1152: Annulment of the marriage of King Louis VII of France and Queen Eleanor of Aquitaine.
March 21, 1188: Emperor Antoku accedes to the throne of Japan.
March 21, 1556: On the day of his execution in Oxford, former Archbishop of Canterbury Thomas Cranmer deviates from the scripted sermon by renouncing the recantations he has made and adds, "And as for the pope, I refuse him, as Christ's enemy, and Antichrist with all his false doctrine."[1]
March 21, 1788: A fire in New Orleans leaves most of the town in ruins.[2]
March 21, 1800: With the church leadership driven out of Rome during an armed conflict, Pius VII is crowned Pope in Venice with a temporary papal tiara made of papier-mâché.
March 21, 1801: The Battle of Alexandria is fought between British and French forces near the ruins of Nicopolis near Alexandria in Egypt.
March 21, 1804: Code Napoléon is adopted as French civil law.
March 21, 1844: The Bahá'í calendar begins. This is the first day of the first year of the Bahá'í calendar. It is annually celebrated by members of the Bahá'í Faith as the Bahá'í New Year or Náw-Rúz.
March 21, 1861: Alexander Stephens gives the Cornerstone Speech.
March 21, 1871: Journalist Henry Morton Stanley begins his trek to find the missionary and explorer David Livingstone.
March 21, 1913: Over 360 are killed and 20,000 homes destroyed in the Great Dayton Flood in Dayton, Ohio.
March 21, 1919: The Hungarian Soviet Republic is established becoming the first Communist government to be formed in Europe after the October Revolution in Russia.
March 21, 1921: The New Economic Policy is implemented by the Bolshevik Party in response to the economic failure as a result of war communism.
March 21, 1925: Syngman Rhee is removed from office after being impeached as the President of the Provisional Government of the Republic of Korea.
March 21, 1928: Charles Lindbergh is presented with the Medal of Honor for the first solo trans-Atlantic flight.
March 21, 1935: Shah of Iran Reza Shah Pahlavi formally asks the international community to call Persia by its native name, Iran.
March 21, 1943: Wehrmacht officer Rudolf von Gersdorff plots to assassinate Adolf Hitler by using a suicide bomb, but the plan falls through; von Gersdorff is able to defuse the bomb in time and avoid suspicion.
March 21, 1946: The Los Angeles Rams sign Kenny Washington, making him the first African American player in professional American football since 1933.
March 21, 1952: Alan Freed presents the Moondog Coronation Ball, the first rock and roll concert, in Cleveland, Ohio.
March 21, 1965: Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr. leads 3,200 people on the start of the third and finally successful civil rights march from Selma to Montgomery, Alabama.
March 21, 1968: Battle of Karameh in Jordan between the Israel Defense Forces and the combined forces of the Jordanian Armed Forces and PLO.
March 21, 1970: The first Earth Day proclamation is issued by Joseph Alioto, Mayor of San Francisco.
March 21, 1980: U.S. President Jimmy Carter announces a United States boycott of the 1980 Summer Olympics in Moscow to protest the Soviet–Afghan War.
March 21, 1983: The first cases of the 1983 West Bank fainting epidemic begin; Israelis and Palestinians accuse each other of poison gas, but the cause is later determined mostly to be psychosomatic.
March 21, 1986: Debi Thomas became the first African American to win the World Figure Skating Championships
March 21, 1990: Namibia becomes independent after 75 years of South African rule.
March 21, 1994: The United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change enters into force.
March 21, 1999: Bertrand Piccard and Brian Jones become the first to circumnavigate the Earth in a hot air balloon.
March 21, 2000: Pope John Paul II makes his first ever pontifical visit to Israel.
March 21, 2006: The social media site Twitter is founded.
March 21, 2009: Four police officers are shot and killed and a fifth is wounded in two shootings at Oakland, California.
March 21, 2019: Jiangsu Tianjiayi chemical plant in China explodes, killing at least 47 people and injuring 640 others. [3]
March 22, 238: Gordian I and his son Gordian II are proclaimed Roman emperors.
March 22, 871: Æthelred of Wessex is defeated by a Danish invasion army at the Battle of Marton.
March 22, 1508: Ferdinand II of Aragon commissions Amerigo Vespucci chief navigator of the Spanish Empire.
March 22, 1621: The Pilgrims of Plymouth Colony sign a peace treaty with Massasoit of the Wampanoags.
March 22, 1630: The Massachusetts Bay Colony outlaws the possession of cards, dice, and gaming tables.
March 22, 1638: Anne Hutchinson is expelled from Massachusetts Bay Colony for religious dissent.
March 22, 1713: The Tuscarora War comes to an end with the fall of Fort Neoheroka, effectively opening up the interior of North Carolina to European colonization.
March 22, 1739: Nader Shah occupies Delhi in India and sacks the city, stealing the jewels of the Peacock Throne.
March 22, 1765: The British Parliament passes the Stamp Act that introduces a tax to be levied directly on its American colonies.
March 22, 1784: The Emerald Buddha is moved with great ceremony to its current location in Wat Phra Kaew, Thailand.
March 22, 1829: In the London Protocol, the three protecting powers (United Kingdom, France and Russia) establish the borders of Greece.
March 22, 1849: The Austrians defeat the Piedmontese at the Battle of Novara.
March 22, 1871: In North Carolina, William Woods Holden becomes the first governor of a U.S. state to be removed from office by impeachment.
March 22, 1872: Illinois becomes the first state to require gender equality in employment.
March 22, 1873: The Spanish National Assembly abolishes slavery in Puerto Rico.
March 22, 1894: The first playoff game for the Stanley Cup starts.
March 22, 1906: The first England vs France rugby union match is played at Parc des Princes in Paris
March 22, 1916: The last Emperor of China, Yuan Shikai, abdicates the throne and the Republic of China is restored.
March 22, 1920: Azeri and Turkish army soldiers with participation of Kurdish gangs attacked the Armenian inhabitants of Shushi (Nagorno Karabakh).
March 22, 1945: The Arab League is founded when a charter is adopted in Cairo, Egypt.
March 22, 1960: Arthur Leonard Schawlow and Charles Hard Townes receive the first patent for a laser.
March 22, 1972: In Eisenstadt v. Baird, the United States Supreme Court decides that unmarried persons have the right to possess contraceptives.
March 22, 1975: A fire at the Browns Ferry Nuclear Power Plant in Decatur, Alabama causes a dangerous reduction in cooling water levels.
March 22, 1978: Karl Wallenda of The Flying Wallendas dies after falling off a tight-rope suspended between two hotels in San Juan, Puerto Rico.
March 22, 1982: NASA's Space Shuttle Columbia is launched from the Kennedy Space Center on its third mission, STS-3.
March 22, 1992: USAir Flight 405 crashes shortly after takeoff from New York City's LaGuardia Airport, leading to a number of studies into the effect that ice has on aircraft.
March 22, 1993: The Intel Corporation ships the first Pentium chips (80586), featuring a 60 MHz clock speed, 100+ MIPS, and a 64 bit data path.
March 22, 1995: Cosmonaut Valeri Polyakov returns to earth after setting a record of 438 days in space.
March 22, 1997: Tara Lipinski, aged 14 years and nine months, becomes the youngest women's World Figure Skating Champion.
March 22, 2004: Ahmed Yassin, co-founder and leader of the Palestinian Sunni Islamist group Hamas, two bodyguards, and nine civilian bystanders are killed in the Gaza Strip when hit by Israeli Air Force Hellfire missiles.
March 22, 2006: Three Christian Peacemaker Team (CPT) hostages are freed by British forces in Baghdad after 118 days of captivity and the murder of their colleague from the U.S., Tom Fox.
March 22, 2013: At least 37 people are killed and 200 are injured after a fire destroys a camp containing Burmese refugees near Ban Mae, Thailand.
March 22, 2016: Three suicide bombers kill 32 people and injure 316 in the 2016 Brussels bombings at the airport and at the Maelbeek/Maalbeek metro station.
March 22, 2017: A terrorist attack in London near the Houses of Parliament leaves four people dead and at least 20 injured.
March 22, 2019: Two buses crashes in Kitampo, a town north of Ghana's capital Accra killing at least 50 people. [1]
March 23, 1400: The Trần dynasty of Vietnam is deposed, after one hundred and seventy-five years of rule, by Hồ Quý Ly, a court official.
March 23, 1540: Waltham Abbey is surrendered to King Henry VIII of England; the last religious community to be closed during the Dissolution of the Monasteries.
March 23, 1568: The Peace of Longjumeau is signed, ending the second phase of the French Wars of Religion.
March 23, 1708: James Francis Edward Stuart lands at the Firth of Forth as part of the planned French invasion of Britain.[1]
March 23, 1801: Tsar Paul I of Russia is struck with a sword, then strangled, and finally trampled to death inside his bedroom at St. Michael's Castle.
March 23, 1806: After traveling through the Louisiana Purchase and reaching the Pacific Ocean, explorers Lewis and Clark and their "Corps of Discovery" begin their arduous journey home.
March 23, 1848: The ship John Wickliffe arrives at Port Chalmers carrying the first Scottish settlers for Dunedin, New Zealand. Otago province is founded.
March 23, 1857: Elisha Otis's first elevator is installed at 488 Broadway New York City.
March 23, 1862: American Civil War – The First Battle of Kernstown, Virginia, marks the start of Stonewall Jackson's Valley Campaign. Although a Confederate defeat, the engagement distracts Federal efforts to capture Richmond.
March 23, 1868: The University of California is founded in Oakland, California when the Organic Act is signed into law.
March 23, 1888: In England, The Football League, the world's oldest professional association football league, meets for the first time.
March 23, 1889: The Ahmadiyya Muslim Community is established by Mirza Ghulam Ahmad in Qadian, British India.
March 23, 1901: Emilio Aguinaldo, only President of the First Philippine Republic, was captured at Palanan, Isabela by the forces of General Frederick Funston.
March 23, 1905: Eleftherios Venizelos calls for Crete's union with Greece, and begins what is to be known as the Theriso revolt.
March 23, 1909: Theodore Roosevelt leaves New York for a post-presidency safari in Africa. The trip is sponsored by the Smithsonian Institution and National Geographic Society.
March 23, 1919: In Milan, Italy, Benito Mussolini founds his Fascist political movement.
March 23, 1931: Bhagat Singh, Shivaram Rajguru and Sukhdev Thapar are hanged for the killing of a deputy superintendent of police during the Indian struggle for independence.
March 23, 1933: The Reichstag passes the Enabling Act of 1933, making Adolf Hitler dictator of Germany.
March 23, 1935: Signing of the Constitution of the Commonwealth of the Philippines.
March 23, 1939: The Hungarian air force attacks the headquarters of the Slovak air force in Spišská Nová Ves, killing 13 people and beginning the Slovak–Hungarian War.
March 23, 1940: The Lahore Resolution (Qarardad-e-Pakistan or Qarardad-e-Lahore) is put forward at the Annual General Convention of the All-India Muslim League.
March 23, 1956: Pakistan becomes the first Islamic republic in the world. This date is now celebrated as Republic Day in Pakistan.
March 23, 1977: The first of The Nixon Interviews (12 will be recorded over four weeks) is videotaped with British journalist David Frost interviewing former United States President Richard Nixon about the Watergate scandal and the Nixon tapes.
March 23, 1978: The first UNIFIL troops arrived in Lebanon for peacekeeping mission along the Blue Line.
March 23, 1980: Archbishop Óscar Romero of El Salvador gives his famous speech appealing to men of the El Salvadoran armed forces to stop killing the Salvadorans.
March 23, 1982: Guatemala's government, headed by Fernando Romeo Lucas García is overthrown in a military coup by right-wing General Efraín Ríos Montt.
March 23, 1991: The Revolutionary United Front, with support from the special forces of Charles Taylor's National Patriotic Front of Liberia, invades Sierra Leone in an attempt to overthrow Joseph Saidu Momoh, sparking the 11-year Sierra Leone Civil War.
March 23, 1994: Aeroflot Flight 593 crashed into the Kuznetsk Alatau mountain, Kemerovo Oblast, Russia, killing 75.
March 23, 1996: Taiwan holds its first direct elections and chooses Lee Teng-hui as President.
March 23, 1999: Gunmen assassinate Paraguay's Vice President Luis María Argaña.
March 23, 2001: The Russian Mir space station is disposed of, breaking up in the atmosphere before falling into the southern Pacific Ocean near Fiji.
March 23, 2003: Battle of Nasiriyah, first major conflict during the invasion of Iraq.
March 23, 2008: Official opening of Rajiv Gandhi International Airport in Hyderabad, India
March 23, 2019: The US-backed Syrian Democratic Forces declared military victory over the Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant after four years of fighting, although the group maintains a scattered presence and sleeper cells across Syria and Iraq.[2]
March 24, 1387: English victory over a Franco-Castilian-Flemish fleet in the Battle of Margate off the coast of Margate.[1]
March 24, 1603: Tokugawa Ieyasu is granted the title of shōgun from Emperor Go-Yōzei, and establishes the Tokugawa shogunate in Edo, Japan.
March 24, 1663: The Province of Carolina is granted by charter to eight Lords Proprietor in reward for their assistance in restoring Charles II of England to the throne.
March 24, 1720: Count Frederick of Hesse-Kassel is elected King of Sweden by the Riksdag of the Estates, after his consort Ulrika Eleonora abdicated the throne on 29 February
March 24, 1721: Johann Sebastian Bach dedicated six concertos to Margrave Christian Ludwig of Brandenburg-Schwedt, now commonly called the Brandenburg Concertos, BWV 1046–1051.
March 24, 1731: Naturalization of Hieronimus de Salis Parliamentary Act is passed.
March 24, 1765: Great Britain passes the Quartering Act, which requires the Thirteen Colonies to house British troops.
March 24, 1794: In Kraków, Tadeusz Kościuszko announces a general uprising against Imperial Russia and the Kingdom of Prussia, and assumes the powers of the Commander in Chief of all of the Polish forces.
March 24, 1829: The Parliament of the United Kingdom passes the Roman Catholic Relief Act 1829, allowing Catholics to serve in Parliament.
March 24, 1832: In Hiram, Ohio, a group of men beat and tar and feather Mormon leader Joseph Smith.
March 24, 1837: Canada gives African Canadian men the right to vote.
March 24, 1869: The last of Titokowaru's forces surrendered to the New Zealand government, ending his uprising.
March 24, 1878: The British frigate HMS Eurydice sinks, killing more than 300.
March 24, 1882: Robert Koch announces the discovery of Mycobacterium tuberculosis, the bacterium responsible for tuberculosis.
March 24, 1896: A. S. Popov makes the first radio signal transmission in history.
March 24, 1900: Mayor of New York City Robert Anderson Van Wyck breaks ground for a new underground "Rapid Transit Railroad" that would link Manhattan and Brooklyn.
March 24, 1907: The first issue of the Georgian Bolshevik newspaper Dro is published.
March 24, 1921: The 1921 Women's Olympiad begins in Monte Carlo, first international women's sports event.
March 24, 1933: The Enabling Act passed in both the Reichstag and Reichsrat.
March 24, 1934: United States Congress passes the Tydings–McDuffie Act, allowing the Philippines to become a self-governing commonwealth.
March 24, 1946: A British Cabinet Mission arrives in India to discuss and plan for the transfer of power from the British Raj to Indian leadership.
March 24, 1958: Rock 'n' roll teen idol Elvis Presley is drafted in the U.S. Army.
March 24, 1961: Quebec Board of the French Language is established.
March 24, 1965: Images from the Ranger 9 lunar probe are broadcast live on network television.
March 24, 1973: Kenyan athlete Kip Keino defeats Jim Ryun at the first-ever professional track meet in Los Angeles.
March 24, 1976: In Argentina, the armed forces overthrow the constitutional government of President Isabel Perón and start a 7-year dictatorial period self-styled the National Reorganization Process.
March 24, 1977: Morarji Desai became the Prime Minister of India, the first Prime Minister not to belong to Indian National Congress.
March 24, 1980: El Salvadorian Archbishop Óscar Romero is assassinated while celebrating Mass in San Salvador.
March 24, 1986: The Loscoe gas explosion leads to new UK laws on landfill gas migration and gas protection on landfill sites.
March 24, 1989: In Prince William Sound in Alaska, the Exxon Valdez spills 240,000 barrels (38,000 m3) of crude oil after running aground.
March 24, 1998: First computer-assisted Bone Segment Navigation, performed at the University of Regensburg, Germany
March 24, 1999: A lorry carrying margarine and flour catches fire inside the Mont Blanc Tunnel. The resulting inferno kills 38 people.
March 24, 2003: The Arab League votes 21–1 in favor of a resolution demanding the immediate and unconditional removal of U.S. and British soldiers from Iraq.
March 24, 2008: Bhutan officially becomes a democracy, with its first ever general election.
March 24, 2015: Germanwings Flight 9525 crashes in the French Alps in an apparent pilot mass murder-suicide, killing all 150 people on board.
March 25, 708: Pope Constantine succeeds Pope Sisinnius as the 88th pope.
March 25, 717: Theodosius III resigns the throne to the Byzantine Empire to enter the clergy.
March 25, 919: Romanos Lekapenos seizes the Boukoleon Palace in Constantinople and becomes regent of the Byzantine emperor Constantine VII.
March 25, 1000: Fatimid caliph al-Hakim bi-Amr Allah assassinates the eunuch chief minister Barjawan and assumes control of the government.
March 25, 1199: Richard I is wounded by a crossbow bolt while fighting France, leading to his death on April 6.
March 25, 1306: Robert the Bruce becomes King of Scots (Scotland).
March 25, 1555: The city of Valencia is founded in present-day Venezuela.
March 25, 1576: Jerome Savage takes out a sub-lease to start the Newington Butts Theatre outside London.
March 25, 1584: Sir Walter Raleigh is granted a patent to colonize Virginia.
March 25, 1655: Saturn's largest moon, Titan, is discovered by Christiaan Huygens.
March 25, 1802: The Treaty of Amiens is signed as a "Definitive Treaty of Peace" between France and the United Kingdom.
March 25, 1807: The Swansea and Mumbles Railway, then known as the Oystermouth Railway, becomes the first passenger-carrying railway in the world.
March 25, 1811: Percy Bysshe Shelley is expelled from the University of Oxford for publishing the pamphlet The Necessity of Atheism.
March 25, 1821: Traditional date of the start of the Greek War of Independence. The war had actually begun on 23 February 1821 (Julian calendar).
March 25, 1845: New Zealand Legislative Council pass the first Militia Act constituting the New Zealand Army.[1]
March 25, 1894: Coxey's Army, the first significant American protest march, departs Massillon, Ohio for Washington, D.C.
March 25, 1911: In New York City, the Triangle Shirtwaist Factory fire kills 146 garment workers.
March 25, 1917: The Georgian Orthodox Church restores its autocephaly abolished by Imperial Russia in 1811.
March 25, 1918: The Belarusian People's Republic is established.
March 25, 1924: On the anniversary of Greek Independence, Alexandros Papanastasiou proclaims the Second Hellenic Republic.
March 25, 1931: The Scottsboro Boys are arrested in Alabama and charged with rape.
March 25, 1941: The Kingdom of Yugoslavia joins the Axis powers with the signing of the Tripartite Pact.
March 25, 1947: An explosion in a coal mine in Centralia, Illinois kills 111.
March 25, 1948: The first successful tornado forecast predicts that a tornado will strike Tinker Air Force Base, Oklahoma.
March 25, 1949: More than 92,000 kulaks are suddenly deported from the Baltic states to Siberia.
March 25, 1957: The European Economic Community is established with West Germany, France, Italy, Belgium, Netherlands and Luxembourg as the first members.
March 25, 1965: Civil rights activists led by Martin Luther King Jr. successfully complete their 4-day 50-mile march from Selma to the capitol in Montgomery, Alabama.
March 25, 1969: During their honeymoon, John Lennon and Yoko Ono hold their first Bed-In for Peace at the Amsterdam Hilton Hotel (until March 31).
March 25, 1971: The Army of the Republic of Vietnam abandon an attempt to cut off the Ho Chi Minh trail in Laos.
March 25, 1975: Faisal of Saudi Arabia is shot and killed by a mentally ill nephew.
March 25, 1979: The first fully functional Space Shuttle orbiter, Columbia, is delivered to the John F. Kennedy Space Center to be prepared for its first launch.
March 25, 1988: The Candle demonstration in Bratislava is the first mass demonstration of the 1980s against the communist regime in Czechoslovakia.
March 25, 1995: WikiWikiWeb, the world's first wiki, and part of the Portland Pattern Repository, is made public by Ward Cunningham.
March 25, 1996: The European Union's Veterinarian Committee bans the export of British beef and its by-products as a result of mad cow disease (Bovine spongiform encephalopathy).
March 25, 2006: Protesters demanding a new election in Belarus, following the rigged 2006 Belarusian presidential election, clash with riot police. Opposition leader Aleksander Kozulin is among several protesters arrested.
March 26, 590: Emperor Maurice proclaims his son Theodosius as co-emperor of the Byzantine Empire.
March 26, 908: Emperor Zhu Wen of Later Liang has Li Zhu, the last Tang Dynasty emperor, poisoned.
March 26, 1027: Pope John XIX crowns Conrad II as Holy Roman Emperor.
March 26, 1169: Saladin becomes the emir of Egypt.
March 26, 1344: The Siege of Algeciras, one of the first European military engagements where gunpowder was used, comes to an end.
March 26, 1484: William Caxton prints his translation of Aesop's Fables.
March 26, 1552: Guru Amar Das becomes the Third Sikh guru.
March 26, 1636: Utrecht University is founded in the Netherlands.
March 26, 1812: A political cartoon in the Boston Gazette coins the term "gerrymander" to describe oddly shaped electoral districts designed to help incumbents win reelection.
March 26, 1830: The Book of Mormon is published in Palmyra, New York.
March 26, 1839: The first Henley Royal Regatta is held.
March 26, 1871: The elections of Commune council of the Paris Commune are held.
March 26, 1885: The Métis people of the District of Saskatchewan under Louis Riel begin the North-West Rebellion against Canada.
March 26, 1915: The Vancouver Millionaires win the 1915 Stanley Cup Finals, the first championship played between the Pacific Coast Hockey Association and the National Hockey Association.
March 26, 1922: The German Social Democratic Party is founded in Poland.
March 26, 1931: Ho Chi Minh Communist Youth Union is founded in Vietnam.
March 26, 1934: The United Kingdom driving test is introduced.
March 26, 1958: The African Regroupment Party is launched at a meeting in Paris.
March 26, 1967: Ten thousand people gather for one of many Central Park be-ins in New York City.
March 26, 1970: South Vietnamese President Nguyễn Văn Thiệu implements a land reform program to solve the problem of land tenancy.
March 26, 1971: East Pakistan declares its independence from Pakistan to form Bangladesh and the Bangladesh Liberation War begins.
March 26, 1975: The Biological Weapons Convention comes into force.
March 26, 1979: Anwar al-Sadat, Menachem Begin and Jimmy Carter sign the Egypt–Israel Peace Treaty in Washington, D.C.
March 26, 1981: Social Democratic Party (UK) is founded as a party.
March 26, 1982: A groundbreaking ceremony for the Vietnam Veterans Memorial is held in Washington, D.C.
March 26, 1991: Argentina, Brazil, Uruguay and Paraguay sign the Treaty of Asunción, establishing Mercosur, the South Common Market.
March 26, 1997: Thirty-nine bodies are found in the Heaven's Gate mass suicides.
March 26, 1998: During the Algerian Civil War, the Oued Bouaicha massacre sees fifty-two people, mostly infants, killed with axes and knives.
March 26, 2005: Around 200,000 to 300,000 Taiwanese demonstrate in Taipei in opposition to the Anti-Secession Law of  China.
March 26, 2010: The South Korean Navy corvette Cheonan is torpedoed, killing 46 sailors. After an international investigation, the President of the United Nations Security Council blames North Korea.
March 26, 2017: Russia-wide anti-corruption protests in 99 cities. The Levada Center survey showed that 38% of surveyed Russians supported protests and that 67 percent held Putin personally responsible for high-level corruption.
March 27, 1309: Pope Clement V imposes excommunication and interdiction on Venice, and a general prohibition of all commercial intercourse with Venice, which had seized on Ferrara, a papal fiefdom.
March 27, 1329: Pope John XXII issues his In Agro Dominico condemning some writings of Meister Eckhart as heretical.
March 27, 1513: Spanish explorer Juan Ponce de León reaches the northern end of The Bahamas on his first voyage to Florida.
March 27, 1625: Charles I becomes King of England, Scotland and Ireland as well as claiming the title King of France.
March 27, 1782: Charles Watson-Wentworth, 2nd Marquess of Rockingham becomes Prime Minister of the United Kingdom.
March 27, 1794: Denmark and Sweden form a neutrality compact.
March 27, 1866: President Andrew Johnson vetoes the Civil Rights Act of 1866. His veto is overridden by Congress and the bill passes into law on April 9.
March 27, 1871: The first international rugby football match, when Scotland defeats England in Edinburgh at Raeburn Place.
March 27, 1884: A mob in Cincinnati, Ohio, attacks members of a jury which had returned a verdict of manslaughter in what was seen as a clear case of murder; over the next few days the mob would riot and eventually destroy the courthouse.
March 27, 1886: Geronimo, Apache warrior, surrenders to the U.S. Army, ending the main phase of the Apache Wars.
March 27, 1899: Emilio Aguinaldo leads Filipino forces for the only time during the Philippine–American War at the Battle of Marilao River.
March 27, 1915: Typhoid Mary, the first healthy carrier of disease ever identified in the United States is put in quarantine for the second time, where she would remain for the rest of her life.
March 27, 1918: The National Council of Bessarabia proclaims union with the Kingdom of Romania.
March 27, 1958: Nikita Khrushchev becomes Chairman of the Council of Ministers of the Soviet Union.
March 27, 1964: The Good Friday earthquake, the most powerful earthquake recorded in North American history at a magnitude of 9.2 strikes Southcentral Alaska, killing 125 people and inflicting massive damage to the city of Anchorage.
March 27, 1975: Construction of the Trans-Alaska Pipeline System begins.
March 27, 1980: The Norwegian oil platform Alexander L. Kielland collapses in the North Sea, killing 123 of its crew of 212.
March 27, 1981: The Solidarity movement in Poland stages a warning strike, in which at least 12 million Poles walk off their jobs for four hours.
March 27, 1986: A car bomb explodes outside Russell Street Police HQ in Melbourne, Australia, killing one police officer and injuring 21 people.
March 27, 1990: The United States begins broadcasting anti-Castro propaganda to Cuba on TV Martí.
March 27, 1993: Italian former minister and Christian Democracy leader Giulio Andreotti is accused of mafia allegiance by the tribunal of Palermo.
March 27, 1998: The Food and Drug Administration approves Viagra for use as a treatment for male impotence, the first pill to be approved for this condition in the United States.
March 27, 2000: A Phillips Petroleum plant explosion in Pasadena, Texas kills one person and injures 71 others.
March 27, 2004: HMS Scylla, a decommissioned Leander-class frigate, is sunk as an artificial reef off Cornwall, the first of its kind in Europe.
March 27, 2009: The dam forming Situ Gintung, an artificial lake in Indonesia, fails, killing at least 99 people.
March 27, 2014: Philippines signs a peace accord with the largest Muslim rebel group, the Moro Islamic Liberation Front, ending decades of conflict.
March 27, 2015: Al-Shabab militants attack and temporarily occupy a Mogadishu hotel leaving at least 20 people dead.
March 27, 2016: A suicide blast in Gulshan-e-Iqbal Park, Lahore claims over 70 lives and leaves almost 300 others injured. The target of the bombing are Christians celebrating Easter.
March 28, AD 37: Roman emperor Caligula accepts the titles of the Principate, bestowed on him by the Senate.
March 28, 193: After assassinating the Roman Emperor Pertinax, his Praetorian Guards auction off the throne to Didius Julianus.[1]
March 28, 364: Roman Emperor Valentinian I appoints his brother Flavius Valens co-emperor.
March 28, 1566: The foundation stone of Valletta, Malta's capital city, is laid by Jean Parisot de Valette, Grand Master of the Sovereign Military Order of Malta.
March 28, 1737: The Marathas under Baji Rao I attack and defeat the Mughals in the Battle of Delhi.
March 28, 1776: Juan Bautista de Anza finds the site for the Presidio of San Francisco.
March 28, 1794: Allies under Prince Josias of Saxe-Coburg-Saalfeld defeat French forces at Le Cateau.
March 28, 1801: Treaty of Florence is signed, ending the war between the French Republic and the Kingdom of Naples.[2]
March 28, 1802: Heinrich Wilhelm Matthäus Olbers discovers 2 Pallas, the second asteroid ever to be discovered.
March 28, 1842: First concert of the Vienna Philharmonic Orchestra, conducted by Otto Nicolai.
March 28, 1871: The Paris Commune is formally established in Paris.
March 28, 1910: Henri Fabre becomes the first person to fly a seaplane, the Fabre Hydravion, after taking off from a water runway near Martigues, France.
March 28, 1920: Palm Sunday tornado outbreak of 1920 affects the Great Lakes region and Deep South states.
March 28, 1933: The Imperial Airways biplane City of Liverpool is believed to be the first airliner lost to sabotage when a passenger sets a fire on board.
March 28, 1959: The State Council of the People's Republic of China dissolves the government of Tibet.
March 28, 1968: Brazilian high school student Edson Luís de Lima Souto is killed by military police at a protest for cheaper meals at a restaurant for low-income students.
March 28, 1969: Greek poet and Nobel Prize laureate Giorgos Seferis makes a famous statement on the BBC World Service opposing the junta in Greece.
March 28, 1978: The US Supreme Court hands down 5–3 decision in Stump v. Sparkman, a controversial case involving involuntary sterilization and judicial immunity.
March 28, 1979: The British House of Commons passes a vote of no confidence against James Callaghan's government by 1 vote, precipitating a general election.
March 28, 1990: United States President George H. W. Bush posthumously awards Jesse Owens the Congressional Gold Medal.
March 28, 1994: In South Africa, African National Congress security guards kill dozens of Inkatha Freedom Party protesters.
March 28, 2003: In a friendly fire incident, two American A-10 Thunderbolt II aircraft attack British tanks participating in the 2003 invasion of Iraq, killing one soldier.
March 28, 2005: An earthquake shakes northern Sumatra with a maximum Mercalli intensity of VI (Strong), leaving 915–1,314 people dead and 340–1,146 injured.
March 28, 2006: Massive protests are mounted against France's First Employment Contract law, meant to reduce youth unemployment.
March 29, 845: Paris is sacked by Viking raiders, probably under Ragnar Lodbrok, who collects a huge ransom in exchange for leaving.
March 29, 1430: The Ottoman Empire under Murad II captures Thessalonica from the Republic of Venice.
March 29, 1500: Cesare Borgia is given the title of Captain General and Gonfalonier by his father Rodrigo Borgia after returning from his conquests in the Romagna.
March 29, 1549: The city of Salvador da Bahia, the first capital of Brazil, is founded.
March 29, 1632: Treaty of Saint-Germain is signed returning Quebec to French control after the English had seized it in 1629.
March 29, 1792: King Gustav III of Sweden dies after being shot in the back at a midnight masquerade ball at Stockholm's Royal Opera 13 days earlier. He is succeeded by Gustav IV Adolf.
March 29, 1806: Construction is authorized of the Great National Pike, better known as the Cumberland Road, becoming the first United States federal highway.
March 29, 1809: King Gustav IV Adolf of Sweden abdicates after a coup d'état. At the Diet of Porvoo, Finland's four Estates pledge allegiance to Alexander I of Russia, commencing the secession of the Grand Duchy of Finland from Sweden.
March 29, 1849: The United Kingdom annexes the Punjab.
March 29, 1857: Sepoy Mangal Pandey of the 34th Regiment, Bengal Native Infantry mutinies against the East India Company's rule in India and inspires the protracted Indian Rebellion of 1857, also known as the Sepoy Mutiny.
March 29, 1867: Queen Victoria gives Royal Assent to the British North America Act which establishes Canada on July 1.
March 29, 1871: Royal Albert Hall is opened by Queen Victoria.
March 29, 1882: The Knights of Columbus is established.
March 29, 1886: John Pemberton brews the first batch of Coca-Cola in a backyard in Atlanta.
March 29, 1911: The M1911 .45 ACP pistol becomes the official U.S. Army side arm.
March 29, 1927: Sunbeam 1000hp breaks the land speed record at Daytona Beach, Florida.[2]
March 29, 1930: Heinrich Brüning is appointed German Reichskanzler.
March 29, 1936: In Germany, Adolf Hitler receives 99% of the votes in a referendum to ratify Germany's illegal remilitarization and reoccupation of the Rhineland, receiving 44.5 million votes out of 45.5 million registered voters.
March 29, 1942: The Bombing of Lübeck in World War II is the first major success for the RAF Bomber Command against Germany and a German city.
March 29, 1946: Instituto Tecnológico Autónomo de México, one of Mexico's leading universities, is founded.
March 29, 1947: Malagasy Uprising against French colonial rule in Madagascar.
March 29, 1951: Ethel and Julius Rosenberg are convicted of conspiracy to commit espionage.
March 29, 1957: The New York, Ontario and Western Railway makes its final run, the first major U.S. railroad to be abandoned in its entirety.
March 29, 1961: The Twenty-third Amendment to the United States Constitution is ratified, allowing residents of Washington, D.C., to vote in presidential elections.
March 29, 1962: Arturo Frondizi, the president of Argentina, is overthrown in a military coup by Argentina's armed forces, ending an 11½ day constitutional crisis.
March 29, 1973: Operation Barrel Roll, a covert American bombing campaign in Laos to stop communist infiltration of South Vietnam, ends.
March 29, 1974: Terracotta Army was discovered in Shaanxi province, China.
March 29, 1982: The Canada Act 1982 receives the Royal Assent from Queen Elizabeth II, setting the stage for the Queen of Canada to proclaim the Constitution Act, 1982.
March 29, 1984: The Baltimore Colts load its possessions onto fifteen Mayflower moving trucks in the early morning hours and transfer its operations to Indianapolis.
March 29, 1990: The Czechoslovak parliament is unable to reach an agreement on what to call the country after the fall of Communism, sparking the so-called Hyphen War.
March 29, 1993: Catherine Callbeck becomes premier of Prince Edward Island and the first woman to be elected in a general election as premier of a Canadian province.
March 29, 1999: A magnitude 6.8 earthquake in India strikes the Chamoli district in Uttar Pradesh, killing 103.
March 29, 2002: In reaction to the Passover massacre two days prior, Israel launches Operation Defensive Shield against Palestinian militants, its largest military operation in the West Bank since the 1967 Six-Day War.
March 29, 2004: Bulgaria, Estonia, Latvia, Lithuania, Romania, Slovakia, and Slovenia join NATO as full members.
March 29, 2010: Two suicide bombers hit the Moscow Metro system at the peak of the morning rush hour, killing 40.
March 29, 2013: At least 36 people are killed when a 16-floor building collapses in the commercial capital Dar es Salaam, Tanzania.
March 29, 2014: The first same-sex marriages in England and Wales are performed.
March 30, 1282: The people of Sicily rebel against the Angevin king Charles I, in what becomes known as the Sicilian Vespers.[1]
March 30, 1296: Edward I sacks Berwick-upon-Tweed, during armed conflict between Scotland and England.[2]
March 30, 1699: Guru Gobind Singh establishes the Khalsa in Anandpur Sahib, Punjab.[3]
March 30, 1815: Joachim Murat issues the Rimini Proclamation which would later inspire Italian unification.
March 30, 1818: Physicist Augustin Fresnel reads a memoir on optical rotation to the French Academy of Sciences, reporting that when polarized light is "depolarized" by a Fresnel rhomb, its properties are preserved in any subsequent passage through an optically-rotating crystal or liquid.[4]
March 30, 1822: The Florida Territory is created in the United States.
March 30, 1841: The National Bank of Greece is founded in Athens.
March 30, 1842: Ether anesthesia is used for the first time, in an operation by the American surgeon Dr. Crawford Long.
March 30, 1844: One of the most important battles of the Dominican War of Independence from Haiti takes place near the city of Santiago de los Caballeros.
March 30, 1856: The Treaty of Paris is signed, ending the Crimean War.
March 30, 1863: Danish prince Wilhelm Georg is chosen as King George of Greece.
March 30, 1867: Alaska is purchased from Russia for $7.2 million, about 2-cent/acre ($4.19/km²), by United States Secretary of State William H. Seward.
March 30, 1870: Texas is readmitted to the United States Congress following Reconstruction.
March 30, 1885: The Battle for Kushka triggers the Panjdeh Incident which nearly gives rise to war between the Russian and British Empire.
March 30, 1899: German Society of Chemistry issues an invitation to other national scientific organizations to appoint delegates to the International Committee on Atomic Weights.
March 30, 1912: Sultan Abd al-Hafid signs the Treaty of Fez, making Morocco a French protectorate.
March 30, 1918: Outburst of bloody March Events in Baku and other locations of Baku Governorate.
March 30, 1939: The Heinkel He 100 fighter sets a world airspeed record of 463 mph (745 km/h).
March 30, 1944: Out of 795 Lancasters, Halifaxes and Mosquitos sent to attack Nuremberg, 95 bombers do not return, making it the largest RAF Bomber Command loss of the war.
March 30, 1961: The Single Convention on Narcotic Drugs is signed in New York City.
March 30, 1979: Airey Neave, a British Member of Parliament, is killed by a car bomb as he exits the Palace of Westminster. The Irish National Liberation Army claims responsibility.
March 30, 1981: U.S. President Ronald Reagan is shot in the chest outside a Washington, D.C., hotel by John Hinckley, Jr.; three others are wounded in the same incident.
March 30, 2009: Twelve gunmen attack the Manawan Police Academy in Lahore, Pakistan.
March 30, 2017: SpaceX conducts the world's first reflight of an orbital class rocket.[6][7]
March 31, 307: After divorcing his wife Minervina, Constantine marries Fausta, daughter of the retired Roman Emperor Maximian.[1]
March 31, 1146: Bernard of Clairvaux preaches his famous sermon in a field at Vézelay, urging the necessity of a Second Crusade. Louis VII is present, and joins the Crusade.[2]
March 31, 1492: Queen Isabella of Castile issues the Alhambra Decree, ordering her 150,000 Jewish and Muslim subjects to convert to Christianity or face expulsion.
March 31, 1561: The city of San Cristóbal, Táchira is founded.
March 31, 1717: A sermon on "The Nature of the Kingdom of Christ" by Benjamin Hoadly, the Bishop of Bangor, preached in the presence of King George I of Great Britain, provokes the Bangorian Controversy.[3]
March 31, 1822: The massacre of the population of the Greek island of Chios by soldiers of the Ottoman Empire following an attempted rebellion, depicted by the French artist Eugène Delacroix.
March 31, 1854: Commodore Matthew Perry signs the Convention of Kanagawa with the Tokugawa Shogunate, opening the ports of Shimoda and Hakodate to American trade.
March 31, 1885: The United Kingdom establishes the Bechuanaland Protectorate.
March 31, 1889: The Eiffel Tower is officially opened.[4]
March 31, 1899: Malolos, capital of the First Philippine Republic, is captured by American forces.[5]
March 31, 1906: The Intercollegiate Athletic Association of the United States (later the National Collegiate Athletic Association) is established to set rules for college sports in the United States.
March 31, 1909: Serbia accepts Austrian control over Bosnia and Herzegovina.
March 31, 1913: The Vienna Concert Society rioted during a performance of modernist music by Arnold Schoenberg, Alban Berg, Alexander von Zemlinsky, and Anton von Webern, causing a premature end to the concert due to violence; this concert became known as the Skandalkonzert.
March 31, 1917: The United States takes possession of the Danish West Indies after paying $25 million to Denmark, and renames the territory the United States Virgin Islands.
March 31, 1918: Daylight saving time goes into effect in the United States for the first time.
March 31, 1921: The Royal Australian Air Force is formed.
March 31, 1930: The Motion Picture Production Code is instituted, imposing strict guidelines on the treatment of sex, crime, religion and violence in film, in the U.S., for the next thirty-eight years.
March 31, 1931: A Transcontinental & Western Air airliner crashes near Bazaar, Kansas, killing eight, including University of Notre Dame head football coach Knute Rockne.
March 31, 1933: The Civilian Conservation Corps is established with the mission of relieving rampant unemployment in the United States.
March 31, 1949: The Dominion of Newfoundland joins the Canadian Confederation and becomes the 10th Province of Canada.
March 31, 1951: Remington Rand delivers the first UNIVAC I computer to the United States Census Bureau.
March 31, 1957: Elections to the Territorial Assembly of the French colony Upper Volta are held. After the elections PDU and MDV form a government.
March 31, 1958: In the Canadian federal election, the Progressive Conservatives, led by John Diefenbaker, win the largest percentage of seats in Canadian history, with 208 seats of 265.
March 31, 1959: The 14th Dalai Lama, crosses the border into India and is granted political asylum.
March 31, 1964: Brazilian General Olímpio Mourão Filho orders his troops to move towards Rio de Janeiro, beginning the coup d'état.
March 31, 1966: The Soviet Union launches Luna 10 which later becomes the first space probe to enter orbit around the Moon.
March 31, 1970: Explorer 1 re-enters the Earth's atmosphere after 12 years in orbit.
March 31, 1980: The Chicago, Rock Island and Pacific Railroad operates its final train after being ordered to liquidate its assets because of bankruptcy and debts owed to creditors.
March 31, 1985: The first WrestleMania, the biggest wrestling event from the WWE (then the WWF), takes place in Madison Square Garden in New York City.
March 31, 1990: Approximately 200,000 protesters take to the streets of London to protest against the newly introduced Poll Tax.
March 31, 1992: The Treaty of Federation is signed in Moscow.
March 31, 1995: Selena is murdered by her fan club's president Yolanda Saldívar at a Days Inn in Corpus Christi, Texas after accusations of Saldívar embezzling money from Selena's fan club.
March 31, 1998: Netscape releases Mozilla source code under an open source license.
April 1, 286: Emperor Diocletian elevates his general Maximian to co-emperor with the rank of Augustus and gives him control over the Western regions of the Roman Empire.
April 1, 325: Crown Prince Jin Chengdi, age 4, succeeds his father Jin Mingdi as emperor of the Eastern Jin dynasty.
April 1, 457: Majorian is acclaimed emperor by the Roman army after defeating 900 Alemanni near Lake Maggiore (Italy).
April 1, 527: Byzantine Emperor Justin I names his nephew Justinian I as co-ruler and successor to the throne.
April 1, 528: The daughter of Emperor Xiaoming of Northern Wei was made the "Emperor" as a male heir of the late emperor by Empress Dowager Hu. Deposed and replaced by Yuan Zhao the next day, she was the first female monarch in the History of China, but is not widely recognised.
April 1, 988: Robert II of France is married to Rozala of Italy. The marriage is arranged by his father, King Hugh Capet.
April 1, 1234: Richard Marshal, 3rd Earl of Pembroke, was defeated by knights loyal to King Henry III of England in the Battle of the Curragh in Ireland.
April 1, 1293: Robert Winchelsey leaves England for Rome, to be consecrated as Archbishop of Canterbury.
April 1, 1318: Berwick-upon-Tweed is captured by Scotland from England.
April 1, 1340: Niels Ebbesen kills Gerhard III, Count of Holstein-Rendsburg in his bedroom, ending the 1332-1340 interregnum in Denmark.
April 1, 1545: Potosí, Bolivia, is founded after the discovery of huge silver deposits in the area.
April 1, 1572: In the Eighty Years' War, the Watergeuzen capture Brielle from the Seventeen Provinces, gaining the first foothold on land for what would become the Dutch Republic.
April 1, 1625: A combined Spanish and Portuguese fleet of 52 ships commences the recapture of Bahia from the Dutch during the Dutch–Portuguese War.
April 1, 1789: In New York City, the United States House of Representatives achieves its first quorum and elects Frederick Muhlenberg of Pennsylvania as its first Speaker.
April 1, 1826: Samuel Morey received a patent for a compressionless "Gas or Vapor Engine".
April 1, 1833: The Convention of 1833, a political gathering of settlers in Mexican Texas to help draft a series of petitions to the Mexican government, begins in San Felipe de Austin
April 1, 1854: Charles Dickens' novel Hard Times begins serialisation in his magazine Household Words.
April 1, 1867: Singapore becomes a British crown colony.
April 1, 1871: The 3rd Duke of Buckingham opened the Brill Tramway, a short railway line to transport goods between his lands and the national rail network.
April 1, 1873: The White Star steamer RMS Atlantic sinks off Nova Scotia, killing 547 in one of the worst marine disasters of the 19th century.
April 1, 1889: The University of Northern Colorado was established, as the Colorado State Normal School.
April 1, 1891: The Wrigley Company is founded in Chicago, Illinois.
April 1, 1893: The rank of Chief Petty Officer in the United States Navy is established.
April 1, 1908: The Territorial Force (renamed Territorial Army in 1920) is formed as a volunteer reserve component of the British Army.
April 1, 1918: The Royal Air Force is created by the merger of the Royal Flying Corps and the Royal Naval Air Service.
April 1, 1924: The Royal Canadian Air Force is formed.
April 1, 1933: English cricketer Wally Hammond set a record for the highest individual Test innings of 336 not out, during a Test match against New Zealand.
April 1, 1935: India's central banking institution, The Reserve Bank of India is formed.
April 1, 1937: The Royal New Zealand Air Force is formed as an independent service.
April 1, 1941: A military coup in Iraq overthrows the regime of 'Abd al-Ilah and installs Rashid Ali al-Gaylani as Prime Minister.
April 1, 1944: Navigation errors lead to an accidental American bombing of the Swiss city of Schaffhausen.
April 1, 1946: The 8.6 Mw  Aleutian Islands earthquake shakes the Aleutian Islands with a maximum Mercalli intensity of VI (Strong). A destructive tsunami reaches the Hawaiian Islands resulting in dozens of deaths, mostly in Hilo, Hawaii.
April 1, 1947: The only mutiny in the history of the Royal New Zealand Navy begins.
April 1, 1948: Faroe Islands gain autonomy from Denmark.
April 1, 1949: The Government of Canada repeals Japanese-Canadian internment after seven years.
April 1, 1954: United States President Dwight D. Eisenhower authorizes the creation of the United States Air Force Academy in Colorado.
April 1, 1955: The EOKA rebellion against the British Empire begins in Cyprus, with the goal of unifying with Greece.
April 1, 1960: The TIROS-1 satellite transmits the first television picture from space.
April 1, 1963: General Hospital premieres on ABC television network in USA.[1][circular reference]
April 1, 1969: The Hawker Siddeley Harrier, the first operational fighter aircraft with Vertical/Short Takeoff and Landing capabilities, entered service with the Royal Air Force.
April 1, 1970: The first of over 670,000 AMC Gremlins were released into North America to compete with foreign imported cars.
April 1, 1973: Project Tiger, a tiger conservation project, is launched in the Jim Corbett National Park, India.
April 1, 1974: The Local Government Act 1972 of England and Wales comes into effect.
