April 19, 1993: The 51-day FBI siege of the Branch Davidian building in Waco, Texas, USA, ends when a fire breaks out. 76 Davidians, including eighteen children under the age of ten, died in the fire.
April 19, 1999: The German Bundestag returns to Berlin.
April 19, 2000: Air Philippines Flight 541 crashes in Samal, Davao del Norte, killing all 131 people on board.[1]
April 19, 2005: Cardinal Joseph Ratzinger is elected to the papacy and becomes Pope Benedict XVI.
April 19, 2011: Fidel Castro resigns as First Secretary of the Communist Party of Cuba after holding the title since July 1961.
April 19, 2013: Boston Marathon bombing suspect Tamerlan Tsarnaev is killed in a shootout with police. His brother Dzhokhar is later captured hiding in a boat inside a backyard in the suburb of Watertown.
April 20, 1303: The Sapienza University of Rome is instituted by Pope Boniface VIII.
April 20, 1453: Three Genoese galleys and a Byzantine blockade runner fight their way through an Ottoman blockading fleet a few weeks before the fall of Constantinople.
April 20, 1534: Jacques Cartier begins his first voyage to what is today the east coast of Canada, Newfoundland and Labrador.
April 20, 1535: The sun dog phenomenon observed over Stockholm and depicted in the famous painting Vädersolstavlan.
April 20, 1653: Oliver Cromwell dissolves the Rump Parliament.
April 20, 1657: Freedom of religion is granted to the Jews of New Amsterdam (later New York City).
April 20, 1689: Deposed monarch James II of England lays siege to Derry.
April 20, 1752: Start of Konbaung–Hanthawaddy War, a new phase in the Burmese Civil War (1740–57).
April 20, 1770: The Georgian king, Erekle II, abandoned by his Russian ally Count Totleben, wins a victory over Ottoman forces at Aspindza.
April 20, 1789: George Washington arrives at Grays Ferry, Philadelphia while en route to Manhattan for his inauguration.
April 20, 1792: France declares war against the "King of Hungary and Bohemia", the beginning of French Revolutionary Wars.
April 20, 1809: Two Austrian army corps in Bavaria are defeated by a First French Empire army led by Napoleon at the Battle of Abensberg on the second day of a four-day campaign that ended in a French victory.
April 20, 1810: The Governor of Caracas, Venezuela declares independence from Spain.
April 20, 1818: The case of Ashford v Thornton ends, with Abraham Thornton allowed to go free rather than face a retrial for murder, after his demand for trial by battle is upheld.
April 20, 1828: René Caillié becomes the second non-Muslim to enter (and the first to return from) Timbuktu, following Major Gordon Laing.
April 20, 1836: U.S. Congress passes an act creating the Wisconsin Territory.
April 20, 1862: Louis Pasteur and Claude Bernard complete the experiment disproving the theory of spontaneous generation.
April 20, 1865: Astronomer Angelo Secchi demonstrates the Secchi disk, which measures water clarity, aboard Pope Pius IX's yacht, the L'Immaculata Concezion.
April 20, 1876: The April Uprising begins. Its suppression shocks European opinion, and Bulgarian independence becomes a condition for ending the Russo-Turkish War.
April 20, 1884: Pope Leo XIII publishes the encyclical Humanum genus.
April 20, 1898: U.S. President William McKinley signed a joint resolution to Congress for declaration of War against Spain, beginning the Spanish–American War.[2]
April 20, 1902: Pierre and Marie Curie refine radium chloride.
April 20, 1908: Opening day of competition in the New South Wales Rugby League.
April 20, 1912: Opening day for baseball's Tiger Stadium in Detroit, and Fenway Park in Boston.
April 20, 1914: Nineteen men, women, and children die in the Ludlow Massacre during a Colorado coal-miners' strike.[3]
April 20, 1916: The Chicago Cubs play their first game at Weeghman Park (currently Wrigley Field), defeating the Cincinnati Reds 7–6 in 11 innings.
April 20, 1918: Manfred von Richthofen, a.k.a. The Red Baron, shoots down his 79th and 80th victims, his final victories before his death the following day.
April 20, 1922: The Soviet government creates South Ossetian Autonomous Oblast within Georgian SSR.
April 20, 1945: Twenty Jewish children used in medical experiments at Neuengamme are killed in the basement of the Bullenhuser Damm school.
April 20, 1946: The League of Nations officially dissolves, giving most of its power to the United Nations.
April 20, 1968: English politician Enoch Powell makes his controversial "Rivers of Blood" speech.
April 20, 1998: Air France Flight 422 crashes after taking off from El Dorado International Airport in Bogotá, Colombia, killing all 53 people on board.[4]
April 20, 2008: Danica Patrick wins the Indy Japan 300 becoming the first female driver in history to win an Indy car race.
April 20, 2010: The Deepwater Horizon drilling rig explodes in the Gulf of Mexico, killing eleven workers and beginning an oil spill that would last six months.
April 20, 2012: One hundred twenty-seven people are killed when a plane crashes in a residential area near the Benazir Bhutto International Airport near Islamabad, Pakistan.
April 20, 2013: A 6.6-magnitude earthquake strikes Lushan County, Ya'an, in China's Sichuan province, killing more than 150 people and injuring thousands.
April 20, 2015: Ten people are killed in a bomb attack on a convoy carrying food supplies to a United Nations compound in Garowe in the Somali region of Puntland.
April 21, 1092: The Diocese of Pisa is elevated to the rank of metropolitan archdiocese by Pope Urban II
April 21, 1506: The three-day Lisbon Massacre comes to an end with the slaughter of over 1,900 suspected Jews by Portuguese Catholics.
April 21, 1509: Henry VIII ascends the throne of England on the death of his father, Henry VII.
April 21, 1526: The last ruler of the Lodi dynasty, Ibrahim Lodi is defeated and killed by Babur in the First Battle of Panipat.
April 21, 1615: The Wignacourt Aqueduct is inaugurated in Malta.
April 21, 1782: The city of Rattanakosin, now known internationally as Bangkok, is founded on the eastern bank of the Chao Phraya River by King Buddha Yodfa Chulaloke.
April 21, 1792: Tiradentes, a revolutionary leading a movement for Brazil's independence, is hanged, drawn and quartered.
April 21, 1802: Twelve thousand Wahhabis under Abdul-Aziz bin Muhammad, invaded city of Karbala, killed over three thousand inhabitants, and sacked the city.
April 21, 1809: Two Austrian army corps are driven from Landshut by a First French Empire army led by Napoleon as two French corps to the north hold off the main Austrian army on the first day of the Battle of Eckmühl.
April 21, 1821: Benderli Ali Pasha arrives in Constantinople as the new Grand Vizier of the Ottoman Empire; he remains in power for only nine days before being sent into exile.
April 21, 1894: Norway formally adopts the Krag–Jørgensen bolt-action rifle as the main arm of its armed forces, a weapon that would remain in service for almost 50 years.
April 21, 1926: Al-Baqi cemetery, former site of the mausoleum of four Shi'a Imams, is leveled to the ground by Wahhabis.
April 21, 1934: The "Surgeon's Photograph", the most famous photo allegedly showing the Loch Ness Monster, is published in the Daily Mail (in 1999, it is revealed to be a hoax).
April 21, 1948: United Nations Security Council Resolution 47 relating to Kashmir conflict is adopted.
April 21, 1952: Secretary's Day (now Administrative Professionals' Day) is first celebrated.
April 21, 1962: The Seattle World's Fair (Century 21 Exposition) opens. It is the first World's Fair in the United States since World War II.
April 21, 1963: The first election of the Universal House of Justice is held, marking its establishment as the supreme governing institution of the Bahá'í Faith.
April 21, 1964: A Transit-5bn satellite fails to reach orbit after launch; as it re-enters the atmosphere, 2.1 pounds (0.95 kg) of radioactive plutonium in its SNAP RTG power source is widely dispersed.
April 21, 1965: The 1964–1965 New York World's Fair opens for its second and final season.
April 21, 1967: A few days before the general election in Greece, Colonel George Papadopoulos leads a coup d'état, establishing a military regime that lasts for seven years.
April 21, 1985: The compound of the militant group The Covenant, The Sword, and the Arm of the Lord surrenders to federal authorities in Arkansas after a two-day government siege.
April 21, 1987: The Tamil Tigers are blamed for a car bomb that detonates in the Sri Lankan capital city of Colombo, killing 106 people.
April 21, 1989: Nintendo launched the original Game Boy in Japan. The portable video game system had four Japanese launch titlesl; Super Mario Land, Alleyway, Baseball, and Yakuman.
April 21, 1993: The Supreme Court in La Paz, Bolivia, sentences former dictator Luis García Meza to 30 years in jail without parole for murder, theft, fraud and violating the constitution.
April 21, 2004: Five suicide car bombers target police stations in and around Basra, killing 74 people and wounding 160.
April 21, 2010: The controversial Kharkiv Pact (Russian Ukrainian Naval Base for Gas Treaty) is signed in Kharkiv, Ukraine, by Ukrainian President Viktor Yanukovych and Russian President Dmitry Medvedev; it was unilaterally terminated by Russia on March 31, 2014.
April 21, 2012: Two trains are involved in a head-on collision near Sloterdijk, Amsterdam, in the Netherlands, injuring 116 people.
April 21, 2014: The American city of Flint, Michigan switches its water source to the Flint River, beginning the ongoing Flint water crisis which has caused lead poisoning in up to 12,000 people, and 15 deaths from Legionnaires disease, ultimately leading to criminal indictments against 15 people, five of whom have been charged with involuntary manslaughter.
April 21, 2019: Eight bombs explode at churches, hotels, and other locations in Sri Lanka on Easter Sunday, more than 200 people were killed. [1]
April 22, 1500: Portuguese navigator Pedro Álvares Cabral lands in Brazil.
April 22, 1519: Spanish conquistador Hernán Cortés establishes a settlement at Veracruz, Mexico.
April 22, 1529: Treaty of Zaragoza divides the eastern hemisphere between Spain and Portugal along a line 297.5 leagues (1,250 kilometres (780 mi)) east of the Moluccas.[1]
April 22, 1622: The Capture of Ormuz by the East India Company ends Portuguese control of Hormuz Island.
April 22, 1864: The U.S. Congress passes the Coinage Act of 1864 that mandates that the inscription In God We Trust be placed on all coins minted as United States currency.
April 22, 1876: The first game in the history of the National League was played at the Jefferson Street Grounds in Philadelphia. This game is often pointed to as the beginning of the MLB.
April 22, 1889: At noon, thousands rush to claim land in the Land Rush of 1889. Within hours the cities of Oklahoma City and Guthrie are formed with populations of at least 10,000.
April 22, 1906: The 1906 Intercalated Games, now recognized as part of the official Olympic Games, open in Athens.[3]
April 22, 1915: The use of poison gas in World War I escalates when chlorine gas is released as a chemical weapon in the Second Battle of Ypres.
April 22, 1930: The United Kingdom, Japan and the United States sign the London Naval Treaty regulating submarine warfare and limiting shipbuilding.
April 22, 1944: The 1st Air Commando Group using Sikorsky R-4 helicopters stage the first use of helicopters in combat with combat search and rescue operations in the China Burma India Theater.
April 22, 1969: British yachtsman Sir Robin Knox-Johnston wins the Sunday Times Golden Globe Race and completes the first solo non-stop circumnavigation of the world.
April 22, 1970: The first Earth Day is celebrated.[4]
April 22, 1977: Optical fiber is first used to carry live telephone traffic.
April 22, 1983: The German magazine Stern claims the "Hitler Diaries" had been found in wreckage in East Germany; the diaries are subsequently revealed to be forgeries.
April 22, 1992: In a series of explosions in Guadalajara, Mexico, 206 people are killed, nearly 500 injured and 15,000 left homeless.
April 22, 1993: Eighteen-year-old Stephen Lawrence is murdered in a racially motivated attack while waiting for a bus in Well Hall, Eltham.
April 22, 1997: Haouch Khemisti massacre in Algeria where 93 villagers are killed.
April 22, 2000: In a pre-dawn raid, federal agents seize six-year-old Elián González from his relatives' home in Miami.
April 22, 2004: Two fuel trains collide in Ryongchon, North Korea, killing up to 150 people.
April 22, 2005: Japan's Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi apologizes for Japan's war record.
April 22, 2008: The United States Air Force retires the remaining F-117 Nighthawk aircraft in service.
April 22, 2013: The Royal Canadian Mounted Police arrest and charge two men with plotting to disrupt a Toronto area train service in a plot claimed to be backed by Al-Qaeda elements.
April 22, 2014: More than 60 people are killed and 80 are seriously injured in a train crash in the Democratic Republic of the Congo's Katanga Province.
April 22, 2016: The Paris Agreement is signed, an agreement to help fight global warming.
April 22, 2019: A  magnitude 6.1 earthquake strikes the main Philippines island of Luzon, killing at least 8 people.[5]
April 23, 215 BC: A temple is built on the Capitoline Hill dedicated to Venus Erycina to commemorate the Roman defeat at Lake Trasimene.
April 23, 599: Maya king Uneh Chan of Calakmul attacks rival city-state Palenque in southern Mexico, defeating queen Yohl Ik'nal and sacking the city.
April 23, 711: Dagobert III succeeds his father King Childebert III as King of the Franks.
April 23, 1016: Edmund Ironside succeeds his father Æthelred the Unready as King of England.
April 23, 1343: St. George's Night Uprising commences in the Duchy of Estonia.
April 23, 1348: The founding of the Order of the Garter by King Edward III is announced on St. George's Day.
April 23, 1516: The Bayerische Reinheitsgebot (regarding the ingredients of beer) is signed in Ingolstadt.
April 23, 1635: The first public school in the United States, Boston Latin School, is founded in Boston.
April 23, 1655: The Siege of Santo Domingo begins during the Anglo-Spanish War, and fails seven days later.
April 23, 1660: Treaty of Oliva is established between Sweden and Poland.
April 23, 1661: King Charles II of England, Scotland and Ireland is crowned in Westminster Abbey.
April 23, 1879: Fire burns down the second main building and dome of the University of Notre Dame, which prompts the construction of the third, and current, Main Building with its golden dome.
April 23, 1914: First baseball game at Wrigley Field, then known as Weeghman Park, in Chicago.
April 23, 1920: The Grand National Assembly of Turkey (TBMM) is founded in Ankara. The assembly denounces the government of Sultan Mehmed VI and announces the preparation of a temporary constitution.
April 23, 1927: Cardiff City defeat Arsenal in the FA Cup Final, the only time it has been won by a team not based in England.
April 23, 1935: The Polish Constitution of 1935 is adopted.
April 23, 1940: The Rhythm Club fire at a dance hall in Natchez, Mississippi, kills 198 people.
April 23, 1946: Manuel Roxas is elected the last President of the Commonwealth of the Philippines.
April 23, 1985: Coca-Cola changes its formula and releases New Coke. The response is overwhelmingly negative, and the original formula is back on the market in less than three months.
April 23, 1990: Namibia becomes the 160th member of the United Nations and the 50th member of the Commonwealth of Nations.
April 23, 1993: Sri Lankan politician Lalith Athulathmudali is assassinated while addressing a gathering, approximately four weeks ahead of the Provincial Council elections for the Western Province.
April 23, 2005: The first ever YouTube video, titled "Me at the zoo", was published by user "jawed".[1]
April 23, 2013: At least 28 people are killed and more than 70 are injured as violence breaks out in Hawija, Iraq.
April 23, 2018: A vehicle-ramming attack kills 10 people and injures 16 in Toronto. A 25-year-old suspect, Alek Minassian is arrested.[2]
April 23, 2019: A mudslide at a jade mine in northern Myanmar, 54 miners are missing and feared dead. [3]
April 24, 1479 BC: Thutmose III ascends to the throne of Egypt, although power effectively shifts to Hatshepsut (according to the Low Chronology of the 18th dynasty).
April 24, 1547: Battle of Mühlberg. Duke of Alba, commanding Spanish-Imperial forces of Charles I of Spain, defeats the troops of Schmalkaldic League.
April 24, 1558: Mary, Queen of Scots, marries the Dauphin of France, François, at Notre Dame de Paris.
April 24, 1704: The first regular newspaper in British Colonial America, The Boston News-Letter, is published.
April 24, 1800: The United States Library of Congress is established when President John Adams signs legislation to appropriate $5,000 to purchase "such books as may be necessary for the use of Congress".
April 24, 1885: American sharpshooter Annie Oakley is hired by Nate Salsbury to be a part of Buffalo Bill's Wild West.
April 24, 1895: Joshua Slocum, the first person to sail single-handedly around the world, sets sail from Boston, Massachusetts aboard the sloop "Spray".
April 24, 1913: The Woolworth Building, a skyscraper in New York City, is opened.
April 24, 1914: The Franck–Hertz experiment, a pillar of quantum mechanics, is presented to the German Physical Society.
April 24, 1915: The arrest of 250 Armenian intellectuals and community leaders in Istanbul marks the beginning of the Armenian Genocide.
April 24, 1916: Ernest Shackleton and five men of the Imperial Trans-Antarctic Expedition launch a lifeboat from uninhabited Elephant Island in the Southern Ocean to organise a rescue for the crew of the sunken Endurance.
April 24, 1922: The first segment of the Imperial Wireless Chain providing wireless telegraphy between Leafield in Oxfordshire, England, and Cairo, Egypt, comes into operation.
April 24, 1926: The Treaty of Berlin is signed. Germany and the Soviet Union each pledge neutrality in the event of an attack on the other by a third party for the next five years.
April 24, 1932: Benny Rothman leads the mass trespass of Kinder Scout, leading to substantial legal reforms in the United Kingdom.
April 24, 1933: Nazi Germany begins its persecution of Jehovah's Witnesses by shutting down the Watch Tower Society office in Magdeburg.
April 24, 1953: Winston Churchill is knighted by Queen Elizabeth II.
April 24, 1963: Marriage of HRH Princess Alexandra of Kent to the Hon Angus Ogilvy at Westminster Abbey in London.
April 24, 1965: Civil war breaks out in the Dominican Republic when Colonel Francisco Caamaño overthrows the triumvirate that had been in power since the coup d'état against Juan Bosch.
April 24, 1967: Cosmonaut Vladimir Komarov dies in Soyuz 1 when its parachute fails to open. He is the first human to die during a space mission.
April 24, 1970: The Gambia becomes a republic within the Commonwealth of Nations, with Dawda Jawara as its first President.
April 24, 1980: Eight U.S. servicemen die in Operation Eagle Claw as they attempt to end the Iran hostage crisis.
April 24, 1990: Gruinard Island, Scotland, is officially declared free of the anthrax disease after 48 years of quarantine.
April 24, 1993: An IRA bomb devastates the Bishopsgate area of London.
April 24, 1996: In the United States, the Antiterrorism and Effective Death Penalty Act of 1996 is passed into law.
April 24, 2004: The United States lifts economic sanctions imposed on Libya 18 years previously, as a reward for its cooperation in eliminating weapons of mass destruction.
April 24, 2005: Cardinal Joseph Ratzinger is inaugurated as the 265th Pope of the Catholic Church taking the name Pope Benedict XVI.
April 24, 2013: Violence in Bachu County, Kashgar Prefecture, of China's Xinjiang results in death of 21 people.
April 25, 404 BC: Admiral Lysander and King Pausanias of Sparta blockade Athens and bring the Peloponnesian War to a successful conclusion.
April 25, 775: The Battle of Bagrevand puts an end to an Armenian rebellion against the Abbasid Caliphate. Muslim control over Transcaucasia is solidified and its Islamization begins, while several major Armenian nakharar families lose power and their remnants flee to the Byzantine Empire.
April 25, 799: After mistreatment and disfigurement by the citizens of Rome, pope Leo III flees to the Frankish court of king Charlemagne at Paderborn for protection.
April 25, 1134: The name Zagreb was mentioned for the first time in the Felician Charter relating to the establishment of the Zagreb Bishopric around 1094.
April 25, 1644: The Chongzhen Emperor, the last Emperor of Ming dynasty China, commits suicide during a peasant rebellion led by Li Zicheng.
April 25, 1707: A coalition of Britain, the Netherlands and Portugal is defeated by a Franco-Spanish army at Almansa (Spain) in the War of the Spanish Succession.
April 25, 1792: "La Marseillaise" (the French national anthem) is composed by Claude Joseph Rouget de Lisle.
April 25, 1804: The western Georgian kingdom of Imereti accepts the suzerainty of the Russian Empire.
April 25, 1829: Charles Fremantle arrives in HMS Challenger off the coast of modern-day Western Australia prior to declaring the Swan River Colony for the United Kingdom.
April 25, 1849: The Governor General of Canada, Lord Elgin, signs the Rebellion Losses Bill, outraging Montreal's English population and triggering the Montreal Riots.
April 25, 1859: British and French engineers break ground for the Suez Canal.
April 25, 1882: French and Vietnamese troops clashed in Tonkin, when Commandant Henri Rivière seized the citadel of Hanoi with a small force of marine infantry.
April 25, 1901: New York becomes the first U.S. state to require automobile license plates.
April 25, 1916: Anzac Day is commemorated for the first time on the first anniversary of the landing at ANZAC Cove.
April 25, 1920: At the San Remo conference, the principal Allied Powers of World War I adopt a resolution to determine the allocation of Class "A" League of Nations mandates for administration of the former Ottoman-ruled lands of the Middle East.
April 25, 1938: U.S. Supreme Court delivers its opinion in Erie Railroad Co. v. Tompkins and overturns a century of federal common law.
April 25, 1940: Merkið, the flag of the Faroe Islands is approved by the British occupation government.
April 25, 1944: The United Negro College Fund is incorporated.
April 25, 1945: The last German troops retreat from Finland's soil in Lapland, ending the Lapland War. Military acts of Second World War end in Finland.
April 25, 1954: The first practical solar cell is publicly demonstrated by Bell Telephone Laboratories.
April 25, 1959: The Saint Lawrence Seaway, linking the North American Great Lakes and the Atlantic Ocean, officially opens to shipping.
April 25, 1960: The United States Navy submarine USS Triton completes the first submerged circumnavigation of the globe.
April 25, 1961: Robert Noyce is granted a patent for an integrated circuit.
April 25, 1975: As North Vietnamese forces close in on the South Vietnamese capital Saigon, the Australian Embassy is closed and evacuated, almost ten years to the day since the first Australian troop commitment to South Vietnam.
April 25, 1981: More than 100 workers are exposed to radiation during repairs of at the Tsuruga Nuclear Power Plant in Japan.
April 25, 1982: Israel completes its withdrawal from the Sinai Peninsula per the Camp David Accords.
April 25, 1986: Mswati III is crowned King of Swaziland, succeeding his father Sobhuza II.
April 25, 1988: In Israel, John Demjanjuk is sentenced to death for war crimes committed in World War II.
April 25, 1990: Violeta Chamorro takes office as the President of Nicaragua, the first woman to hold the position.
April 25, 2001: Michele Alboreto is killed while testing an Audi R8 at the Lausitzring in Germany.
April 25, 2004: The March for Women's Lives brings between 500,000 and 800,000 protesters, mostly pro-choice, to Washington D.C. to protest the Partial-Birth Abortion Ban Act of 2003, and other restrictions on abortion.
April 25, 2005: Bulgaria and Romania sign accession treaties to join the European Union.
April 25, 2015: Nearly 9,100 are killed after a massive 7.8 magnitude earthquake strikes Nepal.
April 26, 1478: The Pazzi family attack Lorenzo de' Medici and kill his brother Giuliano during High Mass in Florence Cathedral.
April 26, 1564: Playwright William Shakespeare is baptized in Stratford-upon-Avon, Warwickshire, England (date of actual birth is unknown).
April 26, 1607: English colonists make landfall at Cape Henry, Virginia.
April 26, 1721: A massive earthquake devastates the Iranian city of Tabriz.
April 26, 1777: Sybil Ludington, aged 16, rode 40 miles to alert American colonial forces to the approach of the British regular forces
April 26, 1794: Battle of Beaumont during the Flanders Campaign of the War of the First Coalition.
April 26, 1802: Napoleon Bonaparte signs a general amnesty to allow all but about one thousand of the most notorious émigrés of the French Revolution to return to France, as part of a reconciliary gesture with the factions of the Ancien Régime and to eventually consolidate his own rule.
April 26, 1803: Thousands of meteor fragments fall from the skies of L'Aigle, France; the event convinces European scientists that meteors exist.
April 26, 1865: Union cavalry troopers corner and shoot dead John Wilkes Booth, assassin of President Abraham Lincoln, in Virginia.
April 26, 1903: Atlético Madrid Association football club is founded
April 26, 1923: The Duke of York weds Lady Elizabeth Bowes-Lyon at Westminster Abbey.
April 26, 1925: Paul von Hindenburg defeats Wilhelm Marx in the second round of the German presidential election to become the first directly elected head of state of the Weimar Republic.
April 26, 1933: The Gestapo, the official secret police force of Nazi Germany, is established.
April 26, 1942: Benxihu Colliery accident in Manchukuo leaves 1549 Chinese miners dead.
April 26, 1943: The Easter Riots break out in Uppsala, Sweden.
April 26, 1944: Heinrich Kreipe is captured by Allied commandos in occupied Crete.
April 26, 1954: The Geneva Conference, an effort to restore peace in Indochina and Korea, begins.
April 26, 1956: SS Ideal X, the world's first successful container ship, leaves Port Newark, New Jersey for Houston, Texas.
April 26, 1958: Final run of the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad's Royal Blue from Washington, D.C., to New York City after 68 years, the first U.S. passenger train to use electric locomotives.
April 26, 1960: Forced out by the April Revolution, President of South Korea Syngman Rhee resigns after twelve years of dictatorial rule.
April 26, 1962: NASA's Ranger 4 spacecraft crashes into the Moon.
April 26, 1963: In Libya, amendments to the constitution transform Libya (United Kingdom of Libya) into one national unity (Kingdom of Libya) and allows for female participation in elections.
April 26, 1964: Tanganyika and Zanzibar merge to form Tanzania.
April 26, 1966: A new government is formed in the Republic of the Congo, led by Ambroise Noumazalaye.
April 26, 1970: The Convention Establishing the World Intellectual Property Organization enters into force.
April 26, 1981: Dr. Michael R. Harrison of the University of California, San Francisco Medical Center performs the world's first human open fetal surgery.
April 26, 1982: Fifty-seven people are killed by former police officer Woo Bum-kon in a shooting spree in South Gyeongsang Province, South Korea.
April 26, 1986: A nuclear reactor accident occurs at the Chernobyl Nuclear Power Plant in the Soviet Union (now Ukraine), creating the world's worst nuclear disaster.
April 26, 1989: People's Daily publishes the April 26 Editorial which inflames the nascent Tiananmen Square protests.
April 26, 1991: Seventy tornadoes break out in the central United States. Before the outbreak's end, Andover, Kansas, would record the year's only F5 tornado.
April 26, 1994: China Airlines Flight 140 crashes at Nagoya Airport in Japan, killing 264 of the 271 people on board.
April 26, 2002: Robert Steinhäuser kills 16 at Gutenberg-Gymnasium in Erfurt, Germany before dying of a self-inflicted gunshot.
April 26, 2005: Under international pressure, Syria withdraws the last of its 14,000 troop military garrison in Lebanon, ending its 29-year military domination of that country (Syrian occupation of Lebanon).
April 26, 2018: American comedian Bill Cosby is found guilty of sexual assault.
April 27, 33 BC: Lucius Marcius Philippus, step-brother to the future emperor Augustus, celebrates a triumph for his victories while serving as governor in one of the provinces of Hispania.
April 27, 395: Emperor Arcadius marries Aelia Eudoxia, daughter of the Frankish general Flavius Bauto. She becomes one of the more powerful Roman empresses of Late Antiquity.
April 27, 629: Shahrbaraz is crowned as king of the Sasanian Empire.
April 27, 1509: Pope Julius II places the Italian state of Venice under interdict.
April 27, 1522: Combined forces of Spain and the Papal States defeat a French and Venetian army at the Battle of Bicocca.
April 27, 1539: Re-founding of the city of Bogotá, New Granada (now Colombia), by Nikolaus Federmann and Sebastián de Belalcázar.
April 27, 1565: Cebu is established becoming the first Spanish settlement in the Philippines.
April 27, 1578: Duel of the Mignons claims the lives of two favourites of Henry III of France and two favorites of Henry I, Duke of Guise.
April 27, 1595: The relics of Saint Sava are incinerated in Belgrade on the Vračar plateau by Ottoman Grand Vizier Sinan Pasha; the site of the incineration is now the location of the Church of Saint Sava, one of the largest Orthodox churches in the world.
April 27, 1667: Blind and impoverished, John Milton sells the copyright of Paradise Lost for £10.
April 27, 1861: American President Abraham Lincoln suspends the writ of habeas corpus.
April 27, 1865: The New York State Senate creates Cornell University as the state's land grant institution.
April 27, 1906: The State Duma of the Russian Empire meets for the first time.
April 27, 1909: Sultan of Ottoman Empire Abdul Hamid II is overthrown, and is succeeded by his brother, Mehmed V.
April 27, 1911: Following the resignation and death of William P. Frye, a compromise is reached to rotate the office of President pro tempore of the United States Senate.
April 27, 1927: Carabineros de Chile (Chilean national police force and gendarmerie) are created.
April 27, 1936: The United Auto Workers (UAW) gains autonomy from the American Federation of Labor.
April 27, 1953: Operation Moolah offers $50,000 to any pilot who defected with a fully mission-capable Mikoyan-Gurevich MiG-15 to South Korea. The first pilot was to receive $100,000.
April 27, 1960: Togo gains independence from French-administered UN trusteeship.
April 27, 1961: Sierra Leone is granted its independence from the United Kingdom, with Milton Margai as the first Prime Minister.
April 27, 1967: Expo 67 officially opens in Montreal, Quebec, Canada with a large opening ceremony broadcast around the world. It opens to the public the next day.
April 27, 1974: Ten thousand march in Washington, D.C., calling for the impeachment of U.S. President Richard Nixon.
April 27, 1978: The Saur Revolution begins in Afghanistan, ending the following morning with the murder of Afghan President Mohammed Daoud Khan and the establishment of the Democratic Republic of Afghanistan.
April 27, 1981: Xerox PARC introduces the computer mouse.
April 27, 1986: The city of Pripyat and surrounding areas are evacuated due to Chernobyl disaster.
April 27, 1987: The U.S. Department of Justice bars Austrian President Kurt Waldheim (and his wife, Elisabeth, who had also been a Nazi) from entering the US, charging that he had aided in the deportations and executions of thousands of Jews and others as a German Army officer during World War II.
April 27, 1989: The April 27 demonstrations, student-led protests responding to the April 26 Editorial, during the Tiananmen Square protests of 1989.
April 27, 1992: The Russian Federation and 12 other former Soviet republics become members of the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank.
April 27, 1993: All members of the Zambia national football team lose their lives in a plane crash off Libreville, Gabon en route to Dakar, Senegal to play a 1994 FIFA World Cup qualifying match against Senegal.
April 27, 2005: Airbus A380 aircraft had its maiden test flight.
April 27, 2006: Construction begins on the Freedom Tower (later renamed One World Trade Center) in New York City.
April 27, 2007: Israeli archaeologists discover the tomb of Herod the Great south of Jerusalem.[1]
April 27, 2011: The 2011 Super Outbreak devastates parts of the Southeastern United States, especially the states of Alabama, Mississippi, Georgia, and Tennessee. 205 tornadoes touched down on April 27 alone, killing more than 300 and injuring hundreds more.
April 27, 2012: At least four explosions hit the Ukrainian city of Dnipropetrovsk with at least 27 people injured.
April 27, 2018: The Panmunjom Declaration is signed by the two Koreas, officially declaring their intentions to end of the Korean conflict.
April 28, 224: The Battle of Hormozdgan is fought. Ardashir I defeats and kills Artabanus V effectively ending the Parthian Empire.
April 28, 357: Emperor Constantius II enters Rome for the first time to celebrate his victory over Magnus Magnentius.
April 28, 1192: Assassination of Conrad of Montferrat (Conrad I), King of Jerusalem, in Tyre, two days after his title to the throne is confirmed by election. The killing is carried out by Hashshashin.
April 28, 1253: Nichiren, a Japanese Buddhist monk, propounds Namu Myōhō Renge Kyō for the very first time and declares it to be the essence of Buddhism, in effect founding Nichiren Buddhism.
April 28, 1503: The Battle of Cerignola is fought. It is noted as one of the first European battles in history won by small arms fire using gunpowder.
April 28, 1611: Establishment of the Pontifical and Royal University of Santo Tomas, The Catholic University of the Philippines, the largest Catholic university in the world.
April 28, 1788: Maryland becomes the seventh state to ratify the United States Constitution.
April 28, 1792: France invades the Austrian Netherlands (present day Belgium and Luxembourg), beginning the French Revolutionary Wars.
April 28, 1794: Sardinians, headed by Giovanni Maria Angioy, start a revolution against Savoy domination, expelling Viceroy Balbiano and his officials from Cagliari, the capital and largest city of the island.
April 28, 1796: The Armistice of Cherasco is signed by Napoleon Bonaparte and Vittorio Amedeo III, King of Sardinia, expanding French territory along the Mediterranean coast.
April 28, 1869: Chinese and Irish laborers for the Central Pacific Railroad working on the First Transcontinental Railroad lay ten miles of track in one day, a feat which has never been matched.
April 28, 1881: Billy the Kid escapes from the Lincoln County jail in Mesilla, New Mexico.
April 28, 1887: A week after being arrested by the Prussian Secret Police, French police inspector Guillaume Schnaebelé is released on order of William I, German Emperor, defusing a possible war.
April 28, 1910: Frenchman Louis Paulhan wins the 1910 London to Manchester air race, the first long-distance aeroplane race in England.
April 28, 1920: Azerbaijan is added to the Soviet Union.
April 28, 1923: Wembley Stadium is opened, named initially as the Empire Stadium.
April 28, 1930: The Independence Producers hosted the first night game in the history of Organized Baseball in Independence, Kansas.
April 28, 1941: The Ustaše massacre nearly 200 Serbs in the village of Gudovac, the first massacre of their genocidal campaign against Serbs of the Independent State of Croatia.
April 28, 1945: Benito Mussolini and his mistress Clara Petacci are shot dead by Walter Audisio, a member of the Italian resistance movement.
April 28, 1947: Thor Heyerdahl and five crew mates set out from Peru on the Kon-Tiki to demonstrate that Peruvian natives could have settled Polynesia.
April 28, 1948: Igor Stravinsky conducted the premiere of his American ballet, Orpheus at the New York City Center.
April 28, 1949: The Hukbalahap are accused of assassinating former First Lady of the Philippines Aurora Quezon, while she is en route to dedicate a hospital in memory of her late husband; her daughter and ten others are also killed.
April 28, 1952: The Sino-Japanese Peace Treaty (Treaty of Taipei) is signed in Taipei, Taiwan between Japan and the Republic of China to officially end the Second Sino-Japanese War.
April 28, 1969: Charles de Gaulle resigns as President of France.
April 28, 1973: The Dark Side of the Moon by Pink Floyd, recorded in Abbey Road Studios goes to number one on the US Billboard chart, beginning a record-breaking 741-week chart run.
April 28, 1975: General Cao Văn Viên, chief of the South Vietnamese military, departs for the US as the North Vietnamese Army closed in on victory.[1]
April 28, 1977: The Red Army Faction trial ends, with Andreas Baader, Gudrun Ensslin and Jan-Carl Raspe found guilty of four counts of murder and more than 30 counts of attempted murder.
April 28, 1978: President of Afghanistan, Mohammed Daoud Khan, is overthrown and assassinated in a coup led by pro-communist rebels.
April 28, 1986: High levels of radiation resulting from the Chernobyl disaster are detected at a nuclear power plant in Sweden, leading Soviet authorities to publicly announce the accident.
April 28, 1988: Near Maui, Hawaii, flight attendant Clarabelle "C.B." Lansing is blown out of Aloha Airlines Flight 243, a Boeing 737, and falls to her death when part of the plane's fuselage rips open in mid-flight.
April 28, 1994: Former Central Intelligence Agency counterintelligence officer and analyst Aldrich Ames pleads guilty to giving U.S. secrets to the Soviet Union and later Russia.
April 28, 2004: CBS News released evidence of the Abu Ghraib torture and prisoner abuse. The photographs show rape and abuse from the American troops over Iraqi detainees.
April 29, 1429: Joan of Arc arrives to relieve the Siege of Orléans.
April 29, 1483: Gran Canaria, the main island of the Canary Islands, is conquered by the Kingdom of Castile.
April 29, 1770: James Cook arrives in Australia at Botany Bay, which he names.
April 29, 1834: Charles Darwin during the second survey voyage of HMS Beagle, ascended the Bell mountain, Cerro La Campana on 17 August 1834, his visit being commemorated by a memorial plaque.[1]
April 29, 1864: Theta Xi fraternity is founded at Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute, the only fraternity to be founded during the American Civil War.[2]
April 29, 1903: A 30 million cubic-metre landslide kills 70 people in Frank, in the District of Alberta, Canada.
April 29, 1910: The Parliament of the United Kingdom passes the People's Budget, the first budget in British history with the expressed intent of redistributing wealth among the British public.
April 29, 1911: Tsinghua University, one of mainland China's leading universities, is founded.[3]
April 29, 1945: The Italian commune of Fornovo di Taro is liberated from German forces by Brazilian forces.
April 29, 1946: The International Military Tribunal for the Far East convenes and indicts former Prime Minister of Japan Hideki Tojo and 28 former Japanese leaders for war crimes.
April 29, 1951: Tibetan delegates to the Central People's Government arrive in Beijing and draft a Seventeen Point Agreement for Chinese sovereignty and Tibetan autonomy.
April 29, 1953: The first U.S. experimental 3D television broadcast showed an episode of Space Patrol on Los Angeles ABC affiliate KECA-TV.
April 29, 1965: Pakistan's Space and Upper Atmosphere Research Commission (SUPARCO) successfully launches its seventh rocket in its Rehber series.
April 29, 1967: After refusing induction into the United States Army the previous day, Muhammad Ali is stripped of his boxing title.
April 29, 1968: The controversial musical Hair, a product of the hippie counter-culture and sexual revolution of the 1960s, opens at the Biltmore Theatre on Broadway, with some of its songs becoming anthems of the anti-Vietnam War movement.
April 29, 1986: A fire at the Central library of the City of Los Angeles Public Library damages or destroys 400,000 books and other items.
April 29, 1991: The 7.0 Mw  Racha earthquake affects Georgia with a maximum MSK intensity of IX (Destructive), killing 270 people.
April 29, 1992: Riots in Los Angeles, following the acquittal of police officers charged with excessive force in the beating of Rodney King. Over the next three days 63 people are killed and hundreds of buildings are destroyed.
April 29, 1997: The Chemical Weapons Convention of 1993 enters into force, outlawing the production, stockpiling and use of chemical weapons by its signatories.
April 29, 2011: The Wedding of Prince William and Catherine Middleton takes place at Westminster Abbey in London.
April 29, 2013: National Airlines Flight 102, a Boeing 747-400, crashes during takeoff from Bagram Airfield in Afghanistan, killing all seven people on board.[6]
April 29, 2015: A baseball game between the Baltimore Orioles and the Chicago White Sox sets the all-time low attendance mark for Major League Baseball. Zero fans were in attendance for the game, as the stadium was officially closed to the public due to the 2015 Baltimore protests.
April 30, 311: The Diocletianic Persecution of Christians in the Roman Empire ends.
April 30, 642: Chindasuinth is proclaimed king by the Visigothic nobility and bishops.
April 30, 1315: Enguerrand de Marigny is hanged at the instigation of Charles, Count of Valois.
April 30, 1492: Spain gives Christopher Columbus his commission of exploration.
April 30, 1513: Edmund de la Pole, Yorkist pretender to the English throne, is executed on the orders of Henry VIII.
April 30, 1557: Mapuche leader Lautaro is killed by Spanish forces at the Battle of Mataquito in Chile.
April 30, 1598: Henry IV of France issues the Edict of Nantes, allowing freedom of religion to the Huguenots.
April 30, 1671: Petar Zrinski, the Croatian Ban from the Zrinski family, is executed.
April 30, 1789: On the balcony of Federal Hall on Wall Street in New York City, George Washington takes the oath of office to become the first elected President of the United States.
April 30, 1812: The Territory of Orleans becomes the 18th U.S. state under the name Louisiana.
April 30, 1838: Nicaragua declares independence from the Central American Federation.
April 30, 1863: A 65-man French Foreign Legion infantry patrol fights a force of nearly 2,000 Mexican soldiers to nearly the last man in Hacienda Camarón, Mexico.
April 30, 1871: The Camp Grant massacre takes place in Arizona Territory.
April 30, 1885: Governor of New York David B. Hill signs legislation creating the Niagara Reservation, New York's first state park, ensuring that Niagara Falls will not be devoted solely to industrial and commercial use.
April 30, 1897: J. J. Thomson of the Cavendish Laboratory announces his discovery of the electron as a subatomic particle, over 1,800 times smaller than a proton (in the atomic nucleus), at a lecture at the Royal Institution in London.[1]
April 30, 1900: Hawaii becomes a territory of the United States, with Sanford B. Dole as governor.
April 30, 1904: The Louisiana Purchase Exposition World's Fair opens in St. Louis, Missouri.
April 30, 1905: Albert Einstein completes his doctoral thesis at the University of Zurich.
April 30, 1925: Automaker Dodge Brothers, Inc is sold to Dillon, Read & Co. for US$146 million plus $50 million for charity.
April 30, 1927: Douglas Fairbanks and Mary Pickford become the first celebrities to leave their footprints in concrete at Grauman's Chinese Theater in Hollywood.
April 30, 1937: The Commonwealth of the Philippines holds a plebiscite for Filipino women on whether they should be extended the right to suffrage; over 90% would vote in the affirmative.
April 30, 1938: The animated cartoon short Porky's Hare Hunt debuts in movie theaters, introducing Happy Rabbit, an early version of Bugs Bunny.
April 30, 1939: NBC inaugurates its regularly scheduled television service in New York City, broadcasting President Franklin D. Roosevelt's N.Y. World's Fair opening day ceremonial address.
April 30, 1947: In Nevada, Boulder Dam is renamed Hoover Dam.
April 30, 1948: In Bogotá, Colombia, the Organization of American States is established.
April 30, 1956: Former Vice President and Democratic Senator Alben Barkley dies during a speech in Virginia.
April 30, 1957: Supplementary Convention on the Abolition of Slavery entered into force.
April 30, 1961: K-19, the first Soviet nuclear submarine equipped with nuclear missiles, is commissioned.
April 30, 1963: The Bristol Bus Boycott is held in Bristol to protest the Bristol Omnibus Company's refusal to employ Black or Asian bus crews, drawing national attention to racial discrimination in the United Kingdom.
April 30, 1966: The Church of Satan is formed in The Black House, San Francisco.
April 30, 1980: The Iranian Embassy siege begins in London.
April 30, 1982: The Bijon Setu massacre occurs in Calcutta, India.
April 30, 1993: CERN announces World Wide Web protocols will be free.
April 30, 1994: Formula One racing driver Roland Ratzenberger is killed in a crash during the qualifying session of the San Marino Grand Prix run at Autodromo Enzo e Dino Ferrari outside Imola, Italy.
April 30, 2000: Canonization of Faustina Kowalska in the presence of 200,000 people and the first Divine Mercy Sunday celebrated worldwide.
April 30, 2004: U.S. media release graphic photos of American soldiers abusing and sexually humiliating Iraqi prisoners at Abu Ghraib prison.
April 30, 2008: Two skeletal remains found near Yekaterinburg, Russia are confirmed by Russian scientists to be the remains of Alexei and Anastasia, two of the children of the last Tsar of Russia, whose entire family was executed at Yekaterinburg by the Bolsheviks.
April 30, 2009: Seven civilians and the perpetrator are killed and another ten injured at a Queen's Day parade in Apeldoorn, Netherlands in an attempted assassination on Queen Beatrix.
April 30, 2012: An overloaded ferry capsizes on the Brahmaputra River in India killing at least 103 people.
April 30, 2013: Willem-Alexander is inaugurated as King of the Netherlands following the abdication of Beatrix.
April 30, 2014: A bomb blast in Ürümqi, China kills three people and injures 79 others.
May 1, 0475 BC: Roman consul Publius Valerius Poplicola celebrates a Roman triumph for his victory over Veii and the Sabines.
May 1, 0305: Diocletian and Maximian retire from the office of Roman emperor.
May 1, 0524: King Sigismund of Burgundy is executed at Orléans after an 8-year reign and is succeeded by his brother Godomar.
May 1, 0880: The Nea Ekklesia is inaugurated in Constantinople, setting the model for all later cross-in-square Orthodox churches.
May 1, 1169: Norman mercenaries land at Bannow Bay in Leinster, marking the beginning of the Norman invasion of Ireland.
May 1, 1455: Battle of Arkinholm, Royal forces end the Black Douglas hegemony in Scotland.
May 1, 1576: Stephen Báthory, the reigning Prince of Transylvania, marries Anna Jagiellon and they become co-rulers of the Polish–Lithuanian Commonwealth.
May 1, 1707: The Act of Union joining the Kingdom of England and Kingdom of Scotland to form the Kingdom of Great Britain takes effect.
May 1, 1753: Publication of Species Plantarum by Linnaeus, and the formal start date of plant taxonomy adopted by the International Code of Botanical Nomenclature.
May 1, 1759: Josiah Wedgwood founds the Wedgwood pottery company in Great Britain.[1]
May 1, 1776: Establishment of the Illuminati in Ingolstadt (Upper Bavaria), by Jesuit-taught Adam Weishaupt.
May 1, 1786: In Vienna, Austria, Mozart's opera The Marriage of Figaro is performed for the first time.[2]
May 1, 1820: Execution of the Cato Street Conspirators, who plotted to kill the British Cabinet and Prime Minister Lord Liverpool.[3]
May 1, 1840: The Penny Black, the first official adhesive postage stamp, is issued in the United Kingdom.
May 1, 1844: Hong Kong Police Force, the world's second modern police force and Asia's first, is established.
May 1, 1846: The few remaining Mormons left in Nauvoo, Illinois, formally dedicate the Nauvoo Temple.
May 1, 1851: Queen Victoria opens The Great Exhibition at The Crystal Palace in London.
May 1, 1856: The Province of Isabela was created in the Philippines in honor of Queen Isabela II.
May 1, 1865: The Empire of Brazil, Argentina, and Uruguay sign the Treaty of the Triple Alliance.
May 1, 1866: The Memphis Race Riots begin. In three days time, 46 blacks and two whites were killed. Reports of the atrocities influenced passage of the Fourteenth Amendment to the United States Constitution.[5]
May 1, 1869: The Folies Bergère opens in Paris.
May 1, 1875: Alexandra Palace reopens after being burned down in a fire in 1873.
May 1, 1884: Moses Fleetwood Walker becomes the first black person to play in a professional baseball game in the United States.
May 1, 1885: The original Chicago Board of Trade Building opens for business.
May 1, 1886: Rallies are held throughout the United States demanding the eight-hour work day, culminating in the Haymarket affair in Chicago, in commemoration of which May 1 is celebrated as International Workers' Day in many countries.
May 1, 1893: The World's Columbian Exposition opens in Chicago.[7]
May 1, 1894: Coxey's Army, the first significant American protest march, arrives in Washington, D.C.[8]
May 1, 1900: The Scofield Mine disaster kills over 200 men in Scofield, Utah in what is to date the fifth-worst mining accident in United States history.
May 1, 1915: The RMS Lusitania departs from New York City on her 202nd, and final, crossing of the North Atlantic. Six days later, the ship is torpedoed off the coast of Ireland with the loss of 1,198 lives.
May 1, 1919: German troops enter Munich to squash the Bavarian Soviet Republic.
May 1, 1925: The All-China Federation of Trade Unions is officially founded. Today it is the largest trade union in the world, with 134 million members.
May 1, 1927: The Union Labor Life Insurance Company is founded by the American Federation of Labor.[10]
May 1, 1929: The 7.2 Mw  Kopet Dag earthquake shakes the Iran–Turkmenistan border region with a maximum Mercalli intensity of IX (Violent), killing up to 3,800 and injuring 1,121.
May 1, 1930: "Pluto" is officially proposed by the for the name of the newly-discovered dwarf planet Pluto by Vesto Slipher in the Lowell Observtory Observation Circular. The name quickly catches on.[11]
May 1, 1931: The Empire State Building is dedicated in New York City.
May 1, 1946: The Paris Peace Conference concludes that the islands of the Dodecanese should be returned to Greece by Italy.
May 1, 1947: Portella della Ginestra massacre against May Day celebrations in Sicily by the bandit and separatist leader Salvatore Giuliano where 11 persons are killed and 33 wounded.
May 1, 1956: A doctor in Japan reports an "epidemic of an unknown disease of the central nervous system", marking the official discovery of Minamata disease.
May 1, 1957: Thirty-four people are killed when a Vickers Viking airliner crashes in Hampshire, England.
May 1, 1960: Formation of the western Indian states of Gujarat and Maharashtra; also known as "Maharashtra Day".
May 1, 1961: The Prime Minister of Cuba, Fidel Castro, proclaims Cuba a socialist nation and abolishes elections.
May 1, 1967: Elvis Presley and Priscilla Beaulieu are married in Las Vegas.
May 1, 1971: Amtrak (the National Railroad Passenger Corporation) takes over operation of U.S. passenger rail service.[12]
May 1, 1974: The Argentine terrorist organization Montoneros is expelled from Plaza de Mayo by president Juan Perón.
May 1, 1977: Thirty-six people are killed in Taksim Square, Istanbul, during the Labour Day celebrations.
May 1, 1978: Japan's Naomi Uemura, travelling by dog sled, becomes the first person to reach the North Pole alone.
May 1, 1983: The Sydney Entertainment Centre is opened.
May 1, 1987: Pope John Paul II beatifies Edith Stein, a Jewish-born Carmelite nun who was gassed in the Nazi concentration camp at Auschwitz.
May 1, 1989: Disney-MGM Studios opens at Walt Disney World near Orlando, Florida, United States.
May 1, 1990: The former Philippine Episcopal Church (supervised by the Episcopal Church of the United States of America) is granted full autonomy and raised to the status of an Autocephalous Anglican Province and renamed the Episcopal Church in the Philippines.
May 1, 1993: Dingiri Banda Wijetunga became president of Sri Lanka automatically after killing of R Premadasa in LTTE bomb explosion.
May 1, 1994: Three-time Formula One world champion Ayrton Senna is killed in an accident whilst leading the San Marino Grand Prix at Imola.
May 1, 2001: Philippine President Gloria Macapagal Arroyo declares the existence of "a state of rebellion", hours after thousands of supporters of her arrested predecessor, Joseph Estrada, storm towards the presidential palace at the height of the EDSA III rebellion.
May 1, 2002: OpenOffice.org released version 1.0, the first stable version of the software.
May 1, 2004: Cyprus, Czech Republic, Estonia, Hungary, Latvia, Lithuania, Malta, Poland, Slovakia, and Slovenia join the European Union, celebrated at the residence of the Irish President in Dublin.
May 1, 2009: Same-sex marriage is legalized in Sweden.
May 1, 2011: Pope John Paul II is beatified by his successor, Pope Benedict XVI.
May 2, 1194: King Richard I of England gives Portsmouth its first Royal Charter.
May 2, 1230: William de Braose is hanged by Prince Llywelyn the Great.
May 2, 1335: Otto the Merry, Duke of Austria, becomes Duke of Carinthia.
May 2, 1536: Anne Boleyn, Queen of England, is arrested and imprisoned on charges of adultery, incest, treason and witchcraft.
May 2, 1559: John Knox returns from exile to Scotland to become the leader of the nascent Scottish Reformation.
May 2, 1568: Mary, Queen of Scots, escapes from Loch Leven Castle.
May 2, 1611: The King James Version of the Bible is published for the first time in London, England, by printer Robert Barker.
May 2, 1670: King Charles II of England grants a permanent charter to the Hudson's Bay Company to open up the fur trade in North America.
May 2, 1672: John Maitland becomes Duke of Lauderdale and Earl of March.
May 2, 1812: The Siege of Cuautla during the Mexican War of Independence ends with both sides claiming victory after Mexican rebels under José María Morelos y Pavón abandon the city after 72 days under siege by royalist Spanish troops under Félix María Calleja.
May 2, 1816: Marriage of Léopold of Saxe-Coburg and Princess Charlotte of Wales.
May 2, 1829: After anchoring nearby, Captain Charles Fremantle of HMS Challenger, declares the Swan River Colony in Australia.
May 2, 1866: Peruvian defenders fight off the Spanish fleet at the Battle of Callao.
May 2, 1876: The April Uprising breaks out in Ottoman Bulgaria.
May 2, 1879: The Spanish Socialist Workers' Party is founded in Madrid by Pablo Iglesias.
May 2, 1885: Cree and Assiniboine warriors win the Battle of Cut Knife, their largest victory over Canadian forces during the North-West Rebellion.
May 2, 1889: Menelik II, Emperor of Ethiopia, signs the Treaty of Wuchale, giving Italy control over Eritrea.
May 2, 1906: Closing ceremony of the Intercalated Games in Athens, Greece.
May 2, 1918: General Motors acquires the Chevrolet Motor Company of Delaware.
May 2, 1920: The first game of the Negro National League baseball is played in Indianapolis.
May 2, 1933: Germany's independent labor unions are replaced by the German Labour Front.
May 2, 1941: Following the coup d'état against Iraq Crown Prince 'Abd al-Ilah earlier that year, the United Kingdom launches the Anglo-Iraqi War to restore him to power.
May 2, 1952: The world's first ever jet airliner, the De Havilland Comet 1 makes its maiden flight, from London to Johannesburg.
May 2, 1955: Tennessee Williams wins the Pulitzer Prize for Drama for Cat on a Hot Tin Roof.
May 2, 1963: Berthold Seliger launches a rocket with three stages and a maximum flight altitude of more than 100 kilometres near Cuxhaven. It is the only sounding rocket developed in Germany.
May 2, 1964: First ascent of Shishapangma, the fourteenth highest mountain in the world and the lowest of the Eight-thousanders.
May 2, 1969: The British ocean liner Queen Elizabeth 2 departs on her maiden voyage to New York City.
May 2, 1972: In the early morning hours a fire breaks out at the Sunshine Mine located between Kellogg and Wallace, Idaho, killing 91 workers.
May 2, 1994: A bus crashes in Gdańsk, Poland killing 32 people.
May 2, 1995: During the Croatian War of Independence, the Army of the Republic of Serb Krajina fires cluster bombs at Zagreb, killing seven and wounding over 175 civilians.
May 2, 1998: The European Central Bank is founded in Brussels in order to define and execute the European Union's monetary policy.
May 2, 2000: President Bill Clinton announces that accurate GPS access would no longer be restricted to the United States military.
May 2, 2004: The Yelwa massacre concludes. It began on 4 February 2004 when armed Muslims killed 78 Christians at Yelwa. In response, about 630 Muslims were killed by Christians on May 2nd.
May 2, 2008: Chaitén Volcano begins erupting in Chile, forcing the evacuation of more than 4,500 people.
May 2, 2011: An E. coli outbreak strikes Europe, mostly in Germany, leaving more than 30 people dead and many others sick from the bacteria outbreak.
May 2, 2012: A pastel version of The Scream, by Norwegian painter Edvard Munch, sells for $120 million in a New York City auction, setting a new world record for a work of art at auction.
May 2, 2014: Two mudslides in Badakhshan, Afghanistan, leave up to 2,500 people missing.
May 2, 2018: Basque separatist terrorist band ETA announces its dissolution and ceasing of all activities.
May 3, 0752: Mayan king Bird Jaguar IV of Yaxchilan in modern-day Chiapas, Mexico assumes the throne.
May 3, 1294: John II becomes Duke of Brabant, Lothier and Limburg.
May 3, 1481: The largest of three earthquakes strikes the island of Rhodes and causes an estimated 30,000 casualties.
May 3, 1491: Kongo monarch Nkuwu Nzinga is baptised by Portuguese missionaries, adopting the baptismal name of João I.
May 3, 1616: Treaty of Loudun ends French civil war.
May 3, 1715: A total solar eclipse was visible across northern Europe, and northern Asia, as predicted by Edmond Halley to within 4 minutes accuracy.
May 3, 1791: The Constitution of May 3 (the first modern constitution in Europe) is proclaimed by the Sejm of Polish–Lithuanian Commonwealth.
May 3, 1802: Washington, D.C. is incorporated as a city after Congress abolishes the Board of Commissioners, the District's founding government. The "City of Washington" is given a mayor-council form of government.[1]
May 3, 1830: The Canterbury and Whitstable Railway is opened; it is the first steam-hauled passenger railway to issue season tickets and include a tunnel.
May 3, 1837: The University of Athens is founded in Athens, Greece.
May 3, 1848: The boar-crested Anglo-Saxon Benty Grange helmet is discovered in a barrow on the Benty Grange farm in Derbyshire.
May 3, 1855: American adventurer William Walker departs from San Francisco with about 60 men to conquer Nicaragua.
May 3, 1860: Charles XV of Sweden–Norway is crowned king of Sweden.
May 3, 1867: The Hudson's Bay Company gives up all claims to Vancouver Island.
May 3, 1901: The Great Fire of 1901 begins in Jacksonville, Florida.
May 3, 1913: Raja Harishchandra the first full-length Indian feature film is released, marking the beginning of the Indian film industry.
May 3, 1920: A Bolshevik coup fails in the Democratic Republic of Georgia.
May 3, 1921: The Government of Ireland Act 1920 is passed, dividing Ireland into Northern Ireland and Southern Ireland.
May 3, 1928: The Jinan incident begins with the deaths of twelve Japanese civilians by Chinese forces in Jinan, China, which leads to Japanese retaliation and the deaths of over 2,000 Chinese civilians in the following days.[2]
May 3, 1939: The All India Forward Bloc is formed by Netaji Subhas Chandra Bose.
May 3, 1947: New post-war Japanese constitution goes into effect.
May 3, 1948: The U.S. Supreme Court rules in Shelley v. Kraemer that covenants prohibiting the sale of real estate to blacks and other minorities are legally unenforceable.[3]
May 3, 1951: The United States Senate Committee on Armed Services and United States Senate Committee on Foreign Relations begin their closed door hearings into the dismissal of General Douglas MacArthur by U.S. President Harry Truman.
May 3, 1952: The Kentucky Derby is televised nationally for the first time, on the CBS network.
May 3, 1957: Walter O'Malley, the owner of the Brooklyn Dodgers, agrees to move the team from Brooklyn to Los Angeles.
May 3, 1960: The Anne Frank House museum opens in Amsterdam, Netherlands.
May 3, 1963: The police force in Birmingham, Alabama switches tactics and responds with violent force to stop the "Birmingham campaign" protesters.  Images of the violent suppression are transmitted worldwide, bringing new-found attention to the civil rights movement.
May 3, 1971: Erich Honecker becomes First Secretary of the Socialist Unity Party of Germany, remaining in power until 1989.[4]
May 3, 1973: The 108-story Sears Tower in Chicago is topped out at 1,451 feet as the world's tallest building.
May 3, 1978: The first unsolicited bulk commercial email (which would later become known as "spam") is sent by a Digital Equipment Corporation marketing representative to every ARPANET address on the west coast of the United States.
May 3, 1986: Twenty-one people are killed and forty-one are injured after a bomb explodes on Air Lanka Flight 512 at Colombo airport in Sri Lanka.
May 3, 1987: A crash by Bobby Allison at the Talladega Superspeedway, Alabama fencing at the start-finish line would lead NASCAR to develop the restrictor plate for the following season both at Daytona International Speedway and Talladega.
May 3, 1999: The southwestern portion of Oklahoma City is devastated by an F5 tornado, killing forty-five people, injuring 665, and causing $1 billion in damage.  The tornado is one of 66 from the 1999 Oklahoma tornado outbreak. This tornado also produces the highest wind speed ever recorded, measured at 301 +/- 20 mph (484 +/- 32 km/h).
May 3, 2000: The sport of geocaching begins, with the first cache placed and the coordinates from a GPS posted on Usenet.
May 3, 2001: The United States loses its seat on the U.N. Human Rights Commission for the first time since the commission was formed in 1947.
May 3, 2002: An Indian Air Force MiG-21 crashes into a bank in Jalandhar, killing eight and injuring 17.
May 3, 2007: The 3-year-old British girl Madeleine McCann disappears in Praia da Luz, Portugal, starting "the most heavily reported missing-person case in modern history".
May 3, 2015: Two gunmen launch an attempted attack on an anti-Islam event in Garland, Texas, which was held in response to the Charlie Hebdo shooting.
May 3, 2016: Eighty-eight thousand people were evacuated from their homes in Fort McMurray, Alberta, Canada as a wildfire ripped through the community, destroying approximately 2,400 homes and buildings.
May 4, 1256: The Augustinian monastic order is constituted at the Lecceto Monastery when Pope Alexander IV issues a papal bull Licet ecclesiae catholicae.
May 4, 1415: Religious reformers John Wycliffe and Jan Hus are condemned as heretics at the Council of Constance.
May 4, 1436: Assassination of the Swedish rebel (later national hero) Engelbrekt Engelbrektsson
May 4, 1493: Pope Alexander VI divides the New World between Spain and Portugal along the Line of Demarcation.
May 4, 1626: Dutch explorer Peter Minuit arrives in New Netherland (present day Manhattan Island) aboard the See Meeuw.
May 4, 1686: The Municipality of Ilagan is founded in the Philippines.
May 4, 1776: Rhode Island becomes the first American colony to renounce allegiance to King George III.
May 4, 1814: King Ferdinand VII of Spain signs the Decree of the 4th of May, returning Spain to absolutism.
May 4, 1836: Formation of Ancient Order of Hibernians
May 4, 1859: The Cornwall Railway opens across the Royal Albert Bridge linking Devon and Cornwall in England.
May 4, 1865: Surrender of the Confederate departments of Alabama, Mississippi and East Louisiana at Citronelle, Alabama.
May 4, 1869: The Naval Battle of Hakodate is fought in Japan.
May 4, 1871: The National Association, the first professional baseball league, opens its first season in Fort Wayne, Indiana.
May 4, 1904: The United States begins construction of the Panama Canal.
May 4, 1910: The Royal Canadian Navy is created.
May 4, 1912: Italy occupies the Greek island of Rhodes.
May 4, 1926: The United Kingdom general strike begins.
May 4, 1932: In Atlanta, mobster Al Capone begins serving an eleven-year prison sentence for tax evasion.
May 4, 1946: In San Francisco Bay, U.S. Marines from the nearby Treasure Island Naval Base stop a two-day riot at Alcatraz Federal Penitentiary; 5 people are killed in the riot.
May 4, 1953: Ernest Hemingway wins the Pulitzer Prize for The Old Man and the Sea.
May 4, 1959: The 1st Annual Grammy Awards are held.
May 4, 1961: Malcolm Ross and Victor Prather attain a new altitude record for manned balloon flight ascending in the Strato-Lab V open gondola to 113,740 feet (34.67 km).
May 4, 1972: The Don't Make A Wave Committee, a fledgling environmental organization founded in Canada in 1971, officially changes its name to "Greenpeace Foundation".
May 4, 1978: The South African Defence Force attacks a SWAPO base at Cassinga in southern Angola, killing about 600 people.
May 4, 1979: Margaret Thatcher becomes the first female Prime Minister of the United Kingdom.
May 4, 1982: Twenty sailors are killed when the British Type 42 destroyer HMS Sheffield is hit by an Argentinian Exocet missile during the Falklands War.
May 4, 1988: The PEPCON disaster rocks Henderson, Nevada, as tons of Space Shuttle fuel detonate during a fire.
May 4, 1990: Latvia proclaims the renewal of its independence after the Soviet occupation.
May 4, 1994: Israeli Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin and PLO leader Yasser Arafat sign a peace accord, granting self-rule in the Gaza Strip and Jericho.
May 4, 1998: A federal judge in Sacramento, California, gives "Unabomber" Theodore Kaczynski four life sentences plus 30 years after Kaczynski accepts a plea agreement sparing him from the death penalty.
May 4, 2000: Ken Livingstone becomes the first Mayor of London.
May 4, 2007: Greensburg, Kansas is almost completely destroyed by a 1.7 mi wide EF5 tornado. It was the first-ever tornado to be rated as such with the new Enhanced Fujita scale.
May 4, 2014: Three people are killed and 62 injured in a pair of bombings on buses in Nairobi, Kenya.
May 5, 0553: The Second Council of Constantinople begins.
May 5, 1215: Rebel barons renounce their allegiance to King John of England — part of a chain of events leading to the signing of the Magna Carta.
May 5, 1260: Kublai Khan becomes ruler of the Mongol Empire.
May 5, 1494: Christopher Columbus lands on the island of Jamaica and claims it for Spain.
May 5, 1640: King Charles I of England dissolves the Short Parliament.
May 5, 1654: Cromwell's Act of Grace, aimed at reconciliation with the Scots, proclaimed in Edinburgh.
May 5, 1762: Russia and Prussia sign the Treaty of St. Petersburg.
May 5, 1789: In France, the Estates-General convenes for the first time since 1614.
May 5, 1809: The Swiss canton of Aargau allows citizenship to Jews.
May 5, 1811: In the second day of fighting at the Peninsular War Battle of Fuentes de Oñoro the French army, under Marshall André Masséna, drive in the Duke of Wellington's overextended right flank, but French frontal assaults fail to take the town of Fuentes de Oñoro and the Anglo-Portuguese army holds the field at the end of the day.
May 5, 1821: Emperor Napoleon dies in exile on the island of Saint Helena in the South Atlantic Ocean.
May 5, 1835: The first railway in continental Europe opens between Brussels and Mechelen.
May 5, 1860: Giuseppe Garibaldi sets sail from Genoa, leading the expedition of the Thousand to conquer the Kingdom of the Two Sicilies and giving birth to the Kingdom of Italy.
May 5, 1866: Memorial Day first celebrated in United States at Waterloo, New York.
May 5, 1891: The Music Hall in New York City (later known as Carnegie Hall) has its grand opening and first public performance, with Tchaikovsky as the guest conductor.
May 5, 1904: Pitching against the Philadelphia Athletics at the Huntington Avenue Grounds, Cy Young of the Boston Americans throws the first perfect game in the modern era of baseball.
May 5, 1905: The trial in the Stratton Brothers case begins in London, England; it marks the first time that fingerprint evidence is used to gain a conviction for murder.
May 5, 1912: Pravda, the "voice" of the Communist Party of the Soviet Union, begins publication in Saint Petersburg.
May 5, 1920: Authorities arrest Nicola Sacco and Bartolomeo Vanzetti for alleged robbery and murder.
May 5, 1927: To the Lighthouse by Virginia Woolf is first published.
May 5, 1936: Italian troops occupy Addis Ababa, Ethiopia.
May 5, 1941: Emperor Haile Selassie returns to Addis Ababa; the country commemorates the date as Liberation Day or Patriots' Victory Day.
May 5, 1946: The International Military Tribunal for the Far East begins in Tokyo with twenty-eight Japanese military and government officials accused of war crimes and crimes against humanity.
May 5, 1950: Bhumibol Adulyadej is crowned as King of Thailand.
May 5, 1955: The General Treaty, by which France, Britain and the United States recognize the sovereignty of West Germany, comes into effect.
May 5, 1961: Alan Shepard becomes the first American to travel into outer space, on a sub-orbital flight.
May 5, 1964: The Council of Europe declares May 5 as Europe Day.
May 5, 1972: Alitalia Flight 112 crashes into Mount Longa near Palermo, Sicily, killing all 115 aboard, making it the deadliest single-aircraft disaster in Italy.
May 5, 1981: Bobby Sands dies in the Long Kesh prison hospital after 66 days of hunger-striking, aged 27.
May 5, 1985: Ronald Reagan visits the military cemetery at Bitburg and the site of the Bergen-Belsen concentration camp, where he makes a speech.
May 5, 1991: A riot breaks out in the Mt. Pleasant section of Washington, D.C. after police shoot a Salvadoran man.
May 5, 1994: American teenager Michael P. Fay is caned in Singapore for theft and vandalism.
May 5, 2006: The government of Sudan signs an accord with the Sudan Liberation Army.
May 5, 2010: Mass protests in Greece erupt in response to austerity measures imposed by the government as a result of the Greek government-debt crisis.
May 5, 2014: Twenty-two people die after two boats carrying refugees collide in the Aegean Sea off the coast of Greece.
May 5, 2019: A Russian plane jet burst into flames while attempting an emergency landing at Sheremetyevo Airport in Moscow killing at least 41 people.[1]
May 6, 1527: Spanish and German troops sack Rome; many scholars consider this the end of the Renaissance.[1]
May 6, 1536: King Henry VIII orders English-language Bibles be placed in every church. In 1539 the Great Bible would be provided for this purpose.
May 6, 1542: Francis Xavier reaches Old Goa, the capital of Portuguese India at the time.
May 6, 1682: Louis XIV of France moves his court to the Palace of Versailles.
May 6, 1757: English poet Christopher Smart is admitted into St Luke's Hospital for Lunatics in London, beginning his six-year confinement to mental asylums.
May 6, 1782: Construction begins on the Grand Palace, the royal residence of the King of Siam in Bangkok, at the command of King Buddha Yodfa Chulaloke.
May 6, 1801: Captain Thomas Cochrane in the 14-gun HMS Speedy captures the 32-gun Spanish frigate El Gamo.
May 6, 1835: James Gordon Bennett, Sr. publishes the first issue of the New York Herald.
May 6, 1840: The Penny Black postage stamp becomes valid for use in the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Ireland.
May 6, 1857: The British East India Company disbands the 34th Regiment of Bengal Native Infantry whose sepoy Mangal Pandey had earlier revolted against the British and is considered to be the First Martyr in the War of Indian Independence.
May 6, 1877: Chief Crazy Horse of the Oglala Lakota surrenders to United States troops in Nebraska.
May 6, 1882: The United States Congress passes the Chinese Exclusion Act.
May 6, 1889: The Eiffel Tower is officially opened to the public at the Universal Exposition in Paris.
May 6, 1906: The Russian Constitution of 1906 is adopted (on April 23 by the Julian calendar).
May 6, 1910: George V becomes King of the United Kingdom upon the death of his father, Edward VII.
May 6, 1915: Babe Ruth, then a pitcher for the Boston Red Sox, hits his first major league home run.
May 6, 1916: Vietnamese Emperor Duy Tân is captured while attempting to call upon the people to rise up against the French, and is later deposed and exiled to Réunion island.
May 6, 1933: The Deutsche Studentenschaft attacked Magnus Hirschfeld's Institut für Sexualwissenschaft, later burning many of its books.
May 6, 1940: John Steinbeck is awarded the Pulitzer Prize for his novel The Grapes of Wrath.
May 6, 1941: The first flight of the Republic P-47 Thunderbolt.
May 6, 1949: EDSAC, the first practical electronic digital stored-program computer, runs its first operation.[3]
May 6, 1954: Roger Bannister becomes the first person to run the mile in under four minutes.
May 6, 1960: More than 20 million viewers watch the first televised royal wedding when Princess Margaret marries Anthony Armstrong-Jones at Westminster Abbey.
May 6, 1966: Myra Hindley and Ian Brady are sentenced to life imprisonment for the Moors murders in England.
May 6, 1972: Deniz Gezmiş, Yusuf Aslan and Hüseyin İnan are executed in Ankara after being convicted of attempting to overthrow the Constitutional order.
May 6, 1975: During a lull in fighting, 100,000 Armenians gather in Beirut to commemorate 60th anniversary of the Armenian Genocide.
May 6, 1976: The 6.5 Mw  Friuli earthquake affected Northern Italy with a maximum Mercalli intensity of X (Extreme), leaving 900–978 dead and 1,700–2,400 injured.
May 6, 1983: The Hitler Diaries are revealed as a hoax after being examined by experts.
May 6, 1984: One hundred three Korean Martyrs are canonized by Pope John Paul II in Seoul.
May 6, 1988: All thirty-six passengers and crew were killed when Widerøe Flight 710 crashed into Mt. Torghatten in Brønnøy.
May 6, 1994: Queen Elizabeth II of the United Kingdom and French President François Mitterrand officiate at the opening of the Channel Tunnel.
May 6, 1996: The body of former CIA director William Colby is found washed up on a riverbank in southern Maryland, eight days after he disappeared.
May 6, 1997: The Bank of England is given independence from political control, the most significant change in the bank's 300-year history.
May 6, 1998: Kerry Wood strikes out 20 Houston Astros to tie the major league record held by Roger Clemens. He threw a one-hitter and did not walk a batter in his fifth career start.
May 6, 1999: The first elections to the devolved Scottish Parliament and Welsh Assembly are held.
May 6, 2001: During a trip to Syria, Pope John Paul II becomes the first pope to enter a mosque.
May 6, 2002: Dutch politician Pim Fortuyn is assassinated following a radio-interview at the Mediapark in Hilversum.
May 6, 2010: In just 36 minutes, the Dow-Jones average plunged nearly 1000 points in what is known as the 2010 Flash Crash.
May 6, 2013: Three women, kidnapped and missing for more than a decade, are found alive in Cleveland, Ohio, in the United States.[4]
May 7, 351: The Jewish revolt against Constantius Gallus breaks out. After his arrival at Antioch, the Jews begin a rebellion in Palestine.
May 7, 558: In Constantinople, the dome of the Hagia Sophia collapses. Justinian I immediately orders that the dome be rebuilt.
May 7, 1274: In France, the Second Council of Lyon opens to regulate the election of the Pope.
May 7, 1487: The Siege of Málaga commences during the Spanish Reconquista.
May 7, 1664: Louis XIV of France begins construction of the Palace of Versailles.
May 7, 1685: Battle of Vrtijeljka between rebels and Ottoman forces.
May 7, 1697: Stockholm's royal castle (dating back to medieval times) is destroyed by fire. It is replaced in the 18th century by the current Royal Palace.
May 7, 1718: The city of New Orleans is founded by Jean-Baptiste Le Moyne, Sieur de Bienville.
May 7, 1763: Pontiac's War begins with Pontiac's attempt to seize Fort Detroit from the British.
May 7, 1824: World premiere of Ludwig van Beethoven's Ninth Symphony in Vienna, Austria. The performance is conducted by Michael Umlauf under the composer's supervision.
May 7, 1832: Greece's independence is recognized by the Treaty of London.
May 7, 1840: The Great Natchez Tornado strikes Natchez, Mississippi killing 317 people. It is the second deadliest tornado in United States history.
May 7, 1846: The Cambridge Chronicle, America's oldest surviving weekly newspaper, is published for the first time in Cambridge, Massachusetts.
May 7, 1864: The world's oldest surviving clipper ship, the City of Adelaide is launched by William Pile, Hay and Co. in Sunderland, England, for transporting passengers and goods between Britain and Australia.
May 7, 1895: In Saint Petersburg, Russian scientist Alexander Stepanovich Popov demonstrates to the Russian Physical and Chemical Society his invention, the Popov lightning detector—a primitive radio receiver. In some parts of the former Soviet Union the anniversary of this day is celebrated as Radio Day.
May 7, 1915: The Republic of China accedes to 13 of the 21 Demands, extending the Empire of Japan's control over Manchuria and the Chinese economy.[1]
May 7, 1930: The 7.1 Mw  Salmas earthquake shakes northwestern Iran and southeastern Turkey with a maximum Mercalli intensity of IX (Violent). Up to three-thousand people were killed.
May 7, 1931: The stand-off between criminal Francis Crowley and 300 members of the New York Police Department takes place in his fifth-floor apartment on West 91st Street, New York City.
May 7, 1946: Tokyo Telecommunications Engineering (later renamed Sony) is founded.[2]
May 7, 1948: The Council of Europe is founded during the Hague Congress.
May 7, 1952: The concept of the integrated circuit, the basis for all modern computers, is first published by Geoffrey Dummer.
May 7, 1976: The Honda Accord is officially launched.
May 7, 1986: Canadian Patrick Morrow becomes the first person to climb each of the Seven Summits.
May 7, 1992: Three employees at a McDonald's Restaurant in Sydney, Nova Scotia, Canada, are brutally murdered and a fourth permanently disabled after a botched robbery. It is the first "fast-food murder" in Canada.
May 7, 1994: Edvard Munch's painting The Scream is recovered undamaged after being stolen from the National Gallery of Norway in February.[3]
May 7, 1998: Mercedes-Benz buys Chrysler for US$40 billion USD and forms DaimlerChrysler in the largest industrial merger in history.[4]
