May 7, 1999: In Guinea-Bissau, President João Bernardo Vieira is ousted in a military coup.
May 7, 2000: Vladimir Putin is inaugurated as president of Russia.
May 7, 2002: A China Northern Airlines MD-82 plunges into the Yellow Sea, killing 112 people.
May 7, 2004: American businessman Nick Berg is beheaded by Islamic militants. The act is recorded on videotape and released on the Internet.[5]
May 8, 413: Emperor Honorius signs an edict providing tax relief for the Italian provinces Tuscia, Campania, Picenum, Samnium, Apulia, Lucania and Calabria, which were plundered by the Visigoths.[1]
May 8, 589: Reccared I opens the Third Council of Toledo, marking the entry of Visigothic Spain into the Catholic Church.[2]
May 8, 1429: Joan of Arc lifts the Siege of Orléans, turning the tide of the Hundred Years' War.
May 8, 1450: Kentishmen revolt against King Henry VI.
May 8, 1516: A group of imperial guards, led by Trịnh Duy Sản, murdered Emperor Lê Tương Dực and fled, leaving the capital Thăng Long undefended.
May 8, 1541: Hernando de Soto stops near present-day Walls, Mississippi, and sees the Mississippi River[3] (then known by the Spanish as Río de Espíritu Santo, the name given to it by Alonso Álvarez de Pineda in 1519).[4]
May 8, 1788: King Louis XVI of France attempts to impose the reforms of Étienne Charles de Loménie de Brienne by abolishing the parlements.
May 8, 1794: Branded a traitor during the Reign of Terror, French chemist Antoine Lavoisier, who was also a tax collector with the Ferme générale, is tried, convicted and guillotined in one day in Paris.
May 8, 1842: A train derails and catches fire in Paris, killing between 52 and 200 people.
May 8, 1877: At Gilmore's Gardens in New York City, the first Westminster Kennel Club Dog Show opens.
May 8, 1886: Pharmacist John Pemberton first sells a carbonated beverage named "Coca-Cola" as a patent medicine.[5]
May 8, 1898: The first games of the Italian football league system are played.
May 8, 1899: The Irish Literary Theatre in Dublin produced its first play.
May 8, 1902: In Martinique, Mount Pelée erupts, destroying the town of Saint-Pierre and killing over 30,000 people. Only a handful of residents survive the blast.
May 8, 1919: Edward George Honey proposes the idea of a moment of silence to commemorate the Armistice of 11 November 1918 which ended World War I.
May 8, 1921: The creation of the Communist Party of Romania.
May 8, 1924: The Klaipėda Convention is signed formally incorporating Klaipėda Region (Memel Territory) into Lithuania.
May 8, 1927: Attempting to make the first non-stop transatlantic flight from Paris to New York, French war heroes Charles Nungesser and François Coli disappear after taking off aboard The White Bird biplane.
May 8, 1933: Mohandas Gandhi begins a 21-day fast of self-purification and launched a one-year campaign to help the Harijan movement.
May 8, 1945: The Halifax riot starts when thousands of civilians and servicemen rampage through Halifax, Nova Scotia.
May 8, 1946: Estonian schoolgirls Aili Jõgi and Ageeda Paavel blow up the Soviet memorial which stood in front of the Bronze Soldier of Tallinn.
May 8, 1963: South Vietnamese soldiers under the Roman Catholic President Ngo Dinh Diem open fire on Buddhists defying a ban on the flying of the Buddhist flag on Vesak, killing nine and sparking the Buddhist crisis.
May 8, 1973: A 71-day standoff between federal authorities and the American Indian Movement members occupying the Pine Ridge Reservation at Wounded Knee, South Dakota ends with the surrender of the militants.
May 8, 1976: The rollercoaster The New Revolution, the first steel coaster with a vertical loop, opens at Six Flags Magic Mountain.
May 8, 1978: The first ascent of Mount Everest without supplemental oxygen, by Reinhold Messner and Peter Habeler.
May 8, 1980: The World Health Organization confirms the eradication of smallpox.[6]
May 8, 1984: The Thames Barrier is officially opened, preventing the floodplain of most of Greater London from being flooded except under extreme circumstances.[7]
May 8, 1987: The SAS kills eight Provisional Irish Republican Army volunteers and a civilian during an ambush in Loughgall, Northern Ireland.
May 8, 1988: A fire at Illinois Bell's Hinsdale Central Office triggers an extended 1AESS network outage once considered to be the "worst telecommunications disaster in US telephone industry history".
May 8, 1997: China Southern Airlines Flight 3456 crashes on approach into Bao'an International Airport, killing 35 people.
May 8, 2019: A British teenager, Isabelle Holdaway, 17, is reported to be the first patient ever to receive a genetically modified phage therapy to treat a drug-resistant infection.[8][9]
May 9, 1271: Ninth Crusade, Edward I of England disembarks at Acre.
May 9, 1386: England and Portugal formally ratify their alliance with the signing of the Treaty of Windsor, making it the oldest diplomatic alliance in the world which is still in force.
May 9, 1540: Hernando de Alarcón sets sail on an expedition to the Gulf of California.
May 9, 1662: The figure who later became Mr. Punch  made his first recorded appearance in England.
May 9, 1671: Thomas Blood, disguised as a clergyman, attempts to steal England's Crown Jewels from the Tower of London.
May 9, 1726: Five men arrested during a raid on Mother Clap's molly house in London are executed at Tyburn.
May 9, 1763: The Siege of Fort Detroit begins during Pontiac's War against British forces.
May 9, 1874: The first horsebus makes its début in the city of Mumbai, traveling two routes.
May 9, 1877: A magnitude 8.8 earthquake off the coast of Peru kills 2,541, including some as far away as Hawaii and Japan.
May 9, 1887: Buffalo Bill Cody's Wild West Show opens in London.
May 9, 1901: Australia opens its first parliament in Melbourne.
May 9, 1904: The steam locomotive City of Truro becomes the first steam engine in Europe to exceed 100 mph (160 km/h).
May 9, 1911: The works of Gabriele D'Annunzio are placed in the Index of Forbidden Books by the Vatican.
May 9, 1926: Admiral Richard E. Byrd and Floyd Bennett claim to have flown over the North Pole (later discovery of Byrd's diary appears to cast some doubt on the claim.)
May 9, 1936: Italy formally annexes Ethiopia after taking the capital Addis Ababa on May 5.
May 9, 1946: King Victor Emmanuel III of Italy abdicates and is succeeded by Umberto II.
May 9, 1948: Czechoslovakia's Ninth-of-May Constitution comes into effect.
May 9, 1949: Rainier III becomes Prince of Monaco.
May 9, 1950: Robert Schuman presents his proposal on the creation of an organized Europe, which according to him was indispensable to the maintenance of peaceful relations. This proposal, known as the "Schuman Declaration", is considered by some people to be the beginning of the creation of what is now the European Union.
May 9, 1958: Alfred Hitchcock's film Vertigo has world premiere in San Francisco.
May 9, 1960: The Food and Drug Administration announces it will approve birth control as an additional indication for Searle's Enovid, making Enovid the world's first approved oral contraceptive pill.
May 9, 1961: FCC Chairman Newton N. Minow gives his Wasteland Speech.
May 9, 1964: Ngô Đình Cẩn, de facto ruler of central Vietnam under his brother President Ngô Đình Diệm before the family's toppling, is executed.
May 9, 1969: Carlos Lamarca leads the first urban guerrilla action against the military dictatorship of Brazil in São Paulo, by robbing two banks.
May 9, 1979: Iranian Jewish businessman Habib Elghanian is executed by firing squad in Tehran, prompting the mass exodus of the once 100,000-strong Jewish community of Iran.
May 9, 1980: In Norco, California, five masked gunmen hold up a Security Pacific bank, leading to a violent shoot-out and one of the largest pursuits in California history. Two of the gunmen and one police officer are killed and thirty-three police and civilian vehicles are destroyed in the chase.
May 9, 1987: LOT Flight 5055 Tadeusz Kościuszko crashes after takeoff in Warsaw, Poland, killing all 183 people on board.
May 9, 1992: Westray Mine disaster kills 26 workers in Nova Scotia, Canada.
May 9, 1994: Disappearance of Cleashindra Hall in Pine Bluff, Arkansas.
May 9, 2001: In Ghana, 129 football fans die in what  became known as the Accra Sports Stadium disaster. The deaths are caused by a stampede (caused by the firing of tear gas by police personnel at the stadium) that followed a controversial decision by the referee.
May 9, 2002: The 38-day stand-off in the Church of the Nativity in Bethlehem comes to an end when the Palestinians inside agree to have 13 suspected terrorists among them deported to several different countries.
May 9, 2012: A Sukhoi Superjet 100 aircraft crashes into Mount Salak in West Java, Indonesia, killing 45 people.
May 9, 2015: Russia stages its biggest ever military parade in Moscow's Red Square to commemorate the 70th anniversary of Victory Day.
May 9, 2018: At the height of the 2018 East Africa floods, the Patel dam breaks in Solai, Kenya, killing 48 people and displacing another 2000.
May 10, 28 BC: A sunspot is observed by Han dynasty astronomers during the reign of Emperor Cheng of Han, one of the earliest dated sunspot observations in China.[1]
May 10, 1291: Scottish nobles recognize the authority of Edward I of England pending the selection of a king.
May 10, 1497: Amerigo Vespucci allegedly leaves Cádiz for his first voyage to the New World.
May 10, 1503: Christopher Columbus visits the Cayman Islands and names them Las Tortugas after the numerous turtles there.
May 10, 1655: England, with troops under the command of Admiral William Penn and General Robert Venables, annexes Jamaica from Spain.
May 10, 1688: King Narai nominates Phetracha as regent, leading to the revolution of 1688 in which Phetracha becomes king of the Ayutthaya Kingdom.[2]
May 10, 1768: John Wilkes is imprisoned for writing an article for The North Briton severely criticizing King George III. This action provokes rioting in London.
May 10, 1773: The Parliament of Great Britain passes the Tea Act, designed to save the British East India Company by reducing taxes on its tea and granting it the right to sell tea directly to North America. The legislation leads to the Boston Tea Party.[3]
May 10, 1774: Louis XVI and Marie Antoinette become King and Queen of France.
May 10, 1824: The National Gallery in London opens to the public.
May 10, 1833: The desecration of the grave of the viceroy of southern Vietnam Lê Văn Duyệt by Emperor Minh Mạng provokes his adopted son to start a revolt.
May 10, 1869: The First Transcontinental Railroad, linking the eastern and western United States, is completed at Promontory Summit, Utah with the golden spike.
May 10, 1872: Victoria Woodhull becomes the first woman nominated for President of the United States.
May 10, 1876: The Centennial Exposition is opened in Philadelphia by U.S. President Ulysses S. Grant and Brazilian Emperor Dom Pedro II.
May 10, 1877: The lower chamber of the Romanian Parliament sanctions the Declaration of Independence from the Ottoman Empire, proclaimed the previous day in the Senate by Mihail Kogălniceanu.
May 10, 1881: Carol I is crowned the King of the Romanian Kingdom.
May 10, 1904: The Horch & Cir. Motorwagenwerke AG is founded. It would eventually become the Audi company.
May 10, 1908: Mother's Day is observed for the first time in the United States, in Grafton, West Virginia.
May 10, 1916: Sailing in the lifeboat James Caird, Ernest Shackleton arrives at South Georgia after a journey of 800 nautical miles from Elephant Island.
May 10, 1922: The United States annexes the Kingman Reef.
May 10, 1924: J. Edgar Hoover is appointed first Director of the United States' Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI), and remains so until his death in 1972.
May 10, 1946: First successful launch of an American V-2 rocket at White Sands Proving Ground.
May 10, 1948: The Republic of China implements "temporary provisions" granting President Chiang Kai-shek extended powers to deal with the Communist uprising; they will remain in effect until 1991.
May 10, 1954: Bill Haley & His Comets release "Rock Around the Clock", the first rock and roll record to reach number one on the Billboard charts.
May 10, 1960: The nuclear submarine USS Triton completes Operation Sandblast, the first underwater circumnavigation of the earth.
May 10, 1962: Marvel Comics publishes the first issue of The Incredible Hulk.
May 10, 1967: The Northrop M2-F2 crashes on landing, becoming the inspiration for the novel Cyborg and TV series The Six Million Dollar Man.
May 10, 1970: Bobby Orr scores "The Goal"[5] to win the 1970 Stanley Cup Finals, for the Boston Bruins' fourth NHL championship in their history.
May 10, 1972: In the Vietnam War, the US had two fighter ace crews.  The USAF's Ritchie and DeBellevue scored their first kill while the USN's Cunningham and Driscoll scored their third, fourth and fifth kills.
May 10, 1975: Sony introduces the Betamax videocassette recorder in Japan.
May 10, 1981: François Mitterrand wins the presidential election and becomes the first Socialist President of France in the French Fifth Republic.
May 10, 1993: In Thailand, a fire at the Kader Toy Factory kills 156 workers.
May 10, 1994: Nelson Mandela is inaugurated as South Africa's first black president.
May 10, 1997: The 7.3 Mw Qayen earthquake strikes Iran's Khorasan Province, killing 1,567, injuring over 2,300, leaving 50,000 homeless, and damaging or destroying over 15,000 homes.
May 10, 2002: FBI agent Robert Hanssen is sentenced to life imprisonment without the possibility of parole for selling United States secrets to Russia for $1.4 million in cash and diamonds.
May 10, 2005: A hand grenade thrown by Vladimir Arutyunian lands about 65 feet (20 meters) from U.S. President George W. Bush while he is giving a speech to a crowd in Tbilisi, Georgia, but it malfunctions and does not detonate.
May 10, 2012: The Damascus bombings are carried out using a pair of car bombs detonated by suicide bombers outside of a military intelligence complex in Damascus, Syria, killing 55 people and injuring 400 others.
May 10, 2013: One World Trade Center becomes the tallest building in the Western Hemisphere.
May 11, 1792: Robert Gray commands the first expedition to sail into the Columbia River.[1]
May 11, 1813: William Lawson, Gregory Blaxland and William Wentworth discover a route across the Blue Mountains, opening up inland Australia to settlement.[2]
May 11, 1833: The Lady of the Lake strikes an iceberg off Newfoundland and sinks with the loss of up to 265 passengers and crew.[3]
May 11, 1846: President James K. Polk asked for a Declaration of War against Mexico, starting the Mexican–American War.[4]
May 11, 1858: Minnesota is admitted as the 32nd state of the United States.[5]
May 11, 1880: Seven people are killed in the Mussel Slough Tragedy, a gun battle in California.[6]
May 11, 1894: Four thousand Pullman Palace Car Company workers go on a wildcat strike.[7]
May 11, 1970: The 1970 Lubbock tornado kills 26 and causes $250 million in damage.[10]
May 11, 1973: Citing government misconduct, Daniel Ellsberg's charges for his involvement in releasing the Pentagon Papers to The New York Times are dismissed.[11]
May 11, 1985: Fifty-six spectators die and more than 200 are injured in the Bradford City stadium fire.[12]
May 11, 1996: After the aircraft's departure from Miami, a fire started by improperly handled chemical oxygen generators in the cargo hold of Atlanta-bound ValuJet Flight 592 causes the Douglas DC-9 to crash in the Florida Everglades, killing all 110 on board.[13]
May 11, 1997: Deep Blue, a chess-playing supercomputer, defeats Garry Kasparov in the last game of the rematch, becoming the first computer to beat a world-champion chess player in a classic match format.[14]
May 11, 1998: India conducts three underground atomic tests in Pokhran.[15]
May 11, 2013: Fifty-two people are killed in a bombing in Reyhanlı, Turkey.[16]
May 11, 2014: Fifteen people are killed and 46 injured in Kinshasa in a stampede caused by tear gas being thrown into soccer stands by police officers.[17]
May 11, 2016: 103 people are killed in an ISIL bombing in Baghdad.[18]
May 12, 254: Pope Stephen I succeeds Pope Lucius I, becoming the 23rd pope of the Catholic Church.[1]
May 12, 907: Zhu Wen forces Emperor Ai into abdicating, ending the Tang dynasty after nearly three hundred years of rule.
May 12, 1191: Richard I of England marries Berengaria of Navarre in Cyprus;[2] she is crowned Queen consort of England the same day.
May 12, 1328: Antipope Nicholas V, a claimant to the papacy, is consecrated in Rome by the Bishop of Venice.
May 12, 1364: Jagiellonian University, the oldest university in Poland, is founded in Kraków.[3]
May 12, 1510: The Prince of Anhua rebellion begins when Zhu Zhifan kills all the officials invited to a banquet and declares his intent on ousting the powerful Ming dynasty eunuch Liu Jin during the reign of the Zhengde Emperor.
May 12, 1551: National University of San Marcos, the oldest university in the Americas, is founded in Lima, Peru.
May 12, 1593: London playwright Thomas Kyd is arrested and tortured by the Privy Council for libel.
May 12, 1743: Maria Theresa of Austria is crowned Queen of Bohemia after defeating her rival, Charles VII, Holy Roman Emperor.
May 12, 1778: Heinrich XI, count of the Principality of Reuss-Greiz, is elevated to Prince by Joseph II, Holy Roman Emperor.[4]
May 12, 1821: The first major battle of the Greek War of Independence against the Turks is fought in Valtetsi.
May 12, 1846: The Donner Party of pioneers departs Independence, Missouri for California, on what will become a year-long journey of hardship and cannibalism.[5]
May 12, 1870: The Manitoba Act is given the Royal Assent, paving the way for Manitoba to become a province of Canada on July 15.
May 12, 1881: In North Africa, Tunisia becomes a French protectorate.
May 12, 1888: In Southeast Asia, the North Borneo Chartered Company's territories become the British protectorate of North Borneo.
May 12, 1926: The Italian-built airship Norge becomes the first vessel to fly over the North Pole.
May 12, 1932: Ten weeks after his abduction, Charles Jr., the infant son of Charles Lindbergh, is found dead near Hopewell, New Jersey, just a few miles from the Lindberghs' home.[7]
May 12, 1933: The Agricultural Adjustment Act, which restricts agricultural production through government purchase of livestock for slaughter and paying subsidies to farmers when they remove land from planting, is signed into law by President Franklin D. Roosevelt.[8]
May 12, 1937: The Duke and Duchess of York are crowned as King George VI and Queen Elizabeth of the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland in Westminster Abbey.
May 12, 1941: Konrad Zuse presents the Z3, the world's first working programmable, fully automatic computer, in Berlin.
May 12, 1948: Wilhelmina, Queen regnant of the Kingdom of the Netherlands, cedes the throne.
May 12, 1965: The Soviet spacecraft Luna 5 crashes on the Moon.
May 12, 1978: In Zaire, rebels occupy the city of Kolwezi, the mining center of the province of Shaba (now known as Katanga); the local government asks the US, France and Belgium to restore order.
May 12, 1981: Francis Hughes, Provisional IRA hunger striker, dies in the Maze Prison, Northern Ireland.
May 12, 1982: During a procession outside the shrine of the Virgin Mary in Fátima, Portugal, security guards overpower Juan María Fernández y Krohn before he can attack Pope John Paul II with a bayonet.
May 12, 1989: The San Bernardino train disaster kills four people. A week later an underground gasoline pipeline explodes killing two more people.
May 12, 1998: Four students are shot at Trisakti University, leading to widespread riots and the fall of Suharto.
May 12, 2002: Former US President Jimmy Carter arrives in Cuba for a five-day visit with Fidel Castro, becoming the first President of the United States, in or out of office, to visit the island since Castro's 1959 revolution.
May 12, 2003: The Riyadh compound bombings, carried out by al-Qaeda, kill 26 people.
May 12, 2006: Iranian Azeris interpret a cartoon published in an Iranian magazine as insulting, resulting in massive riots throughout the country.
May 12, 2008: U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement conducts the largest-ever raid of a workplace in Postville, Iowa, arresting nearly 400 immigrants for identity theft and document fraud.
May 12, 2010: Afriqiyah Airways Flight 771 crashes on final approach to Tripoli International Airport in Tripoli, Libya, killing 103 out of the 104 people on board.
May 12, 2015: Massive Nepal earthquake kills 218 people and injures more than 3500.
May 12, 2017: A ransomware attack attacks over 400 thousand computers worldwide, targeting computers of the United Kingdom's National Health Services and Telefónica computers.
May 13, 1373: Julian of Norwich has visions of Jesus while suffering from a life-threatening illness, visions which are later described and interpreted in her book Revelations of Divine Love.[1]
May 13, 1515: Mary Tudor, Queen of France, and Charles Brandon, 1st Duke of Suffolk, are officially married at Greenwich.
May 13, 1619: Dutch statesman Johan van Oldenbarnevelt is executed in The Hague after being convicted of treason.
May 13, 1780: The Cumberland Compact is signed by leaders of the settlers in the Cumberland River area of what would become the U.S. state of Tennessee, providing for democratic government and a formal system of justice.[2]
May 13, 1787: Captain Arthur Phillip leaves Portsmouth, England, with eleven ships full of convicts (the "First Fleet") to establish a penal colony in Australia.
May 13, 1804: Forces sent by Yusuf Karamanli of Tripoli to retake Derna from the Americans attack the city.
May 13, 1830: Ecuador gains its independence from Gran Colombia.
May 13, 1861: Pakistan's (then a part of British India) first railway line  opens, from Karachi to Kotri.
May 13, 1862: The USS Planter, a steamer and gunship, steals through Confederate lines and is passed to the Union, by a southern slave, Robert Smalls, who later was officially appointed as captain, becoming the first black man to command a United States ship.
May 13, 1880: In Menlo Park, New Jersey, Thomas Edison performs the first test of his electric railway.
May 13, 1888: With the passage of the Lei Áurea ("Golden Law"), Empire of Brazil abolishes slavery.
May 13, 1909: The first Giro d'Italia starts from Milan. Italian cyclist Luigi Ganna will be the winner.
May 13, 1912: The Royal Flying Corps, the forerunner of the Royal Air Force, is established in the United Kingdom.
May 13, 1917: Three children report the first apparition of Our Lady of Fátima in Fátima, Portugal.
May 13, 1940: Queen Wilhelmina of the Netherlands flees her country to Great Britain after the German invasion. Princess Juliana takes her children to Canada for their safety.
May 13, 1950: The first round of the Formula One World Championship is held at Silverstone.
May 13, 1951: The 400th anniversary of the founding of the National University of San Marcos is commemorated by the opening of the first large-capacity stadium in Peru.
May 13, 1952: The Rajya Sabha, the upper house of the Parliament of India, holds its first sitting.
May 13, 1954: The original Broadway production of The Pajama Game opens and runs for another 1,063 performances. Later received three Tony Awards for Best Musical, Best Performance by a Featured Actress in a Musical, and Best Choreography.
May 13, 1958: Ben Carlin becomes the first (and only) person to circumnavigate the world by amphibious vehicle, having travelled over 17,000 kilometres (11,000 mi) by sea and 62,000 kilometres (39,000 mi) by land during a ten-year journey.
May 13, 1960: Hundreds of University of California, Berkeley students congregate for the first day of protest against a visit by the House Committee on Un-American Activities.
May 13, 1967: Dr. Zakir Husain becomes the third President of India. He is the first Muslim President of the Indian Union. He holds this position until August 24, 1969.
May 13, 1969: May 13 Incident involving sectarian violence in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia.
May 13, 1971: Over 900 unarmed Bengali Hindus are murdered in the Demra massacre.
May 13, 1972: Faulty electrical wiring ignites a fire underneath the Playtown Cabaret in Osaka, Japan. Blocked exits and non-functional elevators lead to 118 fatalities, with many victims leaping to their deaths.
May 13, 1980: An F3 tornado hits Kalamazoo County, Michigan.  President Jimmy Carter declares it a federal disaster area.
May 13, 1981: Mehmet Ali Ağca attempts to assassinate Pope John Paul II in St. Peter's Square in Rome. The Pope is rushed to the Agostino Gemelli University Polyclinic to undergo emergency surgery and survives.
May 13, 1985: Police bombed MOVE headquarters in Philadelphia to end a stand-off, killing six adults and five children, and destroying the homes of 250 city residents.
May 13, 1989: Large groups of students occupy Tiananmen Square and begin a hunger strike.
May 13, 1990: The Dinamo–Red Star riot took place at Maksimir Stadium in Zagreb, Croatia between the Bad Blue Boys (fans of Dinamo Zagreb) and the Delije (fans of Red Star Belgrade).
May 13, 1992: Li Hongzhi gives the first public lecture on Falun Gong in Changchun, People's Republic of China.
May 13, 1995: Alison Hargreaves, a 33-year-old British mother, becomes the first woman to conquer Everest without oxygen or the help of sherpas.
May 13, 1996: Severe thunderstorms and a tornado in Bangladesh kill 600 people.
May 13, 1998: India carries out two nuclear tests at Pokhran, following the three conducted on May 11. The United States and Japan impose economic sanctions on India.
May 13, 2005: Andijan uprising, Uzbekistan; Troops open fire on crowds of protestors after a prison break; at least 187 people were killed according to official estimates.
May 13, 2011: Two bombs explode in the Charsadda District of Pakistan killing 98 people and wounding 140 others.
May 13, 2012: Forty-nine dismembered bodies are discovered by Mexican authorities on Mexican Federal Highway 40.
May 13, 2013: American physician Kermit Gosnell is found guilty in Pennsylvania of murdering three infants born alive during attempted abortions, involuntary manslaughter of a woman during an abortion procedure, and other charges.[4]
May 13, 2014: An explosion at an underground coal mine in southwest Turkey kills 301 miners.
May 14, 1097: The Siege of Nicaea begins during the First Crusade.
May 14, 1607: Jamestown, Virginia is settled as an English colony.
May 14, 1608: The Protestant Union, a coalition of Protestant German states, is founded to defend the rights, land and safety of each member against the Catholic Church and Catholic German states.[1]
May 14, 1610: Henry IV of France is assassinated by Catholic zealot François Ravaillac, and Louis XIII ascends the throne.[2]
May 14, 1643: Four-year-old Louis XIV becomes King of France upon the death of his father, Louis XIII.
May 14, 1796: Edward Jenner administers the first smallpox inoculation.[3]
May 14, 1800: The 6th United States Congress recesses, and the process of moving the U.S. Government from Philadelphia to Washington, D.C., begins the following day.[4]
May 14, 1804: William Clark and 42 men depart from Camp Dubois to join Meriwether Lewis at St. Charles, Missouri, marking the beginning of the Lewis and Clark Expedition's historic journey up the Missouri River.[5]
May 14, 1836: The Treaties of Velasco are signed in Velasco, Texas.
May 14, 1870: The first game of rugby in New Zealand is played in Nelson between Nelson College and the Nelson Rugby Football Club.[6]
May 14, 1878: The last witchcraft trial held in the United States begins in Salem, Massachusetts, after Lucretia Brown, an adherent of Christian Science, accused Daniel Spofford of attempting to harm her through his mental powers.[7]
May 14, 1879: The first group of 463 Indian indentured laborers arrives in Fiji aboard the Leonidas.
May 14, 1913: Governor of New York William Sulzer approves the charter for the Rockefeller Foundation, which begins operations with a $100 million donation from John D. Rockefeller.
May 14, 1918: Cape Town Mayor, Sir Harry Hands, inaugurates the Two-minute silence.
May 14, 1925: Virginia Woolf's novel Mrs Dalloway is published.
May 14, 1931: Five unarmed civilians are killed in the Ådalen shootings, as the Swedish military is called in to deal with protesting workers.
May 14, 1935: The Constitution of the Philippines is ratified by a popular vote.
May 14, 1939: Lina Medina becomes the youngest confirmed mother in medical history at the age of five.
May 14, 1948: Israel is declared to be an independent state and a provisional government is established. Immediately after the declaration, Israel is attacked by the neighboring Arab states, triggering the 1948 Arab–Israeli War.
May 14, 1951: Trains run on the Talyllyn Railway in Wales for the first time since preservation, making it the first railway in the world to be operated by volunteers.
May 14, 1970: Andreas Baader is freed from custody by Ulrike Meinhof, Gudrun Ensslin and others, a pivotal moment in the formation of the Red Army Faction.
May 14, 1973: Skylab, the United States' first space station, is launched.[10]
May 14, 2004: Rico Linhas Aéreas Flight 4815 crashes into the Amazon rainforest during approach to Eduardo Gomes International Airport in Manaus, Brazil, killing all 33 people on board.[11]
May 14, 2012: Agni Air Flight CHT crashes in Nepal after a failed go-around, killing 15 people.
May 15, 495 BC: A newly constructed temple in honour of the god Mercury was dedicated in ancient Rome on the Circus Maximus, between the Aventine and Palatine hills. To spite the senate and the consuls, the people awarded the dedication to a senior military officer, Marcus Laetorius.
May 15, 221: Liu Bei, Chinese warlord, proclaims himself emperor of Shu Han, the successor of the Han dynasty.
May 15, 392: Emperor Valentinian II is assassinated while advancing into Gaul against the Frankish usurper Arbogast. He is found hanging in his residence at Vienne.
May 15, 589: King Authari marries Theodelinda, daughter of the Bavarian duke Garibald I. A Catholic, she has great influence among the Lombard nobility.
May 15, 908: The three-year-old Constantine VII, the son of Emperor Leo VI the Wise, is crowned as co-emperor of the Byzantine Empire by Patriarch Euthymius I at Constantinople.
May 15, 1252: Pope Innocent IV issues the papal bull ad extirpanda, which authorizes, but also limits, the torture of heretics in the Medieval Inquisition.
May 15, 1525: Insurgent peasants led by Anabaptist pastor Thomas Müntzer were defeated at the Battle of Frankenhausen, ending the German Peasants' War in the Holy Roman Empire.
May 15, 1536: Anne Boleyn, Queen of England, stands trial in London on charges of treason, adultery and incest; she is condemned to death by a specially-selected jury.
May 15, 1567: Mary, Queen of Scots marries James Hepburn, 4th Earl of Bothwell, her third husband.
May 15, 1618: Johannes Kepler confirms his previously rejected discovery of the third law of planetary motion (he first discovered it on March 8 but soon rejected the idea after some initial calculations were made).
May 15, 1648: The Treaty of Westphalia is signed.
May 15, 1718: James Puckle, a London lawyer, patents the world's first machine gun.
May 15, 1730: Robert Walpole effectively became the first Prime Minister of the United Kingdom.
May 15, 1793: Diego Marín Aguilera flies a glider for "about 360 meters", at a height of 5–6 meters, during one of the first attempted manned flights.
May 15, 1800: King George III of the United Kingdom survives an assassination attempt by James Hadfield, who is later acquitted by reason of insanity.
May 15, 1817: Opening of the first private mental health hospital in the United States, the Asylum for the Relief of Persons Deprived of the Use of Their Reason (now Friends Hospital, Philadelphia, Pennsylvania).
May 15, 1836: Francis Baily observes "Baily's beads" during an annular eclipse.
May 15, 1848: Serfdom is abolished in the Habsburg Galicia, as a result of the 1848 revolutions. The rest of monarchy followed later in the year.
May 15, 1849: Troops of the Two Sicilies take Palermo and crush the republican government of Sicily.
May 15, 1850: The Arana–Southern Treaty is ratified, ending "the existing differences" between Great Britain and Argentina.
May 15, 1851: The first Australian gold rush is proclaimed, although the discovery had been made three months earlier.
May 15, 1858: Opening of the present Royal Opera House in Covent Garden, London.
May 15, 1862: President Abraham Lincoln signs a bill into law creating the United States Bureau of Agriculture. It is later renamed the United States Department of Agriculture.
May 15, 1867: Canadian Bank of Commerce opens for business in Toronto, Ontario. The bank would later merge with Imperial Bank of Canada to become what is CIBC in 1961.
May 15, 1891: Pope Leo XIII defends workers' rights and property rights in the encyclical Rerum novarum, the beginning of modern Catholic social teaching.
May 15, 1905: Las Vegas is founded when 110 acres (0.45 km2), in what later would become downtown, are auctioned off.
May 15, 1911: More than 300 Chinese immigrants are killed in the Torreón massacre when the forces of the Mexican Revolution led by Emilio Madero take the city of Torreón from the Federales.
May 15, 1919: Greek occupation of Smyrna. During the occupation, the Greek army kills or wounds 350 Turks; those responsible are punished by Greek commander Aristides Stergiades.
May 15, 1925: Al-Insaniyyah, the first Arabic communist newspaper, is founded.
May 15, 1928: Walt Disney character Mickey Mouse premieres in his first cartoon, "Plane Crazy".
May 15, 1929: A fire at the Cleveland Clinic in Cleveland, Ohio kills 123.
May 15, 1932: In an attempted coup d'état, the Prime Minister of Japan Inukai Tsuyoshi is assassinated.
May 15, 1933: All military aviation organizations within or under the control of the RLM of Germany were officially merged in a covert manner to form its Wehrmacht military's air arm, the Luftwaffe.
May 15, 1934: Kārlis Ulmanis establishes an authoritarian government in Latvia.
May 15, 1940: McDonald's opens its first restaurant in San Bernardino, California.
May 15, 1941: Joe DiMaggio begins a 56-game hitting streak.
May 15, 1943: Joseph Stalin dissolves the Comintern (or Third International).
May 15, 1948: Following the expiration of The British Mandate for Palestine, the Kingdom of Egypt, Transjordan, Lebanon, Syria, Iraq and Saudi Arabia invade Israel thus starting the 1948 Arab–Israeli War.
May 15, 1957: At Malden Island in the Pacific Ocean, Britain tests its first hydrogen bomb in Operation Grapple.
May 15, 1966: After a policy dispute, Prime Minister Nguyễn Cao Kỳ of South Vietnam's ruling junta launches a military attack on the forces of General Tôn Thất Đính, forcing him to abandon his command.
May 15, 1970: Philip Lafayette Gibbs and James Earl Green are killed at Jackson State University by police during student protests.
May 15, 1972: In Laurel, Maryland, Arthur Bremer shoots and paralyzes Alabama Governor George Wallace while he is campaigning to become President.
May 15, 1976: Aeroflot Flight 1802 crashes in Viktorovka, Chernihiv Raion, killing all 52 people on board.[1]
May 15, 1987: The Soviet Union launches the Polyus prototype orbital weapons platform. It fails to reach orbit.
May 15, 1991: Édith Cresson becomes France's first female Prime  Minister.
May 15, 1997: The United States government acknowledges the existence of the "Secret War" in Laos and dedicates the Laos Memorial in honor of Hmong and other "Secret War" veterans.
May 15, 2004: Arsenal F.C. go an entire league campaign unbeaten in the English Premier League, joining Preston North End F.C with the right to claim the title "The Invincibles".
May 15, 2008: California becomes the second U.S. state after Massachusetts in 2004 to legalize same-sex marriage after the state's own Supreme Court rules a previous ban unconstitutional.
May 15, 2010: Jessica Watson becomes the youngest person to sail, non-stop and unassisted around the world solo.
May 15, 2013: An upsurge in violence in Iraq leaves more than 389 people dead over three days.
May 16, 946: Emperor Suzaku abdicates the throne in favor of his brother Murakami who becomes the 62nd emperor of Japan.
May 16, 1204: Having been elected on May 9, Baldwin IX, Count of Flanders is crowned as the first Emperor of the Latin Empire.[1]
May 16, 1527: The Florentines drive out the Medici for a second time and Florence re-establishes itself as a republic.
May 16, 1532: Sir Thomas More resigns as Lord Chancellor of England.
May 16, 1568: Mary, Queen of Scots, flees to England.[2]
May 16, 1584: Santiago de Vera becomes sixth Governor-General of the Spanish colony of the Philippines.
May 16, 1739: The Battle of Vasai concludes as the Marathas defeat the Portuguese army.
May 16, 1770: The 14-year-old Marie Antoinette marries 15-year-old Louis-Auguste, who later becomes king of France.[3]
May 16, 1771: The Battle of Alamance, a pre-American Revolutionary War battle between local militia and a group of rebels called The "Regulators", occurs in present-day Alamance County, North Carolina.
May 16, 1812: Imperial Russia signs the Treaty of Bucharest, ending the Russo-Turkish War. The Ottoman Empire cedes Bessarabia to Russia.[4]
May 16, 1834: The Battle of Asseiceira is fought, the last and decisive engagement of the Liberal Wars in Portugal.
May 16, 1842: The first major wagon train heading for the Pacific Northwest sets out on the Oregon Trail from Elm Grove, Missouri, with 100 pioneers.[5]
May 16, 1866: The United States Congress establishes the nickel.[6]
May 16, 1868: The United States Senate fails to impeach President Andrew Johnson by one vote.[7]
May 16, 1874: A flood on the Mill River in Massachusetts destroys much of four villages and kills 139 people.
May 16, 1877: The 16 May 1877 crisis occurs in France, ending with the dissolution of the National Assembly 22 June and affirming the interpretation of the Constitution of 1875 as a parliamentary rather than presidential system. The elections held in October 1877 led to the defeat of the royalists as a formal political movement in France.[8]
May 16, 1888: Nikola Tesla delivers a lecture describing the equipment which will allow efficient generation and use of alternating currents to transmit electric power over long distances.
May 16, 1891: The International Electrotechnical Exhibition opens in Frankfurt, Germany, and will feature the world's first long distance transmission of high-power, three-phase electric current (the most common form today).
May 16, 1916: The United Kingdom of Great Britain and Ireland and the French Third Republic sign the secret wartime Sykes-Picot Agreement partitioning former Ottoman territories such as Iraq and Syria.
May 16, 1918: The Sedition Act of 1918 is passed by the U.S. Congress, making criticism of the government during wartime an imprisonable offense. It will be repealed less than two years later.
May 16, 1919: A naval Curtiss NC-4 aircraft commanded by Albert Cushing Read leaves Trepassey, Newfoundland, for Lisbon via the Azores on the first transatlantic flight.
May 16, 1920: In Rome, Pope Benedict XV canonizes Joan of Arc.
May 16, 1929: In Hollywood, the first Academy Awards ceremony takes place.
May 16, 1951: The first regularly scheduled transatlantic flights begin between Idlewild Airport (now John F Kennedy International Airport) in New York City and Heathrow Airport in London, operated by El Al Israel Airlines.
May 16, 1959: The Triton Fountain in Valletta, Malta is turned on for the first time.[9]
May 16, 1960: Theodore Maiman operates the first optical laser (a ruby laser), at Hughes Research Laboratories in Malibu, California.
May 16, 1961: Park Chung-hee leads a coup d'état to overthrow the Second Republic of South Korea.
May 16, 1966: The Communist Party of China issues the "May 16 Notice", marking the beginning of the Cultural Revolution.
May 16, 1974: Josip Broz Tito is elected president for life of Yugoslavia.
May 16, 1988: A report by the Surgeon General of the United States C. Everett Koop states that the addictive properties of nicotine are similar to those of heroin and cocaine.
May 16, 1991: Queen Elizabeth II of the United Kingdom addresses a joint session of the United States Congress. She is the first British monarch to address the U.S. Congress.
May 16, 1997: Mobutu Sese Seko, the President of Zaire, flees the country.
May 16, 2003: In Morocco, 33 civilians are killed and more than 100 people are injured in the Casablanca terrorist attacks.
May 16, 2005: Kuwait permits women's suffrage in a 35–23 National Assembly vote.
May 16, 2011: STS-134 (ISS assembly flight ULF6), launched from the Kennedy Space Center on the 25th and final flight for Space Shuttle Endeavour.
May 16, 2014: Twelve people are killed in two explosions in the Gikomba market area of Nairobi, Kenya.
May 17, 1536: Henry VIII and Anne Boleyn's marriage is annulled.
May 17, 1590: Anne of Denmark is crowned Queen of Scotland.
May 17, 1642: Paul de Chomedey, Sieur de Maisonneuve (1612–1676) founds the Ville Marie de Montréal.
May 17, 1673: Louis Jolliet and Jacques Marquette begin exploring the Mississippi River.
May 17, 1792: The New York Stock Exchange is formed under the Buttonwood Agreement.
May 17, 1805: Muhammad Ali becomes Wāli of Egypt.
May 17, 1809: Emperor Napoleon I orders the annexation of the Papal States to the French Empire.
May 17, 1814: The Constitution of Norway is signed and Crown Prince Christian Frederick of Denmark is elected King of Norway by the Norwegian Constituent Assembly.
May 17, 1859: Members of the Melbourne Football Club codified the first rules of Australian rules football.
May 17, 1863: Rosalía de Castro publishes Cantares Gallegos, the first book in the Galician language.
May 17, 1865: The International Telegraph Union (later the International Telecommunication Union) is established in Paris.
May 17, 1869: Imperial Japanese forces defeat the remnants of the Tokugawa shogunate in the Battle of Hakodate to end the Boshin War.
May 17, 1875: Aristides wins the first Kentucky Derby.
May 17, 1900: The children's novel The Wonderful Wizard of Oz, by L. Frank Baum, is first published in the United States. The first copy is given to the author's sister.[2]
May 17, 1902: Greek archaeologist Valerios Stais discovers the Antikythera mechanism, an ancient mechanical analog computer.
May 17, 1914: The Protocol of Corfu is signed, recognising full autonomy to Northern Epirus under nominal Albanian sovereignty.
May 17, 1915: The last British Liberal Party government (led by H. H. Asquith) falls.
May 17, 1933: Vidkun Quisling and Johan Bernhard Hjort form Nasjonal Samling — the national-socialist party of Norway.
May 17, 1939: The Columbia Lions and the Princeton Tigers play in the United States' first televised sporting event, a collegiate baseball game in New York City.
May 17, 1954: The United States Supreme Court hands down a unanimous decision in Brown v. Board of Education of Topeka, Kansas.
May 17, 1974: Police in Los Angeles raid the Symbionese Liberation Army's headquarters, killing six members, including Camilla Hall.
May 17, 1977: Nolan Bushnell opened the first Chuck E. Cheese's in San Jose, California.
May 17, 1980: On the eve of presidential elections, Maoist guerrilla group Shining Path attacks a polling location in Chuschi (a town in Ayacucho), starting the Internal conflict in Peru.
May 17, 1983: Lebanon, Israel, and the United States sign an agreement on Israeli withdrawal from Lebanon.
May 17, 1984: Prince Charles calls a proposed addition to the National Gallery, London, a "monstrous carbuncle on the face of a much-loved and elegant friend", sparking controversies on the proper role of the Royal Family and the course of modern architecture.
May 17, 1990: The General Assembly of the World Health Organization (WHO) eliminates homosexuality from the list of psychiatric diseases.
May 17, 1992: Three days of popular protests against the government of Prime Minister of Thailand Suchinda Kraprayoon begin in Bangkok, leading to a military crackdown that results in 52 officially confirmed deaths, hundreds of injuries, many disappearances, and more than 3,500 arrests.
May 17, 1994: Malawi holds its first multi-party elections.
May 17, 1995: Shawn Nelson steals an M60 tank from the California Army National Guard Armory in San Diego and proceeds to go on a rampage.
May 17, 1997: Troops of Laurent Kabila march into Kinshasa. Zaire is officially renamed Democratic Republic of the Congo.
May 17, 2000: Arsenal and Galatasaray fans clash in the 2000 UEFA Cup Final riots in Copenhagen
May 17, 2004: The first legal same-sex marriages in the U.S. are performed in the state of Massachusetts.
May 17, 2006: The aircraft carrier USS Oriskany is sunk in the Gulf of Mexico as an artificial reef.
May 17, 2007: Trains from North and South Korea cross the 38th Parallel in a test-run agreed by both governments. This is the first time that trains have crossed the Demilitarized Zone since 1953.
May 17, 2014: A plane crash in northern Laos kills 17 people.
May 18, 332: Emperor Constantine the Great announces free distributions of food to the citizens in Constantinople.[1]
May 18, 872: Louis II of Italy is crowned for the second time as Roman Emperor at Rome, at the age of 47. His first coronation was 28 years earlier, in 844, during the reign of his father Lothair I.[2]
May 18, 1152: The future Henry II of England marries Eleanor of Aquitaine. He would become king 2 years later, after the death of his cousin once removed King Stephen of England.
May 18, 1268: The Principality of Antioch, a crusader state, falls to the Mamluk Sultan Baibars in the Siege of Antioch.
May 18, 1291: Fall of Acre, the end of Crusader presence in the Holy Land.
May 18, 1302: Bruges Matins, the nocturnal massacre of the French garrison in Bruges by members of the local Flemish militia.
May 18, 1388: During the Battle of Buyur Lake, General Lan Yu leads a Chinese army forward to crush the Mongol hordes of Tögüs Temür, the Khan of Northern Yuan.
May 18, 1499: Alonso de Ojeda sets sail from Cádiz on his voyage to what is now Venezuela.
May 18, 1565: The Great Siege of Malta begins, in which Ottoman forces attempt and fail to conquer Malta.
May 18, 1593: Playwright Thomas Kyd's accusations of heresy lead to an arrest warrant for Christopher Marlowe.
May 18, 1631: In Dorchester, Massachusetts, John Winthrop takes the oath of office and becomes the first Governor of Massachusetts.
May 18, 1652: Rhode Island passes the first law in English-speaking North America making slavery illegal.
May 18, 1756: The Seven Years' War begins when Great Britain declares war on France.
May 18, 1783: First United Empire Loyalists reach Parrtown (later called Saint John, New Brunswick), Canada, after leaving the United States.
May 18, 1794: Battle of Tourcoing during the Flanders Campaign of the War of the First Coalition.
May 18, 1804: Napoleon Bonaparte is proclaimed Emperor of the French by the French Senate.
May 18, 1812: John Bellingham is found guilty and sentenced to death by hanging for the assassination of British Prime Minister Spencer Perceval.
May 18, 1843: The Disruption in Edinburgh of the Free Church of Scotland from the Church of Scotland.
May 18, 1848: Opening of the first German National Assembly (Nationalversammlung) in Frankfurt, Germany.
May 18, 1860: Abraham Lincoln wins the Republican Party presidential nomination over William H. Seward, who later becomes the United States Secretary of State.
May 18, 1896: The United States Supreme Court rules in Plessy v. Ferguson that the "separate but equal" doctrine is constitutional.
May 18, 1900: The United Kingdom proclaims a protectorate over Tonga.
May 18, 1912: The first Indian film, Shree Pundalik by Dadasaheb Torne, is released in Mumbai.
May 18, 1926: Evangelist Aimee Semple McPherson disappears in Venice, California.
May 18, 1927: After being founded for 20 years, the Government of the Republic of China approves Tongji University to be among the first national universities of the Republic of China.
May 18, 1944: Deportation of Crimean Tatars by the Soviet Union government.
May 18, 1948: The First Legislative Yuan of the Republic of China officially convenes in Nanking.
May 18, 1953: Jackie Cochran becomes the first woman to break the sound barrier.
May 18, 1955: Operation Passage to Freedom, the evacuation of 310,000 Vietnamese civilians, soldiers and non-Vietnamese members of the French Army from communist North Vietnam to South Vietnam following the end of the First Indochina War, ends.
May 18, 1965: Israeli spy Eli Cohen is hanged in Damascus, Syria.
May 18, 1973: Aeroflot Flight 109 is hijacked mid-flight and the aircraft is subsequently destroyed when the hijacker's bomb explodes, killing all 82 people on board.[4]
May 18, 1977: Likud party wins the 1977 Israeli legislative election, with Menachem Begin, its founder, as the sixth Prime Minister of Israel.[5]
May 18, 1980: Students in Gwangju, South Korea begin demonstrations calling for democratic reforms.
May 18, 1990: In France, a modified TGV train achieves a new rail world speed record of 515.3 km/h (320.2 mph).
May 18, 1991: Northern Somalia declares independence from the rest of Somalia as the Republic of Somaliland but is not recognized by the international community.
May 18, 1993: Riots in Nørrebro, Copenhagen, caused by the approval of the four Danish exceptions in the Maastricht Treaty referendum. Police open fire against civilians for the first time since World War II and injure 11 demonstrators.
May 18, 1994: Israeli troops finish withdrawing from the Gaza Strip, ceding the area to the Palestinian National Authority to govern.
May 18, 2005: A second photo from the Hubble Space Telescope confirms that Pluto has two additional moons, Nix and Hydra.
May 18, 2006: The post Loktantra Andolan government passes a landmark bill curtailing the power of the monarchy and making Nepal a secular country.
May 18, 2009: The LTTE are defeated by the Sri Lankan government, ending almost 26 years of fighting between the two sides.
May 18, 2015: At least 78 people die in a landslide caused by heavy rains in the Colombian town of Salgar.
May 18, 2018: A school shooting at Santa Fe High School in Texas kills 10 people.[6]
May 19, 639: Ashina Jiesheshuai and his tribesmen assaulted Emperor Taizong at Jiucheng Palace.
May 19, 1051: Henry I of France marries the Russian princess, Anne of Kiev.[2]
May 19, 1445: John II of Castile defeats the Infantes of Aragon at the First Battle of Olmedo.
May 19, 1499: Catherine of Aragon is married by proxy to Arthur, Prince of Wales. Catherine is 13 and Arthur is 12.
May 19, 1535: French explorer Jacques Cartier sets sail on his second voyage to North America with three ships, 110 men, and Chief Donnacona's two sons (whom Cartier had kidnapped during his first voyage).
May 19, 1536: Anne Boleyn, the second wife of Henry VIII of England, is beheaded for adultery, treason, and incest.
May 19, 1542: The Prome Kingdom falls to the Taungoo Dynasty in present-day Myanmar.
May 19, 1568: Queen Elizabeth I of England orders the arrest of Mary, Queen of Scots.
May 19, 1649: An Act of Parliament declaring England a Commonwealth is passed by the Long Parliament. England would be a republic for the next eleven years.
May 19, 1655: The Invasion of Jamaica begins during the Anglo-Spanish War.
May 19, 1743: Jean-Pierre Christin developed the centigrade temperature scale.
May 19, 1749: King George II of Great Britain grants the Ohio Company a charter of land around the forks of the Ohio River.
May 19, 1780: New England's Dark Day, an unusual darkening of the day sky was observed over the New England states and parts of Canada.
May 19, 1802: Napoleon Bonaparte founds the Legion of Honour.
May 19, 1828: U.S. President John Quincy Adams signs the Tariff of 1828 into law, protecting wool manufacturers in the United States.
May 19, 1845: Captain Sir John Franklin and his ill-fated Arctic expedition depart from Greenhithe, England.
May 19, 1911: Parks Canada, the world's first national park service, is established as the Dominion Parks Branch under the Department of the Interior.
May 19, 1917: The Norwegian football club Rosenborg BK is founded.
May 19, 1919: Mustafa Kemal Atatürk lands at Samsun on the Anatolian Black Sea coast, initiating what is later termed the Turkish War of Independence.
May 19, 1921: The United States Congress passes the Emergency Quota Act establishing national quotas on immigration.
May 19, 1922: The Young Pioneer Organization of the Soviet Union is established.
May 19, 1934: Zveno and the Bulgarian Army engineer a coup d'état and install Kimon Georgiev as the new Prime Minister of Bulgaria.
May 19, 1950: Egypt announces that the Suez Canal is closed to Israeli ships and commerce.
May 19, 1959: The North Vietnamese Army establishes Group 559, whose responsibility is to determine how to maintain supply lines to South Vietnam; the resulting route is the Ho Chi Minh trail.
May 19, 1961: At Silchar Railway Station, Assam, 11 Bengalis die when police open fire on protesters demanding state recognition of Bengali language in the Bengali Language Movement.
May 19, 1962: A birthday salute to U.S. President John F. Kennedy takes place at Madison Square Garden, New York City. The highlight is Marilyn Monroe's rendition of "Happy Birthday".
May 19, 1963: The New York Post Sunday Magazine publishes Martin Luther King Jr.'s Letter from Birmingham Jail.
May 19, 1986: The Firearm Owners Protection Act is signed into law by U.S. President Ronald Reagan.
May 19, 1991: Croatians vote for independence in a referendum.
May 19, 1997: The Sierra Gorda biosphere, the most ecologically diverse region in Mexico, is established as a result of grassroots efforts.
May 19, 2007: President of Romania Traian Băsescu survives an impeachment referendum and returns to office from suspension.
May 19, 2010: The Royal Thai Armed Forces concludes its crackdown on protests by forcing the surrender of United Front for Democracy Against Dictatorship leaders.
May 19, 2012: A car bomb explodes near a military complex in the Syrian city of Deir ez-Zor, killing nine people.
May 19, 2015: The Refugio oil spill deposited 142,800 U.S. gallons (3,400 barrels) of crude oil onto an area in California considered one of the most biologically diverse coastlines of the west coast.
May 19, 2016: EgyptAir Flight 804 crashes into the Mediterranean Sea while traveling from Paris to Cairo, killing all on board.
May 19, 2018: The wedding of Prince Harry and Meghan Markle is held at St George's Chapel, Windsor, with an estimated global audience of 1.9 billion.
May 20, 325: The First Council of Nicaea is formally opened, starting the first ecumenical council of the Christian Church.[1]
May 20, 491: Empress Ariadne marries Anastasius I. The widowed Augusta is able to choose her successor for the Byzantine throne, after Zeno (late emperor) dies of dysentery.
May 20, 685: The Battle of Dun Nechtain is fought between a Pictish army under King Bridei III and the invading Northumbrians under King Ecgfrith, who are decisively defeated.
May 20, 794: While visiting the royal Mercian court at Sutton Walls with a view to marrying princess Ælfthryth, King Æthelberht II of East Anglia is taken captive and beheaded.[2]
May 20, 1217: The Second Battle of Lincoln is fought near Lincoln, England, resulting in the defeat of Prince Louis of France by William Marshal, 1st Earl of Pembroke.
May 20, 1293: King Sancho IV of Castile creates the Estudio de Escuelas de Generales in Alcalá de Henares.
May 20, 1449: The Battle of Alfarrobeira is fought, establishing the House of Braganza as a principal royal family of Portugal.
May 20, 1497: John Cabot sets sail from Bristol, England, on his ship Matthew looking for a route to the west (other documents give a May 2 date).
May 20, 1498: Portuguese explorer Vasco da Gama discovers the sea route to India when he arrives at Kozhikode (previously known as Calicut), India.[3]
May 20, 1521: Ignatius of Loyola is seriously wounded in the Battle of Pampeluna.
May 20, 1570: Cartographer Abraham Ortelius issues Theatrum Orbis Terrarum, the first modern atlas.
May 20, 1609: Shakespeare's sonnets are first published in London, perhaps illicitly, by the publisher Thomas Thorpe.[4]
May 20, 1631: The city of Magdeburg in Germany is seized by forces of the Holy Roman Empire and most of its inhabitants massacred, in one of the bloodiest incidents of the Thirty Years' War.
May 20, 1775: The Mecklenburg Declaration of Independence is allegedly signed in Charlotte, North Carolina.
May 20, 1802: By the Law of 20 May 1802, Napoleon Bonaparte reinstates slavery in the French colonies, revoking its abolition in the French Revolution.
May 20, 1813: Napoleon Bonaparte leads his French troops into the Battle of Bautzen in Saxony, Germany, against the combined armies of Russia and Prussia. The battle ends the next day with a French victory.
May 20, 1840: York Minster is badly damaged by fire.
May 20, 1862: U.S. President Abraham Lincoln signs the Homestead Act into law, opening 84 million acres of public land to settlers.[6]
May 20, 1873: Levi Strauss and Jacob Davis receive a U.S. patent for blue jeans with copper rivets.[7]
May 20, 1875: Signing of the Metre Convention by 17 nations leading to the establishment of the International System of Units.
May 20, 1882: The Triple Alliance between the German Empire, Austria-Hungary and the Kingdom of Italy is formed.
May 20, 1883: Krakatoa begins to erupt; the volcano explodes three months later, killing more than 36,000 people.
May 20, 1902: Cuba gains independence from the United States. Tomás Estrada Palma becomes the country's first President.
May 20, 1932: Amelia Earhart takes off from Newfoundland to begin the world's first solo nonstop flight across the Atlantic Ocean by a female pilot, landing in Ireland the next day.
May 20, 1948: Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek wins the 1948 Republic of China presidential election and is sworn in as the first President of the Republic of China at Nanjing.
May 20, 1949: In the United States, the Armed Forces Security Agency, the predecessor to the National Security Agency, is established.
May 20, 1956: In Operation Redwing, the first United States airborne hydrogen bomb is dropped over Bikini Atoll in the Pacific Ocean.
May 20, 1964: Discovery of the cosmic microwave background radiation by Robert Woodrow Wilson and Arno Penzias.
May 20, 1967: The Popular Movement of the Revolution political party is established in the Democratic Republic of the Congo.
May 20, 1969: The Battle of Hamburger Hill in Vietnam ends.
May 20, 1971: In the Chuknagar massacre, Pakistani forces massacre thousands, mostly Bengali Hindus.
May 20, 1980: In a referendum in Quebec, the population rejects, by 60% of the vote, a government proposal to move towards independence from Canada.
May 20, 1983: First publications of the discovery of the HIV virus that causes AIDS in the journal Science by Luc Montagnier.
May 20, 1985: Radio Martí, part of the Voice of America service, begins broadcasting to Cuba.
May 20, 1989: The Chinese authorities declare martial law in the face of pro-democracy demonstrations, setting the scene for the Tiananmen Square massacre.
May 20, 1990: The first post-Communist presidential and parliamentary elections are held in Romania.
May 20, 2002: The independence of East Timor is recognized by Portugal, formally ending 23 years of Indonesian rule and three years of provisional UN administration (Portugal itself is the former colonizer of East Timor until 1976).
May 20, 2012: At least 27 people are killed and 50 others injured when a 6.0-magnitude earthquake strikes northern Italy.
May 20, 2013: An EF5 tornado strikes the Oklahoma City suburb of Moore, killing 24 people and injuring 377 others.
May 21, 0293: Roman Emperors Diocletian and Maximian appoint Galerius as Caesar to Diocletian, beginning the period of four rulers known as the Tetrarchy.
May 21, 0878: Syracuse, Sicily, is captured by the Muslim Aghlabids after a nine-month siege.
May 21, 0879: Pope John VIII gives blessings to Branimir of Croatia and to the Croatian people, considered to be international recognition of the Croatian state.[1]
May 21, 0996: Sixteen-year-old Otto III is crowned Holy Roman Emperor.[2]
May 21, 1349: Dušan's Code, the constitution of the Serbian Empire, is enacted by Dušan the Mighty.
May 21, 1403: Henry III of Castile sends Ruy González de Clavijo as ambassador to Timur to discuss the possibility of an alliance between Timur and Castile against the Ottoman Empire.
May 21, 1554: Queen Mary I grants a royal charter to Derby School, as a grammar school for boys in Derby, England.
May 21, 1659: In the Concert of The Hague, the Dutch Republic, the Commonwealth of England and the Kingdom of France set out their views on how the Second Northern War should end.
May 21, 1660: The Battle of Long Sault concludes after five days in which French colonial militia, with their Huron and Algonquin allies, are defeated by the Iroquois Confederacy.
May 21, 1674: The nobility elect John Sobieski King of Poland and Grand Duke of Lithuania.
May 21, 1703: Daniel Defoe is imprisoned on charges of seditious libel.[3]
May 21, 1725: The Order of St. Alexander Nevsky is instituted in Russia by Empress Catherine I. It would later be discontinued and then reinstated by the Soviet government in 1942 as the Order of Alexander Nevsky.
May 21, 1758: Ten-year-old Mary Campbell is abducted in Pennsylvania by Lenape during the French and Indian War. She is returned six and a half years later.
May 21, 1792: A lava dome collapses on Mount Unzen, near the city of Shimbara on the Japanese island of Kyūshū, creating a deadly tsunami that kills nearly 15,000 people.[4]
May 21, 1809: The first day of the Battle of Aspern-Essling between the Austrian army led by Archduke Charles and the French army led by Napoleon I of France sees the French attack across the Danube held.
May 21, 1851: Slavery is abolished in Colombia, South America.
May 21, 1856: Lawrence, Kansas is captured and burned by pro-slavery forces.
May 21, 1864: The Ionian Islands reunite with Greece.
May 21, 1871: Opening of the first rack railway in Europe, the Rigi Bahnen on Mount Rigi.
May 21, 1881: The American Red Cross is established by Clara Barton in Washington, D.C.
May 21, 1894: The Manchester Ship Canal in the United Kingdom is officially opened by Queen Victoria, who later knights its designer Sir Edward Leader Williams.[5]
May 21, 1904: The Fédération Internationale de Football Association (FIFA) is founded in Paris.
May 21, 1911: President of Mexico Porfirio Díaz and the revolutionary Francisco Madero sign the Treaty of Ciudad Juárez to put an end to the fighting between the forces of both men, concluding the initial phase of the Mexican Revolution.
May 21, 1917: The Great Atlanta fire of 1917 causes $5.5 million in damages, destroying some 300 acres including 2,000 homes, businesses and churches, displacing about 10,000 people but leading to only one fatality (due to heart attack).
May 21, 1924: University of Chicago students Richard Loeb and Nathan Leopold, Jr. murder 14-year-old Bobby Franks in a "thrill killing".
May 21, 1927: Charles Lindbergh touches down at Le Bourget Field in Paris, completing the world's first solo nonstop flight across the Atlantic Ocean.
May 21, 1932: Bad weather forces Amelia Earhart to land in a pasture in Derry, Northern Ireland, and she thereby becomes the first woman to fly solo across the Atlantic Ocean.
May 21, 1934: Oskaloosa, Iowa, becomes the first municipality in the United States to fingerprint all of its citizens.
May 21, 1936: Sada Abe is arrested after wandering the streets of Tokyo for days with her dead lover's severed genitals in her handbag. Her story soon becomes one of Japan's most notorious scandals.
May 21, 1937: A Soviet station, North Pole-1, becomes the first scientific research settlement to operate on the drift ice of the Arctic Ocean.
May 21, 1939: The Canadian National War Memorial is unveiled by King George VI and Queen Elizabeth in Ottawa, Ontario, Canada.
May 21, 1946: Physicist Louis Slotin is fatally irradiated in a criticality incident during an experiment with the demon core at Los Alamos National Laboratory.
May 21, 1966: The Ulster Volunteer Force declares war on the Irish Republican Army in Northern Ireland.
May 21, 1969: Civil unrest in Rosario, Argentina, known as Rosariazo, following the death of a 15-year-old student.
May 21, 1972: Michelangelo's Pietà in St. Peter's Basilica in Rome is damaged by a vandal, the mentally disturbed Hungarian geologist Laszlo Toth.
May 21, 1976: The Yuba City bus disaster occurs in Martinez, California. Twenty-nine are killed making it the deadliest road accident in U.S. history.
May 21, 1979: White Night riots in San Francisco following the manslaughter conviction of Dan White for the assassinations of George Moscone and Harvey Milk.
May 21, 1981: Transamerica Corporation agrees to sell United Artists to Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer for $380 million after the box office failure of the 1980 film Heaven's Gate.[7]
May 21, 1991: Mengistu Haile Mariam, president of the People's Democratic Republic of Ethiopia, flees Ethiopia, effectively bringing the Ethiopian Civil War to an end.
May 21, 1992: After 30 seasons Johnny Carson hosted his penultimate episode and last featuring guests (Robin Williams and Bette Midler) of The Tonight Show.
May 21, 1994: The Democratic Republic of Yemen unsuccessfully attempts to secede from the Republic of Yemen; a war breaks out.
May 21, 1996: The ferry MV Bukoba sinks in Tanzanian waters on Lake Victoria, killing nearly 1,000.
May 21, 1998: President Suharto of Indonesia resigns following the killing of students from Trisakti University earlier that week by security forces and growing mass protests in Jakarta against his ongoing corrupt rule.
May 21, 2001: French Taubira law is enacted, officially recognizing the Atlantic slave trade and slavery as crimes against humanity.
May 21, 2003: The 6.8 Mw  Boumerdès earthquake shakes northern Algeria with a maximum Mercalli intensity of X (Extreme). More than 2,200 people were killed and a moderate tsunami sank boats at the Balearic Islands.
May 21, 2005: The tallest roller coaster in the world, Kingda Ka opens at Six Flags Great Adventure in Jackson Township, New Jersey.
May 21, 2006: The Republic of Montenegro holds a referendum proposing independence from the State Union of Serbia and Montenegro; 55% of Montenegrins vote for independence.
May 21, 2010: JAXA, the Japan Aerospace Exploration Agency, launches the solar-sail spacecraft IKAROS aboard an H-IIA rocket. The vessel would make a Venus flyby late in the year.
May 21, 2011: Radio broadcaster Harold Camping predicted that the world would end on this date.
May 21, 2012: A suicide bombing kills more than 120 people in Sana'a, Yemen.
May 21, 2017: Ringling Bros. and Barnum & Bailey Circus performed their final show at Nassau Veterans Memorial Coliseum.
May 22, 192: Dong Zhuo is assassinated by his adopted son Lü Bu.[1]
May 22, 760: Fourteenth recorded perihelion passage of Halley's Comet.
May 22, 853: A Byzantine fleet sacks and destroys undefended Damietta in Egypt.[2]
May 22, 1176: The Hashshashin (Assassins) attempt to assassinate Saladin near Aleppo.
May 22, 1200: King John of England and King Philip II of France sign the Treaty of Le Goulet.
May 22, 1246: Henry Raspe is elected anti-king of the Kingdom of Germany in opposition to Conrad IV.
May 22, 1254: Serbian King Stefan Uroš I and the Republic of Venice sign a peace treaty.
May 22, 1377: Pope Gregory XI issues five papal bulls to denounce the doctrines of English theologian John Wycliffe.
May 22, 1520: The massacre at the festival of Tóxcatl takes place during the Fall of Tenochtitlan, resulting in turning the Aztecs against the Spanish.[4]
May 22, 1629: Holy Roman Emperor Ferdinand II and Danish King Christian IV sign the Treaty of Lübeck ending Danish intervention in the Thirty Years' War.
May 22, 1762: Trevi Fountain is officially completed and inaugurated in Rome.[5]
May 22, 1804: The Lewis and Clark Expedition officially begins as the Corps of Discovery departs from St. Charles, Missouri.
May 22, 1807: A grand jury indicts former Vice President of the United States Aaron Burr on a charge of treason.
May 22, 1809: On the second and last day of the Battle of Aspern-Essling (near Vienna, Austria), Napoleon I is repelled by an enemy army for the first time.
May 22, 1816: A mob in Littleport, Cambridgeshire, England, riots concerning high unemployment and rising grain costs spreads to Ely the next day.
May 22, 1819: SS Savannah leaves port at Savannah, Georgia, United States, on a voyage to become the first steamship to cross the Atlantic Ocean.
May 22, 1826: HMS Beagle departs on its first voyage.
May 22, 1840: The penal transportation of British convicts to the New South Wales colony is abolished.
May 22, 1849: Future U.S. President Abraham Lincoln is issued a patent for an invention to lift boats, making him the only U.S. President to ever hold a patent.
May 22, 1856: Congressman Preston Brooks of South Carolina severely beats Senator Charles Sumner of Massachusetts with a cane in the hall of the United States Senate for a speech Sumner had made regarding  Southerners and slavery.
May 22, 1900: The Associated Press is formed in New York City as a non-profit news cooperative.
May 22, 1906: The Wright brothers are granted U.S. patent number 821,393 for their "Flying-Machine".
May 22, 1915: Three trains collide in the Quintinshill rail disaster near Gretna Green, Scotland, killing 227 people and injuring 246.
May 22, 1926: Chiang Kai-shek replaces the communists in Kuomintang China.
May 22, 1927: Near Xining, China, an 8.3 magnitude earthquake causes 200,000 deaths in one of the world's most destructive earthquakes.
May 22, 1941: During the Anglo-Iraqi War, British troops take Fallujah.
May 22, 1942: Mexico enters World War II, joining the Allies.
May 22, 1957: South Africa's government approves of racial separation in universities.
May 22, 1958: The 1958 riots in Ceylon become a watershed in the race relations of various ethnic communities of Sri Lanka. The total deaths is estimated at 300, mostly Tamils.
May 22, 1960: The Great Chilean earthquake, measuring 9.5 on the moment magnitude scale, hits southern Chile, becoming the most powerful earthquake ever recorded.
May 22, 1962: Continental Airlines Flight 11 crashes after bombs explode on board.
May 22, 1963: Greek left-wing politician Grigoris Lambrakis is shot in an assassination attempt, and dies five days later.
May 22, 1964: Lyndon B. Johnson launches the Great Society.
May 22, 1967: L'Innovation department store in Brussels, Belgium, burns down, resulting in 323 dead or missing and 150 injured, the most devastating fire in Belgian history.
May 22, 1968: The nuclear-powered submarine USS Scorpion sinks with 99 men aboard, 400 miles southwest of the Azores.
May 22, 1969: Apollo 10's lunar module flies within 8.4 nautical miles (16 km) of the moon's surface.
May 22, 1972: Over 400 women in Derry, Northern Ireland attack the offices of Sinn Féin following the shooting by the Irish Republican Army of a young British soldier on leave.
May 22, 1987: First ever Rugby World Cup kicks off with New Zealand playing Italy at Eden Park in Auckland, New Zealand.
May 22, 1990: North and South Yemen are unified to create the Republic of Yemen.
May 22, 1992: Bosnia and Herzegovina, Croatia and Slovenia join the United Nations.
May 22, 1994: A worldwide trade embargo against Haiti goes into effect to punish its military rulers for not reinstating the country's ousted elected leader, Jean-Bertrand Aristide.
May 22, 1996: The Burmese military regime jails 71 supporters of Aung San Suu Kyi in a bid to block a pro-democracy meeting.
May 22, 1998: A U.S. federal judge rules that U.S. Secret Service agents can be compelled to testify before a grand jury concerning the Lewinsky scandal involving President Bill Clinton.
May 22, 2000: In Sri Lanka, over 150 Tamil rebels are killed over two days of fighting for control in Jaffna.
May 22, 2010: Inter Milan beat Bayern Munich 2-0 in the Uefa Champions League final in Madrid, Spain to become the first, and so far only, Italian team to win the historic treble (Serie A, Coppa Italia, Champions League).
May 22, 2011: An EF5 tornado strikes Joplin, Missouri, killing 158 people and wreaking $2.8 billion in damages, the costliest and seventh-deadliest single tornado in U.S. history.
May 22, 2012: Tokyo Skytree opens to the public. It is the tallest tower in the world (634 m), and the second tallest man-made structure on Earth after Burj Khalifa (829.8 m).
May 22, 2014: An explosion occurs in Ürümqi, capital of China's far-western Xinjiang region, resulting in at least 43 deaths and 91 injuries.
May 22, 2015: The Republic of Ireland becomes the first nation in the world to legalize gay marriage in a public referendum.
May 22, 2017: United States President Donald Trump visits the Church of the Holy Sepulchre in Jerusalem and becomes the first sitting U.S. President to visit the Western Wall.
May 23, 1430: Joan of Arc is captured by the Burgundians while leading an army to raise the Siege of Compiègne.
May 23, 1498: Girolamo Savonarola is burned at the stake in Florence, Italy.
May 23, 1533: The marriage of King Henry VIII to Catherine of Aragon is declared null and void.
May 23, 1568: Dutch rebels led by Louis of Nassau, defeat Jean de Ligne, Duke of Arenberg, and his loyalist troops in the Battle of Heiligerlee, opening the Eighty Years' War.
May 23, 1609: Official ratification of the Second Virginia Charter takes place.
May 23, 1618: The Second Defenestration of Prague precipitates the Thirty Years' War.
May 23, 1701: After being convicted of piracy and of murdering William Moore, Captain William Kidd is hanged in London.
May 23, 1706: John Churchill, 1st Duke of Marlborough, defeats a French army under Marshal François de Neufville, duc de Villeroy at the Battle of Ramillies.[1]
May 23, 1788: South Carolina ratifies the United States Constitution as the eighth American state.
May 23, 1793: Battle of Famars during the Flanders Campaign of the War of the First Coalition.
May 23, 1829: Accordion patent granted to Cyrill Demian in Vienna, Austrian Empire.
May 23, 1863: The General German Workers' Association, a precursor of the modern Social Democratic Party of Germany, is founded in Leipzig, Kingdom of Saxony.
May 23, 1873: The Canadian Parliament establishes the North-West Mounted Police, the forerunner of the Royal Canadian Mounted Police.
May 23, 1907: The unicameral Parliament of Finland gathers for its first plenary session.
May 23, 1911: The New York Public Library is dedicated.
May 23, 1932: In Brazil, four students are shot and killed during a manifestation against the Brazilian dictator Getúlio Vargas, which resulted in the outbreak of the Constitutionalist Revolution several weeks later.
May 23, 1934: The Auto-Lite strike culminates in the "Battle of Toledo", a five-day melée between 1,300 troops of the Ohio National Guard and 6,000 picketers.
May 23, 1939: The U.S. Navy submarine USS Squalus sinks off the coast of New Hampshire during a test dive, causing the death of 24 sailors and two civilian technicians. The remaining 32 sailors and one civilian naval architect are rescued the following day.
May 23, 1948: Thomas C. Wasson, the US Consul-General, is assassinated in Jerusalem, Israel.
May 23, 1951: Tibetans sign the Seventeen Point Agreement for the Peaceful Liberation of Tibet with China.
May 23, 1960: A tsunami caused by an earthquake in Chile the previous day kills 61 people in Hilo, Hawaii.[3]
May 23, 1974: British nuclear testing in the United States of nuclear test Fallon for Chevaline under the Polaris (UK nuclear programme), named after the South African Roan antelope in the London zoo, on request of Lord Carrington.[4]
May 23, 1992: Italy's most prominent anti-mafia judge Giovanni Falcone, his wife and three body guards are killed by the Corleonesi clan with a half-ton bomb near Capaci, Sicily. His friend and colleague Paolo Borsellino will be assassinated less than two months later, making 1992 a turning point in the history of Italian Mafia prosecutions.
May 23, 1995: The first version of the Java programming language is released.
May 23, 1998: The Good Friday Agreement is accepted in a referendum in Northern Ireland with roughly 75% voting yes.[5]
May 23, 2002: The "55 parties" clause of the Kyoto Protocol is reached after its ratification by Iceland.
May 23, 2008: The International Court of Justice (ICJ) awards Middle Rocks to Malaysia and Pedra Branca (Pulau Batu Puteh) to Singapore, ending a 29-year territorial dispute between the two countries.
May 23, 2013: A freeway bridge carrying Interstate 5 over the Skagit River collapses in Mount Vernon, Washington.
May 23, 2014: Seven people, including the perpetrator, are killed and another 14 injured in a killing spree near the campus of University of California, Santa Barbara.
May 23, 2015: At least 46 people are killed as a result of floods caused by a tornado in Texas and Oklahoma.
May 23, 2016: Eight bombings were carried out by the Islamic State of Iraq and Syria in Jableh and Tartus, coastline cities in Syria. One hundred eighty-four people were killed and at least 200 people injured.
May 23, 2017: Philippine President Rodrigo Duterte declared martial law in Mindanao, following the Maute's attack in Marawi.
May 24, 919: The nobles of Franconia and Saxony elect Henry the Fowler at the Imperial Diet in Fritzlar as king of the East Frankish Kingdom.
May 24, 1218: The Fifth Crusade leaves Acre for Egypt.
May 24, 1276: Magnus Ladulås is crowned King of Sweden in Uppsala Cathedral.
May 24, 1487: The ten-year-old Lambert Simnel is crowned in Christ Church Cathedral, Dublin, Ireland, with the name of Edward VI in a bid to threaten King Henry VII's reign.
May 24, 1567: Erik XIV of Sweden and his guards murder five incarcerated Swedish nobles.
May 24, 1595: Nomenclator of Leiden University Library appears, the first printed catalog of an institutional library.
May 24, 1607: 100 English settlers disembark in Jamestown, the first permanent English colony in America.
May 24, 1621: The Protestant Union is formally dissolved.
May 24, 1667: The French Royal Army crosses the border into the Spanish Netherlands, starting the War of Devolution opposing France to the Spanish Empire and the Triple Alliance.
May 24, 1683: The Ashmolean Museum in Oxford, England, opens as the world's first university museum.
May 24, 1689: The English Parliament passes the Act of Toleration protecting dissenting Protestants but excluding Roman Catholics.
May 24, 1738: John Wesley is converted, essentially launching the Methodist movement; the day is celebrated annually by Methodists as Aldersgate Day and a church service is generally held on the preceding Sunday.
May 24, 1798: The Irish Rebellion of 1798 led by the United Irishmen against British rule begins.
May 24, 1813: South American independence leader Simón Bolívar enters Mérida, leading the invasion of Venezuela, and is proclaimed El Libertador ("The Liberator").
May 24, 1830: "Mary Had a Little Lamb" by Sarah Josepha Hale is published.
