August 19, 1936: The Great Purge of the Soviet Union begins when the first of the Moscow Trials is convened.
August 19, 1940: First flight of the B-25 Mitchell medium bomber.
August 19, 1955: In the Northeast United States, severe flooding caused by Hurricane Diane, claims 200 lives.
August 19, 1964: Syncom 3, the first geostationary communication satellite, was launched.
August 19, 1965: Japanese prime minister Eisaku Satō becomes the first post-World War II sitting prime minister to visit Okinawa Prefecture.
August 19, 1978: In Iran, Cinema Rex fire caused more than 400 deaths.
August 19, 1980: Saudia Flight 163, a Lockheed L-1011 TriStar burns after making an emergency landing at King Khalid International Airport in Riyadh, Saudi Arabia, killing 301 people.
August 19, 1989: Several hundred East Germans cross the frontier between Hungary and Austria during the Pan-European Picnic, part of the events that began the process of the Fall of the Berlin Wall.
August 19, 1999: In Belgrade, Yugoslavia, tens of thousands of Serbians rally to demand the resignation of Federal Republic of Yugoslavia President Slobodan Milošević.
August 19, 2003: A suicide attack on a bus in Jerusalem, Israel, planned by Hamas, kills 23 Israelis, seven of them children, in the Shmuel HaNavi bus bombing.
August 19, 2005: The first-ever joint military exercise between Russia and China, called Peace Mission 2005 begins.
August 19, 2009: A series of bombings in Baghdad, Iraq, kills 101 and injures 565 others.
August 19, 2010: Operation Iraqi Freedom ends, with the last of the United States brigade combat teams crossing the border to Kuwait.
August 19, 2013: The Dhamara Ghat train accident kills at least 37 people in the Indian state of Bihar.
August 19, 2017: Tens of thousands of farmed non-native Atlantic salmon are accidentally released into the wild in Washington waters in the 2017 Cypress Island Atlantic salmon pen break.
August 20, AD 14: Agrippa Postumus, maternal grandson of the late Roman emperor Augustus, is executed by his guards under mysterious circumstances while in exile.
August 20, 1083: Canonization of the first King of Hungary, Saint Stephen and his son Saint Emeric celebrated as a National Day in Hungary.
August 20, 1191: Richard I of England initiates the Massacre at Ayyadieh, leaving 2,600–3,000 Muslim hostages dead.
August 20, 1308: Pope Clement V pardons Jacques de Molay, the last Grand Master of the Knights Templar, absolving him of charges of heresy.
August 20, 1391: Konrad von Wallenrode becomes the 24th Grand Master of the Teutonic Order.
August 20, 1467: The Second Battle of Olmedo takes places as part of a succession conflict between Henry IV of Castile and his half-brother Alfonso, Prince of Asturias.
August 20, 1519: Philosopher and general Wang Yangming defeats Zhu Chenhao, ending the Prince of Ning rebellion against the reign of the Ming dynasty's Zhengde Emperor.
August 20, 1672: Former Grand Pensionary Johan de Witt and his brother Cornelis are brutally murdered by an angry mob in The Hague.
August 20, 1707: The first Siege of Pensacola comes to end with the failure of the British to capture Pensacola, Florida.
August 20, 1775: The Spanish establish the Presidio San Augustin del Tucson in the town that became Tucson, Arizona.
August 20, 1852: Steamboat Atlantic sank on Lake Erie after a collision, with the loss of at least 150 lives.
August 20, 1858: Charles Darwin first publishes his theory of evolution through natural selection in The Journal of the Proceedings of the Linnean Society of London, alongside Alfred Russel Wallace's same theory.
August 20, 1866: President Andrew Johnson formally declares the American Civil War over.
August 20, 1882: Tchaikovsky's 1812 Overture debuts in Moscow, Russia.
August 20, 1905: Sun Yat-sen, Chinese revolutionary, forms the first chapter of T'ung Meng Hui, a union of all secret societies determined to bringing down the Manchus.
August 20, 1910: The Great Fire of 1910 (also commonly referred to as the "Big Blowup" or the "Big Burn") occurs in northeast Washington, northern Idaho (the panhandle), and western Montana, burning approximately 3 million acres (12,000 km2).
August 20, 1920: The National Football League is organized as the American Professional Football Conference in Canton, Ohio
August 20, 1926: Japan's public broadcasting company, Nippon Hōsō Kyōkai (NHK) is established.
August 20, 1938: Lou Gehrig hits his 23rd career grand slam, a record that stood for 75 years until it was broken by Alex Rodriguez.
August 20, 1940: In Mexico City, exiled Russian revolutionary Leon Trotsky is fatally wounded with an ice axe by Ramón Mercader. He dies the next day.
August 20, 1960: Senegal breaks from the Mali Federation, declaring its independence.
August 20, 1962: The NS Savannah, the world's first nuclear-powered civilian ship, embarks on its maiden voyage.
August 20, 1986: In Edmond, Oklahoma, U.S. Postal employee Patrick Sherrill guns down 14 of his co-workers and then commits suicide.
August 20, 1988: "Black Saturday" of the Yellowstone fire in Yellowstone National Park
August 20, 1989: The pleasure boat Marchioness sinks on the River Thames following a collision. Fifty-one people are killed.
August 20, 1991: Estonia, annexed by the Soviet Union in 1940, issues a decision on the re-establishment of independence on the basis of historical continuity of its pre-World War II statehood.
August 20, 1993: After rounds of secret negotiations in Norway, the Oslo Accords are signed, followed by a public ceremony in Washington, D.C. the following month.
August 20, 1995: The Firozabad rail disaster claimed 358 lives in Firozabad, India.
August 20, 1997: Souhane massacre in Algeria; over 60 people are killed and 15 kidnapped.
August 20, 1998: The Supreme Court of Canada rules that Quebec cannot legally secede from Canada without the federal government's approval.
August 20, 2002: A group of Iraqis opposed to the regime of Saddam Hussein take over the Iraqi Embassy in Berlin, Germany for five hours before releasing their hostages and surrendering.
August 20, 2007: China Airlines Flight 120 caught fire and exploded after landing at Naha Airport in Okinawa, Japan.
August 20, 2008: Spanair Flight 5022, from Madrid, Spain to Gran Canaria, skids off the runway and crashes at Barajas Airport. Of the 172 people on board, 146 die immediately, and eight more later die of injuries sustained in the crash.
August 20, 2012: A prison riot in the Venezuelan capital, Caracas, kills at least 20 people.
August 20, 2014: Seventy-two people are killed in Japan's Hiroshima Prefecture by a series of landslides caused by a month's worth of rain that fell in one day.
August 20, 2016: Fifty-four people are killed when a suicide bomber detonates himself at a Kurdish wedding party in Gaziantep, Turkey.
August 21, 959: Eraclus becomes the 25th bishop of Liège.
August 21, 1140: Song dynasty general Yue Fei defeats an army led by Jin dynasty general Wuzhu at the Battle of Yancheng during the Jin–Song Wars.
August 21, 1331: King Stefan Uroš III, after months of anarchy, surrenders to his son and rival Stefan Dušan, who succeeds as King of Serbia.
August 21, 1415: Henry the Navigator leads Portuguese forces to victory over the Marinids at the Battle of Ceuta.
August 21, 1680: Pueblo Indians capture Santa Fe from the Spanish during the Pueblo Revolt.
August 21, 1689: The Battle of Dunkeld in Scotland.
August 21, 1770: James Cook formally claims eastern Australia for Great Britain, naming it New South Wales.
August 21, 1772: King Gustav III completes his coup d'état by adopting a new Constitution, ending half a century of parliamentary rule in Sweden and installing himself as an enlightened despot.
August 21, 1791: A Vodou ceremony, led by Dutty Boukman, turns into a violent slave rebellion, beginning the Haitian Revolution.
August 21, 1810: Jean-Baptiste Bernadotte, Marshal of France, is elected Crown Prince of Sweden by the Swedish Riksdag of the Estates.
August 21, 1821: Jarvis Island is discovered by the crew of the ship, Eliza Frances.
August 21, 1831: Nat Turner leads black slaves and free blacks in a rebellion in Southampton County, Virginia, which will claim the lives of 55 to 65 whites.
August 21, 1852: Tlingit Indians destroy Fort Selkirk, Yukon Territory.
August 21, 1863: Lawrence, Kansas is destroyed by pro-Confederate guerrillas known as Quantrill's Raiders.
August 21, 1883: An F5 tornado strikes Rochester, Minnesota, leading to the creation of the Mayo Clinic.
August 21, 1888: The first successful adding machine in the United States is patented by William Seward Burroughs.
August 21, 1897: Oldsmobile, an American automobile manufacturer and marque, is founded.
August 21, 1901: Six hundred American school teachers, Thomasites, arrived in Manila on the USAT Thomas.
August 21, 1911: The Mona Lisa is stolen by Vincenzo Perugia, a Louvre employee.
August 21, 1944: Dumbarton Oaks Conference, prelude to the United Nations, begins.
August 21, 1945: Physicist Harry Daghlian is fatally irradiated in a criticality accident during an experiment with the Demon core at Los Alamos National Laboratory.
August 21, 1957: The Soviet Union successfully conducts a long-range test flight of the R-7 Semyorka, the first intercontinental ballistic missile.
August 21, 1959: United States President Dwight D. Eisenhower signs an executive order proclaiming Hawaii the 50th state of the union. Hawaii's admission is currently commemorated by Hawaii Admission Day
August 21, 1961: Motown releases what would be its first #1 hit (in America), "Please Mr. Postman" by The Marvelettes.
August 21, 1968: James Anderson Jr. posthumously receives the first Medal of Honor to be awarded to an African American U.S. Marine.
August 21, 1971: A bomb exploded in the Liberal Party campaign rally in Plaza Miranda, Manila, Philippines with several anti-Marcos political candidates injured.
August 21, 1983: Philippine opposition leader Benigno Aquino, Jr. is assassinated at the Manila International Airport (now renamed Ninoy Aquino International Airport in his honor).
August 21, 1986: Carbon dioxide gas erupts from volcanic Lake Nyos in Cameroon, killing up to 1,800 people within a 20-kilometer range.
August 21, 1988: The 6.9 Mw  Nepal earthquake shakes the Nepal–India border with a maximum Mercalli intensity of VIII (Severe), leaving 709–1,450 people killed and thousands injured.
August 21, 1991: Coup attempt against Mikhail Gorbachev collapses.
August 21, 1993: NASA loses contact with the Mars Observer spacecraft.
August 21, 2000: Tiger Woods, American professional golfer, wins the 82nd PGA Championship and becomes the first golfer since Ben Hogan in 1953 to win 3 majors in a calendar year.
August 21, 2013: Hundreds of people are reported killed by chemical attacks in the Ghouta region of Syria.
August 21, 2016: The closing ceremony of the 2016 Summer Olympics in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil, takes place.
August 21, 2017: A solar eclipse traverses the continental United States.
August 22, 392: Arbogast has Eugenius elected Western Roman Emperor.
August 22, 1138: Battle of the Standard between Scotland and England.
August 22, 1485: The Battle of Bosworth Field, the death of Richard III and the end of the House of Plantagenet.
August 22, 1559: Bartolomé Carranza, Spanish archbishop, is arrested for heresy.
August 22, 1639: Madras (now Chennai), India, is founded by the British East India Company on a sliver of land bought from local Nayak rulers.
August 22, 1642: Charles I raises his standard in Nottingham, which marks the beginning of the English Civil War.
August 22, 1654: Jacob Barsimson arrives in New Amsterdam. He is the first known Jewish immigrant to America.
August 22, 1711: Britain's Quebec Expedition loses eight ships and almost nine hundred soldiers, sailors and women to rocks at Pointe-aux-Anglais.
August 22, 1770: James Cook names and lands on Possession Island, and claims the east coast of Australia for Britain as New South Wales.
August 22, 1777: British forces abandon the Siege of Fort Stanwix after hearing rumors of Continental Army reinforcements.
August 22, 1780: James Cook's ship HMS Resolution returns to England (Cook having been killed on Hawaii during the voyage).
August 22, 1791: Beginning of the Haitian Slave Revolution in Saint-Domingue, Haiti.
August 22, 1798: French troops land at Kilcummin, County Mayo, Ireland to aid the rebellion.
August 22, 1827: José de la Mar becomes President of Peru.
August 22, 1846: The Second Federal Republic of Mexico is established.
August 22, 1849: The first air raid in history. Austria launches pilotless balloons against the city of Venice.
August 22, 1851: The first America's Cup is won by the yacht America.
August 22, 1864: Twelve nations sign the First Geneva Convention, establishing the rules of protection of the victims of armed conflicts.[1]
August 22, 1875: The Treaty of Saint Petersburg between Japan and Russia is ratified, providing for the exchange of Sakhalin for the Kuril Islands.
August 22, 1894: Mahatma Gandhi forms the Natal Indian Congress (NIC) in order to fight discrimination against Indian traders in Natal.
August 22, 1902: Theodore Roosevelt becomes the first President of the United States to make a public appearance in an automobile.
August 22, 1910: Korea is annexed by Japan with the signing of the Japan–Korea Treaty of 1910, beginning a period of Japanese rule of Korea that lasted until the end of World War II.
August 22, 1922: Michael Collins, Commander-in-chief of the Irish Free State Army, is shot dead in an ambush during the Irish Civil War.
August 22, 1934: Bill Woodfull of Australia becomes the only cricket captain to twice regain The Ashes.
August 22, 1942: Brazil declares war on Germany, Japan and Italy.
August 22, 1949: The Queen Charlotte earthquake is Canada's strongest since the 1700 Cascadia earthquake
August 22, 1953: The penal colony on Devil's Island is permanently closed.
August 22, 1962: The OAS attempts to assassinate French president Charles de Gaulle.
August 22, 1963: X-15 Flight 91 reaches the highest altitude of the X-15 program (107.96 km (67.08 mi) (354,200 feet)).
August 22, 1966: Labor movements NFWA and AWOC merge to become the United Farm Workers Organizing Committee (UFWOC), predecessor of the United Farm Workers.
August 22, 1968: Pope Paul VI arrives in Bogotá, Colombia. It is the first visit of a pope to Latin America.
August 22, 1971: J. Edgar Hoover and John Mitchell announce the arrest of 20 of the Camden 28.
August 22, 1972: Rhodesia is expelled by the IOC for its racist policies.
August 22, 1973: The Congress of Chile votes in favour of a resolution condemning President Salvador Allende's government and demands that he resign or else be unseated through force and new elections.
August 22, 1978: The District of Columbia Voting Rights Amendment is passed by the U.S. Congress. The proposed amendment would have provided the District of Columbia with full voting representation in the Congress, the Electoral College, and regarding amending the U.S. Constitution. The proposed amendment failed to be ratified by enough states (ratified by 16, needed 38) and so did not become part of the Constitution.
August 22, 1985: British Airtours Flight 28M suffers an engine fire during takeoff at Manchester Airport. The pilots abort but due to inefficient evacuation procedures 55 people are killed, mostly from smoke inhalation.
August 22, 1989: Nolan Ryan strikes out Rickey Henderson to become the first Major League Baseball pitcher to record 5,000 strikeouts.
August 22, 1992: FBI sniper Lon Horiuchi shoots and kills Vicki Weaver during an 11-day siege at her home at Ruby Ridge, Idaho.
August 22, 2003: Alabama Chief Justice Roy Moore is suspended after refusing to comply with a federal court order to remove a rock inscribed with the Ten Commandments from the lobby of the Alabama Supreme Court building.
August 22, 2004: Versions of The Scream and Madonna, two paintings by Edvard Munch, are stolen at gunpoint from a museum in Oslo, Norway.
August 22, 2006: Grigori Perelman is awarded the Fields Medal for his proof of the Poincaré conjecture in mathematics but refuses to accept the medal.
August 22, 2007: The Texas Rangers defeat the Baltimore Orioles 30–3, the most runs scored by a team in modern Major League Baseball history.
August 22, 2012: Ethnic clashes over grazing rights for cattle in Kenya's Tana River District result in more than 52 deaths.
August 23, 30 BC: After the successful invasion of Egypt, Octavian executes Marcus Antonius Antyllus, eldest son of Mark Antony, and Caesarion, the last king of the Ptolemaic dynasty of Egypt and only child of Julius Caesar and Cleopatra.
August 23, 20 BC: Ludi Volcanalici are held within the temple precinct of Vulcan, and used by Augustus to mark the treaty with Parthia and the return of the legionary standards that had been lost at the Battle of Carrhae in 53 BC.
August 23, AD 79: Mount Vesuvius begins stirring, on the feast day of Vulcan, the Roman god of fire.
August 23, 406: Gothic king Radagaisus is executed after he is defeated by Roman general Stilicho and 12,000 "barbarians" are incorporated into the Roman army or sold as slaves.
August 23, 476: Odoacer, chieftain of the Germanic tribes (Herulic - Scirian foederati), is proclaimed rex Italiae ("King of Italy") by his troops.
August 23, 634: Abu Bakr dies at Medina and is succeeded by Umar I who becomes the second caliph of the Rashidun Caliphate.
August 23, 1305: Sir William Wallace is executed for high treason at Smithfield, London.
August 23, 1514: The Battle of Chaldiran ends with a decisive victory for the Sultan Selim I, Ottoman Empire, over the Shah Ismail I, founder of the Safavid dynasty.
August 23, 1521: Christian II of Denmark is deposed as king of Sweden and Gustav Vasa is elected regent.
August 23, 1541: French explorer Jacques Cartier lands near Quebec City in his third voyage to Canada.
August 23, 1628: George Villiers, the first Duke of Buckingham, is assassinated by John Felton.
August 23, 1784: Western North Carolina (now eastern Tennessee) declares itself an independent state under the name of Franklin; it is not accepted into the United States, and only lasts for four years.
August 23, 1799: Napoleon I of France leaves Egypt for France en route to seizing power.
August 23, 1813: At the Battle of Großbeeren, the Prussians under Von Bülow repulse the French army.
August 23, 1831: Nat Turner's slave rebellion is suppressed.
August 23, 1839: The United Kingdom captures Hong Kong as a base as it prepares for war with Qing China. The ensuing three-year conflict will later be known as the First Opium War.
August 23, 1866: Austro-Prussian War ends with the Treaty of Prague.
August 23, 1873: Albert Bridge in Chelsea, London opens.
August 23, 1898: The Southern Cross Expedition, the first British venture of the Heroic Age of Antarctic Exploration, departs from London.
August 23, 1904: The automobile tire chain is patented.
August 23, 1921: British airship R-38 experiences structural failure over Hull in England and crashes in the Humber Estuary. Of her 49 British and American training crew, only four survive.
August 23, 1923: Captain Lowell Smith and Lieutenant John P. Richter performed the first mid-air refueling on De Havilland DH-4B, setting an endurance flight record of 37 hours.
August 23, 1927: Italian anarchists Sacco and Vanzetti are executed after a lengthy, controversial trial.
August 23, 1946: Ordinance No. 46 of the British Military Government constitutes the German Länder (states) of Hanover and Schleswig-Holstein.
August 23, 1948: World Council of Churches is formed by 147 churches from 44 countries.
August 23, 1954: First flight of the Lockheed C-130 multi-role aircraft.
August 23, 1966: Lunar Orbiter 1 takes the first photograph of Earth from orbit around the Moon.
August 23, 1970: Organized by Mexican American labor union leader César Chávez, the Salad Bowl strike, the largest farm worker strike in U.S. history, begins.
August 23, 1973: A bank robbery gone wrong in Stockholm, Sweden, turns into a hostage crisis; over the next five days the hostages begin to sympathise with their captors, leading to the term "Stockholm syndrome".
August 23, 1975: The Pontiac Silverdome opens in Pontiac, Michigan, 30 miles (48 km) northwest of Detroit, Michigan
August 23, 1985: Hans Tiedge, top counter-spy of West Germany, defects to East Germany.
August 23, 1990: West and East Germany announce that they will reunite on October 3.
August 23, 1991: The World Wide Web is opened to the public.
August 23, 1994: Eugene Bullard, the only African American pilot in World War I, is posthumously commissioned as Second Lieutenant in the United States Air Force.
August 23, 2000: Gulf Air Flight 072 crashes into the Persian Gulf near Manama, Bahrain, killing 143.
August 23, 2006: Natascha Kampusch, who had been abducted at the age of ten, escapes from her captor Wolfgang Přiklopil, after eight years of captivity.
August 23, 2007: The skeletal remains of Russia's last royal family members Alexei Nikolaevich, Tsarevich of Russia, and his sister Grand Duchess Anastasia are discovered near Yekaterinburg, Russia.
August 23, 2011: Libyan leader Muammar Gaddafi is overthrown after the National Transitional Council forces take control of Bab al-Azizia compound during the Libyan Civil War.
August 23, 2012: A hot-air balloon crashes near the Slovenian capital of Ljubljana, killing six people and injuring 28 others.
August 23, 2013: A riot at the Palmasola prison complex in Santa Cruz, Bolivia kills 31 people.
August 24, 367 AD: Gratian, son of Roman Emperor Valentinian I, is named co-Augustus at the age of eight by his father.[1]
August 24, 394: The Graffito of Esmet-Akhom, the latest known inscription in Egyptian hieroglyphs, is written.[2]
August 24, 410: The Visigoths under king Alaric I begin to pillage Rome.
August 24, 455: The Vandals, led by king Gaiseric, begin to plunder Rome. Pope Leo I requests Gaiseric not destroy the ancient city or murder its citizens. He agrees and the gates of Rome are opened. However, the Vandals loot a great amount of treasure.
August 24, 1185: Sack of Thessalonica by the Normans.
August 24, 1200: King John of England, signer of the first Magna Carta, marries Isabella of Angoulême in Bordeaux Cathedral.[3]
August 24, 1215: Pope Innocent III issues a bull declaring Magna Carta invalid.[4]
August 24, 1349: Six thousand Jews are killed in Mainz after being blamed for the bubonic plague.[5]
August 24, 1482: The town and castle of Berwick upon Tweed is captured from Scotland by an English army.[6]
August 24, 1516: The Ottoman Empire under Selim I defeats the Mamluk Sultanate and captures present-day Syria at the Battle of Marj Dabiq.[7]
August 24, 1561: Willem of Orange marries duchess Anna of Saxony.[8]
August 24, 1608: The first official English representative to India lands in Surat.
August 24, 1643: A Dutch fleet establishes a new colony in the ruins of Valdivia in southern Chile.[9]
August 24, 1662: The Act of Uniformity requires England to accept the Book of Common Prayer.
August 24, 1682: William Penn receives the area that is now the state of Delaware, and adds it to his colony of Pennsylvania.
August 24, 1690: Job Charnock of the East India Company establishes a factory in Calcutta, an event formerly considered the founding of the city (in 2003 the Calcutta High Court ruled that the city's foundation date is unknown).
August 24, 1814: British troops invade Washington, D.C. and during the Burning of Washington the White House, the Capitol and many other buildings are set ablaze.
August 24, 1815: The modern Constitution of the Netherlands is signed.
August 24, 1816: The Treaty of St. Louis is signed in St. Louis, Missouri.
August 24, 1821: The Treaty of Córdoba is signed in Córdoba, now in Veracruz, Mexico, concluding the Mexican War of Independence from Spain.
August 24, 1857: The Panic of 1857 begins, setting off one of the most severe economic crises in United States history.
August 24, 1870: The Wolseley expedition reaches Manitoba to end the Red River Rebellion.
August 24, 1891: Thomas Edison patents the motion picture camera.
August 24, 1898: Count Muravyov, Foreign Minister of Russia presents a rescript that convoked the First Hague Peace Conference.
August 24, 1909: Workers start pouring concrete for the Panama Canal.
August 24, 1911: Manuel de Arriaga is elected and sworn-in as the first President of Portugal.
August 24, 1931: Resignation of the United Kingdom's Second Labour Government. Formation of the UK National Government.
August 24, 1932: Amelia Earhart becomes the first woman to fly across the United States non-stop (from Los Angeles to Newark, New Jersey).
August 24, 1933: The Crescent Limited train derails in Washington, D.C., after the bridge it is crossing is washed out by the 1933 Chesapeake–Potomac hurricane.
August 24, 1936: The Australian Antarctic Territory is created.
August 24, 1941: Adolf Hitler orders the cessation of Nazi Germany's systematic T4 euthanasia program of the mentally ill and the handicapped due to protests, although killings continue for the remainder of the war.
August 24, 1949: The treaty creating the North Atlantic Treaty Organization goes into effect.
August 24, 1950: Edith Sampson becomes the first black U.S. delegate to the United Nations.
August 24, 1954: Getúlio Vargas, president of Brazil, commits suicide and is succeeded by João Café Filho.
August 24, 1967: Led by Abbie Hoffman, the Youth International Party temporarily disrupts trading at the New York Stock Exchange by throwing dollar bills from the viewing gallery, causing trading to cease as brokers scramble to grab them.
August 24, 1970: Vietnam War protesters bomb Sterling Hall at the University of Wisconsin–Madison, leading to an international manhunt for the perpetrators.
August 24, 1981: Mark David Chapman is sentenced to 20 years to life in prison for murdering John Lennon.
August 24, 1989: Tadeusz Mazowiecki is chosen as the first non-communist prime minister in Central and Eastern Europe.
August 24, 1991: Ukraine declares itself independent from the Soviet Union.
August 24, 1992: Hurricane Andrew makes landfall in Homestead, Florida as a Category 5 hurricane, causing up to $25 billion (1992 USD) in damages.
August 24, 1994: Initial accord between Israel and the PLO about partial self-rule of the Palestinians on the West Bank.
August 24, 1995: Microsoft Windows 95 was released to the public in North America.
August 24, 1998: First radio-frequency identification (RFID) human implantation tested in the United Kingdom.
August 24, 2004: Eighty-nine passengers die after two airliners explode after flying out of Domodedovo International Airport, near Moscow. The explosions are caused by suicide bombers from Chechnya.
August 24, 2006: The International Astronomical Union (IAU) redefines the term "planet" such that Pluto is now considered a dwarf planet.
August 24, 2010: In San Fernando, Tamaulipas, Mexico, 72 illegal immigrants are killed by Los Zetas and eventually found dead by Mexican authorities.
August 24, 2016: An earthquake strikes Central Italy with a magnitude of 6.2, with aftershocks felt as far as Rome and Florence.
August 25, 766: Emperor Constantine V humiliates nineteen high-ranking officials, after discovering a plot against him. He executes the leaders, Constantine Podopagouros and his brother Strategios.
August 25, 1248: The Dutch city of Ommen receives city rights and fortification rights from Otto III, the Archbishop of Utrecht.
August 25, 1258: Regent George Mouzalon and his brothers are killed during a coup headed by the aristocratic faction under, paving the way for its leader, Michael VIII Palaiologos, to ultimately usurp the throne of the Empire of Nicaea.
August 25, 1270: King Louis IX of France dies in Tunis while on the Eighth Crusade.
August 25, 1537: The Honourable Artillery Company, the oldest surviving regiment in the British Army, and the second most senior, is formed.
August 25, 1543: António Mota and a few companions become the first Europeans to visit Japan.
August 25, 1609: Galileo Galilei demonstrates his first telescope to Venetian lawmakers.
August 25, 1630: Portuguese forces are defeated by the Kingdom of Kandy at the Battle of Randeniwela in Sri Lanka.
August 25, 1823: American fur trapper Hugh Glass is mauled by a grizzly bear while on an expedition in South Dakota.
August 25, 1825: Uruguay declares its independence from Brazil.
August 25, 1835: The first Great Moon Hoax article is published in The New York Sun, announcing the discovery of life and civilization on the Moon.
August 25, 1875: Captain Matthew Webb becomes the first person to swim across the English Channel, traveling from Dover, England, to Calais, France, in 21 hours and 45 minutes.[1]
August 25, 1883: France and Viet Nam sign the Treaty of Huế, recognizing a French protectorate over Annam and Tonkin.
August 25, 1894: Kitasato Shibasaburō discovers the infectious agent of the bubonic plague and publishes his findings in The Lancet.
August 25, 1898: Seven hundred Greek civilians, 17 British guards and the British Consul of Crete are killed by a Turkish mob in Heraklion, Greece.
August 25, 1916: The United States National Park Service is created.
August 25, 1933: The Diexi earthquake strikes Mao County, Sichuan, China and kills 9,000 people.
August 25, 1939: The United Kingdom and Poland form a military alliance in which the UK promises to defend Poland in case of invasion by a foreign power.
August 25, 1945: Ten days after World War II ends with Japan announcing its surrender, armed supporters of the Chinese Communist Party kill U.S. intelligence officer John Birch, regarded by some of the American right as the first victim of the Cold War.
August 25, 1950: President Harry Truman orders the U.S. Army to seize control of the nation's railroads to avert a strike.
August 25, 1961: President Jânio Quadros of Brazil resigns after just seven months in power, initiating a political crisis that culminates in a military coup in 1964.
August 25, 1967: George Lincoln Rockwell, founder of the American Nazi Party, is assassinated by a former member of his group.
August 25, 1981: Voyager 2 spacecraft makes its closest approach to Saturn.
August 25, 1989: Voyager 2 spacecraft makes its closest approach to Neptune, the second to last planet in the Solar System at the time.
August 25, 1991: Linus Torvalds announces the first version of what will become Linux.
August 25, 1997: Egon Krenz, the former East German leader, is convicted of a shoot-to-kill policy at the Berlin Wall.
August 25, 2001: American singer Aaliyah and several members of her record company are killed as their overloaded aircraft crashes shortly after takeoff from Marsh Harbour Airport, Bahamas.
August 25, 2006: Former Prime Minister of Ukraine Pavlo Lazarenko is sentenced to nine years imprisonment for money laundering, wire fraud, and extortion.
August 25, 2012: Voyager 1 spacecraft enters interstellar space becoming the first man-made object to do so.
August 25, 2017: Hurricane Harvey makes landfall in Texas as a powerful Category 4 hurricane, the strongest hurricane to make landfall in the United States since 2004. Over the next few days, the storm causes catastrophic flooding throughout much of eastern Texas, killing 106 people and causing $125 billion in damage.
August 26, 683: Yazid I's army kills 11,000 people of Medina including notable Sahabas in Battle of al-Harrah.
August 26, 1071: The Seljuq Turks defeat the Byzantine army at the Battle of Manzikert, and soon gain control of most of Anatolia.
August 26, 1278: Ladislaus IV of Hungary and Rudolf I of Germany defeat Ottokar II of Bohemia in the Battle on the Marchfeld near Dürnkrut in (then) Moravia.
August 26, 1542: Francisco de Orellana navigated the Amazon River, reaching the Atlantic Ocean.
August 26, 1748: The first Lutheran denomination in North America, the Pennsylvania Ministerium, is founded in Philadelphia.
August 26, 1768: Captain James Cook sets sail from England on board HMS Endeavour.
August 26, 1778: The first recorded ascent of Triglav, the highest mountain in Slovenia.
August 26, 1789: The Declaration of the Rights of Man and of the Citizen is approved by the National Constituent Assembly of France.
August 26, 1791: John Fitch is granted a United States patent for the steamboat.
August 26, 1810: The former viceroy Santiago de Liniers of the Viceroyalty of the Río de la Plata is executed after the defeat of his counter-revolution.
August 26, 1883: The 1883 eruption of Krakatoa begins its final, paroxysmal, stage.
August 26, 1920: The 19th amendment to United States Constitution takes effect, giving women the right to vote.
August 26, 1940: Chad becomes the first French colony to join the Allies under the administration of Félix Éboué, France's first black colonial governor.
August 26, 1942: At Chortkiv, the Ukrainian police and German Schutzpolizei deport two thousand Jews to Bełżec extermination camp. Five hundred of the sick and children are murdered on the spot. This continued until the next day.
August 26, 1966: The South African Border War starts with the battle at Omugulugwombashe.
August 26, 1970: A new feminist movement leads a nationwide Women's Strike for Equality.
August 26, 1977: The Charter of the French Language is adopted by the National Assembly of Quebec
August 26, 1980: After John Birges plants a bomb at Harvey's Resort Hotel in Stateline, Nevada, in the United States, the FBI inadvertently detonates the bomb during its disarming.
August 26, 1997: Beni Ali massacre occurs in Algeria, leaving 60 to 100 people dead.
August 26, 1998: The first flight of the Air Force Delta III ends in disaster 75 seconds after liftoff resulting in the loss of the Galaxy X satellite.
August 26, 1999: Russia begins the Second Chechen War in response to the Invasion of Dagestan by the Islamic International Peacekeeping Brigade.
August 26, 2009: Kidnapping victim Jaycee Dugard is discovered alive in California after being missing for over 18 years.
August 26, 2011: The Boeing 787 Dreamliner, Boeing's all-new composite airliner, receives certification from the EASA and the FAA.
August 26, 2015: Two U.S. journalists are shot and killed by a disgruntled former coworker while conducting a live report in Moneta, Virginia.
August 26, 2017: The Mercedes-Benz Stadium opens in Atlanta, Georgia, replacing the Georgia Dome that was demolished on November 20.
August 27, 410: The sacking of Rome by the Visigoths ends after three days.
August 27, 1172: Henry the Young King and Margaret of France are crowned junior king and queen of England.
August 27, 1557: The Battle of St. Quentin results in Emmanuel Philibert becoming Duke of Savoy.
August 27, 1593: Pierre Barrière fails in his attempt to assassinate King Henry IV of France.
August 27, 1689: The Treaty of Nerchinsk is signed by Russia and the Qing Empire (Julian calendar).
August 27, 1798: Wolfe Tone's United Irish and French forces clash with the British Army in the Battle of Castlebar, part of the Irish Rebellion of 1798, resulting in the creation of the French puppet Republic of Connacht.
August 27, 1813: French Emperor Napoleon I defeats a larger force of Austrians, Russians, and Prussians at the Battle of Dresden.
August 27, 1828: Brazil and Argentina recognize the sovereignty of Uruguay in the Treaty of Montevideo
August 27, 1832: Black Hawk, leader of the Sauk tribe of Native Americans, surrenders to U.S. authorities, ending the Black Hawk War.
August 27, 1859: Petroleum is discovered in Titusville, Pennsylvania leading to the world's first commercially successful oil well.
August 27, 1881: The Georgia hurricane makes landfall near Savannah, Georgia, resulting in an estimated 700 deaths.
August 27, 1893: The Sea Islands hurricane strikes the United States near Savannah, Georgia, killing between 1,000-2,000 people.
August 27, 1927: Five Canadian women file a petition to the Supreme Court of Canada, asking, "Does the word 'Persons' in Section 24 of the British North America Act, 1867, include female persons?"
August 27, 1928: The Kellogg–Briand Pact outlawing war is signed by fifteen nations. Ultimately sixty-one nations will sign it.
August 27, 1933: The first Afrikaans Bible is introduced during a Bible Festival in Bloemfontein.
August 27, 1939: First flight of the turbojet-powered Heinkel He 178, the world's first jet aircraft.
August 27, 1942: First day of the Sarny Massacre.
August 27, 1956: The nuclear power station at Calder Hall in the United Kingdom was connected to the national power grid becoming the world's first commercial nuclear power station to generate electricity on an industrial scale.
August 27, 1962: The Mariner 2 unmanned space mission is launched to Venus by NASA.
August 27, 1964: South Vietnamese junta leader Nguyễn Khánh enters into a triumvirate power-sharing arrangement with rival generals Trần Thiện Khiêm and Dương Văn Minh, who had both been involved in plots to unseat Khánh.
August 27, 1971: An attempted coup d'état fails in the African nation of Chad. The Government of Chad accuses Egypt of playing a role in the attempt and breaks off diplomatic relations.
August 27, 1975: The Governor of Portuguese Timor abandons its capital, Dili, and flees to Atauro Island, leaving control to a rebel group.
August 27, 1979: A Provisional Irish Republican Army bomb kills British retired admiral Lord Mountbatten and three others while they are boating on holiday in Sligo, Republic of Ireland. Shortly after, 18 British Army soldiers are killed in an ambush near Warrenpoint, Northern Ireland.
August 27, 1980: A massive bomb planted by extortionist John Birges explodes at Harvey's Resort Hotel in Stateline, Nevada after a failed disarming attempt by the FBI. Although the hotel is damaged, no one is injured.
August 27, 1982: Turkish military diplomat Colonel Atilla Altıkat is shot and killed in Ottawa. Justice Commandos of the Armenian Genocide claim to be avenging the massacre of 1​1⁄2 million Armenians in the 1915 Armenian Genocide.
August 27, 1985: The Nigerian government is peacefully overthrown by Army Chief of Staff Major General Ibrahim Babangida.
August 27, 1991: Moldova declares independence from the USSR.
August 27, 2003: The first six-party talks, involving South and North Korea, the United States, China, Japan and Russia, convene to find a peaceful resolution to the security concerns of the North Korean nuclear weapons program.
August 27, 2006: Comair Flight 5191 crashes on takeoff from Blue Grass Airport in Lexington, Kentucky bound for Hartsfield–Jackson Atlanta International Airport in Atlanta. Of the passengers and crew, 49 of 50 are confirmed dead in the hours following the crash.
August 27, 2011: Hurricane Irene strikes the United States east coast, killing 47 and causing an estimated $15.6 billion in damage.
August 28, 475: The Roman general Orestes forces western Roman Emperor Julius Nepos to flee his capital city, Ravenna.
August 28, 489: Theodoric, king of the Ostrogoths, defeats Odoacer at the Battle of Isonzo, forcing his way into Italy.
August 28, 632: Fatimah, daughter of the Islamic prophet Muhammad dies, with her cause of death being a controversial topic among the Sunni Muslims and Shia Muslims.
August 28, 663: Silla–Tang armies crush the Baekje restoration attempt and force Yamato Japan to withdraw from Korea in the Battle of Baekgang.
August 28, 1524: The Kaqchikel Maya rebel against their former Spanish allies during the Spanish conquest of Guatemala.
August 28, 1565: Pedro Menéndez de Avilés sights land near St. Augustine, Florida and founds the oldest continuously occupied European-established city in the continental United States.
August 28, 1619: Election of Ferdinand II, Holy Roman Emperor.
August 28, 1648: The Siege of Colchester ends when Royalists Forces surrender to the Parliamentary Forces after eleven weeks, during the Second English Civil War.
August 28, 1709: Meidingnu Pamheiba is crowned King of Manipur.
August 28, 1830: The Baltimore and Ohio Railroad's new Tom Thumb steam locomotive races a horse-drawn car, presaging steam's role in U.S. railroads.
August 28, 1833: King William IV gives Royal Assent to the Slavery Abolition Act 1833, although slavery remained legal in the possessions of the East India Company until the passage of the Indian Slavery Act, 1843.
August 28, 1845: The first issue of Scientific American magazine is published.
August 28, 1849: After a month-long siege, Venice, which had declared itself independent as the Republic of San Marco, surrenders to Austria.
August 28, 1859: The Carrington event is the strongest geomagnetic storm on record to strike the Earth. Electrical telegraph service is widely disrupted.
August 28, 1867: The United States takes possession of the (at this point unoccupied) Midway Atoll.
August 28, 1879: Cetshwayo, last king of the Zulus, is captured by the British.
August 28, 1898: Caleb Bradham's beverage "Brad's Drink" is renamed "Pepsi-Cola".
August 28, 1901: Silliman University is founded in the Philippines. It is the first American private school in the country.
August 28, 1909: A group of mid-level Greek Army officers launches the Goudi coup, seeking wide-ranging reforms.
August 28, 1913: Queen Wilhelmina opens the Peace Palace in The Hague.
August 28, 1917: Ten Suffragettes are arrested while picketing the White House.
August 28, 1924: The Georgian opposition stages the August Uprising against the Soviet Union.
August 28, 1937: Toyota Motors becomes an independent company.
August 28, 1955: Black teenager Emmett Till is brutally murdered in Mississippi, galvanizing the nascent civil rights movement.
August 28, 1957: U.S. Senator Strom Thurmond begins a filibuster to prevent the Senate from voting on Civil Rights Act of 1957; he stopped speaking 24 hours and 18 minutes later, the longest filibuster ever conducted by a single Senator.
August 28, 1968: Rioting takes place in Chicago during the Democratic National Convention, triggering a brutal police crackdown.
August 28, 1990: An F5 tornado strikes the Illinois cities of Plainfield and Joliet, killing 29 people.
August 28, 1993: The Galileo spacecraft discovers a moon, later named Dactyl, around 243 Ida, the first known asteroid moon.
August 28, 1998: Pakistan's National Assembly passes a constitutional amendment to make the "Qur'an and Sunnah" the "supreme law" but the bill is defeated in the Senate.
August 28, 2003: In "one of the most complicated and bizarre crimes in the annals of the FBI", Brian Wells dies after becoming involved in a complex plot involving a bank robbery, a scavenger hunt, and a homemade explosive device.[1]
August 29, 1009: Mainz Cathedral suffers extensive damage from a fire, which destroys the building on the day of its inauguration.
August 29, 1261: Pope Urban IV succeeds Pope Alexander IV as the 182nd pope.
August 29, 1475: The Treaty of Picquigny ends a brief war between  the kingdoms of France and England.
August 29, 1484: Pope Innocent VIII succeeds Pope Sixtus IV.
August 29, 1498: Vasco da Gama decides to depart Calicut and return to Kingdom of Portugal.
August 29, 1541: The Ottoman Turks capture Buda, the capital of the Hungarian Kingdom.
August 29, 1728: The city of Nuuk in Greenland is founded as the fort of Godt-Haab by the royal governor Claus Paarss.
August 29, 1756: Frederick the Great attacks Saxony, beginning the Seven Years' War in Europe.
August 29, 1758: The Treaty of Easton establishes the first American Indian reservation, at Indian Mills, New Jersey, for the Lenape.
August 29, 1786: Shays' Rebellion, an armed uprising of Massachusetts farmers, begins in response to high debt and tax burdens.
August 29, 1807: British troops under Sir Arthur Wellesley defeat a Danish militia outside Copenhagen in the Battle of Køge.
August 29, 1842: Treaty of Nanking signing ends the First Opium War.
August 29, 1869: The Mount Washington Cog Railway opens, making it the world's first mountain-climbing rack railway.
August 29, 1885: Gottlieb Daimler patents the world's first internal combustion motorcycle, the Reitwagen.
August 29, 1898: The Goodyear tire company is founded.
August 29, 1903: The Slava, the last of the five Borodino-class battleships, is launched.
August 29, 1907: The Quebec Bridge collapses during construction, killing 75 workers.
August 29, 1910: The Japan–Korea Treaty of 1910, also known as the Japan–Korea Annexation Treaty, becomes effective, officially starting the period of Japanese rule in Korea.
August 29, 1911: The Canadian Naval Service becomes the Royal Canadian Navy.[1]
August 29, 1915: US Navy salvage divers raise F-4, the first U.S. submarine sunk in an accident.
August 29, 1916: The United States passes the Philippine Autonomy Act.
August 29, 1930: The last 36 remaining inhabitants of St Kilda are voluntarily evacuated to other parts of Scotland.
August 29, 1958: United States Air Force Academy opens in Colorado Springs, Colorado.
August 29, 1965: The Gemini V spacecraft returns to Earth, landing in the Atlantic Ocean.
August 29, 1966: Leading Egyptian thinker Sayyid Qutb is executed for plotting the assassination of President Gamal Abdel Nasser.
August 29, 1970: Chicano Moratorium against the Vietnam War, East Los Angeles, California. Police riot kills three people, including journalist Rubén Salazar.
August 29, 1982: The synthetic chemical element Meitnerium, atomic number 109, is first synthesized at the Gesellschaft für Schwerionenforschung in Darmstadt, Germany.
August 29, 1991: Libero Grassi, an Italian businessman from Palermo, is killed by the Sicilian Mafia after taking a solitary stand against their extortion demands.
August 29, 1996: Vnukovo Airlines Flight 2801, a Tupolev Tu-154, crashes into a mountain on the Arctic island of Spitsbergen, killing all 141 aboard.
August 29, 1997: At least 98 villagers are killed by the Armed Islamic Group of Algeria GIA in the Rais massacre, Algeria.
August 29, 2003: Ayatollah Sayed Mohammed Baqir al-Hakim, the Shia Muslim leader in Iraq, is assassinated in a terrorist bombing, along with nearly 100 worshippers as they leave a mosque in Najaf.
August 29, 2005: Hurricane Katrina devastates much of the U.S. Gulf Coast from Louisiana to the Florida Panhandle, killing up to 1,836 people and causing $125 billion in damage.
August 29, 2012: At least 26 Chinese miners are killed and 21 missing after a blast in the Xiaojiawan coal mine, located at Panzhihua, Sichuan Province.
August 30, AD 70: Titus ends the siege of Jerusalem after destroying Herod's Temple.[1]
August 30, 1282: Peter III of Aragon lands at Trapani to intervene in the War of the Sicilian Vespers.
August 30, 1363: The five-week Battle of Lake Poyang begins, in which the forces of two Chinese rebel leaders (Chen Youliang and Zhu Yuanzhang) meet to decide who will supplant the Yuan dynasty.
August 30, 1464: Pope Paul II succeeds Pope Pius II as the 211th pope.
August 30, 1574: Guru Ram Das becomes the Fourth Sikh Guru/Master.
August 30, 1594: The christening of Prince Henry of Scotland is celebrated with the Masque at the baptism of Prince Henry at Stirling Castle.[2]
August 30, 1727: Anne, eldest daughter of King George II of Great Britain, is given the title Princess Royal.
August 30, 1791: HMS Pandora sinks after having run aground on the outer Great Barrier Reef the previous day.
August 30, 1799: The entire Dutch fleet is captured by British forces under the command of Sir Ralph Abercromby and Admiral Sir Charles Mitchell during the War of the Second Coalition.
August 30, 1800: Gabriel Prosser postpones a planned slave rebellion in Richmond, Virginia, but is arrested before he can make it happen.
August 30, 1873: Austrian explorers Julius von Payer and Karl Weyprecht discover the archipelago of Franz Josef Land in the Arctic Sea.
August 30, 1909: Burgess Shale fossils are discovered by Charles Doolittle Walcott.
August 30, 1917: Vietnamese prison guards led by Trịnh Văn Cấn mutiny at the Thái Nguyên penitentiary against local French authority.
August 30, 1918: Fanni Kaplan shoots and seriously injures Bolshevik leader Vladimir Lenin, which along with the assassination of Bolshevik senior official Moisei Uritsky days earlier, prompts the decree for Red Terror.
August 30, 1940: The Second Vienna Award reassigns the territory of Northern Transylvania from Romania to Hungary.
August 30, 1945: The August Revolution ends as Emperor Bảo Đại abdicates, ending the Nguyễn dynasty.
August 30, 1962: Japan conducts a test of the NAMC YS-11, its first aircraft since World War II and its only successful commercial aircraft from before or after the war.
August 30, 1963: The Moscow–Washington hotline between the leaders of the U.S. and the Soviet Union goes into operation.
August 30, 1967: Thurgood Marshall is confirmed as the first African American Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States.
August 30, 1974: A powerful bomb explodes at the Mitsubishi Heavy Industries headquarters in Marunouchi, Tokyo. Eight are killed, 378 are injured. Eight left-wing activists are arrested on May 19, 1975 by Japanese authorities.
August 30, 1981: President Mohammad-Ali Rajai and Prime Minister Mohammad-Javad Bahonar of Iran are assassinated in a bombing committed by the People's Mujahedin of Iran.
August 30, 1992: The 11-day Ruby Ridge standoff ends with Randy Weaver surrendering to federal authorities.
August 30, 2014: Prime Minister of Lesotho Tom Thabane flees to South Africa as the army allegedly stages a coup.
August 31, 1056: After a sudden illness a few days previously, Byzantine Empress Theodora dies childless, thus ending the Macedonian dynasty.
August 31, 1057: Abdication of Byzantine Emperor Michael VI Bringas after just one year.
August 31, 1218: Al-Kamil becomes sultan of the Ayyubid dynasty.
August 31, 1314: King Haakon V of Norway moves the capital from Bergen to Oslo.
August 31, 1422: King Henry V of England dies of dysentery while in France. His son, Henry VI becomes King of England at the age of 9 months.
August 31, 1776: William Livingston, the first Governor of New Jersey, begins serving his first term.
August 31, 1813: At the final stage of the Peninsular War, British-Portuguese troops capture the town of Donostia (now San Sebastián), resulting in a rampage and eventual destruction of the town. Elsewhere, Spanish troops repel a French attack in the Battle of San Marcial.
August 31, 1864: During the American Civil War, Union forces led by General William T. Sherman launch an assault on Atlanta.
August 31, 1876: Ottoman Sultan Murad V is deposed and succeeded by his brother Abdul Hamid II.
August 31, 1886: The 7.0 Mw  Charleston earthquake affects southeastern South Carolina with a maximum Mercalli intensity of X (Extreme); 60 people killed with damage estimated at $5–6 million.
August 31, 1888: Mary Ann Nichols is murdered. She is the first of Jack the Ripper's confirmed victims.
August 31, 1895: German Count Ferdinand von Zeppelin patents his navigable balloon.
August 31, 1897: Thomas Edison patents the Kinetoscope, the first movie projector.
August 31, 1907: Russia and the United Kingdom sign the Anglo-Russian Convention, by which the UK recognizes Russian preeminence in northern Persia, while Russia recognizes British preeminence in southeastern Persia and Afghanistan. Both powers pledge not to interfere in Tibet.
August 31, 1920: The first radio news program is broadcast by 8MK in Detroit.
August 31, 1935: In an attempt to stay out of the growing tensions concerning Germany and Japan, the United States passes the first of its Neutrality Acts.
August 31, 1936: Radio Prague, now the official international broadcasting station of the Czech Republic, goes on the air.
August 31, 1939: Nazi Germany mounts a false flag attack on the Gleiwitz radio station, creating an excuse to attack Poland the following day, thus starting World War II in Europe.
August 31, 1940: Pennsylvania Central Airlines Trip 19 crashes near Lovettsville, Virginia. The CAB investigation of the accident is the first investigation to be conducted under the Bureau of Air Commerce act of 1938.
August 31, 1943: USS Harmon, the first U.S. Navy ship to be named after a black person, is commissioned.
August 31, 1949: The retreat of the Democratic Army of Greece in Albania after its defeat on Gramos mountain marks the end of the Greek Civil War.
August 31, 1957: The Federation of Malaya (now Malaysia) gains its independence from the United Kingdom.
August 31, 1958: A parcel bomb sent by Ngô Đình Nhu, younger brother and chief adviser of South Vietnamese President Ngô Đình Diệm, fails to kill King Norodom Sihanouk of Cambodia.
August 31, 1963: Crown Colony of North Borneo (now Sabah) achieves self governance.
August 31, 1986: The Soviet passenger liner Admiral Nakhimov sinks in the Black Sea after colliding with the bulk carrier Pyotr Vasev, killing 423.
August 31, 1987: Thai Airways Flight 365 crashes into the ocean near Ko Phuket, Thailand, killing all 83 aboard.
August 31, 1991: Kyrgyzstan declares its independence from the Soviet Union.
August 31, 1993: Russia completes removing its troops from Lithuania.
August 31, 1994: Russia completes removing its troops from Estonia.
August 31, 1996: Saddam Hussein's troops seized Irbil after the Kurdish Masoud Barzani appealed for help to defeat his Kurdish rival PUK.
August 31, 1997: Diana, Princess of Wales, her companion Dodi Fayed and driver Henri Paul die in a car crash in Paris.
August 31, 1999: A LAPA Boeing 737-200 crashes during takeoff from Jorge Newbury Airport in Buenos Aires, killing 65, including two on the ground.
August 31, 2005: The 2005 Al-Aaimmah bridge stampede in Baghdad kills 953 people.
August 31, 2006: Edvard Munch's famous painting The Scream, stolen on August 22, 2004, is recovered in a raid by Norwegian police.
August 31, 2016: Brazil's President Dilma Rousseff is impeached and removed from office.
September 1, 1355: King Tvrtko I of Bosnia writes In castro nostro Vizoka vocatum from the Old town of Visoki.
September 1, 1420: a 9.4 MS-strong earthquake shakes Chile's Atacama Region causing tsunamis in Chile as well as Hawaii and Japan.[1][2]
September 1, 1529: The Spanish fort of Sancti Spiritu, the first one built in modern Argentina, is destroyed by natives.
September 1, 1532: Lady Anne Boleyn is made Marquess of Pembroke by her fiancé, King Henry VIII of England.
September 1, 1604: Adi Granth, now known as Guru Granth Sahib, the holy scripture of Sikhs, was first installed at Harmandir Sahib.
September 1, 1715: King Louis XIV of France dies after a reign of 72 years, which is the longest of any major European monarch.
September 1, 1763: Catherine II of Russia endorses Ivan Betskoy's plans for a Foundling Home in Moscow
September 1, 1772: The Mission San Luis Obispo de Tolosa is founded in San Luis Obispo, California.
September 1, 1774: Massachusetts Bay colonists rise up in the bloodless Powder Alarm.
September 1, 1804: Juno, one of the largest asteroids in the Main Belt, is discovered by the German astronomer Karl Ludwig Harding.
September 1, 1831: The high honor of Order of St. Gregory the Great is established by Pope Gregory XVI of the Vatican State to recognize high support for the Vatican or for the Pope, by a man or a woman, and not necessarily a Roman Catholic.
September 1, 1836: Narcissa Whitman, one of the first English-speaking white women to settle west of the Rocky Mountains, arrives at Walla Walla, Washington.
September 1, 1838: Saint Andrew's Scots School, the oldest school of British origin in South America, is established.
September 1, 1859: One of the largest coronal mass ejections ever recorded, later to be known as the Carrington Event, occurs.
September 1, 1873: Cetshwayo ascends to the throne as king of the Zulu nation following the death of his father Mpande.
September 1, 1878: Emma Nutt becomes the world's first female telephone operator when she is recruited by Alexander Graham Bell to the Boston Telephone Dispatch Company.
September 1, 1880: The army of Mohammad Ayub Khan is routed by the British at the Battle of Kandahar, ending the Second Anglo-Afghan War
September 1, 1894: Over 400 people die in the Great Hinckley Fire, a forest fire in Hinckley, Minnesota.
September 1, 1897: The Tremont Street Subway in Boston opens, becoming the first underground rapid transit system in North America.
September 1, 1905: Alberta and Saskatchewan join the Canadian confederation.
September 1, 1906: The International Federation of Intellectual Property Attorneys is established.
September 1, 1911: The armored cruiser Georgios Averof is commissioned into the Greek Navy. It now serves as a museum ship.
September 1, 1914: The last known passenger pigeon, a female named Martha, dies in captivity in the Cincinnati Zoo.
September 1, 1920: The Fountain of Time opens as a tribute to the 100 years of peace between the United States and Great Britain following the Treaty of Ghent.
September 1, 1923: The Great Kantō earthquake devastates Tokyo and Yokohama, killing about 105,000 people.
September 1, 1928: Ahmet Zogu declares Albania to be a monarchy and proclaims himself king.
September 1, 1934: The first Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer animated cartoon, The Discontented Canary, is released to movie theatres.
September 1, 1939: Adolf Hitler signs an order to begin the systematic euthanasia of mentally ill and disabled people.
September 1, 1951: The United States, Australia and New Zealand sign a mutual defense pact, called the ANZUS Treaty.
September 1, 1952: The Old Man and the Sea, the Pulitzer Prize-winning novel by Ernest Hemingway, is first published.
September 1, 1958: Iceland expands its fishing zone, putting it into conflict with the United Kingdom, beginning the Cod Wars.
September 1, 1961: The first conference of the Non-Aligned Countries is held in Belgrade, Yugoslavia.
September 1, 1967: The Khmer–Chinese Friendship Association is banned in Cambodia.
September 1, 1969: Trần Thiện Khiêm becomes Prime Minister of South Vietnam under President Nguyễn Văn Thiệu.
September 1, 1970: Attempted assassination of King Hussein of Jordan by Palestinian guerrillas, who attack his motorcade.
September 1, 1972: In Reykjavík, Iceland, American Bobby Fischer beats Russian Boris Spassky to become the world chess champion.
September 1, 1974: The SR-71 Blackbird sets (and holds) the record for flying from New York to London in the time of 1 hour, 54 minutes and 56.4 seconds at a speed of 1,435.587 miles per hour (2,310.353 km/h).
September 1, 1979: The American space probe Pioneer 11 becomes the first spacecraft to visit Saturn when it passes the planet at a distance of 21,000 kilometres (13,000 mi).
September 1, 1980: Major General Chun Doo-hwan becomes President of South Korea, following the resignation of Choi Kyu-hah.
September 1, 1981: A coup d'état in the Central African Republic overthrows President David Dacko.
September 1, 1982: The United States Air Force Space Command is founded.
September 1, 1985: A joint American–French expedition locates the wreckage of the RMS Titanic.
September 1, 1991: Uzbekistan declares independence from the Soviet Union.
September 1, 2004: The Crisis in Beslan commences when armed terrorists take schoolchildren and school staff hostage in North Ossetia (Russia); by the end of the siege three days later more than 385 people are dead (including hostages, other civilians, security personnel and terrorists).
September 2, 44 BC: Cicero launches the first of his Philippicae (oratorical attacks) on Mark Antony. He will make 14 of them over the following months.
September 2, 1192: The Treaty of Jaffa is signed between Richard I of England and Saladin, leading to the end of the Third Crusade.
September 2, 1649: The Italian city of Castro is completely destroyed by the forces of Pope Innocent X, ending the Wars of Castro.
September 2, 1666: The Great Fire of London breaks out and burns for three days, destroying 10,000 buildings, including Old St Paul's Cathedral.
September 2, 1752: Great Britain, along with its overseas possessions, adopts the Gregorian calendar.
September 2, 1789: The United States Department of the Treasury is founded.
September 2, 1792: During what became known as the September Massacres of the French Revolution, rampaging mobs slaughter three Roman Catholic bishops, more than two hundred priests, and prisoners believed to be royalist sympathizers.
September 2, 1806: A massive landslide destroys the town of Goldau, Switzerland, killing 457.
September 2, 1807: The British Royal Navy bombards Copenhagen with fire bombs and phosphorus rockets to prevent Denmark from surrendering its fleet to Napoleon.
September 2, 1856: The Tianjing incident takes place in Nanjing, China.
September 2, 1867: Mutsuhito, Emperor Meiji of Japan, marries Masako Ichijō, thereafter known as Empress Shōken.
September 2, 1901: Vice President of the United States Theodore Roosevelt utters the famous phrase, "Speak softly and carry a big stick" at the Minnesota State Fair.
September 2, 1912: Arthur Rose Eldred is awarded the first Eagle Scout award of the Boy Scouts of America.
September 2, 1935: The Labor Day Hurricane, the most intense hurricane to strike the United States, makes landfall at Long Key, Florida, killing at least 400.
September 2, 1945: Vietnam declares its independence, forming the Democratic Republic of Vietnam.
September 2, 1946: The Interim Government of India is formed, headed by Jawaharlal Nehru as Vice President with the powers of a Prime Minister.
September 2, 1957: President Ngô Đình Diệm of South Vietnam becomes the first foreign head of state to make a state visit to Australia.
September 2, 1958: United States Air Force C-130A-II is shot down by fighters over Yerevan in Armenia when it strays into Soviet airspace while conducting a sigint mission. All crew members are killed.
September 2, 1960: The first election of the Parliament of the Central Tibetan Administration, in history of Tibet. The Tibetan community observes this date as Democracy Day.
September 2, 1963: CBS Evening News becomes U.S. network television's first half-hour weeknight news broadcast, when the show is lengthened from 15 to 30 minutes.
September 2, 1968: Operation OAU begins during the Nigerian Civil War
September 2, 1970: NASA announces the cancellation of two Apollo missions to the Moon, Apollo 15 (the designation is re-used by a later mission), and Apollo 19.
September 2, 1984: Seven people are shot and killed and 12 wounded in the Milperra massacre, a shootout between the rival motorcycle gangs Bandidos and Comancheros in Sydney, Australia.
September 2, 1987: In Moscow, the trial begins for 19-year-old pilot Mathias Rust, who flew his Cessna airplane into Red Square in May.
September 2, 1990: Transnistria is unilaterally proclaimed a Soviet republic; the Soviet president Mikhail Gorbachev declares the decision null and void.
September 2, 1992: The 7.7 Mw  Nicaragua earthquake affected the west coast of Nicaragua. With a Ms–Mw disparity of half a unit, this tsunami earthquake triggered a tsunami that caused most of the damage and casualties, with at least 116 killed. Typical runup heights were 3–8 meters (9.8–26.2 ft).
September 2, 1998: The UN's International Criminal Tribunal for Rwanda finds Jean-Paul Akayesu, the former mayor of a small town in Rwanda, guilty of nine counts of genocide.
September 2, 2009: The Andhra Pradesh, India helicopter crash occurred near Rudrakonda Hill, 40 nautical miles (74 km) from Kurnool, Andhra Pradesh, India. Fatalities included Y. S. Rajasekhara Reddy, the Chief Minister of the Indian state of Andhra Pradesh.
September 2, 2018: The National Museum of Brazil is destroyed by a fire, with the loss of over 90% of the museum's collection.
September 3, 36 BC: In the Battle of Naulochus, Marcus Vipsanius Agrippa, admiral of Octavian, defeats Sextus Pompey, son of Pompey, thus ending Pompeian resistance to the Second Triumvirate.
September 3, 301: San Marino, one of the smallest nations in the world and the world's oldest republic still in existence, is founded by Saint Marinus.
September 3, 590: Consecration of Pope Gregory I (Gregory the Great).
September 3, 673: King Wamba of the Visigoths puts down a revolt by Hilderic, governor of Nîmes (France) and rival for the throne.
September 3, 863: Major Byzantine victory at the Battle of Lalakaon against an Arab raid.
September 3, 1189: Richard I of England (a.k.a. Richard "the Lionheart") is crowned at Westminster.
September 3, 1260: The Mamluks defeat the Mongols at the Battle of Ain Jalut in Palestine, marking their first decisive defeat and the point of maximum expansion of the Mongol Empire.
September 3, 1411: The Treaty of Selymbria is concluded between the Ottoman Empire and the Republic of Venice.
September 3, 1658: The death of Oliver Cromwell; Richard Cromwell becomes Lord Protector of England.
September 3, 1666: The Royal Exchange burns down in the Great Fire of London.
September 3, 1798: The week long battle of St. George's Caye begins between Spain and Britain off the coast of Belize.
September 3, 1802: William Wordsworth composes the sonnet Composed upon Westminster Bridge, September 3, 1802.
September 3, 1812: Twenty-four settlers are killed in the Pigeon Roost Massacre in Indiana.
September 3, 1838: Future abolitionist Frederick Douglass escapes from slavery.
September 3, 1843: King Otto of Greece is forced to grant a constitution following an uprising in Athens.
September 3, 1875: The first official game of polo is played in Argentina after being introduced by British ranchers.
September 3, 1878: Over 640 die when the crowded pleasure boat Princess Alice collides with the Bywell Castle in the River Thames.
September 3, 1895: John Brallier becomes the first openly professional American football player, when he was paid US$10 by David Berry, to play for the Latrobe Athletic Association in a 12–0 win over the Jeanette Athletic Association.
September 3, 1914: French composer Albéric Magnard is killed defending his estate against invading German soldiers.
September 3, 1925: USS Shenandoah, the United States' first American-built rigid airship, was destroyed in a squall line over Noble County, Ohio. Fourteen of her 42-man crew perished, including her commander, Zachary Lansdowne.
September 3, 1933: Yevgeniy Abalakov is the first man to reach the highest point in the Soviet Union, Communism Peak (now called Ismoil Somoni Peak and situated in Tajikistan) (7495 m).
September 3, 1935: Sir Malcolm Campbell reaches a speed of 304.331 miles per hour on the Bonneville Salt Flats in Utah, becoming the first person to drive an automobile over 300 mph.
September 3, 1945: A three-day celebration begins in China, following the Victory over Japan Day on September 2.
September 3, 1950: "Nino" Farina becomes the first Formula One Drivers' champion after winning the 1950 Italian Grand Prix.
September 3, 1954: The German submarine U-505 begins its move from a specially constructed dock to its site at Chicago's Museum of Science and Industry.
September 3, 1981: The Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination Against Women, an international bill of rights for women, is instituted by the United Nations.[1]
September 3, 1987: In a coup d'état in Burundi, President Jean-Baptiste Bagaza is deposed by Major Pierre Buyoya.
September 3, 1997: Vietnam Airlines Flight 815 (Tupolev Tu-134) crashes on approach into Phnom Penh airport, killing 64.
September 3, 2001: In Belfast, Protestant loyalists begin a picket of Holy Cross, a Catholic primary school for girls. For the next 11 weeks, riot police escort the schoolchildren and their parents through hundreds of protesters, some of whom hurl missiles and abuse. The protest sparks fierce rioting and grabs world headlines.
September 3, 2004: Beslan school  siege results in over 330 fatalities, including 186 children.
September 3, 2016: The U.S. and China, together responsible for 40% of the world's carbon emissions, both formally ratify the Paris global climate agreement.
September 3, 2010: After taking from Dubai International Airport, UPS Airlines Flight 6 develops an in-flight fire in the cargo hold and crashes near Nad Al Sheba, killing both crew members on board.
September 3, 2017: North Korea conducts its sixth and most powerful nuclear test.
September 4, 476: Romulus Augustulus, last emperor of the Western Roman Empire, is deposed when Odoacer proclaims himself "King of Italy", thus ending the Western Roman Empire.
September 4, 626: Li Shimin, posthumously known as Emperor Taizong of Tang, assumes the throne over the Tang dynasty of China.
September 4, 1260: The Sienese Ghibellines, supported by the forces of Manfred, King of Sicily, defeat the Florentine Guelphs at Montaperti.
September 4, 1282: Peter III of Aragon becomes the King of Sicily.
September 4, 1479: The Treaty of Alcáçovas is signed by the Catholic Monarchs of Castile and Aragon on one side and Afonso V and his son, Prince John of Portugal.
September 4, 1607: The Flight of the Earls takes place in Ireland.
September 4, 1666: In London, England, the most destructive damage from the Great Fire occurs.
September 4, 1774: New Caledonia is first sighted by Europeans, during the second voyage of Captain James Cook.
September 4, 1781: Los Angeles is founded as El Pueblo de Nuestra Señora La Reina de los Ángeles (The Village of Our Lady, the Queen of the Angels) by 44 Spanish settlers.
September 4, 1800: The French garrison in Valletta surrenders to British troops who had been called at the invitation of the Maltese. The islands of Malta and Gozo become the Malta Protectorate.
September 4, 1870: Emperor Napoleon III of France is deposed and the Third Republic is declared.
September 4, 1882: The Pearl Street Station in New York City becomes the first power plant to supply electricity to paying customers.
September 4, 1888: George Eastman registers the trademark Kodak and receives a patent for his camera that uses roll film.
September 4, 1912: Albanian rebels succeed in their revolt when the Ottoman Empire agrees to fulfill their demands
September 4, 1919: Mustafa Kemal Atatürk, who founded the Republic of Turkey, gathers a congress in Sivas to make decisions as to the future of Anatolia and Thrace.
September 4, 1923: Maiden flight of the first U.S. airship, the USS Shenandoah.
September 4, 1948: Queen Wilhelmina of the Netherlands abdicates for health reasons.
September 4, 1949: The Peekskill riots erupt after a Paul Robeson concert in Peekskill, New York.
September 4, 1950: Darlington Raceway is the site of the inaugural Southern 500, the first 500-mile NASCAR race.
September 4, 1951: The first live transcontinental television broadcast takes place in San Francisco, from the Japanese Peace Treaty Conference.
September 4, 1957: The Ford Motor Company introduces the Edsel.
September 4, 1963: Swissair Flight 306 crashes near Dürrenäsch, Switzerland, killing all 80 people on board.
September 4, 1964: Scotland's Forth Road Bridge near Edinburgh officially opens.
September 4, 1970: Salvador Allende is elected President of Chile.
September 4, 1971: Alaska Airlines Flight 1866 crashes near Juneau, Alaska, killing all 111 people on board.
September 4, 1972: The Price Is Right premieres on CBS. As of 2018, it is the longest running game show on American television.
September 4, 1975: The Sinai Interim Agreement relating to the Arab–Israeli conflict is signed.
September 4, 1977: The Golden Dragon massacre takes place in San Francisco.
September 4, 1985: The discovery of Buckminsterfullerene, the first fullerene molecule of carbon.
September 4, 1989: In Leipzig, East Germany, the first of weekly demonstration for the legalisation of opposition groups and democratic reforms takes place.
September 4, 1998: Google is founded by Larry Page and Sergey Brin, two students at Stanford University.
September 4, 2001: Tokyo DisneySea opens to the public as part of the Tokyo Disney Resort in Urayasu, Chiba, Japan.
September 4, 2002: The Oakland Athletics win their 20th consecutive game, an American League record.
September 4, 2007: Three terrorists suspected to be a part of Al-Qaeda are arrested in Germany after allegedly planning attacks on both the Frankfurt International airport and US military installations.
September 4, 2010: A 7.1 magnitude earthquake strikes the South Island of New Zealand causing widespread damage and several power outages.
September 5, 917: Liu Yan declares himself emperor, establishing the Southern Han state in southern China, at his capital of Panyu.
September 5, 1590: Alexander Farnese's army forces Henry IV of France to lift the siege of Paris.
September 5, 1698: In an effort to Westernize his nobility, Tsar Peter I of Russia imposes a tax on beards for all men except the clergy and peasantry.
September 5, 1725: Wedding of Louis XV and Maria Leszczyńska.
September 5, 1774: First Continental Congress assembles in Philadelphia.
September 5, 1791: Olympe de Gouges writes the Declaration of the Rights of Woman and of the Female Citizen.
September 5, 1798: Conscription is made mandatory in France by the Jourdan law.
September 5, 1816: Louis XVIII has to dissolve the Chambre introuvable ("Unobtainable Chamber").
September 5, 1836: Sam Houston is elected as the first president of the Republic of Texas.
September 5, 1839: The United Kingdom declares war on the Qing dynasty of China.
September 5, 1882: Tottenham Hotspur, a Premier League football club from North London, is founded (as Hotspur F.C.).
September 5, 1887: A fire at the Theatre Royal, Exeter, kills 186.
September 5, 1906: The first legal forward pass in American football is thrown by Bradbury Robinson of St. Louis University to teammate Jack Schneider in a 22–0 victory over Carroll College (Wisconsin).
September 5, 1927: The first Oswald the Lucky Rabbit cartoon, Trolley Troubles, produced by Walt Disney, is released by Universal Pictures.
September 5, 1932: The French Upper Volta is broken apart between Ivory Coast, French Sudan, and Niger.
September 5, 1941: Whole territory of Estonia is occupied by Nazi Germany.
September 5, 1944: Belgium, Netherlands and Luxembourg constitute Benelux.
September 5, 1945: Iva Toguri D'Aquino, a Japanese American suspected of being wartime radio propagandist Tokyo Rose, is arrested in Yokohama.
September 5, 1948: In France, Robert Schuman becomes President of the Council while being Foreign minister; as such, he is the negotiator of the major treaties of the end of World War II.
September 5, 1960: Muhammad Ali (then known as Cassius Clay) wins the gold medal in the light heavyweight boxing competition at the Olympic Games in Rome.
September 5, 1970: Jochen Rindt becomes the only driver to posthumously win the Formula One World Drivers' Championship (in 1970), after being killed in practice for the Italian Grand Prix.
September 5, 1980: The Gotthard Road Tunnel opens in Switzerland as the world's longest highway tunnel at 10.14 miles (16.32 km) stretching from Göschenen to Airolo.
September 5, 1984: Western Australia becomes the last Australian state to abolish capital punishment.
September 5, 1986: Pan Am Flight 73 from Mumbai, India with 358 people on board is hijacked at Karachi International Airport.
September 5, 1991: The current international treaty defending indigenous peoples, Indigenous and Tribal Peoples Convention, 1989, comes into force.
September 5, 1996: Hurricane Fran makes landfall near Cape Fear, North Carolina as a Category 3 storm with 115 mph sustained winds. Fran caused over $3 billion in damage and killed 27 people.
September 5, 2012: An accidental explosion at a Turkish Army ammunition store in Afyon, western Turkey kills 25 soldiers and wounds four others.
September 6, 1492: Christopher Columbus sails from La Gomera in the Canary Islands, his final port of call before crossing the Atlantic Ocean for the first time.
September 6, 1522: The Victoria returns to Sanlúcar de Barrameda in Spain, the only surviving ship of Ferdinand Magellan's expedition and the first ship to circumnavigate the world.
September 6, 1620: The Pilgrims sail from Plymouth, England on the Mayflower to settle in North America. (Old Style date; September 16 per New Style date.)
September 6, 1628: Puritans settle Salem which became part of Massachusetts Bay Colony.
September 6, 1781: The Battle of Groton Heights takes place, resulting in a British victory.
September 6, 1803: British scientist John Dalton begins using symbols to represent the atoms of different elements.
September 6, 1847: Henry David Thoreau leaves Walden Pond and moves in with Ralph Waldo Emerson and his family in Concord, Massachusetts.
September 6, 1870: Louisa Ann Swain of Laramie, Wyoming becomes the first woman in the United States to cast a vote legally after 1807.
September 6, 1885: Eastern Rumelia declares its union with Bulgaria, thus accomplishing Bulgarian unification.
September 6, 1901: Leon Czolgosz, an unemployed anarchist, shoots and fatally wounds US President William McKinley at the Pan-American Exposition in Buffalo, New York.
September 6, 1916: The first self-service grocery store Piggly Wiggly was opened in Memphis, Tennessee by Clarence Saunders.
September 6, 1930: Democratically elected Argentine president Hipólito Yrigoyen is deposed in a military coup.
September 6, 1940: King Carol II of Romania abdicates and is succeeded by his son Michael. General Ion Antonescu becomes the Conducător of Romania.
September 6, 1943: Pennsylvania Railroad's premier train derails at Frankford Junction in Philadelphia, killing 79 people and injuring 117 others.
September 6, 1946: United States Secretary of State James F. Byrnes announces that the U.S. will follow a policy of economic reconstruction in postwar Germany.
September 6, 1952: A prototype aircraft crashes at the Farnborough Airshow in Hampshire, England, killing 29 spectators and the two on board.
September 6, 1955: Istanbul's Greek, Jewish, and Armenian minorities are the target of a government-sponsored pogrom; dozens are killed in ensuing riots.
September 6, 1962: Archaeologist Peter Marsden discovers the first of the Blackfriars Ships dating back to the second century AD in the Blackfriars area of the banks of the River Thames in London.
September 6, 1965: India retaliates following Pakistan's Operation Grand Slam which results in the Indo-Pakistani War of 1965 that ends in a stalemate followed by the signing of the Tashkent Declaration.
September 6, 1966: Prime Minister Hendrik Verwoerd, the architect of apartheid, is stabbed to death in Cape Town, South Africa during a parliamentary meeting.
September 6, 1970: Two passenger jets bound from Europe to New York are simultaneously hijacked by Palestinian terrorist members of the PFLP and taken to Dawson's Field, Jordan.
September 6, 1983: The Soviet Union admits to shooting down Korean Air Lines Flight 007, stating that its operatives did not know that it was a civilian aircraft when it reportedly violated Soviet airspace.
September 6, 1986: In Istanbul, two terrorists from Abu Nidal's organization kill 22 and wound six congregants inside the Neve Shalom Synagogue during Shabbat services.
September 6, 1991: The Russian parliament approves the name change of Leningrad back to Saint Petersburg. The change is effective October 1, 1991.
September 6, 1995: Cal Ripken, Jr. of the Baltimore Orioles plays in his 2,131st consecutive game, breaking a record that had stood for 56 years.
September 6, 1997: The Funeral of Diana, Princess of Wales takes place in London. Well over a million people lined the streets and 2​1⁄2 billion watched around the world on television.
