September 23, 1806: Lewis and Clark return to St. Louis after exploring the Pacific Northwest of the United States.
September 23, 1821: Tripolitsa, Greece, is captured by Greek rebels during the Greek War of Independence.
September 23, 1845: The Knickerbockers Baseball Club, the first baseball team to play under the modern rules, is founded in New York.
September 23, 1846: Astronomers Urbain Jean Joseph Le Verrier, John Couch Adams and Johann Gottfried Galle collaborate on the discovery of Neptune.
September 23, 1868: Grito de Lares ("Lares Revolt") occurs in Puerto Rico against Spanish rule.
September 23, 1889: Nintendo Koppai (Later Nintendo Company, Limited) is founded by Fusajiro Yamauchi to produce and market the playing card game Hanafuda.
September 23, 1899: The American Asiatic Squadron destroys a Filipino battery at the Battle of Olongapo.
September 23, 1905: Norway and Sweden sign the "Karlstad treaty", peacefully dissolving the Union between the two countries.
September 23, 1909: The novel Le Fantôme de l'Opéra (The Phantom of the Opera), by Gaston Leroux, is published as a serialization in Le Gaulois.
September 23, 1911: Pilot Earle Ovington makes the first official airmail delivery in America under the authority of the United States Post Office Department
September 23, 1913: Roland Garros of France becomes the first to fly in an airplane across the Mediterranean (from St. Raphael in France to Bizerte, Tunisia).
September 23, 1932: The unification of Saudi Arabia is completed.
September 23, 1938: The Czechoslovak army is mobilized in response to the Munich Agreement.
September 23, 1962: The Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts opens in New York City.
September 23, 1980: Bob Marley plays what would be the last concert of his life in Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania.
September 23, 1983: Gulf Air Flight 771 is destroyed by a bomb, killing all 117 people on board.
September 23, 1986: Houston Astros' Jim Deshaies sets a record, striking out the first eight batters he faces against the Los Angeles Dodgers.
September 23, 2002: The first public version of the web browser Mozilla Firefox ("Phoenix 0.1") is released.
September 23, 2004: Over 3,000 people die in Haiti after Hurricane Jeanne produces massive flooding and mudslides.
September 23, 2008: Matti Saari kills ten people before committing suicide.
September 24, 1180: Manuel I Komnenos, the last Byzantine Emperor of the Komnenian restoration, dies.
September 24, 1645: The Battle of Rowton Heath is a Parliamentarian victory over a Royalist army commanded in person by King Charles.
September 24, 1674: Second Tantrik Coronation of Chhatrapati Shivaji Maharaj.
September 24, 1789: The United States Congress passes the Judiciary Act, creating the office of the Attorney General and federal judiciary system and ordering the composition of the Supreme Court.
September 24, 1830: A revolutionary committee of notables forms the Provisional Government of Belgium.
September 24, 1841: The Sultanate of Brunei cedes Sarawak to the United Kingdom.
September 24, 1852: The first airship powered by (a steam) engine, created by Henri Giffard, travels 17 miles (27 km) from Paris to Trappes.
September 24, 1853: Admiral Despointes formally takes possession of New Caledonia in the name of France.
September 24, 1869: Gold prices plummet after President Grant orders the Treasury to sell large quantities of gold after Jay Gould and James Fisk plot to control the market.
September 24, 1877: The Battle of Shiroyama is a decisive victory of the Imperial Japanese Army over the Satsuma Rebellion.
September 24, 1890: The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints officially renounces polygamy.
September 24, 1906: Racial tensions exacerbated by rumors lead to the Atlanta Race Riot, further increasing racial segregation.
September 24, 1911: His Majesty's Airship No. 1, Britain's first rigid airship, is wrecked by strong winds before her maiden flight at Barrow-in-Furness.
September 24, 1929: Jimmy Doolittle performs the first flight without a window, proving that full instrument flying from take off to landing is possible.
September 24, 1932: Gandhi and Dr. Ambedkar agree to the Poona Pact, which reserved seats in the Indian provincial legislatures for the "Depressed Classes" (Untouchables).
September 24, 1935: Earl and Weldon Bascom produce the first rodeo ever held outdoors under electric lights.
September 24, 1946: The top-secret Clifford-Elsey Report on the Soviet Union is delivered to President Truman.
September 24, 1948: The Honda Motor Company is founded.
September 24, 1950: The Chinchaga fire in western Canada becomes the largest recorded fire in North American history, sending smoke all the way to Europe.
September 24, 1957: President Eisenhower sends the 101st Airborne Division to Little Rock, Arkansas, to enforce desegregation.
September 24, 1960: USS Enterprise, the world's first nuclear-powered aircraft carrier, is launched.
September 24, 1972: Japan Airlines Flight 472 lands at Juhu Aerodrome instead of Santacruz Airport in Bombay, India.
September 24, 1973: Guinea-Bissau declares its independence from Portugal.
September 24, 1975: Southwest Face expedition members become the first persons to reach the summit of Mount Everest by any of its faces, instead of using a ridge route.
September 24, 1993: The Cambodian monarchy is restored, with Norodom Sihanouk as king.
September 24, 1996: Representatives of 71 nations sign the Comprehensive Nuclear-Test-Ban Treaty at the United Nations.
September 24, 2005: Hurricane Rita makes landfall in the United States, devastating portions of southwestern Louisiana and extreme southeastern Texas.
September 24, 2007: Between 30,000 and 100,000 people take part in anti-government protests in Yangon, Burma, the largest in 20 years.
September 24, 2008: Thabo Mbeki resigns as president of South Africa
September 24, 2009: The G20 summit begins in Pittsburgh with 30 global leaders in attendance.
September 24, 2013: A 7.7-magnitude earthquake strikes southern Pakistan, killing at least 327 people.
September 24, 2014: The Mars Orbiter Mission makes India the first Asian nation to reach Mars orbit, and the first nation in the world to do so in its first attempt.
September 24, 2015: At least 1,100 people are killed and another 934 wounded after a stampede during the Hajj in Saudi Arabia.
September 25, 275: For the last time, the Roman Senate chooses an emperor (Marcus Claudius Tacitus).
September 25, 762: Led by Muhammad al-Nafs al-Zakiyya, the Hasanid branch of the Alids begins the Alid Revolt against the Abbasid Caliphate.
September 25, 1066: The Battle of Stamford Bridge sees the defeat of Harald Hardrada by King Harold II of England.
September 25, 1237: England and Scotland sign the Treaty of York, establishing the location of their common border.
September 25, 1396: Ottoman Emperor Bayezid I defeats a Christian army at the Battle of Nicopolis.
September 25, 1513: Spanish explorer Vasco Núñez de Balboa reaches what would become known as the Pacific Ocean.
September 25, 1555: The Peace of Augsburg is signed by Emperor Charles V and the princes of the Schmalkaldic League.
September 25, 1690: Publick Occurrences Both Forreign and Domestick, the first newspaper to appear in the Americas, is published for the first and only time.
September 25, 1790: Four Great Anhui Troupes introduce Anhui opera to Beijing in honor of the Qianlong Emperor's eightieth birthday.
September 25, 1804: The Teton Sioux (a subdivision of the Lakota) demand one of the boats from the Lewis and Clark Expedition as a toll for allowing the expedition to move further upriver.
September 25, 1868: The Imperial Russian steam frigate Alexander Nevsky is shipwrecked off Jutland while carrying Grand Duke Alexei Alexandrovich of Russia.
September 25, 1890: The United States Congress establishes Sequoia National Park.
September 25, 1906: Leonardo Torres y Quevedo demonstrates the Telekino, guiding a boat from the shore, in what is considered to be the first use of a remote control.
September 25, 1911: An explosion of badly degraded propellant charges on board the French battleship Liberté detonates the forward ammunition magazines and destroys the ship.
September 25, 1912: Columbia University Graduate School of Journalism is founded in New York City.
September 25, 1926: The international Convention to Suppress the Slave Trade and Slavery is first signed.
September 25, 1955: The Royal Jordanian Air Force is founded.
September 25, 1956: TAT-1, the first submarine transatlantic telephone cable system, is inaugurated.
September 25, 1957: Central High School in Little Rock, Arkansas, is integrated by the use of United States Army troops.
September 25, 1959: Solomon Bandaranaike, Prime Minister of Sri Lanka, is mortally wounded by a Buddhist monk, Talduwe Somarama, and dies the next day.
September 25, 1962: The North Yemen Civil War begins when Abdullah al-Sallal dethrones the newly crowned Imam al-Badr and declares Yemen a republic under his presidency.
September 25, 1963: Lord Denning releases the UK government's official report on the Profumo Affair.
September 25, 1964: The Mozambican War of Independence against Portugal begins.
September 25, 1969: The charter establishing the Organisation of Islamic Cooperation is signed.
September 25, 1974: Dr. Frank Jobe performs first ulnar collateral ligament replacement surgery (better known as Tommy John surgery) on baseball player Tommy John.
September 25, 1977: About 4,200 people take part in the first running of the Chicago Marathon.
September 25, 1978: PSA Flight 182, a Boeing 727, collides in mid-air with a Cessna 172 and crashes in San Diego, killing 144 people.
September 25, 1983: Thirty-eight IRA prisoners, armed with six handguns, hijack a prison meals lorry and smash their way out of the Maze Prison.
September 25, 1992: NASA launches the Mars Observer. Eleven months later, the probe would fail while preparing for orbital insertion.
September 25, 2003: The 8.3 Mw  Hokkaidō earthquake strikes just offshore Hokkaidō, Japan.
September 25, 2018: Bill Cosby is sentenced to three to ten years in prison.
September 26, 46 BC: Julius Caesar dedicates a temple to Venus Genetrix, fulfilling a vow he made at the Battle of Pharsalus.
September 26, 715: Ragenfrid defeats Theudoald at the Battle of Compiègne.
September 26, 1087: William II is crowned King of England, and reigns until 1100.
September 26, 1212: The Golden Bull of Sicily is issued to confirm the hereditary royal title in Bohemia for the Přemyslid dynasty.
September 26, 1493: Pope Alexander VI issues the papal bull Dudum siquidem to the Spanish, extending the grant of new lands he made them in Inter caetera.
September 26, 1580: Francis Drake finishes his circumnavigation of the Earth.
September 26, 1687: The Parthenon in Athens is partially destroyed during the Morean War.
September 26, 1688: The city council of Amsterdam votes to support William of Orange's invasion of England, which became the Glorious Revolution.
September 26, 1789: George Washington appoints the first cabinet of the United States government.
September 26, 1792: Marc-David Lasource begins accusing Maximilien Robespierre of wanting a dictatorship for France.
September 26, 1810: A new Act of Succession is adopted by the Riksdag of the Estates, and Jean Baptiste Bernadotte becomes heir to the Swedish throne.
September 26, 1905: Albert Einstein publishes the third of his Annus Mirabilis papers, introducing the special theory of relativity.
September 26, 1907: Four months after the 1907 Imperial Conference, New Zealand and Newfoundland are promoted from colonies to dominions within the British Empire.
September 26, 1910: Indian journalist Swadeshabhimani Ramakrishna Pillai is arrested after publishing criticism of the government of Travancore and is exiled.
September 26, 1914: The United States Federal Trade Commission is established by the Federal Trade Commission Act.
September 26, 1923: The German government accepts the occupation of the Ruhr.
September 26, 1933: As gangster Machine Gun Kelly surrenders to the FBI, he shouts out, "Don't shoot, G-Men!", which becomes a nickname for FBI agents.
September 26, 1934: The ocean liner RMS Queen Mary is launched.
September 26, 1941: The Military Police Corps is created as a permanent branch of the United States Army.
September 26, 1953: Rationing of sugar in the United Kingdom ends
September 26, 1954: The Japanese rail ferry Tōya Maru sinks during a typhoon in the Tsugaru Strait, Japan, killing 1,172.
September 26, 1959: Typhoon Vera, the strongest typhoon to hit Japan in recorded history, makes landfall, killing 4,580 people and leaving nearly 1.6 million others homeless.
September 26, 1960: In Chicago, the first televised debate takes place between presidential candidates Richard M. Nixon and John F. Kennedy.
September 26, 1969: Abbey Road, the last recorded album by The Beatles, is released.
September 26, 1973: Concorde makes its first non-stop crossing of the Atlantic in record-breaking time.
September 26, 1977: The Chernobyl Nuclear Power Plant opens for official usage, the first nuclear power plant in the (then) Ukrainian SSR.
September 26, 1980: At the Oktoberfest terror attack in Munich 13 people die and 211 are injured.
September 26, 1981: Nolan Ryan sets a Major League record by throwing his fifth no-hitter.
September 26, 1983: Australia II wins the America's Cup, ending the New York Yacht Club's 132-year domination of the race.
September 26, 1984: The United Kingdom and China agree to a transfer of sovereignty over Hong Kong, to take place in 1997.
September 26, 1997: An earthquake strikes the Italian regions of Umbria and the Marche, causing part of the Basilica of St. Francis at Assisi to collapse.
September 26, 2000: The MS Express Samina sinks off Paros in the Aegean Sea killing 80 passengers.
September 26, 2002: The overcrowded Senegalese ferry, MV Le Joola, capsizes off the coast of the Gambia killing more than 1,000.
September 26, 2005: The PBS Kids Channel is shut down and replaced by a joint network with Comcast called Sprout.
September 26, 2008: Swiss pilot and inventor Yves Rossy becomes first person to fly a jet engine-powered wing across the English Channel.
September 26, 2009: Typhoon Ketsana hits the Philippines, China, Vietnam, Cambodia, Laos and Thailand, causing 700 fatalities.
September 26, 2014: A mass kidnapping occurs in Iguala, Mexico.
September 27, 1066: William the Conqueror and his army set sail from the mouth of the Somme river, beginning the Norman conquest of England.
September 27, 1331: The Battle of Płowce between the Poland and the Teutonic Order is fought.
September 27, 1422: After the brief Gollub War, the Teutonic Knights sign the Treaty of Melno with Poland and Lithuania
September 27, 1529: The Siege of Vienna begins when Suleiman I attacks the city.
September 27, 1540: The Society of Jesus (Jesuits) receives its charter from Pope Paul III.
September 27, 1590: Pope Urban VII dies 13 days after being chosen as the Pope, making his reign the shortest papacy in history.
September 27, 1605: The armies of Sweden are defeated by the Polish–Lithuanian Commonwealth in the Battle of Kircholm.
September 27, 1669: The Venetians surrender the fortress of Candia to the Ottomans, thus ending the 21-year-long Siege of Candia.
September 27, 1791: The National Assembly votes to award full citizenship to Jews in France.
September 27, 1822: Jean-François Champollion announces that he has deciphered the Rosetta Stone.
September 27, 1825: The world's first public railway to use steam locomotives, the Stockton and Darlington Railway, is ceremonially opened.
September 27, 1854: The steamship SS Arctic sinks with 300 people on board.
September 27, 1875: The merchant sailing ship Ellen Southard is wrecked in a storm at Liverpool.
September 27, 1903: The Wreck of the Old 97, an American rail disaster that became the subject of a popular ballad.
September 27, 1908: Production of the Model T automobile begins at the Ford Piquette Avenue Plant in Detroit.
September 27, 1916: Iyasu V is proclaimed deposed as ruler of Ethiopia in a palace coup in favor of his aunt Zewditu.
September 27, 1922: King Constantine I of Greece abdicates his throne in favor of his eldest son, George II.
September 27, 1928: The Republic of China is recognized by the United States.
September 27, 1930: Bobby Jones wins the (pre-Masters) Grand Slam of golf.
September 27, 1938: The ocean liner Queen Elizabeth is launched in Glasgow.
September 27, 1941: The SS Patrick Henry is launched, becoming the first of more than 2,700 Liberty ships.
September 27, 1942: Last day of the Matanikau action on Guadalcanal as United States Marines barely escape after being surrounded by Japanese forces.
September 27, 1944: The Kassel Mission results in the largest loss by a USAAF group on any mission in World War II.
September 27, 1949: Zeng Liansong's design is chosen as the flag of the People's Republic of China.
September 27, 1956: USAF Captain Milburn G. Apt becomes the first person to exceed Mach 3. Shortly thereafter, the Bell X-2 goes out of control and Captain Apt is killed.
September 27, 1959: Typhoon Vera kills nearly 5,000 people in Japan.
September 27, 1962: Rachel Carson's book Silent Spring is published, inspiring an environmental movement and the creation of the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency.
September 27, 1964: The British TSR-2 aircraft XR219 makes its maiden flight.
September 27, 1975: The last use of capital punishment in Spain sparks worldwide protests.
September 27, 1983: Richard Stallman announces the GNU Project to develop a free Unix-like operating system.
September 27, 1988: The National League for Democracy is formed by Aung San Suu Kyi and others to fight dictatorship in Myanmar.
September 27, 1993: The Sukhumi massacre takes place in Abkhazia.
September 27, 1996: Confusion on a tanker ship results in the Julie N. oil spill in Portland, Maine.
September 27, 1998: The Google internet search engine retroactively claims this date as its birthday.
September 27, 2001: In Switzerland, a gunman shoots 18 citizens, killing 14 and then himself.
September 27, 2007: NASA launches the Dawn probe to the asteroid belt.
September 27, 2008: CNSA astronaut Zhai Zhigang becomes the first Chinese person to perform a spacewalk.
September 27, 2012: In Minneapolis, a gunman shoots seven citizens, killing 5 and then himself.
September 27, 2014: The eruption of Mount Ontake in Japan occurs.
September 28, 48 BC: Pompey is assassinated by order of King Ptolemy upon arriving in Egypt.
September 28, 235: Pope Pontian resigns. He is exiled to the mines of Sardinia, along with Hippolytus of Rome.
September 28, 351: Constantius II defeats the usurper Magnentius.
September 28, 365: Roman usurper Procopius bribes two legions passing by Constantinople, and proclaims himself emperor.
September 28, 935: Duke Wenceslaus I of Bohemia is murdered by a group of nobles led by his brother Boleslaus I, who succeeds him.
September 28, 995: Boleslaus II, Duke of Bohemia, kills most members of the rival Slavník dynasty.
September 28, 1066: William the Conqueror lands in England, beginning the Norman conquest.
September 28, 1106: King Henry I of England defeats his brother, Robert Curthose.
September 28, 1238: King James I of Aragon conquers Valencia from the Moors. Shortly thereafter, he proclaims himself king of Valencia.
September 28, 1322: Louis IV, Holy Roman Emperor, defeats Frederick I of Austria in the Battle of Mühldorf.
September 28, 1542: Juan Rodríguez Cabrillo of Portugal arrives at what is now San Diego, California.
September 28, 1787: The Congress of the Confederation votes to send the newly-written United States Constitution to the state legislatures for approval.
September 28, 1821: The Declaration of Independence of the Mexican Empire is drafted. It will be made public on 13 October.
September 28, 1844: Oscar I of Sweden–Norway is crowned king of Sweden.
September 28, 1867: Toronto becomes the capital of Ontario, having also been the capital of Ontario's predecessors since 1796.
September 28, 1868: The Battle of Alcolea causes Queen Isabella II of Spain to flee to France.
September 28, 1871: The Brazilian Parliament passes a law that frees all children thereafter born to slaves, and all government-owned slaves.
September 28, 1889: The General Conference on Weights and Measures (CGPM) defines the length of a meter.
September 28, 1892: The first night game for American football takes place in a contest between Wyoming Seminary and Mansfield State Normal.
September 28, 1893: Foundation of the Portuguese football club FC Porto.
September 28, 1912: Corporal Frank S. Scott of the United States Army becomes the first enlisted man to die in an airplane crash.
September 28, 1919: Race riots begin in Omaha, Nebraska.
September 28, 1924: The first aerial circumnavigation is completed by a team from the US Army.
September 28, 1928: Alexander Fleming notices a bacteria-killing mold growing in his laboratory, discovering what later became known as penicillin.
September 28, 1941: Ted Williams achieves a .406 batting average for the season, and becomes the last major league baseball player to bat .400 or better.
September 28, 1951: CBS makes the first color televisions available for sale to the general public, but the product is discontinued less than a month later.
September 28, 1961: A military coup in Damascus effectively ends the United Arab Republic, the union between Egypt and Syria.
September 28, 1970: Egyptian President Gamal Abdel Nasser dies of a heart attack in Cairo.
September 28, 1971: The British Parliament passes the Misuse of Drugs Act 1971, banning the medicinal use of cannabis.
September 28, 1973: The ITT Building in New York City is bombed in protest at ITT's alleged involvement in the coup d'état in Chile.
September 28, 1975: The Spaghetti House siege, in which nine people are taken hostage, takes place in London.
September 28, 1986: The Democratic Progressive Party becomes the first opposition party in Taiwan.
September 28, 1991: The Strategic Air Command stands down from alert all ICBMs scheduled for deactivation under START I, as well as its strategic bomber force.
September 28, 1992: A Pakistan International Airlines flight crashes into a hill in Nepal, killing all 167 passengers and crew.
September 28, 1994: The cruise ferry MS Estonia sinks in the Baltic Sea, killing 852 people.
September 28, 1995: Israeli Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin and PLO Chairman Yasser Arafat sign the Interim Agreement on the West Bank and the Gaza Strip.
September 28, 2008: Falcon 1 becomes the first privately developed liquid-fuel ground-launched vehicle to put a payload into orbit.
September 28, 2009: The military junta leading Guinea attacks a protest rally, killing or wounding 1400 people.
September 28, 2012: Somali and African Union forces launch a coordinated assault on the Somali port of Kismayo to take back the city from al-Shabaab militants.
September 28, 2014: The 2014 Hong Kong protests begin in response to restrictive political reforms imposed by the NPC in Beijing.
September 28, 2016: The 2016 South Australian blackout occurs, lasting up to three days in some areas.
September 28, 2018: The 7.5 Mw 2018 Sulawesi earthquake, which triggered a large tsunami, leaves 4,340 dead and 10,679 injured.
September 29, 522 BC: Darius I of Persia kills the Magian usurper Bardiya, securing his hold as Persian emperor.
September 29, 61 BC: Pompey the Great celebrates his third triumph for victories over the pirates and the end of the Mithridatic Wars on his 45th birthday.
September 29, 1011: Danes capture Canterbury after a siege, taking Ælfheah, archbishop of Canterbury, as a prisoner.
September 29, 1227: Frederick II, Holy Roman Emperor, is excommunicated by Pope Gregory IX for his failure to participate in the Crusades.
September 29, 1267: The Treaty of Montgomery recognises Llywelyn ap Gruffudd as Prince of Wales, but only as a vassal of King Henry III.
September 29, 1364: English forces defeat the French in Brittany, ending the War of the Breton Succession.
September 29, 1578: Tegucigalpa, capital city of Honduras, is claimed by the Spaniards.
September 29, 1717: An earthquake strikes Antigua Guatemala, destroying much of the city's architecture.
September 29, 1829: The Metropolitan Police of London, later also known as the Met, is founded.
September 29, 1848: The Battle of Pákozd is a stalemate between Hungarian and Croatian forces, and is the first battle of the Hungarian Revolution.
September 29, 1850: The papal bull Universalis Ecclesiae restores the Roman Catholic hierarchy in England and Wales.
September 29, 1855: The Philippine port of Iloilo is opened to world trade by the Spanish administration.[1][2]
September 29, 1864: The Treaty of Lisbon defines the boundaries between Spain and Portugal and abolishes the Couto Misto microstate.
September 29, 1885: The first practical public electric tramway in the world is opened in Blackpool, England.
September 29, 1907: The cornerstone is laid at Washington National Cathedral in the U.S. capital.
September 29, 1911: Italy declares war on the Ottoman Empire.
September 29, 1918: Germany's Supreme Army Command tells the Kaiser and the Chancellor to open negotiations for an armistice.
September 29, 1923: The First American Track & Field championships for women are held.
September 29, 1940: Two Avro Ansons collide in mid-air over New South Wales, Australia, remain locked together, then land safely.
September 29, 1949: The Communist Party of China writes the Common Programme for the future People's Republic of China.
September 29, 1954: The convention establishing CERN (the European Organization for Nuclear Research) is signed.
September 29, 1957: The Kyshtym disaster is the third-worst nuclear accident ever recorded.
September 29, 1975: WGPR becomes the first black-owned-and-operated television station in the US.
September 29, 1979: The dictator Francisco Macias of Equatorial Guinea is shot by soldiers from Western Sahara.
September 29, 1988: NASA launches STS-26, the first mission since the Challenger disaster.
September 29, 1990: The YF-22, which would later become the F-22 Raptor, flies for the first time.
September 29, 1992: Brazilian President Fernando Collor de Mello is impeached.
September 29, 2004: Burt Rutan's Ansari SpaceShipOne performs a successful spaceflight, the first of two required to win the Ansari X Prize.
September 29, 2006: A Boeing 737 and an Embraer 600 collide in mid-air, killing 154 people and triggering a Brazilian aviation crisis.
September 29, 2007: Calder Hall, the world's first commercial nuclear power station, is demolished in a controlled explosion.
September 29, 2009: The 8.1 Mw  Samoa earthquake results in a tsunami that kills 189 and injures hundreds.
September 29, 2011: The special court in India convicted all 269 accused officials for atrocity on Dalits and 17 for rape in the Vachathi case.
September 29, 2013: Over 42 people are killed by members of Boko Haram at the College of Agriculture in Nigeria.
September 29, 2016: Eleven days after the Uri attack, the Indian Army conducted "surgical strikes" against suspected militants in Pakistani-administered Kashmir.[3]
September 30, 489: The Ostrogoths under Theoderic the Great defeat the forces of Odoacer for the second time.
September 30, 737: The Turgesh drive back an Umayyad invasion of Khuttal, follow them south of the Oxus, and capture their baggage train.
September 30, 1399: Henry IV is proclaimed king of England.
September 30, 1520: Suleiman the Magnificent is proclaimed sultan of the Ottoman Empire.
September 30, 1541: Spanish conquistador Hernando de Soto and his forces enter Tula territory in present-day western Arkansas, encountering fierce resistance.
September 30, 1551: A coup by the military establishment of Japan's Ōuchi clan forces their lord to commit suicide, and their city is burned.
September 30, 1791: France's National Constituent Assembly is dissolved, to be replaced the next day by the National Legislative Assembly
September 30, 1882: Thomas Edison's first commercial hydroelectric power plant (later known as Appleton Edison Light Company) begins operation.
September 30, 1888: Jack the Ripper kills his third and fourth victims, Elizabeth Stride and Catherine Eddowes.
September 30, 1906: The Royal Galician Academy, the Galician language's biggest linguistic authority, starts working in Havana.
September 30, 1907: The McKinley National Memorial, the final resting place of assassinated U.S. President William McKinley and his family, is dedicated in Canton, Ohio.
September 30, 1909: The Cunard Line's RMS Mauretania makes a record-breaking westbound crossing of the Atlantic, that will not be bettered for 20 years.
September 30, 1922: The University of Alabama opens the American football season with a 110–0 victory over the Marion Military Institute, which still stands as Alabama's record for largest margin of victory and as their only 100 point game.
September 30, 1927: Babe Ruth becomes the first baseball player to hit 60 home runs in a season.
September 30, 1931: Start of "Die Voortrekkers" youth movement for Afrikaners in Bloemfontein, South Africa.
September 30, 1935: The Hoover Dam, astride the border between the U.S. states of Arizona and Nevada, is dedicated.
September 30, 1938: The League of Nations unanimously outlaws "intentional bombings of civilian populations".
September 30, 1939: NBC broadcasts the first televised American football game.
September 30, 1943: The United States Merchant Marine Academy is dedicated by President Roosevelt.
September 30, 1945: The Bourne End rail crash, in Hertfordshire, England, kills 43
September 30, 1954: The U.S. Navy submarine USS Nautilus is commissioned as the world's first nuclear-powered vessel.
September 30, 1962: James Meredith enters the University of Mississippi, defying racial segregation rules.
September 30, 1965: In Indonesia, a coup by the 30 September Movement is crushed, leading to a mass anti-communist purge, with over 500,000 people killed.
September 30, 1966: Bechuanaland declares its independence, and becomes the Republic of Botswana.
September 30, 1967: The BBC Light Programme, Third Programme and Home Service are replaced with BBC Radio 2, 3 and 4 Respectively, BBC Radio 1 is also launched.
September 30, 1968: The Boeing 747 is rolled out and shown to the public for the first time.
September 30, 1970: Jordan makes a deal with the PFLP for the release of the remaining hostages from the Dawson's Field hijackings.
September 30, 1972: Roberto Clemente records the 3,000th and final hit of his career.
September 30, 1975: The AH-64 Apache makes its first flight. Eight years later, the first production model rolled out of the assembly line.
September 30, 1977: Because of NASA budget cuts and dwindling power reserves, the Apollo program's ALSEP experiment packages left on the Moon are shut down.
September 30, 1980: Ethernet specifications are published by Xerox working with Intel and Digital Equipment Corporation.
September 30, 1990: The Dalai Lama unveils the Canadian Tribute to Human Rights in Canada's capital city of Ottawa.
September 30, 1993: The 6.2 Mw  Latur earthquake shakes Maharashtra, India with a maximum Mercalli intensity of VIII (Severe) killing 9,748 and injuring 30,000.
September 30, 1994: Ongar railway station, the furthest London Underground from central London, closes.
September 30, 1999: The Tokaimura nuclear accident causes the deaths of two technicians in Japan's second-worst nuclear accident.
September 30, 2004: The AIM-54 Phoenix, the primary missile for the F-14 Tomcat, is retired from service. Almost two years later, the Tomcat itself is retired.
September 30, 2005: Controversial drawings of Muhammad are printed in a Danish newspaper.
September 30, 2009: The 7.6 Mw  Sumatra earthquake leaves 1,115 people dead.
September 30, 2016: Two paintings with a combined value of $100 million are recovered after having been stolen from the Van Gogh Museum in 2002.
October 1, 331 BC: Alexander the Great defeats Darius III of Persia in the Battle of Gaugamela.
October 1, 959: Edgar the Peaceful becomes king of all England.
October 1, 1553: Coronation of Queen Mary I of England.
October 1, 1588: Coronation of Shah Abbas I of Persia.
October 1, 1730: Ahmed III is forced to abdicate as the Ottoman sultan.
October 1, 1787: Russians under Alexander Suvorov defeat the Turks at Kinburn.
October 1, 1791: First session of the French Legislative Assembly.
October 1, 1795: More than a year after the Battle of Sprimont, France officially annexes the Southern Netherlands.
October 1, 1800: Via the Third Treaty of San Ildefonso, Spain cedes Louisiana to France, which would sell the land to the United States thirty months later.
October 1, 1814: Opening of the Congress of Vienna, intended to redraw Europe's political map after the defeat of Napoleon the previous spring.
October 1, 1829: South African College is founded in Cape Town, South Africa. It will later separate into the University of Cape Town and the South African College Schools.
October 1, 1832: Texian political delegates convene to petition for changes in the governance of Mexican Texas.
October 1, 1843: The News of the World tabloid begins publication in London.
October 1, 1861: Mrs Beeton's Book of Household Management is published, going on to sell 60,000 copies in its first year and remaining in print until the present day
October 1, 1887: Balochistan is conquered by the British Empire.
October 1, 1890: Yosemite National Park is established by the U.S. Congress.
October 1, 1891: Stanford University opens its doors in California.
October 1, 1898: The Vienna University of Economics and Business Administration is founded under the name k.u.k. Exportakademie.
October 1, 1903: The Boston Americans play the Pittsburgh Pirates in the first game of the modern World Series.
October 1, 1908: Ford Model T automobiles are offered for sale at a price of US$825.
October 1, 1910: A large bomb destroys the Los Angeles Times building, killing 21.
October 1, 1918: Sayid Abdullah becomes the last Khan of Khiva.
October 1, 1928: The Soviet Union introduces its first five-year plan.
October 1, 1931: Clara Campoamor persuades the Constituent Cortes to enfranchise women in Spain's new constitution.
October 1, 1936: Francisco Franco is named head of the Nationalist government of Spain.
October 1, 1940: The Pennsylvania Turnpike, often considered the first superhighway in the United States, opens to traffic.
October 1, 1947: The North American F-86 Sabre flies for the first time.
October 1, 1949: The first National Day of the People's Republic of China is held.
October 1, 1953: A Mutual Defense Treaty Between the United States and the Republic of Korea is concluded in Washington, D.C.[1]
October 1, 1955: The Xinjiang Uyghur Autonomous Region is established.
October 1, 1957: First appearance of In God we trust on U.S. paper currency.
October 1, 1958: The National Advisory Committee for Aeronautics is replaced by NASA.
October 1, 1960: Nigeria gains independence from the United Kingdom.
October 1, 1961: East and West Cameroon merge to form the Federal Republic of Cameroon.
October 1, 1964: Japanese Shinkansen ("bullet trains") begin high-speed rail service from Tokyo to Osaka.
October 1, 1966: West Coast Airlines Flight 956 crashes with no survivors in Oregon.  This accident marks the first loss of a DC-9.
October 1, 1968: Guyana nationalizes the British Guiana Broadcasting Service, which would eventually become part of the National Communications Network, Guyana.
October 1, 1969: Concorde breaks the sound barrier for the first time.
October 1, 1971: The first practical CT scanner is used to diagnose a patient.
October 1, 1975: Muhammad Ali defeats Joe Frazier in a boxing match in Manila, Philippines.
October 1, 1978: Tuvalu gains independence from the United Kingdom.
October 1, 1979: The MTR, the rapid transit railway system in Hong Kong, opens.
October 1, 1982: Sony launches the model CDP-101 compact disk player.
October 1, 1987: The 5.9 Mw  Whittier Narrows earthquake shakes the San Gabriel Valley with a Mercalli intensity of VIII (Severe), killing eight and injuring 200.
October 1, 1989: Denmark introduces the world's first legal same-sex registered partnerships.
October 1, 1994: Palau enters a Compact of Free Association with the United States.
October 1, 2001: Militants attack the state legislature building in Kashmir, killing 38.
October 1, 2009: The Supreme Court of the United Kingdom takes over the judicial functions of the House of Lords.
October 1, 2012: A ferry collision off the coast of Hong Kong kills 38 people and injures 102 others.
October 1, 2014: A series of explosions at a gunpowder plant in Bulgaria completely destroys the factory, killing 15 people.
October 1, 2015: Heavy rains trigger a major landslide in Guatemala, killing 280 people.
October 1, 2017: Fifty-eight people are killed and 851 others injured in a mass shooting on a music festival in Las Vegas.
October 1, 2018: Obligation to Negotiate Access to the Pacific Ocean is decided by the International Court of Justice.[3]
October 2, 939: King Otto I crushes a rebellion against his rule by a coalition of Frankish dukes.
October 2, 1187: Saladin captures Jerusalem after 88 years of Crusader rule.
October 2, 1263: The Battle of Largs is fought between Norwegians and Scots.
October 2, 1528: William Tyndale publishes The Obedience of a Christian Man, which advocates the divine right of kings.
October 2, 1535: Jacques Cartier discovers the present site of Montreal.
October 2, 1789: The United States Bill of Rights is sent to the various States for ratification.
October 2, 1870: A plebiscite held in Rome, supports annexation of city of Rome by the Kingdom of Italy.
October 2, 1919: U.S. President Woodrow Wilson suffers a massive stroke, leaving him incapacitated for several weeks.
October 2, 1925: John Logie Baird performs the first test of a working television system.
October 2, 1928: The "Prelature of the Holy Cross and the Work of God", commonly known as Opus Dei, is founded.
October 2, 1937: Rafael Trujillo orders the execution of Haitians living in the northwestern region of the Dominican Republic.
October 2, 1955: ENIAC, one of the earliest electronic general-purpose computers, is shut down.
October 2, 1958: Guinea declares its independence from France.
October 2, 1959: Rod Serling's anthology series The Twilight Zone premieres on CBS.  The first episode is “Where Is Everybody?”
October 2, 1967: Thurgood Marshall is sworn in as the first African-American justice of the United States Supreme Court.
October 2, 1968: Mexican President Ordaz orders soldiers to suppress a demonstration of students, ten days before the Olympic games will start.
October 2, 1970: An aircraft carrying the Wichita State University football team, administrators, and supporters crashes in Colorado, killing 31 people.
October 2, 1980: Michael Myers becomes the first member of either chamber of Congress to be expelled since the Civil War.
October 2, 1990: Xiamen Airlines Flight 8301 is hijacked and lands at Guangzhou, where it crashes into two other airliners on the ground, killing 128.
October 2, 1992: Military police storm the Carandiru Penitentiary in São Paulo, Brazil during a prison riot. The resulting massacre leaves 111 prisoners dead.
October 2, 1996: The Electronic Freedom of Information Act Amendments are signed by U.S. President Bill Clinton.
October 2, 2000: The Rijndael algorithm is chosen by NIST as the AES standard.
October 2, 2002: The Beltway sniper attacks begin, extending over three weeks.
October 2, 2006: Five Amish girls are murdered in a shooting at a school in Pennsylvania.
October 2, 2007: President Roh Moo-hyun of South Korea goes to North Korea for an Inter-Korean summit with North Korean leader Kim Jong-il.
October 2, 2016: Ethiopian protests break out during a festival in the Oromia region, killing dozens of people.
October 2, 2018: Saudi journalist Jamal Khashoggi is last seen entering the Saudi consulate in Istanbul.
October 3, 2457 BC: Gaecheonjeol, Hwanung (환웅) purportedly descended from heaven. South Korea's National Foundation Day.
October 3, 52 BC: Vercingetorix, leader of the Gauls, surrenders to the Romans under Julius Caesar, ending the siege and battle of Alesia.
October 3, 42 BC: Triumvirs Mark Antony and Octavian fight a decisive battle with Caesar's assassins Brutus and Cassius.
October 3, 382: Roman Emperor Theodosius I concludes a peace treaty with the Goths and settles them in the Balkans.
October 3, 1283: Dafydd ap Gruffydd, prince of Gwynedd in Wales, is the first nobleman to be executed by hanging, drawing and quartering.
October 3, 1392: Muhammed VII becomes the twelfth sultan of the Emirate of Granada.
October 3, 1574: The Siege of Leiden is lifted by the Watergeuzen.
October 3, 1683: Qing dynasty naval commander Shi Lang receives the surrender of the Tungning kingdom on Taiwan after the Battle of Penghu.
October 3, 1712: The Duke of Montrose issues a warrant for the arrest of Rob Roy MacGregor.
October 3, 1739: The Treaty of Niš is signed by the Ottoman Empire and Russia at the end of the Russian–Turkish War.
October 3, 1789: George Washington proclaims a Thanksgiving Day for that year.
October 3, 1795: Slave rebel leader Tula is executed in Curaçao.
October 3, 1863: The last Thursday in November is declared as Thanksgiving Day by U.S. President Abraham Lincoln.
October 3, 1873: Chief Kintpuash and companions are hanged for their part in the Modoc War of northern California.
October 3, 1912: U.S. forces defeat Nicaraguan rebels at the Battle of Coyotepe Hill.
October 3, 1918: King Boris III of Bulgaria accedes to the throne.
October 3, 1919: Cincinnati Reds pitcher Adolfo Luque becomes the first Latin player to appear in a World Series.
October 3, 1929: The Kingdom of Serbs, Croats and Slovenes is renamed to Yugoslavia.
October 3, 1930: The German Socialist Labour Party in Poland – Left is founded.
October 3, 1932: Iraq gains independence from the United Kingdom.
October 3, 1942: A German V-2 rocket reaches a record 85 km (46 nm) in altitude.
October 3, 1949: WERD, the first black-owned radio station in the United States, opens in Atlanta.
October 3, 1952: The United Kingdom successfully tests a nuclear weapon to become the world's third nuclear power.
October 3, 1957: The California State Superior Court rules that the book Howl and Other Poems is not obscene.
October 3, 1963: A violent coup in Honduras begins two decades of military rule.
October 3, 1978: All aboard (12 VIP passengers and 3 crew) die when a Finnish Air Force DC-3 crashes.
October 3, 1981: The hunger strike at the Maze Prison in Northern Ireland ends after seven months and ten deaths.
October 3, 1985: The Space Shuttle Atlantis makes its maiden flight.
October 3, 1986: TASCC, a superconducting cyclotron at the Chalk River Laboratories in Canada, is officially opened.
October 3, 1989: A coup in Panama City is suppressed and 11 participants are executed.
October 3, 1990: The German Democratic Republic is abolished and becomes part of the Federal Republic of Germany.
October 3, 1991: Nadine Gordimer is announced as the winner of the Nobel Prize in Literature.[1]
October 3, 1993: An American attack against a warlord in Mogadishu fails. 18 attackers and over 350 Somalis die.
October 3, 2008: The Emergency Economic Stabilization Act of 2008 for the U.S. financial system is signed by President George W. Bush.
October 3, 2009: Azerbaijan, Kazakhstan, Kyrgyzstan, and Turkey join together in the Turkic Council.
October 3, 2010: The 19th Commonwealth Games commence in Delhi.
October 3, 2013: At least 134 migrants are killed when their boat sinks near the Italian island of Lampedusa.
October 3, 2015: Forty-two are killed and 33 go missing in the Kunduz hospital airstrike.
October 4, AD 23: Rebels sack the Chinese capital Chang'an during a peasant rebellion. They later decapitate emperor Wang Mang.
October 4, 1227: Assassination of Caliph al-Adil of Morocco.
October 4, 1302: The Byzantine–Venetian War comes to an end.
October 4, 1511: Formation of the Holy League of Aragon, the Papal States and Venice against France.
October 4, 1535: The Coverdale Bible is printed, with translations into English by William Tyndale and Myles Coverdale.
October 4, 1582: The Gregorian Calendar is introduced by Pope Gregory XIII.
October 4, 1597: Governor Gonzalo Méndez de Canço begins to suppress a native uprising against his rule in what is now Georgia.
October 4, 1795: Napoleon first rises to prominence by suppressing counter-revolutionary rioters threatening the National Convention.
October 4, 1824: Mexico adopts a new constitution and becomes a federal republic.
October 4, 1830: The Belgian Revolution takes legal form when the provisional government secedes from the Netherlands.
October 4, 1853: The Crimean War begins when the Ottoman Empire declares war on the Russian Empire.
October 4, 1876: The Agricultural and Mechanical College of Texas opens as the first public college in Texas.
October 4, 1883: First meeting of the Boys' Brigade in Glasgow, Scotland.
October 4, 1895: Horace Rawlins wins the first U.S. Open Men's Golf Championship.
October 4, 1904: The IFK Göteborg football club is founded in Sweden.
October 4, 1927: Gutzon Borglum begins sculpting Mount Rushmore.
October 4, 1936: The British Union of Fascists and various anti-fascist organizations violently clash in the Battle of Cable Street.
October 4, 1941: Norman Rockwell's Willie Gillis character debuts on the cover of The Saturday Evening Post.
October 4, 1957: Sputnik 1 becomes the first artificial satellite to orbit the Earth.
October 4, 1958: The current constitution of France is adopted.
October 4, 1960: An airliner crashes on takeoff from Boston's Logan International Airport, killing 62 people.
October 4, 1963: Hurricane Flora kills 6,000 in Cuba and Haiti.
October 4, 1965: Pope Paul VI begins the first papal visit to the Americas.
October 4, 1966: Basutoland becomes independent from the United Kingdom and is renamed Lesotho.
October 4, 1967: Omar Ali Saifuddien III of Brunei abdicates in favour of his son.
October 4, 1983: Richard Noble sets a new land speed record of 633.468 miles per hour (1,019.468 km/h) at the Black Rock Desert in Nevada.
October 4, 1985: The Free Software Foundation is founded.
October 4, 1991: The Protocol on Environmental Protection to the Antarctic Treaty is opened for signature.
October 4, 1992: El Al Flight 1862 crashes into two apartment buildings in Amsterdam, killing 43 including 39 on the ground.
October 4, 1993: Tanks bombard the Russian parliament, while demonstrators against President Yeltsin rally outside.
October 4, 1997: The second largest cash robbery in U.S. history occurs in North Carolina
October 4, 2001: Siberia Airlines Flight 1812 crashes after being struck by an errant Ukrainian missile. Seventy-eight people are killed.
October 4, 2003: The Maxim restaurant suicide bombing Israel kills twenty-one Israelis, both Jews and Arabs.
October 4, 2004: SpaceShipOne wins the Ansari X Prize for private spaceflight.
October 4, 2010: The Ajka plant accident Hungary releases a million cubic metres of liquid alumina sludge, killing nine, injuring 122, and severely contaminating two major rivers.
October 4, 2017: Nigerien and US Special Forces ambushed by Islamic State militants outside the village of Tongo Tongo.
October 5, 610: Heraclius arrives at Constantinople, kills Byzantine Emperor Phocas, and becomes emperor.[1]
October 5, 816: King Louis the Pious is crowned emperor of the Holy Roman Empire by the Pope.
October 5, 869: The Fourth Council of Constantinople is convened to depose patriarch Photios I.
October 5, 1143: King Alfonso VII of León and Castile recognises Portugal as a Kingdom.
October 5, 1450: Louis IX, Duke of Bavaria expels Jews from his jurisdiction.
October 5, 1607: Assassins sent by the Pope attempt to kill Venetian statesman and scientist Paolo Sarpi.
October 5, 1665: The University of Kiel is founded.
October 5, 1838: The Killough massacre in east Texas sees eighteen Texian settlers either killed or kidnapped.
October 5, 1857: The city of Anaheim, California is founded.
October 5, 1869: The Hennepin Island tunnel collapses during construction, nearly destroying St. Anthony Falls.
October 5, 1877: The Nez Perce War in the northwestern United States comes to an end.
October 5, 1905: The Wright Brothers pilot the Wright Flyer III in a new world record flight of 24 miles in 39 minutes.
October 5, 1910: In a revolution in Portugal the monarchy is overthrown and a republic is declared.
October 5, 1921: The World Series is the first to be broadcast on radio.
October 5, 1930: British airship R101 crashes in France en route to India on its maiden voyage.
October 5, 1936: The Jarrow March sets off for London.
October 5, 1938: In Nazi Germany, Jews' passports are invalidated.
October 5, 1943: Ninety-eight American POWs are executed by Japanese forces on Wake Island.
October 5, 1944: The Provisional Government of the French Republic enfranchises women.
October 5, 1945: A six-month strike by Hollywood set decorators turns into a bloody riot at the gates of the Warner Brothers studio.
October 5, 1947: President Truman makes the first televised Oval Office address.[3]
October 5, 1948: The Ashgabat earthquake kills between 10,000 and 110,000 people.
October 5, 1966: A reactor at the Enrico Fermi Nuclear Generating Station near Detroit suffers a partial meltdown.
October 5, 1968: A Northern Ireland Civil Rights Association march in Derry is violently suppressed by police.
October 5, 1970: The British Trade Commissioner is kidnapped by members of the FLQ, triggering the October Crisis in Canada.
October 5, 1974: Bombs planted by the PIRA kill four British soldiers and one civilian.
October 5, 1982: Tylenol products are recalled after bottles in Chicago laced with cyanide cause seven deaths.
October 5, 1984: Marc Garneau becomes the first Canadian in space.
October 5, 1986: Mordechai Vanunu's story in The Sunday Times reveals Israel's secret nuclear weapons.
October 5, 1988: A Chilean opposition coalition defeats Augusto Pinochet in his re-election attempt.
October 5, 1990: After 150 years The Herald newspaper in Melbourne, Australia, is published for the last time as a separate newspaper.
October 5, 1991: An Indonesian Air Force C-130 crash kills 135 people.
October 5, 1999: The Ladbroke Grove rail crash in west London kills 31 people.
October 5, 2000: Mass demonstrations in Serbia force the resignation of Slobodan Milošević.
October 5, 2011: In the Mekong River massacre, two Chinese cargo boats are hijacked and 13 crew members murdered.
October 6, AD 23: Rebels decapitate Wang Mang two days after his capital was sacked during a peasant rebellion.
October 6, 404: Byzantine Empress Eudoxia dies from the miscarriage of her seventh and last pregnancy.
October 6, 1539: Spain's DeSoto expedition takes over the Apalachee capital of Anhaica for their winter quarters.
October 6, 1600: Euridice, the earliest surviving opera, receives its première performance, beginning the Baroque period.
October 6, 1683: Immigrant families found Germantown, Pennsylvania in the first major immigration of German people to America.
October 6, 1849: The execution of the 13 Martyrs of Arad after the Hungarian war of independence.
October 6, 1854: In England the Great fire of Newcastle and Gateshead leads to 53 deaths and hundreds injured.
October 6, 1884: The Naval War College of the United States is founded in Rhode Island.
October 6, 1898: Phi Mu Alpha Sinfonia, the largest American music fraternity, is founded at the New England Conservatory of Music.
October 6, 1903: The High Court of Australia sits for the first time.
October 6, 1908: The Bosnian crisis erupts when Austria-Hungary formally annexes Bosnia and Herzegovina.
October 6, 1910: Eleftherios Venizelos is elected prime minister of Greece for the first of seven times.
October 6, 1923: The Turkish National Movement enters Constantinople.
October 6, 1927: Opening of The Jazz Singer, the first prominent "talkie" movie.
October 6, 1973: Egypt and Syria launch coordinated attacks against Israel, beginning the Yom Kippur War.
October 6, 1976: Dozens are killed by the Thai army in the Thammasat University massacre.
October 6, 1977: The first prototype of the Mikoyan MiG-29, designated 9-01, makes its maiden flight.
October 6, 1979: Pope John Paul II becomes the first pontiff to visit the White House.
October 6, 1981: Egyptian President Anwar Sadat is murdered by Islamic extremists.
October 6, 1985: Police constable Keith Blakelock is murdered as riots erupt in the Broadwater Farm suburb of London.
October 6, 1995: The first planet orbiting another sun, 51 Pegasi b, is discovered.
October 6, 2007: Jason Lewis completes the first human-powered circumnavigation of the Earth.
October 6, 2010: Instagram, a mainstream photo-sharing application, is founded.
October 7, 3761 BC: The epoch reference date epoch (origin) of the modern Hebrew calendar.
October 7, 1477: Uppsala University is inaugurated after receiving its corporate rights from Pope Sixtus IV in February the same year.
October 7, 1571: The Battle of Lepanto is fought, and the Ottoman Navy suffers its first defeat.
October 7, 1691: The charter for the Province of Massachusetts Bay is issued.
October 7, 1763: King George III issues the Royal Proclamation of 1763, closing aboriginal lands in North America north and west of the Alleghenies to white settlements.
October 7, 1800: French corsair Robert Surcouf, commander of the 18-gun ship La Confiance, captures the British 38-gun Kent.
October 7, 1826: The Granite Railway begins operations as the first chartered railway in the U.S.
October 7, 1840: Willem II becomes King of the Netherlands.
October 7, 1868: Cornell University holds opening day ceremonies; initial student enrollment is 412, the highest at any American university to that date.
October 7, 1879: Germany and Austria-Hungary sign the "Twofold Covenant" and create the Dual Alliance.
October 7, 1912: The Helsinki Stock Exchange sees its first transaction.
October 7, 1916: Georgia Tech defeats Cumberland University 222–0 in the most lopsided college football game in American history.
October 7, 1919: KLM, the flag carrier of the Netherlands, is founded. It is the oldest airline still operating under its original name.
October 7, 1924: Andreas Michalakopoulos becomes prime minister of Greece for a short period of time.
October 7, 1929: Photius II becomes Ecumenical Patriarch of Constantinople.
October 7, 1933: Air France is inaugurated, after being formed by a merger of five French airlines.
October 7, 1949: The communist German Democratic Republic (East Germany) is formed.
October 7, 1950: Mother Teresa establishes the Missionaries of Charity.
October 7, 1958: The U.S. manned space-flight project is renamed Project Mercury.
October 7, 1959: The Soviet probe Luna 3 transmits the first-ever photographs of the far side of the Moon.
October 7, 1963: President Kennedy signs the ratification of the Partial Nuclear Test Ban Treaty.
October 7, 1977: The Fourth Soviet Constitution is adopted.
October 7, 1985: Four men from the Palestine Liberation Front hijack the MS Achille Lauro off the coast of Egypt.
October 7, 1987: Sikh nationalists declare the independence of Khalistan from India; it is not internationally recognized.
October 7, 1988: A hunter discovers three gray whales trapped under the ice near Alaska; the situation becomes a multinational effort to free the whales.
October 7, 1993: The flood of '93 ends at St. Louis, Missouri, 103 days after it began, as the Mississippi River falls below flood stage.
October 7, 1998: Matthew Shepard, a gay student at the University of Wyoming, is found tied to a fence after being savagely beaten by two young adults in Laramie, Wyoming.
October 7, 2001: The U.S. invasion of Afghanistan begins with an air assault and covert operations on the ground.
October 7, 2008: Asteroid 2008 TC3 impacts the Earth over Sudan, the first time an asteroid impact is detected prior to its entry into earth's atmosphere.
October 7, 2016: In the wake of Hurricane Matthew, the death toll rises to 800.
October 8, 314: Constantine I defeats Roman Emperor Licinius, who loses his European territories.
October 8, 451: The first session of the Council of Chalcedon begins.
October 8, 876: Frankish forces led by Louis the Younger prevent a West Frankish invasion and defeat emperor Charles II ("the Bald").
October 8, 1075: Dmitar Zvonimir is crowned King of Croatia.
October 8, 1200: Isabella of Angoulême is crowned Queen consort of England.
October 8, 1322: Mladen II Šubić of Bribir is deposed as the Croatian Ban after the Battle of Bliska.
October 8, 1480: The Great stand on the Ugra river puts an end to Tartar rule over Moscow
October 8, 1573: End of the Spanish siege of Alkmaar, the first Dutch victory in the Eighty Years' War.
October 8, 1645: Jeanne Mance open the first lay hospital in North America.
October 8, 1813: The Treaty of Ried is signed between Bavaria and Austria.
October 8, 1821: The Peruvian Navy is established during the War of Independence.
October 8, 1829: Stephenson's Rocket wins the Rainhill Trials.
October 8, 1856: The Second Opium War between several western powers and China begins with the Arrow Incident.
October 8, 1871: The Great Chicago Fire and the much deadlier Peshtigo Fire break out.
October 8, 1895: Korean Empress Myeongseong is assassinated by Japanese infiltrators.
October 8, 1912: The First Balkan War begins when Montenegro declares war against the Ottoman Empire.
October 8, 1921: KDKA in Pittsburgh's Forbes Field conducts the first live broadcast of a football game.
October 8, 1952: The Harrow and Wealdstone rail crash kills 112 people.
October 8, 1956: The New York Yankees's Don Larsen pitches the only perfect game in a World Series.
October 8, 1962: Der Spiegel publishes an article disclosing the sorry state of the Bundeswehr, and is soon accused of treason.
October 8, 1967: Guerrilla leader Che Guevara and his men are captured in Bolivia.
October 8, 1969: The opening rally of the Days of Rage occurs, organized by the Weather Underground in Chicago.
October 8, 1973: Spyros Markezinis begins his 48-day term as prime minister in an abortive attempt to lead Greece to parliamentary rule.
October 8, 1974: Franklin National Bank collapses due to fraud and mismanagement; at the time it is the largest bank failure in the history of the United States.
October 8, 1978: Australia's Ken Warby sets the current world water speed record of 317.60 mph at Blowering Dam, Australia.
October 8, 1982: Cats opens on Broadway and runs for nearly 18 years before closing on September 10, 2000.
October 8, 1991: Upon the expiration of the Brioni Agreement, Croatia and Slovenia sever all official relations with Yugoslavia.
October 8, 2001: U.S. President George W. Bush announces the establishment of the Office of Homeland Security.
October 8, 2005: The 7.6 Mw  Kashmir earthquake leaves 86,000–87,351 people dead, 69,000–75,266 injured, and 2.8 million homeless.
October 8, 2014: Thomas Eric Duncan, the first person in the United States to be diagnosed with Ebola, dies.
October 8, 2016: In the wake of Hurricane Matthew, the death toll rises to nearly 900.
October 9, 768: Carloman I and Charlemagne are crowned kings of the Franks.
October 9, 1238: James I of Aragon founds the Kingdom of Valencia.
October 9, 1410: The first known mention of the Prague astronomical clock.
October 9, 1446: The hangul alphabet is published in Korea.
October 9, 1594: Troops of the Portuguese Empire are defeated on Sri Lanka, bringing an end to the Campaign of Danture.
October 9, 1604: Supernova 1604 is sighted, the most recent supernova to be observed within the Milky Way.
October 9, 1635: Roger Williams is banished from the Massachusetts Bay Colony after religious and policy disagreements.
October 9, 1701: The Collegiate School of Connecticut (later renamed Yale University) is chartered in Old Saybrook.
October 9, 1708: Peter the Great defeats the Swedes at the Battle of Lesnaya.
October 9, 1740: Dutch colonists and Javanese natives begin massacring the ethnic Chinese population in Batavia, eventually killing 10,000.
October 9, 1790: A severe earthquake in northern Algeria causes severe damage and a tsunami in the Mediterranean Sea and kills three thousand.
October 9, 1799: HMS Lutine sinks with the loss of 240 men and a cargo worth £1,200,000.
October 9, 1804: Hobart, capital of Tasmania, is founded.
October 9, 1806: Prussia begins the War of the Fourth Coalition against France.
October 9, 1825: Restauration arrives in New York Harbor from Norway, the first organized immigration from Norway to the United States.
October 9, 1831: Ioannis Kapodistrias, the first head of state of independent Greece, is assassinated.
October 9, 1834: Opening of the Dublin and Kingstown Railway, the first public railway on the island of Ireland.
October 9, 1873: A meeting at the U.S. Naval Academy establishes the U.S. Naval Institute.
October 9, 1874: A international postal union is created by the Treaty of Bern.
October 9, 1900: The Cook Islands become a territory of the United Kingdom.
October 9, 1907: Las Cruces, New Mexico is incorporated.
October 9, 1911: An accidental bomb explosion triggers the Wuchang Uprising against the Chinese monarchy.
October 9, 1913: The steamship SS Volturno catches fire in the mid-Atlantic.
October 9, 1918: The Finnish Parliament offers to Prince Frederick Charles of Hesse the throne of a short-lived Kingdom of Finland.
October 9, 1919: The Cincinnati Reds win the World Series, resulting in the Black Sox Scandal.
October 9, 1934: An Ustashe assassin kills King Alexander I of Yugoslavia and Louis Barthou, Foreign Minister of France, in Marseille.
October 9, 1936: Boulder Dam (later Hoover Dam) begins to generate electricity and transmit it to Los Angeles.
October 9, 1941: A coup in Panama declares Ricardo Adolfo de la Guardia Arango the new president.
October 9, 1942: Australia's Statute of Westminster Adoption Act 1942 receives royal assent.
October 9, 1950: The Goyang Geumjeong Cave massacre in Korea begins.
October 9, 1962: Uganda becomes an independent Commonwealth realm.
October 9, 1963: In Italy, a large landslide a causes a giant wave to overtop the Vajont Dam, killing over 2,000.
October 9, 1967: A day after his capture, Ernesto "Che" Guevara is executed for attempting to incite a revolution in Bolivia.
October 9, 1969: In Chicago, the National Guard is called in as demonstrations continue in over the trial of the "Chicago Eight".
October 9, 1970: The Khmer Republic is proclaimed in Cambodia.
October 9, 1980: Pope John Paul II greets the Dalai Lama during a private audience in Vatican City.
October 9, 1981: President Mitterrand abolishes capital punishment in France.
October 9, 1983: South Korean President Chun Doo-hwan survives an  assassination attempt in Rangoon, Burma, but the blast kills 21 and injures 17 others.
October 9, 1986: The Phantom of the Opera, eventually the second longest running musical in London, opens at Her Majesty's Theatre.
October 9, 1995: An Amtrak Sunset Limited train is derailed by saboteurs near Palo Verde, Arizona.
October 9, 2006: North Korea conducts its first nuclear test.
October 9, 2009: First lunar impact of NASA's Lunar Precursor Robotic Program.
October 9, 2012: Pakistani Taliban attempt to assassinate outspoken schoolgirl Malala Yousafzai.
October 9, 2016: The Arakan Rohingya Salvation Army launches its first attack on Myanmar security forces along the Bangladesh–Myanmar border.
October 9, 2017: The October 2017 Northern California wildfires ravage the North Bay, resulting in over 40 deaths, and about 8,900 structures destroyed.
October 10, 680: Muhammad's grandson Husayn ibn Ali is decapitated by Caliph Yazid I's troops.
October 10, 732: Charles Martel's forces defeat an Umayyad army between near Tours, France.
October 10, 1471: Sten Sture the Elder, the Regent of Sweden, with the help of farmers and miners, repels an attack by King Christian I of Denmark.
October 10, 1575: Roman Catholic forces under Henry I, Duke of Guise defeat the Protestants, capturing Philippe de Mornay among others.
October 10, 1580: Over 600 Papal troops land in Ireland to support the Second Desmond Rebellion.
October 10, 1760: In a treaty with the Dutch colonial authorities, the Ndyuka people of Suriname – descended from escaped slaves – gain territorial autonomy.
October 10, 1780: The Great Hurricane of 1780 kills 20,000–30,000 in the Caribbean.
October 10, 1814: The United States Revenue Marine attempts to defend the cutter Eagle from the Royal Navy.
October 10, 1845: In Annapolis, Maryland, the Naval School (later the United States Naval Academy) opens with 50 students.
October 10, 1846: Triton, the largest moon of the planet Neptune, is discovered by English astronomer William Lassell.
October 10, 1868: The Ten Years' War begins against Spanish rule in Cuba.
October 10, 1871: Chicago burns after a barn accident. The fire lasts from October 8–10.
October 10, 1903: The Women's Social and Political Union is founded in support of the enfranchisement of British women.
October 10, 1911: The day after a bomb explodes prematurely, the Wuchang Uprising begins against the Chinese monarchy.
October 10, 1913: U.S. President Wilson triggers the explosion of the Gamboa Dike, completing major construction on the Panama Canal.
October 10, 1918: RMS Leinster is torpedoed and sunk by UB-123, killing 564, the worst-ever on the Irish Sea.[1][2]
October 10, 1920: The Carinthian plebiscite determines that the larger part of the Duchy of Carinthia should remain part of Austria.
October 10, 1928: Chiang Kai-shek becomes Chairman of the Republic of China.
October 10, 1933: A United Airlines Boeing 247 is destroyed by sabotage, the first such proven case in the history of commercial aviation.
October 10, 1935: In Greece, a coup d'état  ends the Second Hellenic Republic.
October 10, 1938: Abiding by the Munich Agreement, Czechoslovakia completes its withdrawal from the Sudetenland.
October 10, 1945: The Double Tenth Agreement is signed by the Communist Party and the Kuomintang about the future of China.
October 10, 1957: The Windscale fire results in Britain's worst nuclear accident.
October 10, 1963: The Partial Nuclear Test Ban Treaty comes into effect.
October 10, 1964: The Tokyo Summer Olympics opening ceremony is the first to be relayed live by satellites.
October 10, 1967: The Outer Space Treaty comes into force.
October 10, 1970: Canada's October Crisis escalates when Quebec's vice-premier is kidnapped by members of the FLQ.
October 10, 1973: U.S. Vice President Spiro Agnew resigns after being charged with evasion of federal income tax.
October 10, 1975: Papua New Guinea joins the United Nations.
October 10, 1980: The Farabundo Martí National Liberation Front is founded in El Salvador.
October 10, 1985: US Navy aircraft intercept an Egyptian airliner carrying the perpetrators of the Achille Lauro hijacking, and force it to land in Italy.
October 10, 1986: A 5.7 Mw  San Salvador earthquake shakes El Salvador, killing 1,500.
October 10, 1997: Austral Líneas Aéreas Flight 2553 crashes and explodes in Uruguay, killing 74.
October 10, 1998: A Lignes Aériennes Congolaises jetliner is shot down by rebels in Kindu, Democratic Republic of the Congo, killing 41 people.
October 10, 2009: Armenia and Turkey sign the Zurich Protocols, intended to normalize relations. However, they are never ratified by either side.
October 10, 2010: The Netherlands Antilles are dissolved as a country.
October 10, 2015: Twin bomb blasts in the Turkish capital Ankara kill 102 and injure 400.
October 10, 2018: Hurricane Michael makes landfall in the Florida Panhandle as a catastrophic Category 5 hurricane. It kills 57 people in the United States, 45 in Florida, and causes an estimated $25.1 billion in damage.
October 11, 1138: A massive earthquake strikes Aleppo; it is one of the most destructive earthquakes ever.[1]
October 11, 1142: A peace treaty ends the Jin–Song wars.
October 11, 1311: The peerage and clergy restrict the authority of English kings with the Ordinances of 1311.
October 11, 1531: Huldrych Zwingli is killed in battle with the Roman Catholic cantons of Switzerland.
October 11, 1614: The New Netherland Company applies to the States General of the Netherlands for exclusive trading rights in what is now the northeastern United States.
October 11, 1634: The Burchardi flood kills around 15,000 in North Friesland, Denmark and Germany.
October 11, 1649: Cromwell's New Model Army Sacks Wexford, killing over 2,000 Irish Confederate troops and 1,500 civilians.
October 11, 1767: Surveying for the Mason–Dixon line separating Maryland from Pennsylvania is completed.
October 11, 1797: The Royal Navy decisively defeats the Batavian Navy at Camperdown during the French Revolutionary Wars.
October 11, 1811: The Juliana begins operation as the first steam-powered ferry in New York harbor.
October 11, 1840: The Maronite leader Bashir Shihab II surrenders to the Ottoman Empire and later is sent to Malta in exile.
October 11, 1852: The University of Sydney, Australia's oldest university, is inaugurated in Sydney.
October 11, 1865: Hundreds of black men and women march in Jamaica, starting the Morant Bay rebellion.
October 11, 1890: In Washington, D.C., the Daughters of the American Revolution is founded.
October 11, 1899: The Second Boer War erupts in South Africa between the British-ruled Cape Colony, and the Boer-ruled Transvaal and Orange Free State.
October 11, 1906: San Francisco sparks a diplomatic crisis between the United States and Japan by ordering segregated schools for Japanese students.
October 11, 1910: Piloted by Arch Hoxsey, Theodore Roosevelt becomes the first U.S. president to fly in an airplane.
October 11, 1918: The 7.1 Mw San Fermín earthquake shakes Puerto Rico. The quake and resulting tsunami kill up to 116 people.
October 11, 1937: The Duke and Duchess of Windsor tour Nazi Germany for 12 days and meet Adolf Hitler on the 22nd.
October 11, 1941: Beginning of the National Liberation War of Macedonia.
October 11, 1944: The Tuvan People's Republic is annexed by the Soviet Union.
October 11, 1950: CBS's field-sequential color system for television is the first to be licensed for broadcast by the U.S. Federal Communications Commission.
October 11, 1954: In accord with the 1954 Geneva Conference, French troops complete their withdrawal from North Vietnam.
October 11, 1958: NASA launches Pioneer 1, its first space probe, although it fails to achieve a stable orbit.
October 11, 1962: The Second Vatican Council becomes the first ecumenical council of the Roman Catholic Church in 92 years.
October 11, 1968: NASA launches Apollo 7, the first successful manned Apollo mission.
October 11, 1972: A race riot occurs on the United States Navy aircraft carrier Kitty Hawk off the coast of Vietnam.
October 11, 1976: George Washington is posthumously promoted to the grade of General of the Armies.
October 11, 1984: Aeroflot Flight 3352 crashes into maintenance vehicles upon landing in Omsk, Russia, killing 178.
October 11, 1986: Ronald Reagan and Mikhail Gorbachev meet in Iceland to continue discussions about scaling back IRBM arsenals in Europe.
October 11, 1987: Start of Operation Pawan by Indian forces in Sri Lanka. Thousands of civilians, insurgents, soldiers die.
October 11, 1991: Prof. Anita Hill delivers her televised testimony concerning sexual harassment during the Clarence Thomas Supreme Court nomination[2]
October 11, 2000: NASA launches STS-92, the 100th Space Shuttle mission.
October 11, 2001: The Polaroid Corporation files for federal bankruptcy protection.
October 11, 2002: A bomb attack in a shopping mall in Finland kills seven.
October 11, 2013: A migrant boat sinks in the Channel of Sicily with at least 34 people dead.
October 11, 2018: Soyuz MS-10, launching an intended crew for the ISS, suffers an in-flight abort. The crew lands safely.
October 12, 539 BC: The army of Cyrus the Great of Persia takes Babylon, ending the Babylonian empire. (Julian calendar)[1]
October 12, 1279: The Nichiren Shōshū branch of Buddhism is founded in Japan.[3]
October 12, 1398: In the Treaty of Salynas, Lithuania cedes Samogitia to the Teutonic Knights.[4]
October 12, 1492: Christopher Columbus's first expedition makes landfall in the Caribbean, specifically in The Bahamas.[5]
October 12, 1654: The Delft Explosion devastates the city in the Netherlands, killing more than 100 people.
October 12, 1692: The Salem witch trials are ended by a letter from the governor of the Massachusetts Bay Province.
October 12, 1792: The first celebration of Columbus Day is held in New York City.
October 12, 1793: The cornerstone of Old East, the oldest state university building in the United States, is laid at the University of North Carolina.
October 12, 1798: Flemish and Luxembourgish peasants launch the rebellion against French rule known as the Peasants' War.
October 12, 1799: Jeanne Geneviève Labrosse becomes the first woman to jump from a balloon with a parachute.
October 12, 1810: The citizens of Munich hold the first Oktoberfest.
October 12, 1822: Pedro I of Brazil is proclaimed the emperor.
October 12, 1847: Werner von Siemens founds Siemens & Halske, which later becomes Siemens AG.
October 12, 1849: The city of Manizales, Colombia, is founded by 'The Expedition of the 20'.
October 12, 1871: The British in India enact the Criminal Tribes Act, naming many local communities "Criminal Tribes".
October 12, 1892: The Pledge of Allegiance is first recited by students in many US public schools.
October 12, 1901: President Theodore Roosevelt officially renames the "Executive Mansion" to the White House.
October 12, 1918: A massive forest fire kills 453 people in Minnesota.
October 12, 1928: An iron lung respirator is used for the first time at Children's Hospital, Boston.
October 12, 1933: The military Alcatraz Citadel becomes the civilian Alcatraz Federal Penitentiary.
October 12, 1959: At the national congress of the American Popular Revolutionary Alliance in Peru, a group of leftist radicals are expelled from the party who later form APRA Rebelde.
October 12, 1960: Japan Socialist Party leader Inejiro Asanuma is stabbed to death during a live Television broadcast.
October 12, 1962: The Columbus Day Storm strikes the U.S. Pacific Northwest with record wind velocities; 46 dead and at least U.S. $230 million in damages.
October 12, 1963: After nearly 23 years of imprisonment, Reverend Walter Ciszek, a Jesuit missionary, was released from the Soviet Union.
October 12, 1964: The Soviet Union launches the Voskhod 1 into Earth orbit as the first spacecraft with a multi-person crew, and the first flight without pressure suits.
October 12, 1968: Equatorial Guinea becomes independent from Spain.
October 12, 1971: The 2,500 year celebration of the Persian Empire begins.
October 12, 1979: The lowest recorded non-tornadic atmospheric pressure, 87.0 kPa (870 mbar or 25.69 inHg), occurred in the western Pacific Ocean during Typhoon Tip.
October 12, 1983: Japan's former Prime Minister Tanaka Kakuei is found guilty of taking a $2 million bribe from the Lockheed Corporation, and is sentenced to four years in jail.
October 12, 1984: The Provisional Irish Republican Army fail to assassinate Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher and her cabinet.  The bomb kills five people and wounds 31.
October 12, 1988: Two officers of the Victoria Police are gunned down execution-style in the Walsh Street police shootings, Australia.
October 12, 1992: A 5.8 earthquake occurred in Cairo, Egypt. At least 510 died.
October 12, 1994: The Magellan spacecraft burns up in the atmosphere of Venus.
October 12, 1997: The Sidi Daoud massacre in Algeria kills 43 people at a fake roadblock.
October 12, 1998: Matthew Shepard, a gay student at University of Wyoming, dies five days after he was beaten outside of Laramie.
October 12, 1999: The former Autonomous Soviet Republic of Abkhazia declares its independence from Georgia.
October 12, 2000: A US Navy frigate is badly damaged by two suicide bombers, killing 17 crew members and wounding at least 39.
October 12, 2002: Terrorists detonate bombs in the Sari Club in Bali, killing 202 and wounding over 300.
October 12, 2005: The second Chinese human spaceflight, Shenzhou 6, is launched, carrying two cosmonauts in orbit for five days.
October 12, 2013: Fifty-one people are killed after a truck veers off a cliff in Peru.
October 12, 2017: The United States announces its decision to withdraw from UNESCO.[6] and is immediately followed by Israel.
October 12, 2018: Princess Eugenie marries Jack Brooksbank at St. George's Chapel, Windsor Castle.
October 13, AD 54: Roman emperor Claudius dies from poisoning under mysterious circumstances.
October 13, 409: Vandals and Alans cross the Pyrenees and appear in Hispania.
October 13, 1269: The present church building at Westminster Abbey is consecrated.
October 13, 1307: Hundreds of Knights Templar in France are arrested at dawn by King Phillip the Fair, and later confess under torture to heresy.
October 13, 1332: Rinchinbal Khan becomes the Khagan of the Mongols and Emperor of the Yuan dynasty, reigning for only 53 days.
October 13, 1644: A Swedish–Dutch fleet defeats the Danish fleet at Fehmarn and captures about 1,000 prisoners.
October 13, 1710: Port Royal, the capital of French Acadia, falls in a siege by British forces.
October 13, 1775: The Continental Congress establishes the Continental Navy (predecessor of the United States Navy).
October 13, 1792: In Washington, D.C., the cornerstone of the United States Executive Mansion (known as the White House since 1818) is laid.
October 13, 1821: The Declaration of Independence of the Mexican Empire is publicly proclaimed.
October 13, 1843: In New York City, B'nai B'rith, the oldest Jewish service organization in the world, is founded.
October 13, 1881: First known conversation in modern Hebrew by Eliezer Ben-Yehuda and friends.
October 13, 1884: The International Meridian Conference establishes the meridian of the Greenwich Observatory as the  prime meridian.
October 13, 1885: The Georgia Institute of Technology is founded in Atlanta, Georgia.
October 13, 1892: Edward Emerson Barnard discovers first comet discovered by photographic means.
October 13, 1903: The Boston Red Sox win the first modern World Series, defeating the Pittsburgh Pirates in the eighth game.
October 13, 1908: Margaret Travers Symons bursts into the UK parliament and became the first woman to speak there.[1]
October 13, 1911: Prince Arthur, Duke of Connaught and Strathearn, becomes the first Governor General of Canada of royal descent.
October 13, 1917: The "Miracle of the Sun" is witnessed by an estimated 70,000 people in the Cova da Iria in Portugal.
October 13, 1921: Soviet republics sign the Treaty of Kars to formalize the borders between Turkey and the South Caucasus states.
October 13, 1923: Ankara becomes the capital of Turkey.
October 13, 1946: France adopts the constitution of the Fourth Republic.
October 13, 1962: The Pacific Northwest experiences a cyclone the equal of a Cat 3 hurricane, with winds above 150 mph. 46 people die.
October 13, 1972: Uruguayan Air Force Flight 571 crashes in the Andes mountains. 28 survive the crash. All but 16 succumb before rescue on December 23[2]
