October 13, 1976: The first electron micrograph of an Ebola virus is taken at the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention by Dr. F. A. Murphy.
October 13, 1977: Hijacking of Lufthansa Flight 181 by the Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine
October 13, 1983: Ameritech Mobile Communications launches the first US cellular network in Chicago.
October 13, 1990: Syrian forces attack free areas of Lebanon, removing General Michel Aoun from the presidential palace.
October 13, 2010: The mining accident in Copiapó, Chile ends as all 33 trapped miners arrive at the surface after a record 69 days underground.
October 13, 2013: A stampede occurs in India during the Hindu festival Navratri, killing 115 and injuring more than 110.
October 13, 2016: The Maldives announces its decision to withdraw from the Commonwealth of Nations.
October 14, 1066: The Norman conquest of England begins with the Battle of Hastings.
October 14, 1322: Robert the Bruce of Scotland defeats King Edward II of England at the Battle of Old Byland, forcing Edward to accept Scotland's independence.
October 14, 1586: Mary, Queen of Scots, goes on trial for conspiracy against Queen Elizabeth I of England.
October 14, 1656: Massachusetts enacts the first punitive legislation against the Religious Society of Friends (Quakers).
October 14, 1773: The first recorded ministry of education, the Commission of National Education, is formed in the Polish–Lithuanian Commonwealth.
October 14, 1808: The Republic of Ragusa is annexed by France.
October 14, 1843: Irish nationalist Daniel O'Connell arrested by British on charges of criminal conspiracy.
October 14, 1884: American inventor George Eastman receives a U.S. Government patent on his new paper-strip film.
October 14, 1888: Louis Le Prince films the first motion picture, Roundhay Garden Scene.
October 14, 1898: The steam ship SS Mohegan sinks near the Lizard peninsula, Cornwall, killing 106.
October 14, 1908: The Chicago Cubs defeat the Detroit Tigers, 2–0, clinching the 1908 World Series; this would be their last until winning the 2016 World Series.
October 14, 1910: English aviator Claude Grahame-White lands his aircraft on Executive Avenue near the White House in Washington, D.C.
October 14, 1912: Former president Theodore Roosevelt is shot and mildly wounded by John Flammang Schrank. With the fresh wound in his chest, and the bullet still within it, Roosevelt delivers his scheduled speech.
October 14, 1913: Senghenydd colliery disaster, the United Kingdom's worst coal mining accident, claims the lives of 439 miners.
October 14, 1920: Finland and Soviet Russia sign the Treaty of Tartu, exchanging some territories.
October 14, 1926: The children's book Winnie-the-Pooh, by A. A. Milne, is first published.
October 14, 1933: Germany withdraws from the League of Nations and World Disarmament Conference.
October 14, 1938: The first flight of the Curtiss P-40 Warhawk fighter plane.
October 14, 1947: Chuck Yeager becomes the first person to exceed the speed of sound.
October 14, 1949: The Smith Act trials of Communist Party leaders in the United States convicts eleven defendants of conspiring to advocate the violent overthrow of the federal government.
October 14, 1956: Dr. B. R. Ambedkar converts from Hinduism to Buddhism along with 385,000 of his followers.
October 14, 1957: At least 81 people are killed in the most devastating flood in the history of the Spanish city of Valencia.
October 14, 1962: The Cuban Missile Crisis begins when an American reconnaissance aircraft takes photographs of Soviet ballistic missiles being installed in Cuba.
October 14, 1964: The Soviet Presidium and the Communist Party Central Committee each vote to accept Nikita Khrushchev's "voluntary" request to retire from his offices.
October 14, 1966: The city of Montreal begins the operation of its underground Montreal Metro rapid transit system.
October 14, 1968: Jim Hines becomes the first man ever to break the so-called "ten-second barrier" in the 100-meter sprint with a time of 9.95 seconds.
October 14, 1973: In the Thammasat student uprising, over 100,000 people protest in Thailand against the military government. Seventy-seven are killed and 857 are injured by soldiers.
October 14, 1977: Anita Bryant gets a pie thrown in her face at a news conference in Des Moines by gay rights activist Tom Higgins for her anti LGBT commentary. [1]
October 14, 1979: The first National March on Washington for Lesbian and Gay Rights draws approximately 100,000 people.
October 14, 1981: Vice President Hosni Mubarak is elected as the President of Egypt, one week after the assassination of Anwar Sadat.
October 14, 1982: U.S. President Ronald Reagan proclaims a War on Drugs.
October 14, 1991: Burmese opposition leader Aung San Suu Kyi is awarded the Nobel Peace Prize.
October 14, 1994: Yasser Arafat, Yitzhak Rabin and Shimon Peres receive the Nobel Peace Prize for their role in the establishment of the Oslo Accords and the framing of future Palestinian self government.
October 14, 1998: Eric Rudolph is charged with six bombings, including the 1996 Centennial Olympic Park bombing in Atlanta, Georgia.
October 14, 2004: Pinnacle Airlines Flight 3701 crashes in Jefferson City, Missouri. The two pilots (the aircraft's only occupants) are killed.[2]
October 14, 2012: Felix Baumgartner successfully jumps to Earth from a balloon in the stratosphere.
October 14, 2014: The Serbia vs. Albania UEFA qualifying match is canceled after 42 minutes due to several incidents on and off the pitch. Albania is eventually awarded a win.
October 14, 2015: A suicide bomb attack in Pakistan kills at least seven people and injures 13 others.
October 14, 2017: A massive truck bombing in Somalia kills 358 people and injures more than 400 others.
October 15, 1066: Edgar the Ætheling is proclaimed King of England, but is never crowned. He reigns until 10 December 1066.
October 15, 1211: The Latin emperor Henry of Flanders defeats the Nicaean emperor Theodore I Laskaris.
October 15, 1529: The Siege of Vienna ends when Austria routs the invading Ottoman forces, ending its European expansion.
October 15, 1582: Adoption of the Gregorian calendar begins, eventually leading to near-universal adoption.
October 15, 1764: Edward Gibbon is inspired to begin work on The History of the Decline and Fall of the Roman Empire.
October 15, 1783: The Montgolfier brothers' hot air balloon makes the first human ascent, piloted by Jean-François Pilâtre de Rozier.
October 15, 1793: Queen Marie Antoinette of France is tried and convicted, and condemned to death the following day.
October 15, 1809: The Viceroy the Río de la Plata, Baltasar Hidalgo de Cisneros, opens the port of Buenos Aires to trade with nations other than Spain.
October 15, 1815: Napoleon begins his exile on Saint Helena in the South Atlantic Ocean.
October 15, 1821: The Cortes of Cádiz decides to create the providence of Logroño.
October 15, 1874: The Academia Ecuatoriana de la Lengua is established in Quito, Ecuador.
October 15, 1878: The Edison Electric Light Company begins operation.
October 15, 1879: The Segura river in southeastern Spain floods, killing 1077 people.
October 15, 1880: In Germany, the inauguration of the Cologne Cathedral is celebrated.
October 15, 1888: The "From Hell" letter allegedly sent by Jack the Ripper is received by investigators.
October 15, 1894: Alfred Dreyfus is arrested for spying.
October 15, 1910: Airship America is launched from New Jersey in the first attempt to cross the Atlantic by a powered aircraft.
October 15, 1923: The German Rentenmark is introduced in Germany to counter hyperinflation in the Weimar Republic.
October 15, 1928: The airship, Graf Zeppelin completes its first trans-Atlantic flight, landing in the United States.
October 15, 1932: Tata Airlines (later to become Air India) makes its first flight.
October 15, 1939: The New York Municipal Airport (later renamed LaGuardia Airport) is dedicated.
October 15, 1940: President Lluís Companys of Catalonia is executed by the Francoist government.
October 15, 1945: The former premier of Vichy France, Pierre Laval, is executed for treason.
October 15, 1946: The United Nations Security Council Resolution 9 concerning the International Court of Justice is unanimously adopted.
October 15, 1951: Mexican chemist Luis E. Miramontes completes the synthesis of norethisterone, the basis of an early oral contraceptive.
October 15, 1954: Hurricane Hazel devastates the eastern seaboard of North America, killing 95 and causing massive floods as far north as Toronto.
October 15, 1956: FORTRAN, the first modern computer language, is first shared with the coding community.
October 15, 1962: The CIA notifies the State Department that Soviet ballistic missiles are in Cuba, leading to the Cuban Missile Crisis.
October 15, 1964: Alexei Kosygin becomes the General Secretary of the Communist Party of the Soviet Union.
October 15, 1966: The Black Panther Party is founded.
October 15, 1967: The Motherland Calls, a memorial statue "For the heroes of the Battle of Stalingrad", is unveiled.
October 15, 1969: In the Moratorium to End the War in Vietnam, over two million demonstrate nationally; about 250,000 in Washington D.C.
October 15, 1970: Thirty-five construction workers are killed when a section of the new West Gate Bridge in Melbourne collapses.
October 15, 1987: In Burkina Faso, a military coup was orchestrated by Blaise Compaoré against incumbent President Thomas Sankara.
October 15, 1989: Eight of those convicted in the Rivonia Trial are released from prison.
October 15, 1990: Soviet Union leader Mikhail Gorbachev is awarded the Nobel Peace Prize for his efforts to lessen Cold War tensions and open up his nation.
October 15, 1991: The first ultra-high-energy cosmic ray is detected.
October 15, 1994: The Clinton administration returns Haiti's first democratically elected president, Jean-Bertrand Aristide, to the island.
October 15, 1995: Saddam Hussein is reelected president of Iraq through a referendum.
October 15, 1997: The Cassini probe launches from Cape Canaveral on its way to Saturn.
October 15, 2001: NASA's Galileo spacecraft passes within 112 miles of Jupiter's moon Io.
October 15, 2003: China launches Shenzhou 5, its first manned space mission.
October 15, 2005: Iraqis vote to ratify the new constitution.
October 15, 2006: The 6.7 Mw Kiholo Bay earthquake rocks Hawaii, causing property damage, injuries, landslides, power outages, and the closure of Honolulu International Airport.
October 15, 2007: Seventeen activists in New Zealand are arrested in the country's first post-9/11 anti-terrorism raids.
October 15, 2008: The Dow Jones Industrial Average closes down 733.08 points, or 7.87%, the second worst percentage drop in the Dow's history.
October 15, 2013: The 7.2 Mw Bohol earthquake strikes the Philippines. At least 215 die.
October 15, 2016: One hundred ninety-seven nations amend the Montreal Protocol to include a phase-out of hydrofluorocarbons.
October 16, 456: Ricimer defeats Avitus at Piacenza and becomes master of the Western Roman Empire.[1]
October 16, 690: Empress Wu Zetian ascends to the throne of the Tang dynasty and proclaims herself ruler of the Chinese Empire.
October 16, 912: Abd ar-Rahman III becomes the 8th Emir of Córdoba[2]
October 16, 955: King Otto I defeats a Slavic revolt in what is now Mecklenburg-Vorpommern.
October 16, 1311: The Council of Vienne convenes for the first time.[3]
October 16, 1384: Jadwiga is crowned King of Poland, although she is a woman.
October 16, 1590: Prince Gesualdo of Venosa murders his wife and her lover.
October 16, 1736: Mathematician William Whiston's predicted comet fails to strike the Earth.[4]
October 16, 1780: The Great Hurricane of 1780 finishes after its sixth day, killing between 20,000 and 24,000 residents of the Lesser Antilles.[5]
October 16, 1813: The Sixth Coalition attacks Napoleon in the three-day Battle of Leipzig.
October 16, 1817: Simón Bolívar sentences Manuel Piar to death for challenging the racial-caste in Venezuela.[7]
October 16, 1834: Much of the ancient structure of the Palace of Westminster in London burns to the ground.
October 16, 1841: Queen's University is founded in the Province of Canada.
October 16, 1843: William Rowan Hamilton invents quaternions, a three-dimensional system of complex numbers.
October 16, 1846: William T. G. Morton administers ether anesthesia during a surgical operation.
October 16, 1847: The novel Jane Eyre is published in London.
October 16, 1859: John Brown leads a raid on Harpers Ferry, Virginia.
October 16, 1869: Girton College, Cambridge is founded, becoming England's first residential college for women.
October 16, 1875: Brigham Young University is founded in Provo, Utah.
October 16, 1882: The Nickel Plate Railroad opens for business.
October 16, 1905: The Partition of Bengal in India takes place.
October 16, 1906: The Wilhelm Voigt fools the city hall of Köpenick and several soldiers by impersonating a Prussian officer.
October 16, 1909: William Howard Taft and Porfirio Díaz hold the first summit between a U.S. and a Mexican president. They narrowly escape assassination.[8]
October 16, 1916: Margaret Sanger opens the first family planning clinic in the United States.
October 16, 1919: Adolf Hitler delivers his first public address at a meeting of the German Workers' Party.[9]
October 16, 1923: The Walt Disney Company is founded.
October 16, 1934: Chinese Communists begin the Long March to escape Nationalist encirclement.
October 16, 1947: The Philippines takes over the administration of the Turtle Islands and the Mangsee Islands from the United Kingdom.
October 16, 1949: The Greek Communist Party announces a "temporary cease-fire", thus ending the Greek Civil War.
October 16, 1950: The Lion, the Witch and the Wardrobe by C.S. Lewis is published.
October 16, 1951: The first Prime Minister of Pakistan, Liaquat Ali Khan, is assassinated in Rawalpindi.
October 16, 1964: Leonid Brezhnev becomes leader of the Soviet Communist Party, while Alexei Kosygin becomes the head of government.
October 16, 1968: Yasunari Kawabata becomes the first Japanese person to be awarded the Nobel Prize in Literature.
October 16, 1970: Canadian Prime Minister Pierre Trudeau invokes the War Measures Act during the October Crisis.
October 16, 1973: Henry Kissinger and Lê Đức Thọ are awarded the Nobel Peace Prize.
October 16, 1975: The Australian Coalition sparks a constitutional crisis when they vote to defer funding for the government's annual budget.
October 16, 1978: Pope John Paul II becomes the first non-Italian pontiff since 1523.
October 16, 1984: Desmond Tutu is awarded the Nobel Peace Prize.
October 16, 1991: George Hennard runs amok in Killeen, Texas, killing 23 and wounding 20.
October 16, 1995: The Skye Bridge in Scotland is opened.
October 16, 1996: Eighty-four football fans die and 180 are injured in a massive crush at a match in Guatemala City.
October 16, 1998: Former Chilean dictator Augusto Pinochet is arrested in London on a murder extradition warrant.
October 16, 2002: The Bibliotheca Alexandrina opens in Egypt, commemorating the ancient library of Alexandria.
October 16, 2013: Lao Airlines Flight 301 crashes on approach to Pakse International Airport in Laos, killing 49 people.
October 16, 2017: Storm Ophelia strikes the U.K. and Ireland causing major damage and power loss.
October 17, 1346: The English capture King David II of Scotland at Neville's Cross and imprison him for eleven years.
October 17, 1448: An Ottoman army defeats a Hungarian army at the Second Battle of Kosovo.
October 17, 1456: The University of Greifswald is established as the second oldest university in northern Europe.
October 17, 1534: Anti-Catholic posters appear in Paris and other cities supporting Huldrych Zwingli's position on the Mass.
October 17, 1558: Poczta Polska, the Polish postal service, is founded.
October 17, 1604: Kepler's Supernova is observed in the constellation of Ophiuchus.
October 17, 1610: French king Louis XIII is crowned in Reims Cathedral.
October 17, 1660: The Nine regicides who signed the death warrant of Charles I of England are hanged, drawn and quartered.
October 17, 1662: Charles II of England sells Dunkirk to France for 40,000 pounds.
October 17, 1771: Premiere in Milan of the opera Ascanio in Alba, composed by Mozart at age 15.
October 17, 1806: Former leader of the Haitian Revolution, Emperor Jacques I, is assassinated after an oppressive rule.
October 17, 1814: Eight people die in the London Beer Flood.
October 17, 1817: The tomb of Pharaoh Seti I is discovered.[1]
October 17, 1827: Bellini's third opera, Il pirata, is premiered at Milan.
October 17, 1860: First The Open Championship (referred to in North America as the British Open).
October 17, 1861: Aborigines kill Nineteen Europeans in the Cullin-la-ringo massacre.
October 17, 1888: Thomas Edison files a patent for the Optical Phonograph (the first movie).
October 17, 1907: Marconi begins the first commercial transatlantic wireless service.
October 17, 1912: Bulgaria, Greece and Serbia declare war on the Ottoman Empire, joining Montenegro in the First Balkan War.
October 17, 1919: RCA is incorporated as the Radio Corporation of America.
October 17, 1931: Al Capone is convicted of income tax evasion.
October 17, 1933: Albert Einstein flees Nazi Germany and moves to the United States.
October 17, 1940: The body of Communist propagandist Willi Münzenberg found in South France, starting a never-resolved mystery.
October 17, 1943: The Burma Railway (Burma–Thailand Railway) is completed.
October 17, 1945: A massive demonstration in Buenos Aires, Argentina, demands Juan Perón's release.
October 17, 1956: Bobby Fischer defeats Donald Byrne in the chess Game of the Century.
October 17, 1961: Directed by their chief Maurice Papon, Paris police massacre scores of Algerian protesters.
October 17, 1965: The 1964–65 New York World's Fair closes after two years and more than 51 million attendees.
October 17, 1966: The 23rd Street Fire in New York City kills 12 firefighters.
October 17, 1970: FLQ terrorists murder Quebec Vice-Premier and Minister of Labour Pierre Laporte.
October 17, 1973: OPEC imposes an oil embargo against countries they deem to have helped Israel in the Yom Kippur War.
October 17, 1977: The hijacked Lufthansa Flight 181 lands in Mogadishu. The remaining hostages are later rescued.
October 17, 1979: The Department of Education Organization Act creates the US Department of Education.
October 17, 1980: As part of the Holy See–United Kingdom relations a British monarch makes the first state visit to the Vatican
October 17, 1989: The East German Politburo votes to remove Erich Honecker from his role as General Secretary.
October 17, 1992: Having gone to the wrong house, Japanese student Yoshihiro Hattori is killed by the homeowner in Baton Rouge, Louisiana.
October 17, 1994: Russian journalist Dmitry Kholodov is assassinated while investigating corruption in the armed forces.
October 17, 2000: The Hatfield rail crash leads to the collapse of Railtrack.
October 17, 2001: Israeli tourism minister Rehavam Ze'evi becomes the first Israeli minister to be assassinated in a terrorist attack.
October 17, 2003: Taipei 101, a 101-floor skyscraper in Taipei, becomes the world's tallest highrise.
October 17, 2018: Kerch Polytechnic College attack in Crimea.
October 18, 320: Pappus of Alexandria observes a solar eclipse.
October 18, 614: The Edict of Paris defends the rights of the Frankish nobles and restricts Jewish employment.
October 18, 629: Dagobert I is crowned King of the Franks.
October 18, 1009: Fatimid caliph Al-Hakim bi-Amr Allah demolishes the Church of the Holy Sepulchre in Jerusalem.
October 18, 1016: Cnut the Great completes his conquest of England in the Battle of Assandun.
October 18, 1244: The Khwarazmian Turks and Egypt defeat Damascus and the crusader Kingdom of Jerusalem at the Battle of La Forbie.
October 18, 1356: The Basel earthquake is the most significant historic seismological event north of the Alps.
October 18, 1540: Spanish conquistadors destroy the fortified town of Mabila in present-day Alabama, killing Tuskaloosa.
October 18, 1561: In Japan, the fourth Battle of Kawanakajima was fought between the forces of Uesugi Kenshin and Takeda Shingen, resulting in a draw.
October 18, 1565: Ships belonging to the Matsura clan of Japan fail to capture a Portuguese trading carrack in the Battle of Fukuda Bay, the first recorded naval battle between Japan and the West.
October 18, 1599: Michael the Brave, Prince of Wallachia, defeats the army of Andrew Báthory in the Battle of Șelimbăr, leading to the first recorded unification of the Romanian people.
October 18, 1748: The signing of the Treaty of Aix-la-Chapelle ends the War of the Austrian Succession.
October 18, 1797: The Treaty of Campo Formio between France and Austria, among other provisions, abolishes the Republic of Venice.
October 18, 1851: Moby-Dick is first published as The Whale.
October 18, 1860: The Second Opium War ends at the Convention of Peking.
October 18, 1867: The United States takes possession of Alaska after purchasing it from Russia for $7.2 million.
October 18, 1914: The Catholic Schoenstatt Movement is founded in Germany.
October 18, 1921: The Crimean Autonomous Soviet Socialist Republic is formed as part of the Russian Soviet Federative Socialist Republic.
October 18, 1922: The British Broadcasting Company (later Corporation)  is founded by a consortium, to establish a national broadcasting service.
October 18, 1929: The Judicial Committee of the Privy Council overrules the Supreme Court of Canada in Edwards v. Canada when it declares that women are considered "Persons" under Canadian law.
October 18, 1945: Argentine military officer and politician Juan Perón marries actress Eva Duarte.
October 18, 1951: The Studio for Electronic Music was established at the West German Broadcasting facility in Cologne, making the first modern music studio.
October 18, 1954: Texas Instruments announces the first transistor radio.
October 18, 1963: Félicette, a black and white female Parisian stray cat becomes the first cat launched into space.
October 18, 1967: The Soviet probe Venera 4 reaches Venus, and becomes the first spacecraft to measure the atmosphere of another planet.
October 18, 1979: The Federal Communications Commission begins allowing people to have home satellite earth stations without a federal government license.
October 18, 1991: The Supreme Council of Azerbaijan adopts a declaration of independence from the Soviet Union.
October 18, 2003: President Gonzalo Sánchez de Lozada is forced into exile by the Bolivian gas conflict.
October 18, 2007: A suicide attack on a motorcade carrying former Pakistani Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto kills 139 and wounds 450 more. Bhutto herself was uninjured.
October 18, 2011: An Israeli soldier, Gilad Shalit of the Israel Defense Forces is released by Hamas as part of a prisoner exchange deal, after being held captive for over five years.
October 19, 439: The Vandals, led by King Gaiseric, take Carthage in North Africa.
October 19, 1216: King John of England dies at Newark-on-Trent and is succeeded by his nine-year-old son Henry.
October 19, 1386: The Universität Heidelberg holds its first lecture, making it the oldest German university.
October 19, 1466: The Thirteen Years' War between Poland and the Teutonic Order ends with the Second Treaty of Thorn.
October 19, 1469: Ferdinand II of Aragon marries Isabella I of Castile, a marriage that paves the way to the unification of Aragon and Castile into a single country, Spain.
October 19, 1512: Martin Luther becomes a doctor of theology.
October 19, 1596: The Spanish ship San Felipe runs aground on the coast of Japan and its cargo is confiscated by local authorities
October 19, 1649: New Ross town in Ireland surrenders to Oliver Cromwell.
October 19, 1789: John Jay is sworn in as the first Chief Justice of the United States.
October 19, 1812: The French invasion of Russia fails when Napoleon begins his retreat from Moscow.
October 19, 1866: In accordance with the Treaty of Vienna, Austria cedes Veneto and Mantua to France, which immediately awards them to Italy in exchange for the earlier Italian acquiescence to the French annexation of Savoy and Nice.
October 19, 1900: Max Planck discovers Planck's law of black-body radiation.
October 19, 1921: The Portuguese Prime Minister and several officials are murdered in the Bloody Night coup.
October 19, 1922: British Conservative MPs vote to terminate the coalition government with the Liberal Party.
October 19, 1933: Konstantin von Neurath withdraws Germany from the League of Nations.
October 19, 1935: The League of Nations places economic sanctions on Italy for its invasion of Ethiopia.
October 19, 1943: Streptomycin, the first antibiotic remedy for tuberculosis, is isolated by researchers at Rutgers University.
October 19, 1944: A coup is launched against Juan Federico Ponce Vaides, beginning the ten-year Guatemalan Revolution
October 19, 1950: Iran becomes the first country to accept technical assistance from the United States under the Point Four Program.
October 19, 1956: The Soviet Union and Japan sign a Joint Declaration, officially ending the state of war between the two countries that had existed since August 1945.
October 19, 1960: The United States imposes a near-total trade embargo against Cuba.
October 19, 1973: President Nixon rejects an Appeals Court decision that he turn over the Watergate tapes.
October 19, 1974: Niue becomes a self-governing colony of New Zealand.
October 19, 1984: A Roman Catholic priest, Jerzy Popiełuszko, associated with the Solidarity Union, is killed by three agents of the Polish Communist internal intelligence agency.
October 19, 1986: The president of Mozambique and a prominent leader of FRELIMO, along with 33 others, die when their aircraft crashes into the Lebombo Mountains.
October 19, 1987: The United States Navy conducts Operation Nimble Archer, an attack on two Iranian oil platforms in the Persian Gulf.
October 19, 1988: The British government imposes a broadcasting ban on television and radio interviews with members of Sinn Féin and eleven Irish republican and Ulster loyalist paramilitary groups.
October 19, 1989: The convictions of the Guildford Four are quashed by the Court of Appeal of England and Wales, after they had spent 15 years in prison.
October 19, 2001: SIEV X, an Indonesian fishing boat en route to Christmas Island, carrying over 400 migrants, sinks in international waters with the loss of 353 people.
October 19, 2003: Mother Teresa is beatified by Pope John Paul II.
October 19, 2005: Hurricane Wilma becomes the most intense Atlantic hurricane on record with a minimum pressure of 882 mb.
October 19, 2012: A bomb explosion kills eight people and injures 110 more in Lebanon.
October 19, 2013: At least 105 people are injured in a train crash in Buenos Aires.
October 20, 1548: The city of La Paz is founded by Alonso de Mendoza.
October 20, 1568: The Spanish Duke of Alba defeats a Dutch rebel force under William the Silent.
October 20, 1720: Caribbean pirate Calico Jack is captured by the Royal Navy.
October 20, 1740: France, Prussia, Bavaria and Saxony refuse to honour the Pragmatic Sanction, and the War of the Austrian Succession begins.
October 20, 1781: The Patent of Toleration, providing limited freedom of worship, is approved in Austria.
October 20, 1803: The United States Senate ratifies the Louisiana Purchase.
October 20, 1818: The Convention of 1818 is signed between the United States and the United Kingdom, which settles the Canada–United States border on the 49th parallel for most of its length.
October 20, 1827: In the Battle of Navarino, a combined Turkish and Egyptian fleet is defeated by British, French and Russian naval forces in the last significant battle fought with wooden sailing ships.
October 20, 1883: Peru and Chile sign the Treaty of Ancón, by which the Tarapacá province is ceded to the latter, bringing an end to Peru's involvement in the War of the Pacific.
October 20, 1904: Chile and Bolivia sign the Treaty of Peace and Friendship, delimiting the border between the two countries.
October 20, 1910: The hull of the RMS Olympic, sister-ship to the ill-fated RMS Titanic, is launched from the Harland and Wolff shipyard in Belfast.
October 20, 1935: The Long March, a mammoth retreat undertaken by the armed forces of the Chinese Communist Party a year prior, ends.
October 20, 1944: American general Douglas MacArthur fulfills his promise to return to the Philippines when he commands an Allied assault on the islands.
October 20, 1947: The House Un-American Activities Committee begins its investigation into Communist infiltration of the Hollywood film industry, resulting in a blacklist that prevents some from working in the industry for years.
October 20, 1951: The "Johnny Bright incident" occurs in Stillwater, Oklahoma.
October 20, 1952: The Governor of Kenya declares a state of emergency and begins arresting hundreds of suspected leaders of the Mau Mau Uprising.
October 20, 1961: The Soviet Union performs the first armed test of a submarine-launched ballistic missile, launching an R-13 from a Golf-class submarine.
October 20, 1962: People's Republic of China launches simultaneous offensives in Ladakh and across the McMahon Line, igniting the Sino-Indian War.
October 20, 1968: Former First Lady Jacqueline Kennedy marries Greek shipping tycoon Aristotle Onassis.
October 20, 1973: The Sydney Opera House is opened by Elizabeth II after 14 years of construction.
October 20, 1976: The ferry George Prince is struck by a ship while crossing the Mississippi River. Seventy-eight passengers and crew die, and only 18 people aboard the ferry survive.
October 20, 1977: Rock band Lynyrd Skynyrd's airplane crashes. Lead singer Ronnie Van Zant and guitarist Steve Gaines perish in the crash.
October 20, 1981: Two police officers and an armored car guard are killed during an armed robbery carried out by members of the Black Liberation Army and Weather Underground.
October 20, 1982: During the UEFA Cup match between FC Spartak Moscow and HFC Haarlem, 66 people are crushed to death in the Luzhniki disaster.
October 20, 1991: A 6.8 Mw earthquake strikes the Uttarkashi region of India, killing more than 1,000 people.
October 21, 1096: A Seljuk Turkish army successfully fight off the People's Crusade.
October 21, 1097: Crusaders led by Godfrey of Bouillon, Bohemund of Taranto, and Raymond IV, Count of Toulouse, begin the Siege of Antioch.
October 21, 1209: Otto IV is crowned emperor of the Holy Roman Empire by Pope Innocent III.
October 21, 1392: Japanese Emperor Go-Kameyama abdicates in favor of rival claimant Go-Komatsu.
October 21, 1512: Martin Luther joins the theological faculty of the University of Wittenberg.
October 21, 1520: João Álvares Fagundes discovers the islands of Saint Pierre and Miquelon, bestowing them their original name of "Islands of the 11,000 Virgins".
October 21, 1600: Tokugawa Ieyasu defeats the leaders of rival Japanese clans in the Battle of Sekigahara and becomes shōgun of Japan.
October 21, 1774: The flag of Taunton, Massachusetts is the first to include the word "Liberty".
October 21, 1797: In Boston Harbor, the 44-gun United States Navy frigate USS Constitution is launched.
October 21, 1854: Florence Nightingale and a staff of 38 nurses are sent to the Crimean War.
October 21, 1867: The Medicine Lodge Treaty is signed by southern Great Plains Indian leaders. The treaty requires Native American Plains tribes to relocate to a reservation in western Oklahoma.
October 21, 1879: Thomas Edison applies for a patent for his design for an incandescent light bulb.
October 21, 1888: Foundation of the Swiss Social Democratic Party.
October 21, 1892: Opening ceremonies for the World's Columbian Exposition are held in Chicago, though because construction was behind schedule, the exposition did not open until May 1, 1893.
October 21, 1895: The Republic of Formosa collapses as Japanese forces invade.
October 21, 1910: HMS Niobe arrives in Halifax Harbour to become the first ship of the Royal Canadian Navy.
October 21, 1921: President Warren G. Harding delivers the first speech by a sitting U.S. President against lynching in the deep South.
October 21, 1931: A secret society in the Imperial Japanese Army launches an abortive coup d'état attempt.
October 21, 1940: The first edition of the Ernest Hemingway novel For Whom the Bell Tolls is published.
October 21, 1945: French women vote for the first time during the 1945 French legislative election.
October 21, 1956: The Mau Mau Uprising in Kenya is defeated.
October 21, 1959: President Eisenhower approves the transfer of all US Army space-related activities to NASA, including most of the Army Ballistic Missile Agency.
October 21, 1965: Comet Ikeya–Seki approaches perihelion, passing 450,000 kilometers (279,617 miles) from the sun.
October 21, 1966: A colliery spoil tip collapses on the village of Aberfan in Wales, killing 144 people, mostly schoolchildren.
October 21, 1967: The National Mobilization Committee to End the War in Vietnam organizes a march of fifty thousand people from the Lincoln Memorial to the Pentagon.
October 21, 1969: The 1969 Somali coup d'état establishes a Marxist–Leninist administration.
October 21, 1971: A gas explosion kills 22 people at a shopping centre near Glasgow, Scotland.
October 21, 1973: Fred Dryer of the Los Angeles Rams becomes the first player in NFL history to score two safeties in the same game.
October 21, 1978: Australian civilian pilot Frederick Valentich vanishes over the Bass Strait south of Melbourne, after reporting contact with an unidentified aircraft.
October 21, 1979: Moshe Dayan resigns from the Israeli government because of strong disagreements with Prime Minister Menachem Begin over policy towards the Arabs.
October 21, 1981: Andreas Papandreou becomes Prime Minister of Greece, ending an almost 50-year-long system of power dominated by conservative forces.
October 21, 1983: The metre is defined as the distance light travels in a vacuum in 1/299,792,458 of a second.
October 21, 1986: In Lebanon, pro-Iran kidnappers claim to have abducted American writer Edward Tracy (he is released in August 1991).
October 21, 1987: The Jaffna hospital massacre is carried out by Indian Peace Keeping Force in Sri Lanka, killing 70 ethnic Tamil patients, doctors and nurses.
October 21, 1994: In Seoul, South Korea, 32 people are killed when a span of the Seongsu Bridge collapses.[1]
October 21, 2005: Images of the dwarf planet Eris are taken and subsequently used in documenting its discovery.
October 22, 451: The Chalcedonian Creed, regarding the divine and human nature of Jesus, is adopted.
October 22, 794: Emperor Kanmu relocates the Japanese capital to Heian-kyō (now Kyoto).
October 22, 906: Ahmad ibn Kayghalagh leads a raid against the Byzantine Empire, taking 4,000–5,000 captives.[1]
October 22, 1383: King Fernando dies without a male heir to the Portuguese throne, sparking a period of civil war and disorder.
October 22, 1575: Foundation of Aguascalientes City in New Spain.
October 22, 1633: The Ming dynasty defeats the Dutch East India Company.
October 22, 1707: Four British naval vessels run aground on the Isles of Scilly because of faulty navigation. In response, the first Longitude Act is enacted in 1714.
October 22, 1730: Construction of the Ladoga Canal is completed.
October 22, 1746: The College of New Jersey (later renamed Princeton University) receives its charter.
October 22, 1784: Russia founds a colony on Kodiak Island, Alaska.
October 22, 1797: André-Jacques Garnerin makes the first recorded parachute jump, from one thousand meters (3,200 feet) above Paris.
October 22, 1836: Sam Houston is inaugurated as the first President of the Republic of Texas.
October 22, 1844: Millerites, followers of anticipate the end of the world in conjunction with the Second Advent of Christ. The following day became known as the Great Disappointment.
October 22, 1866: A plebiscite ratifies the annexion of Veneto and Mantua to Italy, which had occurred three days before, on October 19.
October 22, 1877: The Blantyre mining disaster in Scotland kills 207 miners.
October 22, 1878: The Bramall Lane stadium sees the first rugby match played under floodlights.
October 22, 1879: Using a filament of carbonized thread, Thomas Edison tests the first practical electric incandescent light bulb (it lasts 13½ hours before burning out).
October 22, 1883: The Metropolitan Opera House in New York City opens with a performance of Gounod's Faust.
October 22, 1884: The Royal Observatory in Britain is adopted as the prime meridian of longitude.
October 22, 1895: In Paris an express train derails after overrunning the buffer stop, crossing almost 30 metres (100 ft) of concourse before crashing through a wall and falling 10 metres (33 ft) to the road below.
October 22, 1907: A run on the stock of the Knickerbocker Trust Company sets events in motion that will spark the Panic of 1907.
October 22, 1910: Hawley Harvey Crippen (the first felon to be arrested with the help of radio) is convicted of poisoning his wife.
October 22, 1923: The royalist Leonardopoulos–Gargalidis coup d'état attempt fails in Greece, discrediting the monarchy and paving the way for the establishment of the Second Hellenic Republic.
October 22, 1928: Phi Sigma Alpha fraternity is founded at the University of Puerto Rico.
October 22, 1934: In East Liverpool, Ohio, FBI agents shoot and kill notorious bank robber Pretty Boy Floyd.
October 22, 1946: Operation Osoaviakhim takes place, recruiting of thousands of military-related technical specialists from the Soviet occupation zone of post–World War II Germany for employment in the Soviet Union.
October 22, 1947: The Kashmir conflict between India and Pakistan begins, having started just after the partition of India.
October 22, 1963: A BAC One-Eleven prototype airliner crashes in UK with the loss of all on board.
October 22, 1964: An all-party Parliamentary Committee selects the design which will become the new official flag of Canada.
October 22, 1975: The Soviet unmanned space mission Venera 9 lands on Venus.
October 22, 1976: Red Dye No. 4 is banned by the US Food and Drug Administration after it is discovered that it causes tumors in the bladders of dogs.
October 22, 1981: The United States Federal Labor Relations Authority votes to decertify the Professional Air Traffic Controllers Organization (PATCO) for its strike the previous August.
October 22, 1983: Two correctional officers are killed by inmates at the United States Penitentiary in Marion, Illinois. The incident inspires the Supermax model of prisons.
October 22, 1999: Maurice Papon, an official in the Vichy France government during World War II, is jailed for crimes against humanity.
October 22, 2001: Grand Theft Auto III is released, popularizing a genre of open-world, action-adventure video games, as well as spurring controversy around violence in video games.
October 22, 2005: Bellview Airlines Flight 210 crashes in Nigeria, killing all 117 people on board.
October 22, 2006: A Panama Canal expansion proposal is approved by 77.8% of voters in a National referendum.
October 22, 2007: A raid on Anuradhapura Air Force Base is carried out by 21 Tamil Tiger commandos. All except one die in this attack. Eight Sri Lanka Air Force planes are destroyed and 10 damaged.
October 22, 2008: India launches its first unmanned lunar mission Chandrayaan-1.
October 22, 2013: The Australian Capital Territory becomes the first Australian jurisdiction to legalize same-sex marriage with the Marriage Equality (Same Sex) Act 2013
October 22, 2014: Michael Zehaf-Bibeau attacks the Parliament of Canada, killing a soldier and injuring three other people.
October 23, 425: Valentinian III is elevated as Roman emperor at the age of six.
October 23, 501: The Synodus Palmaris, called by Gothic king Theoderic, absolves Pope Symmachus of all charges, thus ending the schism of Antipope Laurentius.
October 23, 1157: The Battle of Grathe Heath ends a civil war in Denmark.
October 23, 1295: The first treaty forming the Auld Alliance between Scotland and France against England is signed in Paris.
October 23, 1641: Irish Catholic gentry from Ulster attempt to seize control of Dublin Castle, the seat of English rule in Ireland, so as to force concessions.
October 23, 1642: The Battle of Edgehill is the first major battle of the English Civil War.
October 23, 1707: The First Parliament of Great Britain convenes.
October 23, 1739: The War of Jenkins' Ear begins when Prime Minister Walpole reluctantly declares war on Spain.
October 23, 1812: A French general begins a conspiracy to overthrow Napoleon, claiming that the Emperor died in Russia.
October 23, 1850: The first National Women's Rights Convention begins in Worcester, Massachusetts.
October 23, 1906: Alberto Santos-Dumont flies an airplane in the first heavier-than-air flight in Europe.
October 23, 1911: The Italo-Turkish War sees the first use of an airplane in combat when an Italian pilot makes a reconnaissance flight.
October 23, 1939: The Japanese Mitsubishi G4M twin-engine "Betty" Bomber makes its maiden flight.
October 23, 1942: All 12 passengers and crewmen aboard American Airlines Flight 28 are killed when it collides with a USAAF bomber near Palm Springs, California.
October 23, 1955: The people of the Saar region vote in a referendum to unite with Germany instead of France.
October 23, 1956: Secret police shoot several anti-communist protesters, igniting the Hungarian Revolution.
October 23, 1958: Canada's Springhill mining disaster kills seventy-five miners, while ninety-nine others are rescued.
October 23, 1970: Gary Gabelich sets a land speed record in a rocket-powered automobile called the Blue Flame, fueled with natural gas.
October 23, 1982: A gunfight breaks out between police officers and members of a religious cult in Arizona. The shootout leaves two cultists dead and dozens of cultists and police officers injured.
October 23, 1989: Bankruptcy of Wärtsilä Marine; the biggest bankruptcy in the Nordic countries up until then.
October 23, 1991: Signing of the Paris Peace Accords which ends the Cambodian–Vietnamese War.
October 23, 1995: Yolanda Saldívar is found guilty of first-degree murder in the shooting death of popular Latin singer Selena.
October 23, 1998: Israel and the Palestinian Authority sign the Wye River Memorandum.
October 23, 2002: Chechen terrorists seize the House of Culture theater in Moscow and take approximately 700 theater-goers hostage.
October 23, 2004: A powerful earthquake and its aftershocks hit Niigata Prefecture in northern Japan, killing 35 people, injuring 2,200, and leaving 85,000 homeless or evacuated.
October 23, 2007: A storm causes the Mexican Kab 101 oil platform to collide with a wellhead, leading to the death and drowning of 22 people during rescue operations after evacuation of the platform.
October 23, 2011: The Libyan National Transition Council deems the Libyan Civil War over.
October 23, 2012: After 38 years, the world's first teletext service (BBC's Ceefax) ceases broadcast due to Northern Ireland completing the digital switchover.
October 23, 2015: The lowest sea-level pressure in the Western Hemisphere, and the highest reliably-measured non-tornadic sustained winds, are recorded in Hurricane Patricia, which strikes Mexico hours later, killing at least 13 and causing over $280 million in damages.
October 24, AD 69: In the Second Battle of Bedriacum, troops loyal to Vespasian defeat those of Emperor Vitellius.
October 24, 1260: Chartres Cathedral is dedicated in the presence of King Louis IX of France.
October 24, 1360: The Treaty of Brétigny is ratified, marking the end of the first phase of the Hundred Years' War.
October 24, 1590: John White, the governor of the second Roanoke Colony, returns to England after an unsuccessful search for the "lost" colonists.
October 24, 1641: Felim O'Neill of Kinard, the leader of the Irish Rebellion, issues his Proclamation of Dungannon, justifying the uprising and declaring continued loyalty to Charles I.
October 24, 1648: The Peace of Westphalia is signed, marking the end of the Thirty Years' War.
October 24, 1795: Poland is completely consumed by Russia, Prussia and Austria.
October 24, 1851: William Lassell discovers the moons Umbriel and Ariel orbiting Uranus.
October 24, 1857: Sheffield F.C., the world's oldest association football club still in operation, is founded in England.
October 24, 1861: The first transcontinental telegraph line across the United States is completed.
October 24, 1871: An estimated 17 to 20 Chinese immigrants are lynched in Los Angeles, California.
October 24, 1889: Henry Parkes delivers the Tenterfield Oration, effectively starting the federation process in Australia.
October 24, 1901: Annie Edson Taylor becomes the first person to go over Niagara Falls in a barrel.
October 24, 1902: Guatemala's Santa María Volcano begins to erupt, becoming the third-largest eruption of the 20th century.
October 24, 1911: Orville Wright remains in the air nine minutes and 45 seconds in a glider at Kill Devil Hills, North Carolina.
October 24, 1926: Harry Houdini's last performance takes place at the Garrick Theatre in Detroit.
October 24, 1929: "Black Thursday" on the New York Stock Exchange.
October 24, 1930: A bloodless coup d'état in Brazil ends the First Republic, replacing it with the Vargas Era.
October 24, 1931: The George Washington Bridge opens to public traffic over the Hudson River.
October 24, 1945: The United Nations Charter comes into effect.
October 24, 1946: A camera on board the V-2 No. 13 rocket takes the first photograph of earth from outer space.
October 24, 1947: Famed animator Walt Disney testifies before the House Un-American Activities Committee, naming Disney employees he believes to be communists.
October 24, 1949: The cornerstone of the United Nations Headquarters is laid.
October 24, 1954: President Eisenhower pledges United States support to South Vietnam.
October 24, 1956: At the request of the Stalinist regime of Ernő Gerő, a massive Soviet force invades Budapest during the Hungarian Revolution. Imre Nagy is reinstalled as Prime Minister.
October 24, 1957: The United States Air Force starts the X-20 Dyna-Soar manned space program.
October 24, 1960: A ballistic missile explodes on the launch pad in the Soviet Union, killing over 100 people.
October 24, 1963: An oxygen leak from an R-9 Desna missile at the Baikonur Cosmodrome triggers a fire that kills seven people.
October 24, 1964: Northern Rhodesia gains independence from the United Kingdom and becomes Zambia.
October 24, 1975: In Iceland, 90% of women take part in a national strike, refusing to work in protest of gender inequality.
October 24, 1980: The government of Poland legalizes the Solidarity trade union.
October 24, 1986: Nezar Hindawi is sentenced to 45 years in prison, the longest sentence handed down by a British court, for the attempted bombing of an El Al flight at Heathrow Airport.
October 24, 1990: Italian prime minister Giulio Andreotti reveals to the Italian parliament the existence of Gladio, the Italian NATO force formed in 1956, intended to be activated in the event of a Warsaw Pact invasion.
October 24, 1992: The Toronto Blue Jays become the first Major League Baseball team based outside the United States to win the World Series.
October 24, 1998: Deep Space 1 is launched to explore the asteroid belt and test new spacecraft technologies.
October 24, 2002: Police arrest spree killers John Allen Muhammad and Lee Boyd Malvo, ending the Beltway sniper attacks in the area around Washington, D.C.
October 24, 2003: Concorde makes its last commercial flight.
October 24, 2004: Arsenal Football Club loses to Manchester United, ending a row of unbeaten matches at 49 matches, which is the record in the Premier League.
October 24, 2005: Hurricane Wilma makes landfall in Florida, resulting in 35 direct and 26 indirect fatalities and causing $20.6B USD in damage.
October 24, 2007: Chang'e 1, the first satellite in the Chinese Lunar Exploration Program, is launched from Xichang Satellite Launch Center.
October 24, 2008: "Bloody Friday" saw many of the world's stock exchanges experience the worst declines in their history, with drops of around 10% in most indices.
October 24, 2014: The China National Space Administration launches an experimental lunar mission, Chang'e 5-T1, which will loop behind the Moon and return to Earth.
October 24, 2015: A driver crashes into the Oklahoma State Homecoming parade, killing four people and injuring 34.
October 24, 2016: A French surveillance aircraft flying to Libya crashes on takeoff in Malta, killing all five people on board.
October 25, 285 (or 286): Execution of Saints Crispin and Crispinian during the reign of Diocletian, now the patron saints of leather workers, curriers, and shoemakers.
October 25, 473: Emperor Leo I acclaims his grandson Leo II as Caesar of the East Roman Empire.
October 25, 1147: Seljuk Turks defeat German crusaders under Conrad III at the Battle of Dorylaeum.
October 25, 1616: Dutch sea-captain Dirk Hartog makes the second recorded landfall by a European on Australian soil, at the later-named Dirk Hartog Island off the West Australian coast.
October 25, 1854: The Battle of Balaclava takes place during the Crimean War. It is soon memorialized in verse as The Charge of the Light Brigade.
October 25, 1861: The Toronto Stock Exchange is created.
October 25, 1900: The United Kingdom annexes the Transvaal.
October 25, 1917: Old Style date of the October Revolution in Russia.
October 25, 1920: After 74 days on hunger strike in Brixton Prison, England, the Sinn Féin Lord Mayor of Cork, Terence MacSwiney dies.
October 25, 1924: The Zinoviev letter, which Zinoviev himself denied writing, is published in the Daily Mail; the Labour party would later blame this letter for the Conservatives' landslide election win four days later.
October 25, 1927: The Italian luxury liner SS Principessa Mafalda sinks off the coast of Brazil, killing 314.
October 25, 1940: Benjamin O. Davis Sr. is named the first African American general in the United States Army.
October 25, 1945: Fifty years of Japanese administration of Taiwan formally ends when the Republic of China assumes control.
October 25, 1949: The Battle of Guningtou in the Taiwan Strait begins.
October 25, 1971: The People's Republic of China replaces the Republic of China at the United Nations.
October 25, 1973: Egypt and Israel accept United Nations Security Council Resolution 339.
October 25, 1980: Proceedings on the Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction conclude.
October 25, 1983: The United States and its Caribbean allies invade Grenada, six days after Prime Minister Maurice Bishop and several of his supporters are executed in a coup d'état.
October 25, 1995: A commuter train slams into a school bus in Fox River Grove, Illinois, killing seven students.
October 25, 1997: After a brief civil war, Denis Sassou Nguesso proclaims himself President of the Republic of the Congo.
October 25, 2009: The October 2009 Baghdad bombings kill 155 and wounds at least 721.
October 26, 1185: The Uprising of Asen and Peter begins on the feast day of St. Demetrius of Thessaloniki and ends with the creation of the Second Bulgarian Empire.
October 26, 1341: The Byzantine civil war of 1341–47 formally begins with the proclamation of John VI Kantakouzenos as Byzantine Emperor.
October 26, 1377: Tvrtko I is crowned the first king of Bosnia.
October 26, 1520: Charles V is crowned as Holy Roman Emperor.
October 26, 1640: The Treaty of Ripon is signed, restoring peace between Covenanter Scotland and King Charles.
October 26, 1689: General Piccolomini of Austria burns down Skopje to prevent the spread of cholera. He died of cholera himself soon after.
October 26, 1774: The first Continental Congress adjourns in Philadelphia.
October 26, 1825: The Erie Canal opens, allowing direct passage from the Hudson River to Lake Erie.
October 26, 1859: The Royal Charter is wrecked on the coast of Anglesey with 459 dead.
October 26, 1860: The Expedition of the Thousand ends when Giuseppe Garibaldi presents his conquests to King Victor Emmanuel of Sardinia.
October 26, 1905: King Oscar II recognizes the dissolution of the union between Norway and Sweden.
October 26, 1909: An Jung-geun assassinates Japan's Resident-General of Korea.
October 26, 1918: Erich Ludendorff, quartermaster-general of the Imperial German Army, is dismissed by Kaiser Wilhelm II for refusing to cooperate in peace negotiations.
October 26, 1936: The first electric generator at Hoover Dam goes into full operation.
October 26, 1955: Ngô Đình Diệm declares himself Premier of South Vietnam.
October 26, 1958: Pan American Airways makes the first commercial flight of the Boeing 707 from New York City to Paris.
October 26, 1967: Mohammad Reza Pahlavi crowns himself Emperor of Iran.
October 26, 1968: Soviet cosmonaut Georgy Beregovoy pilots Soyuz 3 into space for a four-day mission.
October 26, 1970: Muhammad Ali boxes for the first time after Ali's three-year hiatus due to draft evasion.
October 26, 1977: Ali Maow Maalin, the last natural case of smallpox, develops a rash in Somalia. The World Health Organization and the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention consider this date to be the anniversary of the eradication of smallpox, the most spectacular success of vaccination.
October 26, 1979: Park Chung-hee, President of South Korea, is assassinated by Korean CIA head Kim Jae-gyu.
October 26, 1985: The Australian government returns ownership of Uluru to the local Pitjantjatjara Aboriginals.
October 26, 1991: Three months after the end of the Ten-Day War, the last soldier of the Yugoslav People's Army leaves the territory of the Republic of Slovenia.
October 26, 1994: Jordan and Israel sign a peace treaty.
October 26, 1995: Mossad agents assassinate Islamic Jihad leader Fathi Shaqaqi in his hotel in Malta.
October 26, 1999: Britain's House of Lords votes to end the right of hereditary peers to vote in Britain's upper chamber of Parliament.
October 26, 2000: A wave of protests forces Robert Guéï to step down as president after the Ivorian presidential election.
October 26, 2001: The United States passes the USA PATRIOT Act into law.
October 26, 2002: Approximately 50 Chechen terrorists and 150 hostages die when Russian special forces troops storm a theater building in Moscow, which had been occupied by the terrorists during a musical performance three days before.
October 26, 2003: The Cedar Fire, the third-largest fire in California history, kills 15 people, consumes 250,000 acres (1,000 km2), and destroys 2,200 homes around San Diego.
October 26, 2015: A 7.5 magnitude earthquake strikes in the Hindu Kush mountain range in northeastern Afghanistan, killing 398 people and leaving 2,536 people injured.
October 26, 2016: An earthquake of magnitude 6.6 strikes central Italy.
October 27, 312: Constantine is said to have received his famous Vision of the Cross.
October 27, 939: Æthelstan, the first king of all England, dies and is succeeded by his half-brother, Edmund I.
October 27, 1275: Traditional founding of the city of Amsterdam.
October 27, 1524: French troops lay siege to Pavia.
October 27, 1553: Condemned as a heretic, Michael Servetus is burned at the stake just outside Geneva.
October 27, 1644: Second Battle of Newbury in the English Civil War.
October 27, 1682: Philadelphia is founded in the Commonwealth of Pennsylvania.
October 27, 1775: King George III expands on his Proclamation of Rebellion in the Thirteen Colonies in his speech from the throne at the opening of Parliament.[1]
October 27, 1795: The United States and Spain sign the Treaty of Madrid, which establishes the boundaries between Spanish colonies and the U.S.
October 27, 1806: The French Army enters Berlin, following the Battle of Jena–Auerstedt.
October 27, 1810: United States annexes the former Spanish colony of West Florida.
October 27, 1838: Missouri governor Lilburn Boggs issues the Extermination Order, which orders all Mormons to leave the state or be killed.
October 27, 1904: The first underground New York City Subway line opens, later designated as the IRT Broadway–Seventh Avenue Line.
October 27, 1907: Fifteen people are killed in Hungary when a gunman opens fire on a crowd gathered at a church consecration.
October 27, 1916: Negus Mikael, marching on the Ethiopian capital in support of his son Emperor Iyasu V, is defeated by Fitawrari abte Giyorgis, securing the throne for Empress Zewditu I.
October 27, 1922: A referendum in Rhodesia rejects the country's annexation to the South African Union.
October 27, 1924: The Uzbek SSR is founded in the Soviet Union.
October 27, 1930: Ratifications exchanged in London for the first London Naval Treaty go into effect immediately, further limiting the expensive naval arms race among its five signatories.
October 27, 1936: Mrs Wallis Simpson obtains her divorce, which would eventually allow her to marry King Edward VIII of the United Kingdom, thus forcing his abdication from the throne.
October 27, 1954: Benjamin O. Davis, Jr. becomes the first African-American general in the United States Air Force.
October 27, 1958: Iskander Mirza, the first President of Pakistan, is deposed by General Ayub Khan, who had been appointed the enforcer of martial law by Mirza 20 days earlier.
October 27, 1961: NASA tests the first Saturn I rocket in Mission Saturn-Apollo 1.
October 27, 1962: A aircraft carrying Enrico Mattei, post-war Italian administrator, crashes in mysterious circumstances.
October 27, 1964: Ronald Reagan delivers a speech on behalf of the Republican candidate for president, Barry Goldwater. The speech launches his political career and comes to be known as "A Time for Choosing".
October 27, 1967: Catholic priest Philip Berrigan and others of the 'Baltimore Four' protest the Vietnam War by pouring blood on Selective Service records.
October 27, 1971: The Democratic Republic of the Congo is renamed Zaire.
October 27, 1979: Saint Vincent and the Grenadines gains its independence from the United Kingdom.
October 27, 1986: The British government suddenly deregulates financial markets, leading to a total restructuring of the way in which they operate in the country, in an event now referred to as the Big Bang.
October 27, 1991: Turkmenistan achieves independence from the Soviet Union.
October 27, 1992: United States Navy radioman Allen R. Schindler, Jr. is murdered by shipmate Terry M. Helvey for being gay, precipitating debate about gays in the military that results in the United States' "Don't ask, don't tell" military policy.
October 27, 1994: Gliese 229B is the first Substellar Mass Object to be unquestionably identified.
October 27, 1995: Former Prime Minister of Italy Bettino Craxi is convicted in absentia of corruption.
October 27, 1997: The 1997 Asian financial crisis causes a crash in the Dow Jones Industrial Average.
October 27, 1999: Gunmen open fire in the Armenian Parliament, killing the Prime Minister  and seven others.
October 27, 2004: The Boston Red Sox defeat the St. Louis Cardinals to win their first World Series in 86 years.
October 27, 2014: Britain withdraws from Afghanistan at the end of Operation Herrick, after 12 years four months and seven days.
October 27, 2018: A gunman opens fire on a Pittsburgh synagogue killing 11 and injuring 6, including 4 police officers.
October 28, AD 97: Emperor Nerva is forced by the Praetorian Guard to adopt general Marcus Ulpius Trajanus as his heir and successor.
October 28, 312: Constantine I defeats Maxentius, becoming the sole Roman emperor in the West.
October 28, 969: The Byzantine Empire recovers Antioch from Arab rule.
October 28, 1344: The lower town of Smyrna is captured by Crusaders in response to Aydınid piracy.
October 28, 1420: Beijing is officially designated the capital of the Ming dynasty when the Forbidden City is completed.
October 28, 1449: Christian I is crowned king of Denmark.
October 28, 1453: Ladislaus the Posthumous is crowned king of Bohemia in Prague.
October 28, 1492: Christopher Columbus lands in Cuba on his first voyage to the New World.
October 28, 1538: The Universidad Santo Tomás de Aquino is founded in what is now the Dominican Republic.
October 28, 1636: The Massachusetts Bay Colony votes to establish a theological college, which would later become Harvard University.
October 28, 1664: The Duke of York and Albany's Maritime Regiment of Foot, later to be known as the Royal Marines, is established.
October 28, 1707: The 1707 Hōei earthquake causes more than 5,000 deaths in Japan.
October 28, 1726: The novel Gulliver's Travels is published.
October 28, 1834: The Pinjarra massacre occurs in the Swan River Colony. An estimated 30 Noongar people are killed by British colonists.
October 28, 1835: The United Tribes of New Zealand are established with the signature of the Declaration of Independence.
October 28, 1886: President Cleveland dedicates the Statue of Liberty.
October 28, 1891: The Mino–Owari earthquake is the largest inland earthquake in Japan's history.
October 28, 1893: Tchaikovsky's Symphony No. 6 in B Minor, Pathétique receives its première performance only nine days before the composer's death.
October 28, 1919: The U.S. Congress passes the Volstead Act over President Wilson's veto, paving the way for Prohibition to begin the following January.
October 28, 1922: Italian fascists led by Benito Mussolini march on Rome and take over the Italian government.
October 28, 1928: The Indonesia Raya, now the national anthem, is first sung.
October 28, 1942: The Alaska Highway first connects Alaska to the North American railway network at Dawson Creek in Canada.
October 28, 1948: Paul Müller is awarded the Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine for his discovery of the insecticidal properties of DDT.
October 28, 1949: An Air France Lockheed Constellation crashes in the Azores, killing all 48 people on board.
October 28, 1956: Elvis Presley receives a polio vaccination on national TV.
October 28, 1965: Pope Paul VI promulgates Nostra aetate, by which the Church officially recognizes the legitimacy of non-Christian faiths.
October 28, 1971: Prospero becomes the only British satellite to be launched by a British rocket.
October 28, 1982: The Spanish general election begins fourteen years of rule by the Spanish Socialist Workers' Party.
October 28, 1990: Georgia holds its only free election under Soviet rule.
October 28, 1995: The Baku Metro fire sees 289 people killed and 270 injured.
October 28, 2005: Vice-president Cheney's chief of staff is indicted due to his involvement in the Plame affair.
October 28, 2006: A funeral service takes place at the Bykivnia graves for those Ukrainians who were killed by the Soviet secret police.
October 28, 2007: Cristina Fernández de Kirchner becomes the first woman elected President of Argentina.
October 28, 2009: NASA successfully launches the Ares I-X mission, the only rocket launch for its short-lived Constellation program.
October 28, 2013: Five people are killed and 38 are injured after a car crashes into barriers at the Tiananmen Square in China.
October 28, 2014: A rocket carrying NASA's Cygnus CRS Orb-3 resupply mission to the International Space Station explodes seconds after taking off from the Mid-Atlantic Regional Spaceport in Virginia.
October 29, 539 BC: Cyrus the Great (founder of Persian Empire) entered the capital of Babylon and allowed the Jews to return to their land.
October 29, 312: Constantine the Great enters Rome after his victory at the Battle of the Milvian Bridge, stages a grand adventus in the city, and is met with popular jubilation. Maxentius' body is fished out of the Tiber and beheaded.
October 29, 437: Valentinian III, Western Roman Emperor, marries Licinia Eudoxia, daughter of his cousin Theodosius II, Eastern Roman Emperor in Constantinople unifying the two branches of the House of Theodosius.
October 29, 1268: Conradin is executed along with his companion Frederick I, Margrave of Baden by Charles I of Sicily.
October 29, 1390: First trial for witchcraft in Paris leading to the death of three people.
October 29, 1611: Russian homage to the King of Poland, Sigismund III Vasa.
October 29, 1618: English adventurer, writer, and courtier Sir Walter Raleigh is beheaded for allegedly conspiring against James I of England.
October 29, 1665: Portuguese forces defeat the Kingdom of Kongo and decapitate King António I of Kongo, also known as Nvita a Nkanga.
October 29, 1675: Leibniz makes the first use of the long s (∫) as a symbol of the integral in calculus.
October 29, 1787: Mozart's opera Don Giovanni receives its first performance in Prague.
October 29, 1792: Mount Hood (Oregon) is named after Samuel Hood, 1st Viscount Hood by Lt. William E. Broughton who sighted the mountain near the mouth of the Willamette River.
October 29, 1863: Eighteen countries meet in Geneva and agree to form the International Red Cross.
October 29, 1888: The Convention of Constantinople is signed, guaranteeing free maritime passage through the Suez Canal during war and peace.
October 29, 1901: Leon Czolgosz, the assassin of U.S. President William McKinley, is executed by electrocution.
October 29, 1914: Ottoman entry into World War I.
October 29, 1918: The German High Seas Fleet is incapacitated when sailors mutiny on the night of the 29th-30th, an action which would trigger the German Revolution of 1918–19.
October 29, 1921: The Harvard University football team loses to Centre College, ending a 25-game winning streak. This is considered one of the biggest upsets in college football.
October 29, 1922: King Victor Emmanuel III of Italy appoints Benito Mussolini as Prime Minister.
October 29, 1923: Turkey becomes a republic following the dissolution of the Ottoman Empire.
October 29, 1929: The New York Stock Exchange crashes in what will be called the Crash of '29 or "Black Tuesday", ending the Great Bull Market of the 1920s and beginning the Great Depression.
October 29, 1944: The Dutch city of Breda is liberated by 1st Polish Armoured Division.
October 29, 1953: BCPA Flight 304 DC-6 crashes near San Francisco.
October 29, 1955: The Soviet battleship Novorossiysk strikes a World War II mine in the harbor at Sevastopol.
October 29, 1957: Israel's prime minister David Ben-Gurion and five of his ministers are injured when Moshe Dwek throws a grenade into Israel's Knesset.
October 29, 1960: An airplane carrying the Cal Poly football team crashes on takeoff in Toledo, Ohio.
October 29, 1961: Syria exits from the United Arab Republic.
October 29, 1964: A collection of irreplaceable gems, including the 565 carat (113 g) Star of India, is stolen by a group of thieves (among them is "Murph the surf") from the American Museum of Natural History in New York City.
October 29, 1967: Montreal's World Fair, Expo 67, closes with over 50 million visitors.
October 29, 1969: The first-ever computer-to-computer link is established on ARPANET, the precursor to the Internet.
October 29, 1971: In Macon, Georgia, guitarist Duane Allman is killed in a motorcycle accident.
October 29, 1972: The three surviving perpetrators of the Munich massacre are released from prison in exchange for the hostages of hijacked Lufthansa Flight 615.
October 29, 1980: Demonstration flight of a secretly modified C-130 for an Iran hostage crisis rescue attempt ends in crash landing at Eglin Air Force Base's Duke Field, Florida leading to cancellation of Operation Credible Sport.
October 29, 1985: Major General Samuel K. Doe is announced the winner of the first multi-party election in Liberia.
October 29, 1986: British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher opens the last stretch of the M25 motorway.
October 29, 1991: The American Galileo spacecraft makes its closest approach to 951 Gaspra, becoming the first probe to visit an asteroid.
October 29, 1994: Francisco Martin Duran fires over two dozen shots at the White House; he is later convicted of trying to kill US President Bill Clinton.
October 29, 1998: The Gothenburg discothèque fire in Sweden kills 63 and injures 200.
October 29, 1999: A large cyclone devastates Odisha, India.
October 29, 2002: Ho Chi Minh City ITC fire, a fire destroys a luxurious department store where 1500 people are shopping. Over 60 people die and over 100 are unaccounted for. It is the deadliest disaster in Vietnam during peacetime.
October 29, 2004: The Arabic-language news network Al Jazeera broadcasts an excerpt from a 2004 Osama bin Laden video in which the terrorist leader first admits direct responsibility for the September 11, 2001 attacks and references the 2004 U.S. presidential election.
October 29, 2005: Bombings in Delhi, India kill more than 60.
October 29, 2008: Delta Air Lines merges with Northwest Airlines, creating the world's largest airline and reducing the number of US legacy carriers to five.
October 29, 2012: Hurricane Sandy hits the east coast of the United States, killing 148 directly and 138 indirectly, while leaving nearly $70 billion in damages and causing major power outages.
October 29, 2015: China announces the end of One-child policy after 35 years.
October 30, 758: Guangzhou is sacked by Arab and Persian pirates.
October 30, 1137: Ranulf of Apulia defeats Roger II of Sicily at the Battle of Rignano, securing his position as duke until his death two years later.
October 30, 1270: The Eighth Crusade ends by an agreement between Charles I of Anjou (replacing his deceased brother King Louis IX of France) and the Hafsid dynasty of Tunis, Tunisia.
October 30, 1485: King Henry VII of England is crowned, beginning the Tudor reign.
October 30, 1817: Simón Bolívar becomes President of the Third Republic of Venezuela.
October 30, 1831: Nat Turner is arrested for leading the bloodiest slave rebellion in United States history.
October 30, 1863: Danish Prince Vilhelm arrives in Athens to assume his throne as George I, King of the Hellenes.
October 30, 1864: The Treaty of Vienna is signed, by which Denmark relinquishes one province each to Prussia and Austria.
October 30, 1888: The Rudd Concession is granted by Matabeleland to agents of Cecil Rhodes.
October 30, 1905: Czar Nicholas II issues the October Manifesto, granting the Russian peoples basic civil liberties and the right to form a duma. (October 17 in the Julian calendar)
October 30, 1920: The Communist Party of Australia is founded in Sydney.
October 30, 1925: John Logie Baird creates Britain's first television transmitter.
October 30, 1938: Orson Welles broadcasts his radio play of H. G. Wells's The War of the Worlds, causing anxiety in some of the audience in the United States.
October 30, 1941: President Roosevelt approves $1 billion in Lend-Lease aid to the Allied nations.
October 30, 1945: Jackie Robinson of the Kansas City Monarchs signs a contract for the Brooklyn Dodgers, breaking the baseball color line.
October 30, 1947: The General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade is founded.
October 30, 1953: President Eisenhower approves the top-secret document NSC 162/2 concerning the maintenance of a strong nuclear deterrent force against the Soviet Union.
October 30, 1961: Due to "violations of Vladimir Lenin's precepts", it is decreed that Joseph Stalin's body be removed from inside Lenin's tomb and buried nearby with a plain marker instead.
October 30, 1973: The Bosphorus Bridge in Turkey is completed, connecting the continents of Europe and Asia over the Bosphorus for the second time.
October 30, 1974: The Rumble in the Jungle boxing match between Muhammad Ali and George Foreman takes place in Zaire.
October 30, 1975: Prince Juan Carlos I of Spain becomes acting head of state, taking over for the country's ailing dictator, Gen. Francisco Franco.
October 30, 1980: El Salvador and Honduras agree to put the border dispute fought over in 1969's Football War before the International Court of Justice.
October 30, 1983: The first democratic elections in Argentina, after seven years of military rule, are held.
October 30, 1985: Space Shuttle Challenger lifts off for mission STS-61-A, its final successful mission.
October 30, 1995: Quebec citizens narrowly vote (50.58% to 49.42%) in favour of remaining a province of Canada in their second referendum on national sovereignty.
October 30, 2005: The rebuilt Dresden Frauenkirche (destroyed in the firebombing of Dresden during World War II) is reconsecrated after a thirteen-year rebuilding project.
October 30, 2014: Sweden is the first European Union member state to officially recognize the State of Palestine.
October 30, 2015: Sixty-four people are killed and more than 147 injuries after a fire in a nightclub in the Romanian capital Bucharest.
October 31, 475: Romulus Augustulus is proclaimed Western Roman Emperor.
October 31, 683: During the Siege of Mecca, the Kaaba catches fire and is burned down.
October 31, 802: Empress Irene is deposed and banished to Lesbos. Conspirators place Nikephoros, the minister of finance, on the Byzantine throne.
October 31, 932: Abbasid caliph al-Muqtadir is killed while fighting against the forces of general Mu'nis al-Muzaffar. Al-Muqtadir's brother al-Qahir is chosen to succeed him.
October 31, 1587: Leiden University Library opens its doors after its founding in 1575.
October 31, 1614: First performance of Ben Jonson's comedy Bartholomew Fair by the Lady Elizabeth's Men company at the Hope Theatre in London.
October 31, 1822: Emperor Agustín de Iturbide attempts to dissolve the Congress of the Mexican Empire.
October 31, 1863: The New Zealand Wars resume as British forces in New Zealand led by General Duncan Cameron begin their Invasion of the Waikato.
October 31, 1864: Nevada is admitted as the 36th U.S. state.
October 31, 1903: The Purdue Wreck, a railroad train collision in Indianapolis, kills 17 people, including 14 players of the Purdue University football team.
October 31, 1913: The Indianapolis Streetcar Strike and subsequent riot begins.
October 31, 1922: Benito Mussolini is made Prime Minister of Italy
October 31, 1923: The first of 160 consecutive days of 100° Fahrenheit at Marble Bar, Western Australia.
October 31, 1924: World Savings Day is announced in Milan, Italy by the Members of the Association at the 1st International Savings Bank Congress (World Society of Savings Banks).
October 31, 1926: Last issue of the independent Italian newspaper Il Mondo, thereafter suppressed by the Mussolini regime
October 31, 1941: After 14 years of work, Mount Rushmore is completed.
October 31, 1961: In the Soviet Union, Joseph Stalin's body is removed from the Lenin's Mausoleum, also known as the Lenin Tomb.
October 31, 1963: A propane tank explosion at the Indiana State Fair Coliseum (now the Indiana Farmers Coliseum) in Indianapolis kills 74 people and injures another 400 during an ice skating show.
October 31, 1973: Mountjoy Prison helicopter escape. Three Provisional Irish Republican Army members escape from Mountjoy Prison, Dublin aboard a hijacked helicopter that landed in the exercise yard.
October 31, 1979: Western Airlines Flight 2605 crashes on landing in Mexico City, killing 73 people.
October 31, 1984: Indian Prime Minister Indira Gandhi is assassinated by two Sikh security guards. Riots break out in New Delhi and other cities and around 3,000 Sikhs are killed.
October 31, 1996: TAM Transportes Aéreos Regionais Flight 402 crashes in São Paulo, Brazil, killing 99 people.
October 31, 1999: EgyptAir Flight 990 crashes into the Atlantic Ocean near Nantucket, killing all 217 people on board.
October 31, 2000: Singapore Airlines Flight 006 crashes on takeoff from Taipei, killing 83.
October 31, 2002: A federal grand jury in Houston, Texas indicts former Enron chief financial officer Andrew Fastow on 78 counts of wire fraud, money laundering, conspiracy and obstruction of justice related to the collapse of his ex-employer.
October 31, 2003: Mahathir bin Mohamad resigns as Prime Minister of Malaysia and is replaced by Deputy Prime Minister Abdullah Ahmad Badawi, marking an end to Mahathir's 22 years in power.
October 31, 2011: The global population of humans reaches seven billion. This day is now recognized by the United Nations as the Day of Seven Billion.
October 31, 2014: During a test flight, the VSS Enterprise, a Virgin Galactic experimental spaceflight test vehicle, suffers a catastrophic in-flight breakup and crashes in the Mojave Desert, California,
October 31, 2015: Metrojet Flight 9268 is bombed over the northern Sinai Peninsula, killing all 224 people on board.
October 31, 2017: A truck drives in a crowd of people in Lower Manhattan, killing eight people.
October 31, 2018: The Statue of Unity was inaugurated in the state of Gujarat
October 31, 2019: The UK’s membership of the European Union is expected to cease in accordance with Article 50 following the outcome of their EU membership referendum on June 23 2016 after being delayed twice from March 29 and April 12.
November 1, 365: The Alemanni cross the Rhine and invade Gaul. Emperor Valentinian I moves to Paris to command the army and defend the Gallic cities.
November 1, 996: Emperor Otto III issues a deed to Gottschalk, Bishop of Freising, which is the oldest known document using the name Ostarrîchi (Austria in Old High German).
November 1, 1009: Berber forces led by Sulayman ibn al-Hakam defeat the Umayyad caliph Muhammad II of Córdoba in the battle of Alcolea.
November 1, 1141: Empress Matilda's reign as 'Lady of the English' ends with Stephen of Blois regaining the title of 'King of England'.
November 1, 1179: Philip II is crowned as 'King of France'.
November 1, 1214: The port city of Sinope surrenders to the Seljuq Turks.
November 1, 1348: The anti-royalist Union of Valencia attacks the Jews of Murviedro on the pretext that they are serfs of the King of Valencia and thus "royalists".
November 1, 1512: The ceiling of the Sistine Chapel, painted by Michelangelo, is exhibited to the public for the first time.
November 1, 1520: The Strait of Magellan, the passage immediately south of mainland South America connecting the Pacific and the Atlantic Oceans, is first discovered and navigated by European explorer Ferdinand Magellan during the first recorded circumnavigation voyage.
November 1, 1555: French Huguenots establish the France Antarctique colony in present-day Rio de Janeiro, Brazil.
November 1, 1570: The All Saints' Flood devastates the Dutch coast.
November 1, 1604: William Shakespeare's tragedy Othello is performed for the first time, at Whitehall Palace in London.
November 1, 1611: Shakespeare's play The Tempest is performed for the first time, at Whitehall Palace in London.
November 1, 1612: During the Time of Troubles, Polish troops are expelled from Moscow's Kitay-gorod by Russian troops under the command of Dmitry Pozharsky (22 October O.S.) .
November 1, 1683: The British Crown colony of New York is subdivided into 12 counties.
November 1, 1688: William III of Orange sets out a second time from Hellevoetsluis in the Netherlands to seize the crowns of England, Scotland and Ireland from King James II of England during the Glorious Revolution.
November 1, 1755: In Portugal, Lisbon is totally devastated by a massive earthquake and tsunami, killing between 60,000 and 90,000 people.
November 1, 1765: The British Parliament enacts the Stamp Act on the Thirteen Colonies in order to help pay for British military operations in North America.
