December 26, 2004: The 9.1–9.3 Mw  Indian Ocean earthquake shakes northern Sumatra with a maximum Mercalli intensity of IX (Violent). One of the largest observed tsunamis follows, affecting the coastal areas of Thailand, India, Sri Lanka, the Maldives, Malaysia, Myanmar, Bangladesh, and Indonesia; death toll is estimated at 227,898.
December 26, 2009: China opens the world's longest high-speed rail route, which links Beijing and Guangzhou.
December 26, 2015: During the December 2015 North American storm complex, a Tornado Outbreak occurred in the DFW Metroplex, with the most notable tornadoes being an EF2, EF3, and an EF4. About a dozen people died due to various reasons, 10 of which due to the EF4, which did substantial damage to the suburb of Rowlett.
December 27, 537: The construction of the Hagia Sophia in Constantinople is completed.
December 27, 1512: The Spanish Crown issues the Laws of Burgos, governing the conduct of settlers with regard to native Indians in the New World.
December 27, 1521: The Zwickau prophets arrive in Wittenberg, disturbing the peace and preaching the Apocalypse.
December 27, 1657: The Flushing Remonstrance articulates for the first time in North American history that freedom of religion is a fundamental right.
December 27, 1703: Portugal and England sign the Methuen Treaty which gives preference to Portuguese imported wines into England.
December 27, 1831: Charles Darwin embarks on his journey aboard HMS Beagle, during which he will begin to formulate his theory of evolution.
December 27, 1836: The worst ever avalanche in England occurs at Lewes, Sussex, killing eight people.
December 27, 1845: Journalist John L. O'Sullivan, writing in his newspaper the New York Morning News, argues that the United States had the right to claim the entire Oregon Country "by the right of our manifest destiny".
December 27, 1911: "Jana Gana Mana", the national anthem of India, is first sung in the Calcutta Session of the Indian National Congress.
December 27, 1918: The Great Poland Uprising against the Germans begins.
December 27, 1922: Japanese aircraft carrier Hōshō becomes the first purpose built aircraft carrier to be commissioned in the world.
December 27, 1927: Kern and Hammerstein's musical play Show Boat, considered to be the first true American musical play, opens at the Ziegfeld Theatre on Broadway.
December 27, 1929: Soviet General Secretary Joseph Stalin orders the "liquidation of the kulaks as a class".
December 27, 1932: Radio City Music Hall, "Showplace of the Nation", opens in New York City.
December 27, 1935: Regina Jonas is ordained as the first female rabbi in the history of Judaism.
December 27, 1939: The 7.8 Mw  Erzincan earthquake shakes eastern Turkey with a maximum Mercalli intensity of XI (Extreme). At least 32,700 people were killed.
December 27, 1945: The International Monetary Fund is created with the signing of an agreement by 29 nations.
December 27, 1966: The Cave of Swallows, the largest known cave shaft in the world, is discovered in Aquismón, San Luis Potosí, Mexico.
December 27, 1978: Spain becomes a democracy after 40 years of fascist dictatorship.
December 27, 1979: The Soviet Union invades the Democratic Republic of Afghanistan.
December 27, 1983: Pope John Paul II visits Mehmet Ali Ağca in Rebibbia's prison and personally forgives him for the 1981 attack on him in St. Peter's Square.
December 27, 1985: Palestinian guerrillas kill eighteen people inside the airports of Rome, Italy, and Vienna, Austria.
December 27, 1989: The Romanian Revolution concludes, as the last minor street confrontations and stray shootings abruptly end in the country's capital, Bucharest.
December 27, 1996: Taliban forces retake the strategic Bagram Airfield which solidifies their buffer zone around Kabul, Afghanistan.
December 27, 1997: Protestant paramilitary leader Billy Wright is assassinated in Northern Ireland, United Kingdom.
December 27, 2002: Two truck bombs kill 72 and wound 200 at the pro-Moscow headquarters of the Chechen government in Grozny, Chechnya, Russia.
December 27, 2004: Radiation from an explosion on the magnetar SGR 1806-20 reaches Earth. It is the brightest extrasolar event known to have been witnessed on the planet.
December 27, 2007: Riots erupt in Mombasa, Kenya, after Mwai Kibaki is declared the winner of the presidential election, triggering a political, economic, and humanitarian crisis.
December 28, 169 BC: The menorah is lit to rededicate the Holy Temple of Jerusalem after two centuries of foreign rule and religious oppression and a seven-year revolt. The menorah burns for eight days without the sufficient fuel needed to do so, birthing the holiday Hanukkah.
December 28, 457: Majorian is acclaimed emperor of the Western Roman Empire and recognized by Emperor Leo I the Thracian.
December 28, 484: Alaric II succeeds his father Euric and becomes king of the Visigoths. He establishes his capital at Aire-sur-l'Adour (Southern Gaul).
December 28, 893: An earthquake destroys the city of Dvin, Armenia.
December 28, 1065: Edward the Confessor's Romanesque monastic church at Westminster Abbey is consecrated.[1]
December 28, 1308: The reign of Emperor Hanazono of Japan begins.
December 28, 1659: The Marathas defeat the Adilshahi forces in the Battle of Kolhapur.
December 28, 1768: King Taksin's coronation achieved through conquest as a king of Thailand and established Thonburi as a capital.
December 28, 1795: Construction of Yonge Street, formerly recognized as the longest street in the world, begins in York, Upper Canada (present-day Toronto).
December 28, 1832: John C. Calhoun becomes the first Vice President of the United States to resign.
December 28, 1835: Osceola leads his Seminole warriors in Florida into the Second Seminole War against the United States Army.
December 28, 1836: Spain recognizes the independence of Mexico with the signing of the Santa María–Calatrava Treaty.
December 28, 1846: Iowa is admitted as the 29th U.S. state.
December 28, 1885: Indian National Congress, a political party of India, is founded in Bombay Presidency, British India.
December 28, 1895: Wilhelm Röntgen publishes a paper detailing his discovery of a new type of radiation, which later will be known as x-rays.
December 28, 1902: The Syracuse Athletic Club defeated the New York Philadelphians, 5–0, in the first indoor professional football game, which was held at Madison Square Garden.
December 28, 1908: The 7.1 Mw  Messina earthquake shakes Southern Italy with a maximum Mercalli intensity of XI (Extreme), killing between 75,000 and 200,000.
December 28, 1912: The first municipally owned streetcars take to the streets in San Francisco.
December 28, 1918: Constance Markievicz, while detained in Holloway prison, became the first woman to be elected MP to the British House of Commons.
December 28, 1943: Soviet authorities launch operation Operation Ulussy, beginning the deportation of the Kalmyk nation to Siberia and Central Asia.
December 28, 1944: Maurice Richard becomes the first player to score eight points in one game of NHL ice hockey.
December 28, 1948: The DC-3 airliner NC16002 disappears 50 miles south of Miami.
December 28, 1956: Chin Peng, David Marshall and Tunku Abdul Rahman meet in Baling, Malaya to try and resolve the Malayan Emergency situation.
December 28, 1967: Muriel Siebert becomes the first woman to own a seat on the New York Stock Exchange.
December 28, 1973: The United States Endangered Species Act is signed into law by Pres. Richard Nixon.
December 28, 1989: A magnitude 5.6 earthquake hits Newcastle, New South Wales, Australia, killing 13 people.
December 28, 2009: Forty-three people die in a suicide bombing in Karachi, Pakistan, where Shia Muslims are observing the Day of Ashura.
December 28, 2014: Nine people die and another 19 are reported missing, when the MS Norman Atlantic catches fire in the Strait of Otranto, in the Adriatic Sea, in Italian waters.
December 29, 875: Charles the Bald, King of the Franks, is crowned as Holy Roman Emperor Charles II.
December 29, 1170: Thomas Becket, Archbishop of Canterbury, is assassinated inside Canterbury Cathedral by followers of King Henry II; he subsequently becomes a saint and martyr in the Anglican Communion and the Catholic Church.
December 29, 1427: The Ming army begins its withdraw from Hanoi, ending the Chinese domination of Đại Việt.
December 29, 1503: The Battle of Garigliano (1503) was fought between a Spanish army under Gonzalo Fernández de Córdoba and a French army commanded by Ludovico II, Marquess of Saluzzo
December 29, 1508: Portuguese forces under the command of Francisco de Almeida attack Khambhat at the Battle of Dabul.
December 29, 1812: USS Constitution, under the command of Captain William Bainbridge, captures HMS Java off the coast of Brazil after a three-hour battle.
December 29, 1835: The Treaty of New Echota is signed, ceding all the lands of the Cherokee east of the Mississippi River to the United States.
December 29, 1845: In accordance with International Boundary delimitation, the United States annexes the Republic of Texas, following the manifest destiny doctrine. The Republic of Texas, which had been independent since the Texas Revolution of 1836, is thereupon admitted as the 28th U.S. state.
December 29, 1851: The first American YMCA opens in Boston, Massachusetts.
December 29, 1860: The launch of HMS Warrior, with her combination of screw propeller, iron hull and iron armour, renders all previous warships obsolete.
December 29, 1874: The military coup of Gen. Martinez Campos in Sagunto ends the failed First Spanish Republic and the monarchy is restored as Prince Alfonso is proclaimed King of Spain.
December 29, 1876: The Ashtabula River railroad disaster occurs, leaving 64 injured and 92 dead at Ashtabula, Ohio.
December 29, 1890: Wounded Knee Massacre on Pine Ridge Indian Reservation, 300 Lakota are killed by the United States 7th Cavalry Regiment.
December 29, 1911: Sun Yat-sen becomes the provisional President of the Republic of China; he formally takes office on January 1, 1912.
December 29, 1916: A Portrait of the Artist as a Young Man, the first novel by James Joyce, was first published as a book by an American publishing house B. W. Huebschis after it had been serialized in The Egoist (1914–15).
December 29, 1930: Sir Muhammad Iqbal's presidential address in Allahabad introduces the two-nation theory and outlines a vision for the creation of Pakistan.
December 29, 1934: Japan renounces the Washington Naval Treaty of 1922 and the London Naval Treaty of 1930.
December 29, 1937: The Irish Free State is replaced by a new state called Ireland with the adoption of a new constitution.
December 29, 1949: KC2XAK of Bridgeport, Connecticut becomes the first Ultra high frequency (UHF) television station to operate a daily schedule.
December 29, 1972: Eastern Air Lines Flight 401 (a Lockheed L-1011 TriStar) crashes in the Florida Everglades on approach to Miami International Airport, Florida, killing 101 of the 176 people on board.
December 29, 1975: A bomb explodes at LaGuardia Airport in New York City, killing 11 people and injuring 74.
December 29, 1989: Czech writer, philosopher and dissident Václav Havel is elected the first post-communist President of Czechoslovakia.
December 29, 1992: Fernando Collor de Mello, president of Brazil, tries to resign amidst corruption charges, but is then impeached.
December 29, 1996: Guatemala and leaders of Guatemalan National Revolutionary Unity sign a peace accord ending a 36-year civil war.
December 29, 1997: Hong Kong begins to kill all the city's 1.25 million chickens to stop the spread of a potentially deadly influenza strain.
December 29, 1998: Leaders of the Khmer Rouge apologize for the 1970s genocide in Cambodia that claimed over one million lives.
December 29, 2003: The last known speaker of Akkala Sami dies, rendering the language extinct.
December 29, 2006: UK settles its Anglo-American loan, post-WWII loan debt.
December 29, 2011: Samoa and Tokelau skip straight to December 31 when moving from one side of the International Date Line to another.
December 29, 2012: A Tupolev Tu-204 airliner crashes in a ditch between the airport fence and the M3 highway after overshooting a runway at Vnukovo International Airport in Moscow, Russia, killing five people and leaving three others critically injured.
December 29, 2013: A suicide bomb attack at the Volgograd-1 railway station in the southern Russian city of Volgograd kills at least 18 people and wounds 40 others.
December 30, 1816: The Treaty of St. Louis between the United States and the united Ottawa, Ojibwa, and Potawatomi Indian tribes is proclaimed.
December 30, 1825: The Treaty of St. Louis between the United States and the Shawnee Nation is proclaimed.
December 30, 1890: Following the Wounded Knee Massacre, the United States Army and Lakota warriors face off in the Drexel Mission Fight.[1]
December 30, 1896: Canadian ice hockey player Ernie McLea scores the first hat-trick in Stanley Cup play, and the Cup-winning goal as the Montreal Victorias defeat the Winnipeg Victorias 6–5.
December 30, 1897: The British Colony of Natal annexes Zululand.
December 30, 1903: A fire at the Iroquois Theater in Chicago, Illinois kills at least 605.
December 30, 1905: Former Idaho Governor Frank Steunenberg is assassinated at the front gate of his home in Caldwell.
December 30, 1906: The All-India Muslim League is founded in Dacca, East Bengal, British India (later Dhaka, Bangladesh).
December 30, 1916: The last coronation in Hungary is performed for King Charles IV and Queen Zita.
December 30, 1922: The Union of Soviet Socialist Republics is formed.
December 30, 1927: The Ginza Line, the first subway line in Asia, opens in Tokyo, Japan.
December 30, 1935: The Italian Air Force bombs a Swedish Red Cross hospital during the Second Italo-Abyssinian War.
December 30, 1936: The United Auto Workers union stages its first sitdown strike.
December 30, 1943: Subhas Chandra Bose raises the flag of Indian independence at Port Blair.
December 30, 1944: King George II of Greece declares a regency, leaving the throne vacant.
December 30, 1958: The Guatemalan Air Force sinks several Mexican fishing boats alleged to have breached maritime borders, killing three and sparking international tension.
December 30, 1965: Ferdinand Marcos becomes President of the Philippines.
December 30, 1993: Israel establishes diplomatic relations with Vatican City and also upgrades to full diplomatic relations with Ireland.
December 30, 1996: Proposed budget cuts by Benjamin Netanyahu spark protests from 250,000 workers who shut down services across Israel.
December 30, 1997: In the worst incident in Algeria's insurgency, the Wilaya of Relizane massacres, 400 people from four villages are killed.
December 30, 2004: A fire in the República Cromagnon nightclub in Buenos Aires, Argentina kills 194.
December 30, 2005: Tropical Storm Zeta forms in the open Atlantic Ocean, tying the record for the latest tropical cyclone ever to form in the North Atlantic basin.
December 30, 2006: Former President of Iraq Saddam Hussein is executed.
December 30, 2009: A suicide bomber kills nine people at Forward Operating Base Chapman, a key facility of the Central Intelligence Agency in Afghanistan.
December 30, 2013: More than 100 people are killed when anti-government forces attack key buildings in Kinshasa, Democratic Republic of the Congo.
December 31, 406: Vandals, Alans and Suebians cross the Rhine, beginning an invasion of Gaul.
December 31, 535: Byzantine general Belisarius completes the conquest of Sicily, defeating the Gothic garrison of Palermo (Panormos), and ending his consulship for the year.
December 31, 1225: The Lý dynasty of Vietnam ends after 216 years by the enthronement of the boy emperor Trần Thái Tông, husband of the last Lý monarch, Lý Chiêu Hoàng, starting the Trần dynasty.
December 31, 1229: James I the Conqueror, King of Aragon enters Medina Mayurqa (now known as Palma, Spain) thus consummating the Christian reconquest of the island of Majorca.
December 31, 1501: The First Battle of Cannanore commences.
December 31, 1600: The British East India Company is chartered.
December 31, 1660: James II of England is named Duke of Normandy by Louis XIV of France.
December 31, 1687: The first Huguenots set sail from France to the Cape of Good Hope.
December 31, 1757: Empress Elizabeth I of Russia issues her ukase incorporating Königsberg into Russia.
December 31, 1759: Arthur Guinness signs a 9,000 year lease at £45 per annum and starts brewing Guinness.
December 31, 1790: Efimeris, the oldest Greek newspaper of which issues have survived till today, is published for the first time.
December 31, 1796: The incorporation of Baltimore as a city.
December 31, 1831: Gramercy Park is deeded to New York City.
December 31, 1853: A dinner party is held inside a life-size model of an iguanodon created by Benjamin Waterhouse Hawkins and Sir Richard Owen in south London, England.
December 31, 1857: Queen Victoria chooses Ottawa, then a small logging town, as the capital of Canada.
December 31, 1878: Karl Benz, working in Mannheim, Germany, filed for a patent on his first reliable two-stroke gas engine, and he was granted the patent in 1879.
December 31, 1879: Thomas Edison demonstrates incandescent lighting to the public for the first time, in Menlo Park, New Jersey.
December 31, 1906: Mozaffar ad-Din Shah Qajar signs the Persian Constitution of 1906.
December 31, 1907: The first New Year's Eve celebration is held in Times Square (then known as Longacre Square) in Manhattan.
December 31, 1946: President Harry S. Truman officially proclaims the end of hostilities in World War II.
December 31, 1955: General Motors becomes the first U.S. corporation to make over US$1 billion in a year.
December 31, 1956: The Romanian Television network begins its first broadcast in Bucharest.
December 31, 1961: RTÉ, Ireland's state broadcaster, launches its first national television service.
December 31, 1963: The Central African Federation officially collapses, subsequently becoming Zambia, Malawi and Rhodesia.
December 31, 1965: Jean-Bédel Bokassa, leader of the Central African Republic army, and his military officers begins a coup d'état against the government of President David Dacko.
December 31, 1968: The first flight of the Tupolev Tu-144, the first civilian supersonic transport in the world.
December 31, 1981: A coup d'état in Ghana removes President Hilla Limann's PNP government and replaces it with the Provisional National Defence Council led by Flight lieutenant Jerry Rawlings.
December 31, 1983: In Nigeria a coup d'état led by Major General Muhammadu Buhari ends the Second Nigerian Republic.
December 31, 1986: Arson at the Dupont Plaza Hotel in San Juan, Puerto Rico kills 97 people and injures 140.
December 31, 1991: All official Soviet Union institutions have ceased operations by this date five days after the Soviet Union is officially dissolved.
December 31, 1992: Czechoslovakia is peacefully dissolved in what is dubbed by media as the Velvet Divorce, resulting in the creation of the Czech Republic and the Slovak Republic.
December 31, 1998: The European Exchange Rate Mechanism freezes the values of the legacy currencies in the Eurozone, and establishes the value of the euro currency.
December 31, 1999: Indian Airlines Flight 814 hijacking ended after seven days with the release of 190 survivors at Kandahar Airport, Afghanistan.
December 31, 2000: The last day of the 20th Century and 2nd Millennium.
December 31, 2004: The official opening of Taipei 101, the tallest skyscraper at that time in the world, standing at a height of 509 metres (1,670 ft).
December 31, 2009: Both a blue moon and a lunar eclipse occur.
December 31, 2010: Tornadoes touch down in midwestern and southern United States, including Washington County, Arkansas; Greater St. Louis, Sunset Hills, Missouri, Illinois, and Oklahoma, with a few tornadoes in the early hours. A total 36 tornadoes touched down, resulting in the deaths of nine people and $113 million in damages.
December 31, 2011: NASA succeeds in putting the first of two Gravity Recovery and Interior Laboratory satellites in orbit around the Moon.
December 31, 2014: A New Year's Eve celebration stampede in Shanghai kills at least 36 people and injures 49 others.
December 31, 2015: A fire broke out at the Downtown Address Hotel in Downtown Dubai, United Arab Emirates located near the Burj Khalifa two hours before the fireworks display was due to commence. Sixteen injuries were reported; one had a heart attack, another suffered a major injury, and fourteen others with minor injuries.
December 31, 2018: 39 people were killed after a 10-storey building in the Industrial Russian City of Magnitogorsk collapsed. [1]
